Reviews.Author: Alysa P.
Reviews.Content: The food is always outstanding, everything tastes fresh and I always leave happy. be prepared to wait in line outside. Patrons are sat in the order of where they are in line, no reservations, no writing down names--I recommend showing up at 5 PM or earlier.  Inside, you'll be elbow to elbow with fellow diners but that is what makes this place authentic Italian, because that's how they do it in Italy too. If you are a pasta lover, this is the place to go in the North End.

Reviews.Author: Liz N.
Reviews.Content: This is a really late review but I only got my Yelp account recently so I wanted to go back to talk about this awesome restaurant. First off, I'm from Texas and visited Giacomo's in September of 2013. My boss recommended the place with the warning that we'd probably have to wait but it's so worth it that even our VP will wait in line. He was absolutely right!Two of my friends and I got there around 7 and waited in a line of about 12 people. Dinner here was on the "to do" list for Boston so we weren't going to give up on waiting. We met a really nice couple that were standing in line in front of us. They are locals and regulars at Giacomo's. Talking to them made waiting in line much more bearable. We probably waited for a little over and hour before we were seated. So when you first see the menu, it looks a little plain. Don't let this deter you! We got the calamari first and it was perfectly fried. Not too oily and very lightly battered in a good way. I got the shrimp and scallop linguine with the Giacomo's sauce. The pasta was almost a little too al dente for me but over the course of the meal, I got over it and really ended up liking it. The plate was so big but I couldn't stop eating it and, before I knew it, I was done!You can really tell that the waitresses here are accustomed to the rush and know how to work in a very efficient manner. It makes it so that the service doesn't seem to be as much of an issue like at other places.SUPER TIP:Don't come here by yourself if you really want to be by yourself. A couple in front of my friends and I in line were very observant and noticed that two people that were previously standing in line were seated together but didn't seem to know each other when they were standing in line. The couple were regulars so they said would ask the lady that sat the people at the table about it. The most awesome part: the waitress, Rose, said that she does it often for single people that come to fill tables. She said she hopes that people she pairs up will one say get together. It worked because in this case, the table went to get coffee and dessert after dinner!!

Reviews.Author: Yangyang L.
Reviews.Content: Be prepared to wait ........and wait ....... and be prepared to wear more and have some fun topic to chat about with your friend during the wait....We arrived Giacomo at 5:00 pm, and we waited about 2 hours until we were able to sit down, order and eat. We started with the fired calamari, and mozzarella marinara. They both taste good, warm up our stomach. Their sauce taste nice.Then, I ordered my entree from the special menu, forgot the full name, but it is the lobster linguini. I would say it taste okay, not as good as I expected. All my friends think their pasta are good. I guess it may because the wait and the high expectation. The whole experience is nice, I would like to suggest this place to people who have high tolerance for waiting, and  luv petite  Italian restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Linda H.
Reviews.Content: Has a reputation for a reason. A variety of options for specials. We started with the mozzarella stuffed with burrata - melt in your mouth and the simple treatment allowed for full appreciation of the flavors. Lovely crusty italian bread of course. For entrees - black pepper pappardelle with roasted red peppers broccoli rabe and 1/2 lobster, mussels and clams with the giacomo sauce over linguini. I am so glad that I went with something different; the pappardelle was the best pasta dish I've had maybe ever.Some things I wish I knew before I went. Bring cash... it is cash only. There are lots of ATMs on your walk down Hanover. You will most likely wait in line. Make sure you follow protocol when you go through the doors to keep the dining room from getting a blast of cold air. Toast if you get wine. Be forgiving of a crowded/snug dining experience it a communal space that has regulars and visitors alike.It's a treat to go here so I look forward to another celebratory reason to indulge.

Reviews.Author: Ken M.
Reviews.Content: So good don't know what even to say.  For $65 ($55 w/out a bottle of wine) you can get this HUGE platter of 2 lobsters, mussels/scallops/whatever was in there. The lobster ravioli is like $16 or $19 bucks and is awesome.  Everything is awesome.Loooong waits, but we got lucky as a 2 group and were seated within 10 minutes.  But this place probably is really worth it.  Very special, no wonder it's so popular.

Reviews.Author: Steph S.
Reviews.Content: When we arrived at Giacomo's, the line was already down the block and around the corner. "Are you serious??? Dude, pull up the Yelp app, there's no way...""But it's the top rated restaurant in Boston! We're here anyway, let's just stick around."We weren't the only ones to have this conversation that night, and I'm pretty sure it's repeated quite often, especially with tourists like us. People passing by stared, laughed, and mocked. It was cold and threatening to rain. But we continued to wait for nearly 2 hours, rocking back and forth on our feet, draining the power on our phones, and sending each other to scout out other nearby places for the occasional snack (such as cannolis from Mike's one block away).2 hours later though, and we were in. And it was WORTH it! We were seated quickly and handed our menus, but with 2 hours to make my menu choices, I already knew what we wanted, save for the menu specials on the left wall that I hadn't seen from outside.Fresh burrata with tomatoes to begin (I never, ever say no to burrata - who can?). The calamari ("SMALL CAL!") with mildly spicy pickled peperoncinis and spicy tomato sauce. House special for two, obviously.The burrata was extremely fresh, and of all the burrata I've eaten, it ranks pretty high up there. Burrata is made from mozzarella and cream, so it has both that pliable cheesiness and rich creaminess that is so yummy. It was refreshing with the slices of tomato that it was served with.The calamari was unlike any calamari I've had before; I've never had it with peperoncinis before and now I will probably wish that all of them are supposed to include them. The batter was very seasoned and the tomato sauce was spicy - a must-order!Now, onto the house special. Our tablemates had chosen the ravioli and some kind of spicy pasta, which were both fairly generic choices. I'll bet they were tasty as well, but nevertheless, our tablemates had HUGE menu jealousy when our house special platter holding two lobsters, clams, mussels, shrimp, scallops, and a pile of pasta in spicy lobster sauce was set down.Is it weird that the action of the platter being set down on the table has been on loop in my head for the last few weeks? It was seriously the biggest plate of food I've ever had (esp. for two people only) at a restaurant and I've never had so much fresh seafood.I mean, I've had king crab legs in Las Vegas and garlic-scallion crab in LA, but this is a whole different level of seafood, particularly for the price. At $55 for the house special for two, this is so much cheaper than what it would probably cost in LA -- $55 would probably just get you a single serving with 1/6th of the clams, mussels, shrimp, and scallops, and a few chunks of lobster on a bit of pasta. NOT all of this for two people.It was as delicious as it looked, and I am so very glad we stuck out the 2 hours to wait. If you are waiting in line and reading this, don't lose hope! Send your friend down the block to pick up some morale-boosting cannolis and you'll be through the door in no time.

Reviews.Author: Stef R.
Reviews.Content: Two stars. This place is absolutely not worth the wait. If you give this place five stars, then you're the assholes who go to Mikes after for the "best" cannolis. Tourist trap. Shitty service.

Reviews.Author: Steve B.
Reviews.Content: Always great food & service!

Reviews.Author: R H.
Reviews.Content: Cool experience. Tiny place. Get there when it opens, otherwise you wait.Food pretty cheap. Believe the hype.

Reviews.Author: Julia M.
Reviews.Content: My visit to Giacomo's last night resulted in a complete 180 of my view toward the restaurant. Prior to last night, I held the restaurant in high regard & frequently recommended the place to others, but after my horrendous dining experience yesterday evening, I hold it in rather low regard & will cease recommending it as a place to eat in Boston.My unpleasant dining experience began almost immediately after my friends & I were seated at our table. We had waited in line for 40 minutes & were one of the first people to be seated at 4:30. We were seated in the back of the restaurant against the wall with the menu written on it, & I took the seat right next to the wall. As I was up against the wall with the menu, I could not easily read the menu from my seat, so I stood up to quickly look over it. I had been standing for a grand total of 2 seconds, if that, when one of the waitresses ordered me in an irritated tone to "sit down", because I was "blocking everyone's view." She said this while simultaneously pointing to my chair. After barking at me to sit down, she handed everyone at the table a menu, noting that everything that was on the wall menu was also on this paper menu. As I looked around the restaurant, I noticed that every other customer had also received a paper menu, which begs the question, if everyone had already received a paper menu, why would it have mattered if I was "blocking" the menu on the wall?Although thoroughly annoyed, I decided stay, as I had been looking forward to eating at Giacomo's all day. We ordered calamari for the table, which we enjoyed. For my entree, I ordered the scallops served over linguine in a scampi sauce, which was extremely disappointing. The scampi sauce was bland, & the scallops were chewy from having been overcooked. To add insult to injury, we were the last table from our seating to be served - by the time we received our dishes, everyone else from the 4:30 seating had already left or was in the process of paying.I left feeling very disappointed, but unbeknownst to me, that was not the end of my awful dining experience. Giacomo's had one more surprise in store for me: food poisoning. I am unsure whether the calamari or scallops caused the food poisoning, but I spent the remainder of the evening nauseous & feeling absolutely miserable. Needless to say, I do not plan on returning to Giacomo's any time soon.

Reviews.Author: RONALD W.
Reviews.Content: Cash only, delicious food at affordable prices. It may not be the best Italian food I have had in general but definitely best at this price point ($20 for a seafood entree).Shared a large fried calamari appetizer. Excellent! Big and tasty. Had a half lobster, mussels, clam linguine from the daily specials menu with a house lobster tomato sauce. It was excellent. I only wish that it came with more linguine.

Reviews.Author: Brian P.
Reviews.Content: This review is very well past due, but I've gotta write it for everyone heading out to Boston looking for an epic place to eat and enjoy life at. Well, maybe not due to the hundreds before me, but still. Get the Lobster frutti di mari plate (house special). It's quite possibly one of the most delicious seafood creations you'll ever experience. I'm not kidding...it's a huge-ass lobster that's uber-fresh with with clams, their crazy tasty marinara+pasta, and seven other ingredients that I completely left out; a total sin considering those ingredients would probably make another tasty dish elsewhere alone. The line outside is long if you don't arrive early. Expect an hour plus if you arrive after 6pm. I got there at 5:30 and waited half an hour....but that was on a weeknight. Just go and wait. It's worth it. If you're impatient, you're lame.

Reviews.Author: Tyler O.
Reviews.Content: Well worth the wait! We stood outside for about an hour and a half, but luckily it was a mild December evening. Once inside, we were seated at the bar area, where all the magic happens. We ordered the calimari and fried mozzarella for appetizers which were in front of us, no joke, within two minutes. Our entrees were in front of us in less than 10 minutes. Rosemarie, the owner's sister, was our waitress and she was fantastic. The service was great and obviously fast. The calimari was very tender and fresh. The fried mozzarella was amazingly creamy, and the marinara it was drenched in was very flavorful.The butternut squash ravioli in a mascarpone sauce is amazing.Giacomo's is a fantastic restaurant. Definitely worth the wait if you're with good company.

Reviews.Author: G R.
Reviews.Content: Like this place needs another review, probably not, but here it is anyhow. This place has been on my bucket list of restaurants to try, the last time I was in Boston there was a line, this time also a line, but not to bad and I'm glad I got in it when I did. I got there about an hour before they opened and managed to be seated with the first group in. Here's a tip it sort of goes in order so be friendly to the people close to you in line, odds are you'll be rubbing elbows with them.I was worried that as a solo diner I'd get the stink eye, but not at all. Did get a friendly welcome, along with quick efficient service, the place is like a well oiled machine. I had the house salad, and the butternut squash ravioli. The bread also was delicious, something about the bread on the east coast always worth the carbs. The meal was outstanding, I ate it all, every bite, I usually end up leaving half my entree when I go out for dinner. Even the server noticed that I ate it all and gave me a "good job" I was waiting for atta girl pat on the back.The place is small and busy, don't plan on picking out a special table, you sit when a space becomes available, if you're lucky to get a seat at the counter take it because you'll get a great view of all the busy kitchen activity. Bring cash!

Reviews.Author: Stephanie T.
Reviews.Content: We went to Giacomo's on Saturday evening, got there early at 5.30pm and had to wait one and a half hour before we got seated. Despite the reviews that we read, it was NOT worth the one and a half hour wait. We ordered the fried calamari, butternut squash ravioli, and house special linguine with mixed of giacomo and fra diavolo sauce. The lobster was the best here, it was really delicious and fresh. Probably one of the freshest lobster that we've had. But other than that, the food was just ok. Butternut squash ravioli was a little too creamy, calamari was soft and good but we could have gone somewhere else for that. Service is horrendous. Waiters were really rude and the place was super cramped. I would say that 30-45 min wait outside in the cold is probably worth it, but this place is definitely not worth one and a half hour wait for only pretty good food and horrendous service. Yes, seafood was fresh, but we have had that quality of seafood without the super long wait.

Reviews.Author: Jax P.
Reviews.Content: Sometimes when reading the yelp reviews you wonder if it's the yelp stars driving things, or the place is just that good. At Giacomo's it's just that good.  I don't believe that ones genetics mean their taste is any better than anyone else's, but I'm 1/2 Sicilian, and grew up in North Jersey. I've experienced American style Italian food there, and NYC, and North Beach SF and - and if I'm honest with myself this may have been the best of this type of food I've ever had outside of my father's kitchen.Arrived at about 5:45 on a warm but slightly damp Thursday to catch a bite before a concert at the Garden (yay for Boston walk-ability.) There were three or four parties already waiting, and because we were just 2, our wait was less than 20 minutes, the larger parties were about 40 minutes.  I can imagine on weekends the line is no joke 3 hours long like others have suggested, my counting says 38 people is their max dining capacity. I'm also not a fan of waiting and did a quick walk around of the other similar restaurants in a 2 block area and none of the other places were very busy at all - so we decided to wait.Glass of wine each, shared an order of fried calamari which was perfect, crisp, light, not greasy and everything you want fried seafood to be. Fresh tasting marinara served with it. I will agree w/ others that the jalepeno coins are sort of weird, but, I enjoyed the heat they brought to the dish.Wife had a mixed seafood scampi that she said was delicious - if a bit heavy handed with the saucing.I had the scallops and shrimp linguine with a mix of Fra-Diavolo and a small amount of cream. I asked for it to be fairly spicy and it was PERFECT. Shellfish cooked correctly, great sauce ratio (got extra bread for the extra sauce) good acidity, consistency and fantastic tasted. Service was quick, and remarkably attentive for how crowded the place was. For both of us dinner, including tip was $60, so totally reasonable for date night. The line came and went a few times as the place seems to empty all at once and fill back up just as quickly. Never felt rushed but we didn't linger either.All in all a fantastic experience and will most certainly be back - even if we have to wait longer.

Reviews.Author: Kun C.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food. Definitely an "experience" to come here as almost always a wait. Last time, we waited in the cold weather for an hour before got to our seats. However, the food is very good and the service is mostly friendly and efficient. You will see many tourists that come here because it is famous, but that reputation is well deserved. Their seafood is amazing. One of the big seafood dishes is usually enough for 3-4 people to share and is fresh and delicious.Definitely recommend coming here.

Reviews.Author: Lauren G.
Reviews.Content: Finally tried Giacomo's after 10 years in Boston. I live around the corner and see the insane nightly lines, rain or shine. The food is solid Italian American with a heavy emphasis on seafood. The service is classic rude Boston - no intention of making you feel welcome, they want you out of there as fast as possible to bring in the next group. We were crowded into a corner and asked to get up in the middle of our meal to switch chairs so another table could fit one more. Definitely would not waste my time there again. I had some great garlic bread and the spicy fracomo sauce but could have made it at home.

Reviews.Author: Doug B.
Reviews.Content: I just visited Giacomo's for the second time, and this place has made it on my list of favorite restaurants in Boston. There isn't much to sat that hasn't already been said in other reviews: for a starter the Calamari is excellent, as is the garlic bread. I had the Gnocchi with Braised Beef Ragu on this occasion and was very impressed - highly recommended. All their house wines are very reasonably priced at $18/bottle, and the Chianti which we had paired very nicely with the food.As others have pointed out it is very small, you will likely need to wait outside for a table and once you are seated you will be elbow to elbow with the other tables. Don't let this deter you - the atmosphere is part of what makes this place so unique. The poor reviews I have seen appear to be largely based on people who were expecting a big fancy restaurants and this is not that kind of place. Come with your expectations in check and you will not be disappointed. Important Tip: Cash Only - no credit cards accepted, but there is an ATM directly across the street.

Reviews.Author: Johnathon B.
Reviews.Content: Small, loud, fast, pretty good food.That's my review in a nutshell. I went to Giacomo's because of the Yelp reviews and I wasn't disappointed, but I also didn't see the point of standing in line and being rushed through my meal again. Because of the size limitations, this place is not a comfortable place to be. The waitresses' sole purpose is to get you your food and get you out. You don't hang around and talk or enjoy the company of your guests and honestly...that's not how an Italian dinner should be.The food is good, no doubts, but not enough to warrant the terribly uncomfortable environment.Do your self a favor, get out of the tourist hub known as Hanover St, make a reservation for La Famiglia Giorgio's on Salem St., go for a nice walk and see the Old North Church or other sites, and have yourself a true Italian dinner...one that takes longer to eat than to stand outside waiting for a table.TIP: CASH ONLY.

Reviews.Author: Asha W.
Reviews.Content: I had my first meal at Giacomo's tonight, it won't be my last meal there either. I came to the North End with two girlfriends tonight in search of authentic Italian food. Fair to say we found it at Giacomo's. We waited about thirty minutes in the cold to get a seat inside but it was well worth the wait. For a small restaurant that could easily be mistaken as a hole in the wall on Hanover Street, it was everything but that. The atmosphere inside was like an authentic Italian kitchen, and the aroma of fresh food hits you as soon as you walk through the door. Our server was a helpful gentleman & really made us feel welcomed at the restaurant.I had the Chicken Marsala, A++ with my compliments to the chef.My friends got a Chicken Caesar Salad, made to order, and the Chicken Ziti Broccoli. Plus we got a large order of the Calamari too.Everything was amazing. It was well worth the wait & I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this spot to a friend.

Reviews.Author: Martina M.
Reviews.Content: I came here on a Friday night around 8PM - the line was still way out the door to the shop next door. My party of 3 waited for about 45-50 minutes and the temperature outside was about the same. Brrrrrrr. If you're in a really extremely hungry and impatient mood, don't go here. However, you're missing out on probably the best Italian food you've ever had. Not probably -  definitely the best.We had the butternut squash ravioli with asparagus, prosciutto and mascarpone cream sauce, and a couple of specials (homemade fusilli with lobster and shrimps in the fra diavolo sauce, and clams with spaghetti in the Giacomo sauce).  That butternut squash ravioli was amazing. I can't even describe it. Plus just thinking about it makes me hungry so i will leave it at that.The homemade fusilli was also really good. Perfectly al dente and the sauce was spicy and yummy. Too yummy. The shrimp and lobster was fresh and added texture to the whole dish. Agh - too hungry already. I will definitely come back here next time I'm in Boston.  Kthxbye.Ps. bring cash and don't be afraid if you have to share table with another party.

Reviews.Author: Tina M.
Reviews.Content: I went to giacomo's on a weekday around 4:30 pm and got right in. I had really high expectations because of the yelp reviews, but when we arrived I found out it was a mostly seafood restaurant. I hate seafood.  I got the chicken parmesan and it was so-so, hence my 3 star rating. That being said, maybe all of the other people who've commented on how good this place is are really into oysters and lobster and such. The non-seafood options aren't extensive and the service, feel and look of the inside are just your like your average north end Italian restaurant - it's small and the servers are somewhat friendly but also sassy and fast-paced. If you really don't like seafood, skip Giacomo's despite it's great reviews.

Reviews.Author: Food Monster ..
Reviews.Content: Have been going here for years. This past Sunday night was no difference. What to expect once you get to this restaurant LONG LINES, great food, small space, crowded, no credit cards and pushy wait staff. WELL WORTH THE FOOD AND EXPERIENCE!!

Reviews.Author: Neil T.
Reviews.Content: Adorable little gem! Great staff and you can't really go wrong with anything on the menu. We got calamari, the butternut squash ravioli (delicious but expect only like 6-8 pieces of ravioli, *sigh*) and a delicious shrimp/clam fusilli with the Fa-como sauce. You want to order that sauce, cause it's a spicy combo of the last two sauces on the page! Also considering how well they keep the demand up (we stood outside this tiny place in 14 degree weather for like 25 minutes, and it's Rachel Ray's blah blah choice blah blah) it's very reasonably priced. Then again...it's cash only. They have a remarkably quick turn over, even if you get an entire bottle of wine like we did. Wouldn't come here often but it's like a little adventure every time you do, plus: modern pastry, mikes pastry, and cafe Vittoria are all just across the street for adorable after dinner dessert/cappuccinos. Again, all cash only.

Reviews.Author: Isabelle J.
Reviews.Content: The food is amazing! Went there two nights ago. A little bit expensive, but totally worth it! Had the butternut squash ravioli for my first time and after reading other reviews, I absolutely agree. It's an amazing dish

Reviews.Author: Lorena O.
Reviews.Content: Every time I've asked someone where to eat in Boston, I've heard Giacomo's as a heavy favorite.  But every time I've been to Boston, I've skipped it because of the perennial line of people that exists outside their door. This time around, however, we were determined to try them out.  So, my sister queued up while  we huffed it over to Cross St. in time for some cannolis from our favorite spot.  15 minutes later my sister texted to tell us not to rush, the line hadn't moved a bit.  And sure enough, ten minutes after that when we made it back to her, she was pretty much in the same spot. Mamma Mia, I was ah-starving!  I kept peering inside the window at all the people chomping down on good food thinking, "Whas a' matter wichoo?  Cantchoo see I'm stahving here?!  Make it snappy!"  They could not, nor were they reading my mind.  A total of one hour and fifteen minutes in line, backs aching, dogs barking, we were finally being ushered inside.  Our table of three was sat at a table for five with a nice couple rounding us out.  Prepare to get cozy when you're eating atGiacomo's, the entire restaurant only holds about thirty patrons. The menu was rattled off to us by our server, we ordered and two minutes later our appetizer was being dolled out to us.  No time for pictures, no time to settle on how much of that app you actually wanted, the decision was being made for you.  Suffice it to say, the experience was a hectic one.  All at the table agreed that we felt like we had to shovel food into our mouths hurriedly so as to turn the table for the sorry saps still waiting outside.  Luckily, the food was good so I was able to kind of forgive that hectic part. But next time, I'll probably skip the line and hit up another Italin place in the North End.  There's so many, with equally high praise on Yelp.

Reviews.Author: Kelsey G.
Reviews.Content: Ate here once with a friend. Incredible food, huge portions- prices are certainly high but for good reason. This place is the real deal. Great service and fantastic food.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie L.
Reviews.Content: I work at a restaurant that constantly has lines out the door, so waiting in Giacomo's restaurant didn't bother me or my friend all that much. We may have waited a grand total of 45 minutes. When we were inside, we were seated at the table closest to the window and front door. It was a little awkward having people outside stare at our food while we ate but it didn't disrupt our meal. It was amusing being able to lip read the woman outside pointing at my friend's dish excitedly asking, "What's that??"I ordered the famed butternut squash ravioli and it was not disappointed. Sometimes I feel like when I order ravioli I only get five pieces which doesn't leave me very satisfied. I have a black void in my stomach for pasta so to say that I waddled out of Giacomo's full and content is very positive. The service was much appreciated as well. Even though there was a long wait outside, we didn't feel rushed to finish our meal. Our server was friendly, but straight enough to the point to quickly bring us our food and beverages. Naturally, having waited outside a while ourselves, we did not want to linger in the restaurant too long. We stayed just long enough to enjoy some conversation and a great lunch!I can't think of anything particularly wrong with my experience there, so I'm going with five stars here. Waiting in line is not so bad with good company so just be patient!Will definitely be back again -- maybe even today! ;)

Reviews.Author: Bret C.
Reviews.Content: The food is decent italian. Very middle-of-the-road. Solid. Reliable. Safe.The line is not so decent.  It's packed every single night before they open at 5pm.  Don't deal with this.  Go to the South End location on Columbus Ave. which has the same menu and takes reservations!  (This one is small, too - so don't think it's a breeze - but it's better than waiting outside on Hanover Street at the North End location).Giacomo's needs to get with the times and accept credit cards.  Cash only makes them look antiquated (not in a good way).

Reviews.Author: Marina M.
Reviews.Content: The home fusilini with lobster and shrimp (with the Giacomo sauce) is TO DIE FOR! There is a line outside but the place is worth it. It is fast and to the point. Very italian :).

Reviews.Author: Linda T.
Reviews.Content: such a cute mom and pops restaurant. waited an hour for this place but well worth it. what's in the marinera sauce?? i swear there's crack in it. SOOOO GOOOD. had the lobster ravioli and fusilli with lobster and shrimp in fra diavolo sauce. amazingggggly good. must go to when visiting boston. it also helps that one of the waiters (old italian man) was such a clown. funny man! he made my dine in experience enjoyable

Reviews.Author: Brandon V.
Reviews.Content: Very intimate seating (ie. seated at a table with complete strangers) is just one of the things that makes this small North End Italian restaurant a somewhat unique and wicked fun place for dinner.  It's been a few years since I have visited, but I remember the line outside did not take long, that the restrooms were in some remote place but I didn't care, that the food was good and  inexpensive.  Worth a shot!

Reviews.Author: Donna Y.
Reviews.Content: Expect a long wait. This restaurant does not take reservations. Don't expect good service here. The waitress was very curt and rude. At times, she almost spilled hot steaming food on my friends. The food on the other hand was very good. The calamari is ammmmazing. The breading is light and tasty and the calamari not chewy. I ordered the butternut squash ravioli with asparagus for my entree. I felt the asparagus was unnecessarily placed in the cream sauce and it didn't lend any help to the flavor of the sauce or dish so I would have preferred it on the side or nothing at all. The butternut squash ravioli however was deelicious!

Reviews.Author: Azat E.
Reviews.Content: Pros:1) The food is second to none2) The prices are reasonable 3) The service is relatively good4) The environment is cozy and funCons:1) The lines for a table can go well into an hour long wait2) The wine is not always complimentary of the dishes and as such I, in good conscious cannot give them five stars.

Reviews.Author: Charlene G.
Reviews.Content: I'm a fan.  Yes- I was in town on business, so I'm sure I'm labeled 'a tourist', but come on...  This place is wonderful.  I think if you complain about it too much, you are just spoiled.  But, as a southerner who doesn't have access to many great italian joints, this place was tops. Since i was travelling alone, I thought it might be easier to get a table, but basically when I got there a line had already formed out the door.  So, I joined the back and eventually a server came out and checked in w/ everyone waiting. I think if a spot for one was open then, she'd have let me in, but as it was I just waited my turn.  It was about 20 min. Once you get inside, the servers are very nice and cheerful- if a bit brusque simply because they are working hard. However, I had at least 3 of them come by and chat w/ me- probably because I was on my own, but it was nice.  The tables are definitely wedged together, but it adds to the 'fun'. I was so tempted by the butternut ravioli, but there was a fusilli special w/ lobster and shrimp that I had to try instead.  I ordered w/ the Giacomo sauce, which is a fra diavolo with a touch of cream.  It was absolutely delicious- and as much as I adored the seafood (which came in huge chunks), I actually picked out the pasta the most.  perfectly al dente and covered in sauce (but not drowned), it was divine.  Also, ordere the small calamari and a class of chianti. Can't wait to go back for that butternut squash.  If I was a local, I'd try to beat the tourists here every day.

Reviews.Author: Laura F.
Reviews.Content: I came here last night, and was intrigued because it was the only restaurant on Hanover Street that had a line in front of it on a Tuesday night, while most of the other restaurants on the street were pretty dead. I figured if it was attracting that much business on a random week night, it was worth a try. I waited about 20 minutes. when I got in, I could definitely see why people love this restaurant. The food is delicious and affordable. Every entre on the menu is below $20, the appetizers are like around $10, a glass of wine is $5, and the bottles are $18. You can't beat that.The menu options also are straightforward and classic Italian (calamari, mozarella tomato salad, chicken parmesan, ravioli, ziti, frutti de mar, and simply-prepared fish dishes). They are prepared exactly the way you would expect, but somehow they taste better than any other version of that dish that you've ever had. I had the Chicken Parmesan, and it was simple but incredible, probably because the ingredients  like the pasta and tomato sauce are super fresh and prepared from scratch on site. One thing you have to be prepared for is the fast-pacedness of your meal (they are turning tables really fast to help move the line) and the bare-bones atmosphere. I assume that they can afford to make the food so inexpensive because the restaurant is saving a lot of money on other features. For example, the restaurant is really small with a small staff and has litterally no special atmosphere or interior decoration. The food is served on plain white ceramic plates along with paper napkins. Also, its cash only, so the restaurant can avoid the credit card company fees. Overall, I would highly recomend this place if you're looking for an affordable authentic italian food experience, and are willing to forgo the  upscale atmospheric elements.

Reviews.Author: Brooke J.
Reviews.Content: OH MY GOD THE LOBSTER RAVIOLI. By far the best in town, plus it's dirt cheap.Here's the situation with Giacomo's: Not everything on the menu is fantastic. Some dishes are sort of... boring. But if you do Giacomo's right, it's the best Italian meal for under $20 you can find.The caprese is fine as long as you don't mind obnoxious, pink, mushy tomatoes. I'm a tomato snob, but the cheese is fresh and tasty and the vinegar is bright and fruity. I always end up getting the burrata, even if I sass the tomatoes. The cheese is just too good, nice and creamy. The lobster ravioli is a must, with a light, refined tomato sauce and fresh-fresh-fresh lobster. Just a little salty and a tad sweet, The sauce doesn't overpower the lobster and the pasta is definitely homemade. I dream about the lobster ravioli here. The butternut squash tortellini is my backup. It's so well made and the butternut squash is a great balance of sweetness and salt. Still, if you have a choice, get the lobster ravioli.Don't forget to grab a bottle of wine. Broke college students, pay attention: If you order a bottle of wine, it's mad cheap and you can take that sucker with you if you don't finish it at the table. Fun fact: Although the North End location doesn't take reservations, the SOUTH END location totally does. Important ish.

Reviews.Author: Kozue M.
Reviews.Content: This is one of those restaurants that do not take reservations, no cards (just cash), no wait "list"- you just stand in line outside of the hotel to get your spot. According to the other yelpers, there's a line that starts at 5pm. My friends and I got to the restaurant around 6:30pm, we had a party of 6 and waited 30-45min. There were probably 6-7 groups in front of us. But the wait was definitely worth it!! If you don't have cash on you, no worries there's an ATM right across the street so you can grab cash while you wait.This restaurant is very small- seats around 50; very busy but the service is quick.Once we ordered, the food came out in 10min.We ordered calamaris for the table- it was delicious! Nice & crispy:)I ordered the eggplant parmesan- it was pretty big,  I could barely finish it. and it came with a side of pasta+marinara.My friends ordered: *house salad- the salad is pretty big for an appetizer*lobster ravioli- they said it was amazing but there were only 8 pieces so it looks like there isn't enough but they were full at the end of their meal.*scallops linguine- lots of big scallops, the sauce that they used was a cream sauceFood was great, service was great. Even though the wait was long, it was worth it! The price was decent too; my food was $14 for a large plate of eggplant & pasta. Might not be a place to bring your first date because it's quite noisy and if there are not enough seats you will be seated with strangers.

Reviews.Author: Benjamin V.
Reviews.Content: Every time I travel to Hudson I make sure that I make my way to this lovely place.  The good is amazing.  It is worth the wait which includes 1hr+ in line outside.  It is also cash only.  My favorite Italian!!!!

Reviews.Author: Tiffany S.
Reviews.Content: Happened to be walking along Hanover looking for a place to eat when I came across this place on a weeknight. Hands down best pasta I have ever had. I had the Frutti Di Mare with the Giacomo sauce, the seafood was fresh and tasy, the pasta was great, and the sauce was amazing, absolutely amazing. Beware, this place takes cash only and its tiny (only 10 tables or so) so you have to line up and get a table (no reservations).

Reviews.Author: TinoX T.
Reviews.Content: Delicious Food ,nice place,

Reviews.Author: Kyle R.
Reviews.Content: Came here a few times on my trips fromCalifornia. Absolutely love Boston! But more so, I absolutely love eating authentic Italian home-style cooking in the north end. I am really glad it only took my 2 trips to find this joint. It definitely reminds me of growing up my Italian grandma who makes her pasta from scratch by hand. The place is quite small maybe seats about 12 parties of 2-4. On busy nights there will definitely be a wait. Got there at 430 once when they opened and the place was full by 5. Waits not too long as their turnaround is very quick. Great service as well as great food means quick but memorable satisfaction. Definitely try to go when Rosemarie (I hope thats how you spell it) is there. She is probably the best server there and in my opinion she runs the place. You won't be waiting long nor will you have to ask twice for anything when she's waiting on you. I highly recommend the house salad to start. The dressing is amazing and also adds something nice to dip your bread in while waiting for your meal. The calamari was good as well but what's even better is the house made red sauce they give you to dip it in. As for entrees I've had the chicken parm and the lobster ravioli. Strongly recommend both however I thought the chicken parm was better. But the sauce that comes with the raviolis is one to cherish and enjoy. My friend had one of their specials and he said their house made Giacomo sauce is spectacular. It's cash only but there's a 7-11 and a B of A across the street so don't fret. A must have and a real treasure in the north end!

Reviews.Author: Mel G.
Reviews.Content: Delicious food at great prices. You might feel rushed but that's expected when there is a huge line outside ! Totally worth the wait

Reviews.Author: Eric N.
Reviews.Content: No Res. No Credit Cards. No Wait list.  There is a wait "line."  As mentioned by a fellow yelper, the ATM is right across the street, so make sure you have cash before you go in.  Also, as "Kozue M." said, might not be the best place for a first date since it's a little  loud.  There was a couple that got seated next to us, and I could tell the girl was mortified.  Not the place to take a shy date who is afraid to speak up.  However...if you are a couple that loves food (especially Italian), this is for you!We got there at primetime, 730pm.  Waited 30 minutes for a 2 top.  So worth the wait!  Did service feel a little rushed?  Yeah...I mean, they have a line of people waiting out the door!  You were that guy that was waiting before, but once you sit down, you will have a big smile cause it's time to relax and enjoy your meal...My friend and I split everything:Calamari - As everyone describes, crispy, not chewy, served with marinara.  Great way to start your meal.  (I would try the caprese salad to start next time.  Caught myself drooling when one came out)Cesar Salad - cold, crisp leaves of romaine with a nice creamy dressing.  Big enough to share if you both get entrees.Scallop and Shrimp Pasta - Made with bay scallops, but not overly chewy.  We ordered them with the Giacomo's sauce that was kind of a red cream sauce made with a nice touch of lobster stock.Lobster Ravioli - Made with a heavy cream sauce and fresh basil. This rich and creamy dish, was the star of the night.We ordered a bottle of Pino Noir for $17, and we both walked away from the table only spending $40/person.  Not bad for amazing food, with an "Old Italy" type atmosphere.  Definitely recommend it to anyone staying in the area, as it is walking distance from the Seaport area hotels and convention center.  Worth the wait for both the food and experience.

Reviews.Author: Katy F.
Reviews.Content: Great food, nice ambiance and amazing value!  Wait staff were a bit stuffy and snobby. It's cash only but no issue if you come with green stuff. The wait was so freaking long, though.

Reviews.Author: Sorina P.
Reviews.Content: On our visit to Boston's North End, we took notice of Giacomo's Ristorante because of the long line outside.   Stopped by a few days later to check it out.We were fortunate to get the last table for four upon our arrival at 10 min. to 5pm.   A line started forming right after we were seated.This restaurant is quite small inside and accommodates maybe 50 people max.  The tables are very close to each other too.   We had to move our table in order for two of us to get to the other side by the windows to sit down.   You are nearly elbow to elbow with your fellow patrons.Anyway, we ordered the fried calamari and went for the large portion (just $3 more than the small).   It was as other Yelpers described.   Moist and tasty.  The pieces of fried chili added a nice kick to the dish.  We devoured this in minutes.We also ordered the Lobster/muscles/clams with Linguini.  One order with Giacomo sauce and one with the Pesto.   In retrospect, we should have made one order with shrimp and scallops as I think we would have gotten a better variety of seafood.   Nevertheless, both were delicious, but the Giacomo sauce was the better of the two.  Lobster was good.  You can ask for more complimentary bread to sop up the pasta sauce.   The 4th dish we ordered was the Chicken and broccoli Penne with creamy garlic sauce.  Highly recommended for those who cannot eat seafood (like my daughter).   She LOVED it!I think we had psyched ourselves out to enjoy and nice Italian meal our last night in Boston.   Therefore, Giacomo's satisfied us.Our waitress was nice but a bit forgetful.  She forgot to bring my glass of wine and was doing more PR than waitressing.  Maybe she wears two hats?   Overall, service was good.  Our water glasses were always being refilled and of course they were prompt with the check.  Understandably.

Reviews.Author: Jon N.
Reviews.Content: Had the lobster ravioli while my girlfriend got the daily special: 1/2 lobster, clams & mussels over linguini in pesto sauce. 10/10 for both dishes we had. Lobster was fresh, succulent, and delicious. Pasta and ravioli were cooked to the right degree, nth else I could have asked for.This might possibly be the best Italian meal I have ever had!

Reviews.Author: Manos S.
Reviews.Content: Very solid food, great atmosphere, reasonable prices.Had the Mussels and Clams Linguini in Pesto Sauce, definitely recommending it.Finally, sincere Mediterranean cuisine in Boston.

Reviews.Author: James L.
Reviews.Content: Amazing food..  Seriously a must do in Boston..  Amazing pastas so much better than any place I have tried in NYC..  And the price is cheap for the quality you're getting..

Reviews.Author: Yvonne S.
Reviews.Content: The wait in line is so worth it.  As far as the service goes I don't know what everyone is talking about, RoseMarie was our server and they don't come any nicer!  The calamari was outstanding !  We had house made fussiilli with lobster and shrimp with Giacomo sauce.....food heaven.  Hats off to the chefs in the back!  Beyond recommend this fine restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Michelle W.
Reviews.Content: The hype is real. No seriously, the hype is real, the food is great and you will not be disappointed. We were lucky enough to get in right before the restaurant closed and didn't have to wait more than 20 minutes. The place is small, you'll likely be sharing a table with someone, but everyone here is here for the delicious food. We started with the mozarella and that just set the tone for the meal. It was so fresh, so flavorful and stuffed with pure heaven. I knew the rest of dinner was going to be delicious. We then had the zuppa di pesce which was really for 3-4 people, but after a 4 hour ride from NYC, the boyfriend and I inhaled this dish and finished it! The giacomo's sauce is so flavorful, the seafood cooked to perfection and the pasta was coked al dente. Everything about this place was great, but you need to keep in mind that everyone comes because of the hype. The staff aren't exactly super friendly, but they're here to get people in and get them out. They know they have the goods that people want and they're just focused on feeding people and feeding the person after them. Worth the wait...even if it is a hour or two...you won't be let down.

Reviews.Author: Terry G.
Reviews.Content: Great atmos and food...even the two executive chefs with us loved it.

Reviews.Author: Adam H.
Reviews.Content: My favorite Italian restaurant in Boston. I love the seafood special with half a lobster. You cant go wrong on the prices here, especially the price of a bottle of wine which is unbeatable in the north end. Service is unique and i cant complain. There is usually a line during dinner, but its well worth the wait. Have been here at least half a dozen times now and still have not a single compliant about this place.

Reviews.Author: Allen Y.
Reviews.Content: This place is so good!! I've tried the seafood pasta and the lobster ravioli and they were both delicious!! We also got a large fried calamari as an appetizer and oh boi was it delicious! The line is long and you usually wait 1+ hours before you get to sit down unless you come close to closing time....but let me tell you guys, it is DEFINITELY worth the wait. The first time I came here, a group of people came out and said to us "it's worth the wait guys" and after we ate, we all totally agreed!I will definitely return again to try some of their other dishes.This place is definitely comparable to the food back home in Cali! ^_^v

Reviews.Author: Annie P.
Reviews.Content: The line is always long, but I've found that the wait is always worth it even if it's freezing out. There's a spot for two at the bar(?) counter(?) area looking into the open kitchen. Try to get it if possible at all

Reviews.Author: Irene C.
Reviews.Content: We came, we waited, we conquered.Well warned of the wait, we arrived at 5pm on a Saturday, prepared for our snowy wait. 35 minutes later, our party of two are escorted to a table inside the warm exterior, and we began our feast: small calamari and House Special for Two (Zuppa di Pesce) with red Giacomo sauce. There wasn't much talking once the enormous platter of linguine with lobster, clams, mussels, calamari, shrimp, and scallops was placed down, and we went to work.PROS- The fried calamari was delicious: not too fried, seasoned well, and fresh (as far as you can tell from fried stuff)- In truth, the red Giacomo sauce really made the entire dish extraordinary: I'm not sure what they put in it, but I would buy bottles of it to transform my home cooking. Creamy, tomato-based, plenty of seasoning, great consistency. At the end of our dish, we asked for more bread just to mop up the remaining sauce- Zuppa di Pesce was as desired: lots of fresh seafood on top of linguine. The lobster is already split for you, so you just need to crack open the claws. Yum! The variety of seafood was quite astounding and a phenomenal deal.- The bread was simple but high-quality, allowing it to serve as a base on which you could add whatever you wanted (mostly sauce for us haha)- The staff was courteous, efficient, and professional. This is clearly a place where they try to get you in and out as quickly as possible while allowing you to enjoy your restaurant experience.CONS- I'm not a huge fan of long lines, and it was snowing the day we went. Bleh for the 35 minute wait. The line moves fast though, so if you have only one person waiting, make sure the rest of the party is close by. Larger groups will wait much longer than a 2-person group.- Along those lines, no reservations. :(- Other reviewers describe the Zuppa di Pesce as more than enough for 3-4 people. While it is a lot of food, my boyfriend and I had enough room afterwards to saunter down the street to Mike's Pastry for some dessert. I suspect they might have cut down on the amount of linguine given since our pasta portion was relatively small. I got 3-4 fork-spinfuls of linguine, and I think my boyfriend got 5-6 spinfuls, which is decent but not enough to feed a small nation the way others have described it.- Cash only. There's a Bank of America down the street, but it's still a pain.All in all, would definitely recommend, but given the hassle, it might be awhile before I return.

Reviews.Author: Gina B.
Reviews.Content: Waited outside in line for about 30 minutes but it was totally worth it! Came here with my family of 4 and ordered the large calamari appetizer, butternut squash ravioli (my favorite) and the house seafood special + a bottle of wine for an extra $10 with the special. This was more than enough to fill all of our appetites. Our waiter was extremely friendly and helpful despite how busy it was. Parking is difficult to find but Parcel 7 garage charged us only $1 after getting our ticket validated by a nearby cornerstore. Sweet deal!

Reviews.Author: Lauren W.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is very good Italian. That being said, if you're hungry, I'm not sure Giacomo's is worth the wait (and you will wait). There are plenty of other Italian restaurants in the area without the wait that you'll be happy with. I'd agree with Jenn Z, that Giacomo's is only worth it if the wait is less than 20 minutes. I had been wanting to try Giacomo's for months, and was always intimidated by the line. They don't take reservations, so if you're dead-set on coming, try a week night. They open at 5, so I would come at 4:45. As others have mentioned, Giacomo's is small and cozy, which makes the experience. The service was very attentive (clearly they want you in and out) and the prices are very reasonable (especially being in the North End!) A glass of their house wine is only five bucks! If you do decide to forgo the wait, make sure you have plenty of $$$ on you (they don't accept credit cards) and check out the specials on the walls.

Reviews.Author: Jenn Z.
Reviews.Content: As a long time resident of the North End, my advice on Giacamo's: go there only if your wait is less than 20 minutes, or go on a week day after 9pm (very little wait). Also, bring cash. Giacomo's is not bad; I enjoy their pasta especially when it comes with the homemade "Giacomo" sauce. But the reality is there are plenty of decent Italian restaurants (true, and also tourist traps..but aren't they all?) on Hanover Street. If you are hungry or simply craving Italian, chances are you are not going to be disappointed with another place (ex. Panza across the street). In other words, Giacomo's is good, but it's not worth the wait and I know people have gotten disappointed with their food there. Additionally,  the fried calamari is very good but the wine is so-so.

Reviews.Author: Stacy-Michelle R.
Reviews.Content: I regularly wonder if people who eat here haven't tried any other restaurant in the north end?  Seriously. The food is not better than average for the street (and there are many that are better than average...that's what an average is). It's cash only (sketchy). You wait in line outside to get inside with no AC (Seriously? They make a butt-load of money - just get AC, unless this is a ploy to make people leave faster). And the service....well....they do bring you the food. And that's the nicest thing I can say about it.The only saving grace is the cheap wine.  Seriously though, Citra? You can buy the giant bottle of that for $6 at the liquor barn. And it tastes like it.  Please - go spend your money at someplace with better food who works their ass off to make your dinner a pleasant one. Message me and I can give you a list of em.

Reviews.Author: Wini H.
Reviews.Content: The food was amazing and the wait wasn't terrible when we went as a group of four (we stood outside for about ten minutes until we were seated on a weekday). Unfortunately the waiter spilled parmesan cheese on a very expensive purse (it got into some crevices and was hard to clean out), muttered sorry, and walked away without doing anything about it (no comp, no glass of seltzer and extra cloth to help clean it out). A large blemish of poor service in an otherwise great dinner of great food.

Reviews.Author: Domenic V.
Reviews.Content: Big portions.  Enough left over for lunch the next day.  Decent overall.

Reviews.Author: Danny T.
Reviews.Content: The line here can be pretty intimidating, but I was impressed with how streamlined the workers here were. I only had a day in Boston, so I didn't want to leave thinking I should have just waited in line.Here's some things I wish I had known while I was waiting in line. Hopefully it will ease you're mind while you wait:I got there at about 20:50 (8:50 PM), and the line was backed up about eight parties in front of us.- There are about ten tables that seat about four people as well as a couple seats at the bar. I think your best chance of getting a table quickly is with a party of four or less.- You don't need to put your name down. The waiters and waitresses will come out and see how many are in your party to assess how they will get you in- We were told that upon arrival, we had an hour to an hour and a half wait. We got in at about twenty to thirty minutes- We were also told that if we didn't get in by 21:30 (9:30 PM), we wouldn't get to eat today. However, we left at 22:07 (10:07 PM), and they were still letting people come in to eat. Still, this could be a nice day, so I do suggest getting there early.Inside:Like I said, there's only about ten tables, so you imagine that things are tight. Don't be surprised if you're sharing a table with another group. There's a lot of hustle and bustle, but it's all a part of the process.Service:I thought service was great. You order right when you get in, the food comes out hot and quickly, your drinks are always filled, and the waiters and waitresses are pretty entertaining. If you feel like you're being rushed, think about the poor souls that are outside waiting to be as happy as you are! I did my best to get in and out while still getting the full experience.Food:- Calamari. Best I've ever had. This is a must! Super tender. Not rubbery. The breading doesn't separate from the squid and isn't gritty. The especially liked that they fried some peppers and through it in with the squid.- Mussels in Giacomo sauce. First off, if you're like me, you always butcher Italian dish names. The restaurant and the sauce is pronounced gee-ack-ko-mo. Alright, the mussels combined with the Giacomo sauce combined with a little bread for dipping... Awesome! The sauce just melts in your mouth, and the mussels taste so fresh.- 1/2 Lobster, Clams, and Mussels over Linguini in Giacomo Sauce. Usually when I go Italian, I like to get the Frutti di Mare. Though this was an option, I couldn't say no to the 1/2 lobster option for a dollar more. The one thing that made me hesitant at first was that I wouldn't get scallops, but when I got my dish, there was a single scallop on my plate for me to get my fix. Hahaha. The plate is no joke. Nothing on the plate is lacking. You get enough of everything. The lobster was sweet and consisted of head, tail, and claw. The linguini was cooked very well, and the plate is piping hot. It didn't take me long to clean my plate. I did leave the claw at first because it's not usually my thing, but the waiter came out and told me that I need to finish, so I complied. Not going to lie, it was pretty good!I'm so glad my first real meal in Boston got to be here at Giacomo's!

Reviews.Author: Phil O.
Reviews.Content: Wow, this place is awesome. I can understand why they haven't felt the need to start accepting credit cards to bring in more business. Our 3 entrees and 3 side salads came to $94 after tip and tax. Giacomo's menu offers a nice blend of shellfish-style dishes and Southern Italian traditions (i.e. w/ red sauce). I went with the caprese salad and the chicken marsala with linguini. Everything was terrific. It's nice to see that out of all the restaurants in the North End, the one that's likely the most profitable is on the lower spectrum of menu prices.

Reviews.Author: Jessica C.
Reviews.Content: Omg. Waited abt an hour and a half in line and it was worth every minute! Hubs and I split the special for two and got a suggested bottle of red wine. I was ooohing and ahhhhing over every bite! Now I know where to bring friends and family when they visit! Yummo!

Reviews.Author: Caitlin Y.
Reviews.Content: Waited in line for about 90 minutes one Saturday in November. I had the butternut squash ravioli and we also had a bottle of red wine. They get you in and out of there pretty quickly, and they pack people in. My husband got the pasta with bolognese. The sauce was excellent. We'd probably go back in the summer when the waiting wouldn't be too bad. You get bread and we got mozzarella sticks. The price is excellent for the quality of food. Everything was fantastic.

Reviews.Author: Geno K.
Reviews.Content: Seriously I've never done a Yelp on Giacomos?  Gotta be a glitch.No trip back to Boston is complete until I've stood in line for an hour and had my chair nudged 20-30 times as I devour the best chicken parmesan in the world.  No need to go over everything I'm sure all the other reviews have.  It's just simply the best Italian anywhere. Anywhere.

Reviews.Author: Scott P.
Reviews.Content: Foods Amazing! the line in front is well worth the wait, great food at a great price

Reviews.Author: Max R.
Reviews.Content: As everyone else has stated, plan on standing in line for a while and bring cash if coming here.  While not the best Italian food in the city, it was still a fun time, the food was good (i had the eggplant), and the prices are great for being on a major tourist street in Boston.  Considering how busy they are I thought the service was very efficient and friendly as well.  It's more of an experience than anything, as it's a little strange eating while people are standing outside waiting for you to get up and leave so they can have their turn.  The waitstaff was good in getting people in and out without coming across as rude. I don't know if I would wait in line to eat here again, but I'd consider it if out of town guests wanted to experience dinner in the North End.

Reviews.Author: Tracy T.
Reviews.Content: I visited this restaurant on a blustery November evening. Thankfully the line wasn't too long and was moving at a constant pace. When we finally got in, I understood why. I think we waited in line about 30 minutes before having a table for four open up. Typically I don't like to wait in lines, but the smell of the savory Italian food that wafted everytime someone opened the door piqued my interest and made my stomach rumble even more. So that's what kept me in line.When a table opened up, we were shuffled in briskly by the no-nonsense hostess/waitress/part-owner of the restaurant. She's the type to hold a poker face, yet turned out to be the sweetest lady ever. We had about 1 minute to review the menu before we were asked to order. I felt the pressure. Even though this was a sit-down restaurant, it was more like "fast-food, sit down and eat as fast as you can to make room for the dozens of others standing outside in line and waiting for a table to open up".  I chose to get the salmon in lobster sauce fettucine dish, and it definitely didn't disappoint. Our food came promptly and was delicious as ever. I liked that we could actually see our food being made (and probably not by choice, but just because the restaurant was super small). TWe scarved down ourhe portions were immense. Two can totally share one dish, or one is guaranteed to have leftovers to savor the next day. From the time of sitting down to finishing our meal, it probably took a total of 30 minutes (super fast for restaurant standards, in my opinion). Although not an Italian fan, I would probably come back to this place. There are a ton of other restaurants in the North End near Giacomo's, so I would definitely have to try those first to compare, but I liked what I saw and got, so I highly recommend.Pros: Quick service, no-nonsense waiters/waitresses, and great food at a great price Cons: Cash only  (for those that swear by plastic), and the line may be a turn off on super cold days (although I can tell you it's worth it to wait). I also didn't really like the bread (I prefer softer bread), but still delicious.

Reviews.Author: Lynn D.
Reviews.Content: It's as good as everyone says it is. I lived in the neighborhood, and the key is to get there right when they open.

Reviews.Author: esther d.
Reviews.Content: Got in line at around 5:30pm on a Friday.Stood outside in 90+ heat for about 45mins.Got seated in a cramped space, only to realize NO AC! Rushed to order [sweating].Rushed to eat [sweating].Rushed to pay [sweating].Overall, not a good experience. The food was good, but comparable to any NY Italian place. Heat + frantic service = probably won't come back again.

Reviews.Author: J R.
Reviews.Content: Good food and service at a reasonable price.  Very rare combination in Boston.  Bring cash!

Reviews.Author: Nicole B.
Reviews.Content: This restaurant is problematic. With the glowing reviews on Yelp, I was honestly expecting a nice dining experience, yet we received the complete opposite. I took guests visiting from NYC here and was embarrassed that I picked this place out. My main gripe is the service and the cramped cave of a space they use as a dining room. First, we waited about 30-45min to get into the restaurant, which would have been fine if we were treated with some respect once we got inside. From the second we stepped foot in the restaurant the wait staff was screaming at us to move swiftly to our table. The issue was that a group was leaving and blocking our path, yet  we continued to get barked at. Once seated we were squeezed between the other tables and we were repeatedly hit in the back by wait staff and other customers. The cramped condition made our experience uncomfortable and unbearably hot (it was cooler outside in the eighty-five degree weather).  The speed at which our food was served and cleared made it obvious that this is a tourist mill. I know this isn't high class dining, but nevertheless, when I pay money at a restaurant I expect to be treated with some common courtesy and have some level of relaxation. I am sure the wait staff is pushed to their limits with the sheer volume of customers here, but the overall tone of the experience was to rush customers out. Although the food was decent, it's was not worth the aggravation. Some Yelp reviewers viewed the service as "charming" because of the "no nonsense" attitude, but that is NOT my idea of a nice dining experience. Politeness goes a long way in life. I am from NJ and not unfamiliar with gruffness, but I refuse to PAY for that kind of treatment. The "no nonsense" attitude isn't cute, it's unprofessional. I will not return.

Reviews.Author: Ann M.
Reviews.Content: Cozy and delicious. Don't let the line scare you, it's worth it. You're squeezed in tight, but it's all part of the experience. Classic North End dinner, everything is good, but the Butternut Squash Ravioli is divine!

Reviews.Author: Jennifer T.
Reviews.Content: Great food and quick service! The only downside was that there was a line outside the door that we had to wait it. However, it was worth the wait

Reviews.Author: Kristine J.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian restaurant I've been to thus far. Certainly recommend this homecooked, family-style restaurant to anyone craving Italian food when visiting Boston! There's definitely a line at this place, but I was able to beat the long, long wait fortunately. Just make sure to come before or around 5 pm if you come on a weekday, since the crowd starts by 5:30 or so.  So I gotta say,this place is so darn small! It could literally only feed like 10 people at most inside! I went here with my family back in May, & found everyone to be so friendly here, INCLUDING the fellow patrons. It's 'cuz your're seated very closely by each other, which sorta forces you to chat people up. Which is definitely not a problem. Adds to the charm of the place.We ended up having a convo with an old cute couple from Colorado I think, alongside our table. I wanted to try their butternut squash ravioli, but since I have a nut allergy, decided not to risk it. THOUGH, now I'm regretting this decision because it seems to be a true to the hype dish hahha. I even had some Benadryl handy. But the waitress (who had the coolest Boston accent btw) checked with the cooks, saying they weren't even sure if there were cashews or not inside. :/ It's cool. I still had a DELICIOUS alternative. The lobster ravioli. It was pure heaven in my mouth. I finished my whole plate. The sauce, the lobster---- meshed together so well. Oh & the Calamari was very tasteful. Forgot what the rest of my fam had, but I'm pretty sure I had a taste test of all of their dishes too hahah. I remember they were also very good. Check out the pics below which only testify half the amazingness of their food!

Reviews.Author: Diana C.
Reviews.Content: In the words of my ex-CA governor...I'LL BE BACK.

Reviews.Author: Carrie F.
Reviews.Content: Food Good!!

Reviews.Author: Gail M.
Reviews.Content: I've been to Giacomo's Ristorante gazillions of times over the years. My sister-in-law is from the UK and wanted good Italian food with little fuss. She didn't care about the wait. After a 10-minute wait, we were seated at a window and the wait staff was tremendous, only outdone by the wonderful food! I've dined by myself at different times of the day/night. Still, no problem. Excellent service. Not a long wait either.

Reviews.Author: Tanya Y.
Reviews.Content: Give me any of Giacomo's sauces and some bread for dipping, and I'd die happily in a carb loaded heaven.Yes, the lines are as long as all the others say; for a 5 person party, we waited nearly an hour.  On a different occasion with just two, we were lucky enough to only wait about 20-30 minutes.  This location is a hole in the wall.  They take no reservations, and you're forced to wait outside until they can accommodate to your party size.  Yes, the waitresses have a bit of pizzazz and attitude, though that's what adds flare to the atmosphere.  The waitstaff consists of just about 4 people.  They know how things work and they don't take any crap.  I don't like crap.The menu is chalk written on the walls and is the same as the paper menu that the waitress gives you.  The menu isn't huge, but their food quality is so good that they don't need much more.And the food.  My goodness, the food.  There are about 5 sauces to choose from, but the best is the Fracomo sauce : Combination of their fiery Fra Diablo and the house Giacomo blend.  In our group of 5, we had the chance to order an abundance of food:  a fatty's dream.Large Fried Calimari, $10.  Simple.  With a squeeze of lemon.  Comes out piping hot.  You can't go wrong.Garlic Bread, $4.  slightly burnt, but still good.Lobster Ravioli, $16, with diced tomatoes in a garlic cream sauce.  Delicious, too.  Split amongst 5 people, it served as more of an appetizer rather than an entree.  About 10-12 pieces of ravioli were in this plate.Fettucini with prosciutto and peas in a garlic cream sauce, $14.  A quarter sized portion of this was all that was doggy bagged home.  Good, but outshined by the Zuppa Di Pesce....Zuppa Di Pesce, $55, "Serves 2 people" consists of shrimp, scallops, calamari, clams, mussels and lobster, served over lingiune with your choice of sauce.  This plate is huge.   Definitely capable of serving 3-4 people rather than the 2 they suggest.  The amount of seafood included was like a fisherman's dream.  Tons of clams and mussels, enough shrimp so everyone in our party got at least one, and one giant lobster sat ontop like it was king.  Warning: ask for extra napkins because cracking the lobster can be quite messy.  Delicious.  We even asked for extra bread to soak up that sauceAll of this food, with tax and tip included turned out to be just $25 per person (cash only)?  Definitely worth the wait, and increases my need to come back for more.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer Y.
Reviews.Content: Honestly, what more could I add that someone else hasn't mentioned in the last 1000 reviews? This place is that hole-in-the-wall Italian restaurant of the North End that people hear about from all over the country and wait in line for because "you just have to experience it." The calamari is unbelievable - that perfect crunch with a fried pepper surprise. You have not lived until you have the butternut squash ravioli - no, really. Make friends with the people in line. You'll have some great conversation and it'll make the time pass more quickly so you can enjoy all that delicious, exquisite grub.

Reviews.Author: Meghan H.
Reviews.Content: Man, if you're looking for some quality Italian in North End - come to Giacomo's.I ordered the sautéed calamari in red sauce and it tasted really fresh and was so delicious.Their bread is also wonderfully chewy and so FRESH! dunk it in some of their olive oil -and aw man, forget about it!I must say that this was quite a small restaurant, so our party of five ended up waiting an hour or so during prime dinner time (weekday) for a table.Great spot!

Reviews.Author: Margo B.
Reviews.Content: Brought my out of town friend here two years ago and we loved it! The line was out the door and around the corner and we had to wait for maybe 35 minutes, but it was worth it. Everyone else in line couldn't stop raving about it. I think I got pumpkin ravioli (or tortellini can't remember which) and it was amazing. The garlic bread was OK. Highly recommend the calamari appetizer, it was fried and had surprise pieces of battered jalapeños mixed in. Definitely worth the long wait!

Reviews.Author: Christine T.
Reviews.Content: It has been 2 months since i had dinner there and i still dream about it at night. Undoubtedly one of the best dishes so far in my life, the butternut squash ravioli will make me go back to Boston. I can't describe the heaven of that dish but it was just perfect. Not too filling but just enough to hit the spot. This restaurant has already quite the reputation and is to me the best in little Italy. They have decent prices, great quality and good service.Here's some tips:A bottle of house wine is only $17 and is pretty good, the calamari is great, the squash ravioli is divine. They only accept cash, no reservations and there's always a line so go at a reasonable time. If you don't like sitting next to other parties, tough luck. This place is the size of a shoe box, so everyone sits very cozily near each other.In the end, all worth it. Worth waiting in the cold.

Reviews.Author: Nicole I.
Reviews.Content: We ordered take-out on a Sunday evening, even though the line was relatively short at 545pm.  It was rainy, cold and with 4kids, we opted to take out despite the wait being probably only 20-30mins.  I had to go into the restaurant to order because no one picked up the phone after trying to call over 15mins.  The food was excellent!!  The homemade fusilli was so yummy!  We also tried the pumpkin ravioli - good but a little sweet for my taste.  The frutti de mare with their house special sauce (Giacomo?) was very good too.  We will definitely be back again before leaving town.

Reviews.Author: Simon C.
Reviews.Content: This is where the clout of social network really shows through.Came here based on Yelpers reviews. Almost all Italian restaurants on Hanover Street have no wait but two or three have loooong lines and this has the longest. Chatting with a local young couple waiting in front of us and they confirmed that this is THE place to come. Loved their fried calamari and two specials: Zuppa di pesce with the pesto sauce and home made pasta (chewy in a good way) with clam in a diavolo sauce. The fact that three of us were completely full (used bread to scape up every last bit of the diavolo sauce) and the total bill came to just over $60 also explained the value this place provides.

Reviews.Author: Jenn T.
Reviews.Content: HOLY ORGASMIC!  This place is spectacular.  Now I know the line looks intimidating and very painful, but I'd say that it is well worth the wait.  This place doesn't take names or reservations so the only way to get a table is to stand in a long long line.  However, it does give you plenty of time to plan out what you would like to eat, and trust me, you'll need plenty of time because literally everything on the menu looks SUPER yummy.  I couldn't decide even after standing in line for 45minutes and even then I made a split second decision and decided to go with a special written on the board.  The restaurant is very small and crowded, full of the hustle and bustle atmosphere, which makes you slightly hyper while eating.  Everything looks good, but what they feature is a great pasta, with different types of sauces that all sound yummy.We got the calamari because everyone was raving about it on yelp and boy was it yummy.  I tried some of the lobster ravioli, which was SO full of flavor and lobster.  I also tried the squash ravioli, which to my shock, was BETTER than the lobster ravioli.  I got the homemade fucili with lobster and shrimp with the friacomo sauce.  SO AMAZING, full of flavor, basically a fricken explosion in your mouth with some spice and zest to it.  LOVED IT and could not stop eating it even though I was stuffed because the flavor was so amazing.  The other downside to this place is that it is cash only, which makes it some what a hassle, but well worth it.  Everyone here was very helpful and polite despite the crazy atmosphere in side.  It was definitely a fun fun find and a delicious meal!

Reviews.Author: Allison K.
Reviews.Content: This is my favorite Italian restaurant in the city. The prices are reasonable (especially compared to its neighbors) the food is spectacular (go for the lobster ravioli) and the service is great. They've got specials written in chalk on the wall and the tin tile ceiling panels are a nice touch. I like that Giacomo's does not accept credit cards. It gives me more of a family-run feel and I think it helps speed up the process (think about groups who split up checks three or four ways...)The main problem, as everyone has mentioned, is the line. Once you make it close enough to see inside the restaurant you're still looking at between 30 and 40 minutes of a wait, assuming you have four or less people in your party. For those who are driving, this isn't so bad since that's about the amount of time it will take you to find a parking spot (yes, really) so leave one or two people in line while you do that and you should make it in at about the same time. I saw a couple bring a cocktail to share while they waited last time I was there, and it seemed to help them endure the line.There is also the issue of seating. You are completely cramped in this restaurant. For parties of two you are often brushing elbows with a couple next to you, and I would never even consider bringing more than four. But as I said, even with the close quarters and long wait, this restaurant is completely worth it.

Reviews.Author: Victoria P.
Reviews.Content: Long line? WORTH THE WAIT.My boyfriend and I waited for what seemed like ages to get a table, but it moves pretty quickly. The waitstaff even came out to offer us some garlic bread which, while delicious, made me hungrier - I felt like my stomach was going to eat itself. Once inside we ordered quickly...the calamari, butternut squash ravioli, and shrimp and scallop pasta dish with giacomo's sauce. Everything was soooooo good. The calamari has these deep fried spicy peppers hidden amongst the delicious little squid - absolute culinary genius. It changed my life. The butternut squash was a sweet and savory party in my mouth. My boyfriend loved his pasta dish and said it was the best scallop he ever had. We ate everything so fast that we hardly remember what happened - it was like everything was a beautiful dream. Ok, now my stomach is grumbling - time to head over to Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: Larlar S.
Reviews.Content: The Italian food here knocks it out of the ball park.  Best. Italian. Meal. Of. My. Life!!!Giacomo's opens at 4 pm.  We get there at 3:30 and there is already a line of excited Bostonians huddled in the pouring rain.  Definitely a good sign.
