Trusting my brother and taking the line of avid customers into consideration, I tolerated freezing my Hawai`i butt for half an hour to see what the hype was about.  Clearly, it was worth the suffering.Entering that tiny restaurant was extremely delightful.  The waitress was hospitable, the atmosphere was homely, and the smell of garlic was beyond words.  I couldn't wait to devour my lobster ravioli.  When our entrees came out, they were gorgeous.  My meal consisted of cute pasta pillows sprinkled with dices of tomatoes and covered in thick garlic cream sauce.  My sister and brother both ordered linguine, heaped of clams and mussels, and soaked in delicious scampi sauce and spicy marinara sauce, respectively.  My brother's linguine also had a good-sized lobster.  I don't understand how each dish was under $20.  I have never eaten anything this extravagant for this price!  When I took a bite of my lobster ravioli, it was perfect.  I loved the rich combination of the cheese, the lobster, the sauce, and the sweet tomatoes.  UGH...I felt deprived and privileged simultaneously...strange feeling.  Yes, this deserves the cliche, "where have you been all my life??"  Umm..in Boston...duh.  More than 10 hours away by plane from where you live??? Gosh darn it!!!  Bottom line: #amore

Reviews.Author: Kiev R.
Reviews.Content: We visited Giacomo's on the recommendation of a co-worker.  First off, bring cash because that's the only thing that they accept. Second, be very comfortable sitting and eating in close proximity to complete strangers because this place is crackerjack box tiny!! More than likely, you will be bumping elbows with the person sitting next to you. But the food is delicious! And the portions: huge!!! My recommendation would be to come with a completely empty stomach. Even then, you'll probably only be able to finish half your meal. Everything taste homemade and fresh and who doesn't love that! We were lucky enough to snag a seat without a wait but even if there was a line, I'd wait in it just to have this dining experience all over again.

Reviews.Author: Leona Y.
Reviews.Content: Probably one of the best pasta sauces I've ever had. If you're not into spicy but want to explore something other than a typical marinara, I highly recommend the giacomo sauce on your pasta.There was a special available with half a lobster, clams, and mussels in their linguini and it was only $20! What a great deal! The portions aren't necessarily huge but order the calamari appetizer and munch on the bread while you wait for your main dish and it's definitely plenty. The food comes out pretty quickly and the service is awesome. I can understand how many reviews say they feel rushed but I think its just the atmosphere and we didn't necessarily feel like they were trying to get us out the door. We arrived around 5:15 and there was already a line outside. We only waited about 20 minutes outside before we got seated. Definitely come in a group of 4 or smaller. Even better if you're a group of 2 since you might actually get seated before the larger parties waiting in front of you!

Reviews.Author: Jed D.
Reviews.Content: We had wondered about the line, and decided to give it a try. We decided to get in early for the first seating. The reason for the line became apparent in the quality of the food, the value in the prices, and efficiency of the wait staff.

Reviews.Author: Christina S.
Reviews.Content: We had to wait outside in a long line for 40 minutes. It was not really worth the wait. Very small inside. I felt very rushed to order so they can have others come in to eat.  People are staring at you eat from the line outside.  They had really good fried calamari. That was the best part. I had bread with cheese and oil and that wasnt good either. The cheese or something had such a strong taste. It wasn't good. The bread was warm. ummmm.... I got shrimp, scallop and broccoli in a garlic cream sauce and that was okay. I ONLY GOT 3 SHRIMP ON MY ENTIRE PLATE. that was not worth my 16.00 meal for 3 jumbo shrimp.  They do not take credit card so bring lots of cash. Ive had better Italian food elsewhere. was not worth the long wait in the line outside on a cold night. They also dont take reservations hence the long wait line. There's a convenient random ATM across the street.  I wouldn't go back.

Reviews.Author: Roger I.
Reviews.Content: We waited about 50 minutes but it wasn't a drag at all!  IT'S BOSTON !!Once inside, Chris took expert (over 20 years experience) care of us. After the obligatory Calamari,  I had the Chicken Parmesan. It was good but I LOVED my daughter's Lobster Ravioli in white sauce and my son's Swordfish Linguine with Pesto. DW has some kind of garlic allergy and yet, we went anyway (Molto thanks, Dear Wife). Chris had the cooks fix up a +garlic-free+ dish of Scallop and Shrimp Linguine which she DEVOURED !! (Knocking my fork away on every attempt!)DW and I reminisced of out trips to Italy before children, had TWO glasses of Merlot and ALL was WELL with the WORLD.  ...Really Well !Afterword, Chris sent us down the sidewalk for gelato which somehow we had room for... (There's ALWAYS room for gelato!)  With a stomach full of Italian, watching the world wonder by, listening to the many langues and licking my Melone Gelaaato... The world became really, REALLY well.We LOVE that Dolci Vita Stuff...And I love Giacomo's Ristorante !!

Reviews.Author: Robin T.
Reviews.Content: WOWOWOWOWOWOW!!!!! I was blown away by this place! I didn't know Italian food could taste so good!! We thought this place opened at 5pm, so we thought if we got there at exactly 5pm, we wouldn't have a problem getting seated without much of a wait -- wow were we wrong. At 5pm, there were already people seated and dining, and with a group of 5, it was another 1 hour wait outside in the 95-degree Boston summer heat. Highly recommend going with a group of 4 or less -- definitely not for big groups. We were so excited to go inside because we thought that we could take refuge from the sweltering heat but to our surprise, inside was even hotter!!! It felt like a freaking sauna in there with no AC. The inside of this place is extremely crowded and we were practically sitting on top of the table next to us and the servers were tripping over our chairs to get around us. Despite the miserable lack of air conditioning and long wait, it is without a doubt, 100% worth every minute/sweat drop!!!!! The food was incredible -- literally the best Italian food I have ever eaten. I think my favorites were the butternut squash ravioli and a simple shrimp and scallops ziti. Calamari as an appetizer was to die for, as well. Can't say enough good things about the food!!!!! Love love love it, would eat from here every day if I could!!

Reviews.Author: Nina O.
Reviews.Content: I really enjoyed going to Giacomo's Ristorante. The line moves quickly, and you can make close friends from the table next to you...I mean the adjoining table connected to yours. If you like your space don't go here. The waiters yell to the kitchen, I got tapped on the head with the waiter's order book taking the order next to me..which did not annoy me. This place has a lot of character and the food comes to your table about a second after it's done - piping hot. The food was fantastic and I recommend trying this place out. I smile just thinking about Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: Tina S.
Reviews.Content: Okay this place really doesn't need any more (5-star) reviews but I had SUCH AN AMAZING DINING EXPERIENCE HERE that I just can't resist.We came on a Wednesday evening at 9pm, and there was a 30 minute wait which was a little surprising - but we waited and jealously looked in at the happy diners in the tiny restaurant. When it was finally our turn, the waitress treated us like family and was incredibly nice, even though it was clear we were the last to be seated for the night before they closed. Awesome customer service.We started by ordering 2 glasses of wine - only $5 per glass?! I'm a newcomer to the North End restaurant scene but that seems incredible to me. Then we got the calamari with Giacomo sauce and the lobster ravioli. Simply amazing. Usually I'm not a huge fan of calamari but it was cooked to perfection and the pasta tasted incredibly fresh. Even after we finished the plate we were still eating the leftover sauce because it was so good! The lobster ravioli consisted of 9 plump raviolis with generous chunks of lobster. The best part was each entree was only $15! Seriously the best quality of meal to cost ratio that I've experienced in a while. This place is definitely somewhere I'll be taking anyone and everyone who hasn't yet been, especially people who are visiting Boston. Remember it's cash only!!

Reviews.Author: Eva W.
Reviews.Content: After wandering around North End, we decided fit in a quick dinner before our Amtrak. Decided to come here, and lucky we got here early. We were here about half an hour before they opened on a Sunday and took the third to last table. Crazy to see such lines..Menu is written on the wall. Cheap bottles of wine. Space is a bit cramped and you'll likely be rubbing elbows with your  neighbors. But I guess that's all a part of the appeal? The service is fast, and the food is pretty darn fresh and good, but not so spectacular it's worth an hour wait. Great calamari, but I'd be sad if this really were the best in town.

Reviews.Author: Alice H.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's Ristorante always seems to have a line going out-the-door. After only a few short minutes in line, many passers-by stopped, checked out the line, and asked "Is this place really that good?"An hour later, we were seated at a cozy two-top next to the "Specials" wall, amazingly close to the open kitchen with its wall of copper cookware. The service here is super fast-paced and rapid-fire. Works for us!The large order of fried calamari was among the best I've ever tasted and hands-down arrived to our table piping hot the FASTEST of any restaurant. The batter was perfectly seasoned and I loved the fried pickled peppers sprinkled throughout.We also picked up a side order of the garlic bread, which used olive oil instead of butter. The edges of the bread was so charred that it made the whole plate bitter. I'd pass on this next time.I selected a dish off the specials - homemade fusilli with lobster and shrimp in a fra diavolo sauce. The pasta was al dente, the sauce was piping hot in temperature and spice, and the chunks of lobster and shrimp were fresh and plentiful. For those who can't quite take the heat, they also offered this dish with the house Giacomo sauce (red, non-spicy marinara) or half-and-half with the fra diavolo to lessen the blow.M went with the lobster ravioli with diced tomatoes in a garlic cream sauce. The lobster meat was generous and ravioli thin enough to let the flavors of the lobster shine through. The cream sauce wasn't heavy and along with the tomatoes, made the dish very enjoyable.So long story short, Giacomo's was definitely worth the wait. Yup - it's that good.Fun fact: The seating arrangement is pure luck, but I have to say the tables next to the window would definitely be the worst spots simply because all the hungry, slightly irritated patrons would be staring you down, Jedi mind-tricking you to eat faster and leave.

Reviews.Author: Ashley M.
Reviews.Content: This place lived up to the hype for me. $18 for a nice bottle of red wine? $14 for a huge portion of cheese smothered chicken parm & spaghetti? Sign me up. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive and I couldn't help but feel like my own grandma was taking care of us. Did not wait when we went, but then again it was a weeknight and it was 15 degrees outside.

Reviews.Author: Brutally H.
Reviews.Content: Lobster ravioli was good.I don't like salmon but Salmon and sundried tomatoes in a tomato cream sauce Fettucine was good.My friends liked Frutti di Mare.Expect to wait in line for half an hr to an hr because they don't take reservations.

Reviews.Author: charles l.
Reviews.Content: I just want  to follow up by saying this service at this place really sucks!!!  I wish I could give this place a negative 10 stars.

Reviews.Author: Hannah C.
Reviews.Content: Summary: blah blah blah.. tourist trap... blah... FRIED CALAMARI AND FRACOMO SAUCE ARE DIVINE. Just try it once. No regrets. Likely, our best meal in Boston. CASH ONLY!Yes, there are only like 10-12 tables in this teeny tiny restaurant.  Yes, it gets crowded early, and the line grows exponentially as the sun sets.  And yes, it's just another homey Italian joint in the North End. But no, it's freaking tasty and really cheap for the quality of seafood and size of portions. No, it's not a waste to stand in line before the restaurant opens at 4:30 so you can be seated RIGHT AWAY. And no, husband had never tasted such tasty pasta before in his life... I've been to Italy, so I'll say that this is the best Italian-American food that's ever entered my mouth and stomach.First, the fried calamari: crisp and fresh, they also fry up some peppers that are the perfect complement to the rich butteriness of the calamari. Dip in the fantastic marinara (rich but not overpoweringly tomato-y) and pop into your mouth. Yum-o.Next, the bottle of wine: so tasty and so affordable. I think we got the tempranillo and I think it was like $17. Um, yes please! Finally: Fracomo Sauce. Get it on anything, and you're good. We got it on our shrimp and scallops with linguine. Fra diavolo = spicy marinara. Giacomo = creamy lobster. Fracomo = magic. Creamy, rich tomato sauce with a kick. So so SO very tasty. I tried replicating the sauce at home, but I couldn't capture the full flavor profile that made this meal so memorable.  Not super heavy, considering the creamy and richness of it all. One of the most well-rounded and balanced pasta sauces I've had.We also ordered and enjoyed a veal parmigiana. Not too soggy or greasy and topped with the wonderful marinara sauce we so enjoyed.  AND our server was so kind and sweet.  I'm sure she's seen people from all over come through her tables, but she was still excited to hear where we were from and why we were visiting. Yay for delicious food, genuinely friendly service, and crossing an item off of our Boston food bucket list. We're definitely coming back the next time we're in Beantown. Husband wanted to go again on our short trip; he loved it so much.

Reviews.Author: Meridith H.
Reviews.Content: There is usually a long line snaking down the street for Giacomo's, so when we had the opportunity to grab a table for an early dinner, we jumped. Shortly thereafter, we were seated at a table with strangers and presented with a lightning fast verbal description of the menu. Our server was friendly, but overworked; she had the entire (crowded) dining room to work on her own. Our dishes came quickly and so did the check. Aside from waiting in line, you can expect an extraordinarily efficient dinner here. The food was excellent; on par with several other restaurants in the area. The difference between Giacomo's and those other restaurants is the opportunity to eat at a leisurely pace and linger over conversation and drinks.

Reviews.Author: Matthew F.
Reviews.Content: One of the best Italian restaurants I've been to.  I had the calamari appy, cooked perfectly and the house spicy/cream sauce blend on pasta and shrimp as main course that was absolutely incredible, paired with a nice Chianti Classico.  I was from out of town and stumbled on this place using my NYC learned instinct to go to the restaurant that has a line.  Worth the wait and got seated at the bar top quickly since I was single.  The wait staff was very pleasant and helpful. 5 stars!  Oh yea, must bring cash only, but there is a money station next door.  Great value overall.

Reviews.Author: E D.
Reviews.Content: This restaurant is small-, but very busy.  The service is quick. Once we ordered, the food came out with 10 minutes or less. We ordered calamaris and eggplant parmesane. The portion here is pretty big,  My friend & I could barely finish it. Delicious!

Reviews.Author: Pierre B.
Reviews.Content: This place gets packed. The line reaches the end of the block, tables are squeezed in right next to each other, and they try hard to get you out as fast possible. But once you take your first bite, all else ceases to matter. So much so that it's one of the few places I make sure to stop by when I'm in town; the others being Neptune Oyster, Flour Bakery & Cafe, and Alive & Kicking Lobsters.Calamari, while not mind-blowing, is one of the best I've had. It's crisp, light, and tender. The lobster ravioli with diced tomatoes with garlic cream sauce and butter-squash ravioli with asparagus with a prosciutto/mascarpone cream sauce were both delicious. The Frutti di mare linguine, however, was my favorite; the sauce was packed with flavor and was certainly not one-note -- I think we chose well by asking them for a half giacomo, half diavolo (spicy) sauce.Don't usually go out to Italian restaurants, but I'm looking forward to my next trip to Boston just so I can come back.

Reviews.Author: Brad L.
Reviews.Content: All I have to say is "Whoa!"When we arrived, the line was fairly long, but we got in after about 30-45 minutes. Service was fast and knowledgeable. Food and wine was fantastic. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone.

Reviews.Author: A B.
Reviews.Content: Fantastic Italian seafood, but be warned, this is "an experience."The food is as good as it gets for pasta and seafood.  The prices are very reasonable, especially considering this is the North End, where food is generally steeply overpriced.The best and worst thing about this place is the popularity and the line. The wait is long, and you stand outside on the street. On a nice evening, this can be fun and part of the evening.  Once inside, things move fast.  The menu is on chalkboard.  The service is solid, friendly and efficient.  But they will move you "in and out."  Head off into the night for desert and drinks somewhere else in the neighborhood.A Boston favorite of mine.  Just know what you are in for, and I think you will love it.

Reviews.Author: Scott M.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's has what I consider to be some of the best Italian Food in America.  They are found right on Hanover Street in the historic Boston North End.  Here is your first tip.  Watch where you park!  You will get a ticket and might get towed.  Use one of the lots on Commercial Street.  There are good ones down toward the Warf and toward Langone Park.  Here is your second tip bring cash, because it's the only way to pay at Giacomo's.  Lastly, bring a bit of patience as your wait will be a little long and outside so an umbrella would be handy if the weather is bad.All of that is sooooo worth it.  The wait could be twice as long and I would still do it.  When you walk in you cannot help but be swept away by the cooking garlic.  I have tried a different item each time I go.  I now often order the special.  The menu is written up on the wall in chalk.  The ingredients are so fresh and prepared in view just a few feet from where you are seated.The staff is on the move and seating is tight.  You have had plenty of time consider your order while peering in the windows.  So get on with it.  I strongly suggest the Calamari.  It may be the best I have ever had.  If you are not too adventurous the lobster ravioli will not steer you wrong.  Don't be afraid to ask your server about the specials and if they would recommend them.  They may be the hidden treasure of Giacomo's.If you are a single don't be shy let them know.  You may be to jump up in line a lot faster.  Hold off on coffee and dessert, because there are great options in the North End for both.So sit back, loosen your belt and prepare your taste buds for an experience they will not soon forget.  Sooooo Good!

Reviews.Author: Brenda S.
Reviews.Content: LOVED IT.I ordered Butternut Squash Ravioli; my friend ordered Lobster Ravioli; and my uncle ordered Gnocchi Filled With Roasted Red Peppers And Goat Cheese.So delicious. I love Italian food, especially pasta, and I'm really picky, but I must say- I was extremely satisfied. It was definitely worth the wait.Great service too!

Reviews.Author: Christine N.
Reviews.Content: Came in on a Wednesday around 5:30 and was seated around 6:15. Definitely a shorter wait if you come in a party of two (I had a party of three). The space in the restaurant is very small and you will have to squeeze into some spots. The waiters are not very attentive but I can understand since they are very busy and it's a small place. We ordered the fried calamari which was delicious!!! I would definitely recommend the butternut squash ravioli, best ravioli I've had yet! Overall a good experience and worth the wait. Even in the cold weather !!

Reviews.Author: Christine B.
Reviews.Content: A great place! Fast clean service !!! Couldn't be any happier:)

Reviews.Author: Sayed I.
Reviews.Content: This is a true Boston original. Been coming here for years, when I can get in since they don't take reservations and are cash only. The food is the reason to come here, they don't mess around with their tremendous selection of sauces and fresh pastas. This is a no-nonsense place with a chalkboard menu, and old school Italian staff that gives you a consistently great meal. The main reason I go to the North End is this gem and then probably Mike's Pastry for a cannoli.

Reviews.Author: caroline h.
Reviews.Content: I love Giacomo's. I've been here a few dozen times and will keep going back.  My usual order is chicken picatta with their homemade fusilli pasta and a side order of the deliciously garlicky broccoli. I hold all other picattas to this as the standard. They are always busy, but service is always quick and the wine pours are heavy and cheap!

Reviews.Author: Jessica O.
Reviews.Content: There is nothing I can say about Giacomo's that hasn't already been said, so I will simply lend my five star rating to the masses and attempt to negate the crazies who gave this place anything less than five stars. Giacomo's is perfection. Go there. Bring cash. Be happy. If you aren't a local, be prepared to be seriously considering a move to Boston before your meal is over.

Reviews.Author: Ken A.
Reviews.Content: It's pretty good. We got there a bit before "dinner time" to try to beat the rush. There was still a wait (maybe about 15 minutes). The food was really nice. We had the veal marsala and one of the pasta specials. It was gnocci with vegetables. The pasta special was just ok, the veal marsala was fantastic. We had the calamari for an appetizer, it was pretty good-- not the best I've had, but certainly not the worst.The waitress was a bit pushy, but I think they are just trying to get people in and out as quickly as possible.

Reviews.Author: Steph H.
Reviews.Content: I had already read the reviews about the wait and saw a friend's Facebook picture of the line she was in on Monday, so when I arrived in Boston on Thursday afternoon, I walked straight there from my hotel in the Theatre District...in the rain. I arrived at 4pm on the dot and was first in line. I even got to hang out in the doorway to get out of the downpour. At exactly 4:30, we were let inside and I took the solo spot at the bar/counter since it was just me, myself, and I. Rosemary was my waitress. Because I already knew exactly what I wanted - the highly touted butternut squash ravioli - I was served immediately. I downed it quickly because it was AMAZING. I kept getting more water in an attempt to make myself slowdown and enjoy the meal, but I couldn't stop shoveling. When the young man came to bus my spot and asked how it was, I said, "If it wasn't rude, I'd lick my plate clean." He laughed and said, "Trust me, I've seen it happen."It is tight space and you'll likely be seated an inch from someone you don't know, but that's part of the fun! The couple at the table next to me was from Kansas City - just like me! The restrooms are downstairs and beware the heat! I was sweating big while waiting for the person ahead of me.

Reviews.Author: David A.
Reviews.Content: Came here with the girlfriend last night. Yes there was a line, but because we were only two we were able to jump the queue and get a table within about 20 minutes. So coming with a large group could be problematic. As with the general consensus of the other reviews, the overall experience felt a bit rushed. The service was ok but sensed some disinterest and even arrogance. I got the homemade fussili with lobster, shrimp and giacomo sauce. The sauce was nice, fresh and flavorsome, but the pasta was severely undercooked. Normally I wouldn't mind if it was a bit firmer than al dente as I'm not usually one to make a fuss, but this was hard. Bordering on raw. I proceeded to inform the waiter quite reluctantly that it was undercooked (which is something I've never done), and straight away he retorted with a defensive and derogatory tone, that this was how they do it here and that's what al dente was. Wait, what? Al dente is al dente, there's no degrees of al dente. It either is or it isn't. So this really annoyed and irked me, as I myself am Italian with parents born in Italy, and I've been eating pasta for 26 years - I think I know what al dente is, and I know for a fact that that pasta was nowhere near. Period. But anyway, he offered to take it back and cook it a bit more which I gladly accepted and thanked him for, and it returned fairly promptly and a lot better (but still on the firm side). But overall the situation left me feeling a bit uneasy and quite frankly belittled. FYI, I tried my girlfriend's tortellini and that was nice, and the calamari entree was pretty good. The cash only policy is a bit strange but manageable I suppose, just come prepared. I'm hoping I just had an off experience compared to rest of the reviews, but I won't be raving about this place either.Thank you for reading.

Reviews.Author: Lucy K.
Reviews.Content: I had to wait 30 min. to get seated on a Saturday night, which isn't so bad. Food was exceptional. The next time I go to Boston, I'll def. make a stop at this place again.Pro:-Food: BEST capri salad you'll ever have in your lifetime-Fresh ingredients: including pasta-Price: not too expensiveCon:-Service: We felt neglected at times. We know they were extremely busy, but they didn't even notice the fact that we desperately needed napkins.

Reviews.Author: B C.
Reviews.Content: Four of us came here for dinner on a Monday night and we still had to wait about 15 minutes outside. Super crowded inside. We ordered the fried calamari for the table and I ordered their famous butternut squash ravioli as my entree. I think the butternut squash ravioli is the best pasta dish I've ever had thus far in my lifetime. The calamari was fresh and delicious too! It is very much a mom-and pop-restaurant and it seemed like everyone who works there is related. Our server was pretty in-your-face and I would have given this place 5 starts but, I kid you not, he pulled on my hair from behind me while I was eating to ask my how my food was--the food was great but really, there wasn't a better way to ask?All in all, I can't wait to go back here to order the butternut squash ravioli again although I should probably try something new on the menu!

Reviews.Author: Marcos O.
Reviews.Content: This place is a classic. It can only sit like 25 people, tops! Therefore there is always a line to get in. This leads to some serious pressure from the staff to order, eat, and get out quickly, but it's all part of the experience at this little dive. Donna, the waitress, is one of the best servers I have ever witnessed, and I made sure to tell her that. She is a hard worker and knows how to wait on customers! I had the lahbstah and clams pasta dish, which was frickin wicked, as the Bostonians would say.Only down side to this place is they only accept cash, so for my friends that only have plastic and no green paper, I give this place "foah staws!"

Reviews.Author: Wesley H.
Reviews.Content: The perfect pasta place. The Fra Diavolo with half-lobster and a bottle of Chianti is the way to go here.

Reviews.Author: Jodi K.
Reviews.Content: So we tried this infamous little place after reading many wonderful reviews and watching people wait in line to get a table. We too,waited 40 minutes outside to get in. It's definitely lively with a strong,delicious garlic aroma wafting through the air.The food however,isn't all that the line makes it out to be. It's ok, don't get me wrong ... But it's typical Italian fare without any crazy flavor that stands above anywhere else that I've been.What you do get is a cool atmosphere, quick service, decent prices, and warm bread!If you have time, try it out. But don't rearrange your schedule to accommodate their long lines ... Go elsewhere in the North end where you'll still walk out satisfied without the added 45 minute wait!

Reviews.Author: Rene C.
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for a high end five star borderline pretentious dining, keep walking as this is not the place for you.What you will find here is a down home, comfort Italian cooked meals at a VERY affordable prices. First off, do not be afraid of the line. We arrived just after 7 and found a fairly long line of hungry patrons waiting to get inside the door. We were a group of five, no need to check in just get in line and wait. We chatted up with some of the others waiting in the cold (and it was cold!), and this helped pass the time. After a bit the hostess came out and and pointed asking "how many" and then disappeared back inside the restaurant. We figured we would be in line for at least an hour, but the line moved quickly and we were seated within 30 minutes.The menu is basic, nothing fancy but perfect for what we were looking for. Your server will explain the menu as some of the pasta dishes come with your choice of three house made sauces. We needed some time and ordered a few appetizers.1. Deep fried mozzarella. This is not your TGI Friday's version. This is actually pretty well executed. The cheese is fried to perfection and tastes phenomenal. The red sauce is mind blowing and was so good we kept it for dipping later.2. Garlic bread. Sounds boring right? It wasn't. It's garlic bread done right, with a slight burnt edge and just the right amount of butter to garlic ratio. ORDER IT!3. Fried calamari. Not my thing, but everyone else at the table seemed to enjoy it.For my entree, I went with the gnocchi special which was served in a red sauce, along with pancetta and a few other things that for the moment is slipping my mind. I am a fan of al dente pasta and was happy that this Giacomo's is too. My gnocchi was perfect, I enjoyed every last bite.The wine list is small, but has enough to keep you interested and included some nice Italian and domestic selections and very little mark up. There is no dessert here, but that's ok. Just head down to Mike's Pastry shop just a few doors down for some of the best sweets in the North End.My overall impressions, this place is extremely causal and touristy but this doesn't mean that the food is bad. In fact, it's pretty damn good and if you aren't afraid to stand in line for a bit , fight for parking (we found a spot right in front) and no dessert you will love this place. And the fact that the prices are super cheap makes it very expense report friendly.

Reviews.Author: Carolyn L.
Reviews.Content: Yup, I was one of thoooose people who waited in line for an hour outside. This restaurant is tiny but the line moves fast. You wait for an hour, you order, your food arrives in minutes, you eat, you pay, and you're out. Kudos to Giacomo's for their efficiency! With the amount of people in front of me in line, I was sure the wait would be at least two hours. The food was pretty good. It's as authentic as it gets. We started with the calamari. I tried ordering the large size after reading about its epicness on yelp, but our waitress insisted the small was enough. You don't see that often! Waiters usually try to make you order the most to get all yo moniez. So that was surprising. And the calamari definitely lives up to its expectations. Best. Calamari. Ever. There's an unexpected kick of jalapeno in the marinara sauce, which is to die for. Perfectly fried with fresh seafood. Yum!I ordered the Lobster Ravioli since it was so popular on yelp. It was pretty disappointing. There was nothing wrong with it, but after waiting outside for an hour I was expecting it to be incredible. There is a decent amount of lobster but nothing noteworthy. The sauce was pretty good but not amazing. I will say that the price of $16 is pretty sweet. My mom ordered the seafood pasta. Again, we were disappointed. It was really good but not worth an hour wait. I will say that it was really flavorful with fresh seafood! Also, I noticed a lot the reviews complained about the customer service here. My waitress (blond, short hair) was really nice! No complaints.Likely won't come back because I don't think it's worth the wait. But I would definitely go back if there was no line and get the calamari.

Reviews.Author: Eunice M.
Reviews.Content: Start the meal with fried calamari which comes with a side of warm tomato sauce. Pasta with shrimps + scallops and Giacomo sauce (their house specialty - tomato sauce). While you're waiting, the server will bring out a basket of olive bread which is just a delicious combination of salty and lightly sour with chewy texture to it.All in all:- Casual setting- Delicious Italian food- Simple menu (go for the house specialty sauce - Giacomo sauce)- Quick service- Fun, communal ambianceThis place is a gem. The place is small (seats ~30 people?). You may have to wait outside for a bit, but wait. It's worth it. Buon appetit!

Reviews.Author: Jennifer N.
Reviews.Content: I really want to give this place a 3.5 stars, but because of the service it'll just have to be a 3 instead of a 4. I wanted to love this place based on the reviews and the authenticity of the italian food; however, it left me a bit disappointed. A little overrated if you ask me. We waited in line for about an hour. For new comers...you'll see a line forming outside the door - just go to the back of the line and wait. No need to put your name down or anything.  Someone will come outside and ask how many is in your party and they base the table off of that. I ordered the frutti di mare with fra como sauce and it was a good pasta dish, but not worth the price or time. There were more clam and mussel shells in the dish than actual clam and mussels. My brother ordered the lobster ravioli, which he did enjoy a lot. My mom and sister both ordered a dish similar to mines and they were not that pleased. The service...well, our waitress was a little scary. Even the table next to us (which was literally right next to us - you can feel the person's breath on your neck - that's how close you are to others) mentioned that they were scared to ask our server for anything. Some of the other servers seemed a bit nicer, so I don't think everyone would receive bad service. I'd say...if the wait is longer than 30 minutes..it's not even worth it to try this plae out to be honest.

Reviews.Author: Ian S.
Reviews.Content: This place is small, cramped, and probably pretty intense to the uninitiated, but for anyone who truly loves authentic Italian food, this is heaven.We expected a line, and there was a line of maybe ten people, in the rain. We were slightly worried about a long wait but we were out there less than five minutes before one of the waitresses came out."How many? Two? By the bar. Go."We were in - and forty-five minutes later we were out, after having had a burrata-stuffed mozzarella ball with basil, tomato, peppers and balsamic; fettucine with prosciutto and peas in cream sauce; butternut squash ravioli in mascarpone cheese sauce; bread and wine - totalling $50. Everything was just divine - I married into an Italian family and I've had a LOT of great Italian food, but this was just above and beyond.Without question the most efficient restaurant I've ever been to, and one of the very best Italian meals I've ever had. Bliss.

Reviews.Author: Alice L.
Reviews.Content: Amazing.The line this place will be long, even if you go early, but the service here is pretty quick. Pricing is extremely fair considering you would probably be paying about the same or more at Olive Garden. We got the small calamari (which in my opinion was a very good portion). One of the best calamaris I've had! We also got linguine with scallops with giacomo sauce, lobster ravioli,  and pumpkin tortellini. Everything was completely mouthgasmic. If I lived in Boston, I would seriously come here all the time. Tip: try not to come in a large party. The smaller, the better since the place is literally the size of my living room.

Reviews.Author: Natalie T.
Reviews.Content: Went here twice, both times when it first opened at about 4 in the afternoon, so there wasn't too much of a line. I like the different combinations of pasta, I got pesto which was very nice, but with a cream sauce. I also felt like the waiter was trying to sell the wine to us a bit too much.

Reviews.Author: Allene T.
Reviews.Content: No wonder this place has so many good reviews!  I'm usually a bit skeptic of "touristy" restaurant spots, but Yelp did not fail me this time!After braving windy, low 40's temperatures at the end of May for God's sake, I was beyond ready to eat.  We waited outside for an hour and there was pretty much nobody behind us for the rest of the night. In hindsight, we should have showed up closer to 9:30/10pm for no wait at all on Saturday on Memorial day weekend.  I hate to say it, but the food was just about worth the freezing hour.Compared to the rest of the seafood Italian restaurants in North End, Giacomo's (JAH-co-mo's) is by FAR the best bang for your buck.  Most of the seafood dishes are under $20 and doesn't leave you hungry or way too stuffed - just perfectly satisfied.  The other places we went over the weekend were severely overpriced and bland.We ordered a large calamari (5 people had a nice small plate each) which was fried to perfection and had a delicious spicy marinara sauce to accompany it.I personally had the special for the night - 1/2 lobster, clams, and mussels over a bed of linguine.  I chose the scampi (white wine, garlic, butter, the usual) to go with it and oh my, it was AMAZING.  All seafood was fresh and I was just about in food heaven at that point.  My only gripe is my failure to crack open lobster claws, but that's my fault.  Note - they have a variety of difference sauces to choose from.The only thing I wasn't so much a fan of but will forgive them for is the mediocre cold bread.But.... dare I say it?  Best Italian/seafood I have EVER had.  Yup, you heard it.

Reviews.Author: Jay B.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food. Among the best places to go in the North End. If you arrive after 530 you have to wait in a line, but there is a liquor store nearby, you get a 40 ounce beer in a paper bag and pass it around while you make friends with the people in line. I would have given this place 5 stars because the food is so good, but it is also so incredibly crowded that you are in the laps of strangers nearby. This is NOT the place to go in the summer when it's hot out -- they have no AC, and when you take a crowded room of people sitting on top of one another and combine it with no AC and an open kitchen with flames, you might as well be eating in a sauna.But the food is outstanding. Cash only. No reservations. No valet.

Reviews.Author: Veronica C.
Reviews.Content: This is my favorite Italian place in Boston. The food is simple, service quick (too quick - they hustle to get you in and out because chances are, there is a line out the door that snakes around the block). The Smoking Loon Pinot Noir is delicious, perfect for red sauce and seafood dishes. Speaking of which, they do a special (great for date night!) where for $65 you get a mega-entree to split with all sorts of seafood tossed in whatever sauce and noodles you like plus a bottle of wine. GREAT VALUE for the North End.Two minor downsides: good luck making this into a long, romantic dinner or extended evening with family. Like I said, the waitstaff hustle to get you in and out (more wine? Why yes, I will top off your only half empty glass). Also, and I don't blame them, the restaurant is cramped so they can serve as many patrons as possible.

Reviews.Author: tiffanie t.
Reviews.Content: Still haven't had Italian that beats this place. Every year when I make my pilgrimage to Boston for thanksgiving, I visit this place no matter how cold or long the line is. When you're here, make sure to starve yourself and fill up on:1) Calamari plate2)Butternut squash ravioli 3)Lobster stuff ravioli 4)...if you drink a glass of wine of course.

Reviews.Author: Erica R.
Reviews.Content: I was visiting a friend in Boston and we decided to visit this place, especially because he knows I have an obsession with calamari. They're supposed to have the best in town, after all. We got in line around 4:30pm on Friday night, knowing we'd have to wait in line. About 10 minutes before opening (5pm), someone came out to take down names and the number of people per party. When the doors opened at 5pm, my friend and I managed to be the last party able to sneak in right away...considering it was only the two of us. We got the last table of that first round/group of people to walk in the door. Yay!We were seated and immediately noticed how small the restaurant actually IS. It's small, yes, but with a friendly atmosphere. While the activity level and service in the restaurant seemed pretty fast, my friend and I ordered calamari...then had to order it from the same woman again because it never came from the kitchen after that first order. Once we HAD the calamari though, as well as each of our entrees, we realized how delicious the food really is. Perhaps it's not the most amazing calamari ever, especially having traveled and taste tested different calamari from all over, but it's certainly some of the best I've had in a long time. The portions are large and the price for anything is surprisingly minimal. We didn't feel rushed at all either.All in all, a generally good time...besides the wait times for our food. To reinforce the "cash only" policy though, yes...definitely remember to bring cash. A couple across the room either forgot it was cash only or didn't know about it, so the husband had to run to the bank and withdraw some. The woman herself looked so uncomfortable waiting there, and she seemed to know that the people right outside were eying that table.

Reviews.Author: Patrizia n.
Reviews.Content: Had a great experience over all. Friendly staff and delicious food. Worth the wait, even with a baby...Negatives: 1.When I attempted to Breastfeed a waiter brought napkins (to cover up). Excuse me: is he aware if the laws? I'm glad my daughter stopped before he said anything, because it would've been a real issue...2. We heard the waiter shouting the order in Spanish. Oh well, not that authentic, is it?But yes, I would recommend it!

Reviews.Author: Stephanie M.
Reviews.Content: I'm not gonna lie....I'm pretty glad I live on the opposite side of the country because if I were closer I would eat here every single day! I was referred by a friend, and then knew it must be delicious considering the line out the door and around the corner.It was worth the wait!Giacomo's is the best Italian seafood restaurant I have eaten at in the US. I had the linguine with scallops and Giacomo Sauce (of course!) and it was so amazing I ended up eating the entire plate! It could have easily made 2 or 3 meals worth for me, but no way was I going to stop myself from eating every bite. Everything was fresh and delicious.

Reviews.Author: Miriam A.
Reviews.Content: Meh...This restaurant gets a lot of hype for being one of the best Italian places around. If you live in the South End, it is probably one of the best Italian joints you will find here but if you add Giacomo's to the larger pool of Italian restaurants in the greater Boston area, it gets diluted to just "Meh".First off, please make reservations. Its a busy restaurant in a tight ass spot! If you are forced to wait for a table, you could be stuck outside standing for hours. If you are waiting for your table at their tiny bar inside you will inherit the biggest pit stains of your life due to its location right in front of the hot kitchen... so plan ahead.I haven't had many appetizers here but if you must have one, please try the Mussels with a red sauce...yummy! The red sauce is really special and I guarantee you will finish off the bread to soak up every last ounce of flavor! For entree dishes I've had Butternut Squash Ravioli, Lobster Ravioli, and Chicken Parmesan. All these dishes were definitely flavorful but not spectacular.  However, the Chicken Parmesan is really a must have here. I must say though, I was a little disheartened to receive my side of spaghetti cold, dry, and clumped together into a ball with no flavoring on it whatsoever. Shame on you Giacomo's...your bread and butter is your pasta and its like I got a side dish of leftover cafeteria food. There are some memorable meals here but its time to make new memories elsewhere. Ciao!

Reviews.Author: Susan W.
Reviews.Content: There is always a long line, and they don't take reservations. Honestly, the food here is quite expensive. But it's worth the time and money. Service is much better than the "Daily Catch" down the street.

Reviews.Author: Ashley P.
Reviews.Content: I am so torn about writing this review!   I wanted to fall in love with Giacomo's, but I just couldn't. I have lived in Boston for most of life, and I frequent the North End, but I have always avoided this place due to the long lines. We arrived on a very snowy Friday night, hoping to miss some of the lines. We were partially correct - there were about three parties ahead of us, so we waited about 15 minutes. From what I have seen of these lines before, that was nothing compared to other Friday nights. The setting is typical North End - Tables so close together you can barely move and you better make friends with those sitting next to you since you will basically have dinner with them, too. No problem, I love the North End and was expecting no less! Our waitress came over and was fantastic - helpful, funny, and direct to the point. I could tell there would be no dilly-dallying in this place. We ordered wine ($17 bottle? Yes please!) and an appetizer of calamari. The app came out so quickly I swear the must have known we were coming. It was tasty but not the best. Then comes the main course. I ordered a shrimp and scallop dish with the house sauce. First, the pasta was boxed spaghetti. I have nothing against boxed pasta, but in the North End I at least expect the option to have handmade pasta. Perhaps I could have ordered it? I am not sure because I was never given a choice. The sauce was very good, but not out-of-control-amazing as I would have hoped it was. The scallops were small and the shrimp was a bit overcooked. Wait.... wasn't this supposed to be the most amazing Italian food I have ever had? Unfortunately, it wasn't. To give them some credit - The food was pretty cheap... $30 each including tip and the wine. I just don't see myself waiting in those long lines to eat here again.

Reviews.Author: Khoa N.
Reviews.Content: If you see a long line for this place, don't hesitate to join. Yes, it is worth the 1.5-2 hr wait. It's a rule of thumb that wherever there's a line for food, it must be good. This generally works. I said generally because the crowd had failed me before. But not here at Giacomo's.No, you won't regret it.Now that you're in line, you'll have the hour+ to mull over what you want to gobble down once you're seated. I've only tried the seafood option (once with lobster) and the giacomo and the fra diovolo sauce here, and both were amazing. The fra diavolo sauce was the best I've had out of all the Italian restaurants I've tried. You'll get the spicy kick you've longed for. It is so good that I'm hesitant to try something new next time. But I must!I apologize to the people eating by the windows. It must be real awkward to have people outside in line like me staring at you eating. But it really can't be helped.

Reviews.Author: The T.
Reviews.Content: Positives:-affordable Italian in the north end.-simple/delicious dishes.-stand by their way of running their restaurant.Negatives or Right for you:-rushed in and out (so busy you sit/eat/pay/leave). -overall mentality "I don't care about you or have time to interact, but what I can guarantee is that you'll have a great Italian meal at a great price"Restaurant suggestions:-Overly busy does not justify bad service.-Your so busy, why not condense your menu? Memorable/Afterthought/Forgettable:-Afterthought

Reviews.Author: Frederick N.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's Ristorante! Located in Boston's famous and historic North End! Lol. I love this place. I have yet to find better Italian cuisine outside of Italy. On the other hand, like most reviews state, it's almost unbearably busy. Depending on your mood that can be part of its charm. Definitely not a place to go for a romantic meal experience. Every thing is just divine here from the light crispy fried calamari to the chicken Marsala to the ravioli. Everything is just great. Service is all in all pretty good for a place as chaotic. The wait staff slap on a happy face and will answer any questions that you have. In my opinion if you are visiting our Great city of Boston, the Giacomo's experience is one that should not be passed by.

Reviews.Author: Joanna Y.
Reviews.Content: Two words - INSANELY GOODLocated in the North End of Boston, in the Italian district, this small 10 table restaurant ain't an easy place to get a seat, especially with no reservations allowed.After much research, we found the best time for a guaranteed table right away, was at 4:30pm, right when it opens.  Yes, it'll be an early dinner but its better than lining up 1.5+ hours during the dinner rush.Nice, charming place, with a simple menu on the wall.  Everything sounded so good but we opted for a Small Calamari (good enough to feed 3).  The batter was very light and crispy, perfectly complimented with the side of Marinara.We also ordered the House Special Zuppa di Pesce for 2 (more like for 4) - Shrimp, Scallops, Calamari, Clams, Mussels and Lobster served over Linguine.  You can choose any of their house sauces and we went with Giacomo.  There was honestly more seafood than pasta.  AMAZING!!!  Served with an easy bottle of red wine, $65!  Can't beat that.  We had leftovers to take back to the hotel.Everything tasted so authentic and the atmosphere felt exactly what you'll get in a small local Trattoria in Italy.  Open kitchen allowed you to see the hustle and bustle that happens behind the counter and the staff were really friendly.If you're looking for a fancy schmancy romantic dinner, this ain't the place for you.  If you want true family fare, with lots of commotions and eat like a true Italiano, this is a must visit.

Reviews.Author: Amir K.
Reviews.Content: This place is so good that if you don't like it please send me a message in my inbox with your location so I can come punch you in the face.

Reviews.Author: Wendy P.
Reviews.Content: We came on a Saturday evening at about 7pm and got in line round the block. We waited for about 45 minutes in the cold and rainy weather before we got seated. Our party of 3 ordered the zuppa di pesce with giacomo sauce, lobster ravioli and a bottle of wine. Came up to about $100 with tax and tips. Meal was AWESOME - you could taste the freshness in the pasta and seafood. Our wine (pinot grigio) paired very well with the meal. I have nothing but good things to say about this place, despite the wait in the chilly weather. I will definitely come back!

Reviews.Author: Erin M.
Reviews.Content: I went here for my anniversary dinner the other day. We got there at 6pm on a Tuesday and there was already a line out the door.  However, it was less than a 10 minute wait until we were at a table. I didn't like that the restaurant was so crammed that it felt as if we were sharing a table with the people next to us. It was also quite noisy, not good if you're on a first date.I really enjoy that they have the menu written on the wall, but also give you paper menus. The service was very quick and pretty friendly, especially for how busy they were. They give generous portions and the food isn't very expensive.Before you even order they bring you very yummy bread, but no butter to go with it :(. We started off with the calamari for an appetizer. We ordered a small and we even had leftovers. That was by far the best calamari I have had in my life! Amazing!For the rest of the dinner, it was very good, but judging from all of the wonderful reviews on here I was expecting more..I had the lobster ravioli which was very good, and I couldn't even finish it. My boyfriend got the shrimp and scallops over pasta with a spicy lobster red sauce which he gobbled right up.With both entrees and the appetizer, our bill was only $41 which we were both very pleased with. My last complaint.....no dessert menu!? What's that all about?All in all it was a nice night, great service and yummy food.Oh and remember... its CASH ONLY! I saw a few people there that didn't know

Reviews.Author: Stephanie M.
Reviews.Content: Not much to add that hasn't already been said, but my answer is "Yes!" to all the people who walked by while we were in line and asked "Is this place really that good?"We waited in line maybe 30 minutes after arriving at around 5PM (it was Sunday so they opened at 4:30). Definitely go early if you want to try Giacomo's, since the line by the time we got inside was 45+ minutes.We had the Garlic Bread and then Butternut Squash Ravioli and Chicken Parm. Homemade bread is also delicious and we asked for some to soak up the remaining sauce from our dishes!Ravioli was really something special, sauce was amazing and the ravioli were cooked just until they were soft but not mushy. I understand why everyone says that they're a must-try.Parm was delicious with an awesome homemade red sauce, but its more of a standard italian dish and you can probably get it almost as good somewhere else or even make it at home. I just had a craving :)Only thing negative that I can say is that this isn't a place to go with a group that you want to visit with-- they take your order almost immediately and clear your plates as soon as you put down your fork long enough to suggest being finished. Can you really blame them though?

Reviews.Author: Ami P.
Reviews.Content: This was the second time I came, and I waited 45 mins with my two friends. I got the butternut squash ravioli and it was very good, and my other friend had the eggplant Parmesan while the other one had the salmon with pasta on the side. We also ordered a small Calamari which was nice, but not the best. The portions were big so we took home the eggplant Parmesan and the salmon and I'm prolly going to come back here next time to try other dishes, but it wasn't to die for!

Reviews.Author: Dan P.
Reviews.Content: Another staple of the North End. I think their are better restaurants to go to, but this is an experience. Food is good, services is alright, but what do you expect when theres a line of 50 people waiting to get in and eat at the 3 tables they have. I wouldn't go here if you're looking to have a long sit down dinner, or good conversation as the food is almost thrown at you it's so quick.

Reviews.Author: Imran G.
Reviews.Content: This is the first restaurant I've been to that isn't a bar/club and that has bouncer. It is also the first place that I've been to that has an old lady as a bouncer. Trying to get dinner on a Friday or Saturday night? Stand in line until, outside, until a table opens up. Don't open the door and allow cold air to get in and break the vacuum, otherwise the bouncer will kick your a** :) From the outside it seems harsh, but once you get inside, take your coat off and get cozy, you'll realize how great of an idea it is.If you're looking for an extremely intimate place to have dinner while talking to your significant other you can probably cross Giacomo's off your list. This doesn't necessarily detract from their overall rating, but its just a fact that if there are only two of you, chances are you'll be sitting next to another couple. It really isn't that problematic as the service was still top notch.Unfortunately, I didn't feel that the pasta was creme de la creme. Wait, there isn't a problem with using French to describe Italian food, is there? To be honest though, the pasta was very forgettable. The chicken and peppers with onions in marinara was too watery for me, and the chicken taste and texture felt like it might have been frozen. If I'm paying $15 for pasta in North End, it better be amazing given the amount of competition in the area. I might have gotten the wrong pasta, everyone raves about the lobster ravioli, but I don't eat seafood, so I'm at a loss I guess.The only reason I thought it was decent was because my fiancee thought it was decent. Otherwise I found nothing special about Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: Tanya K.
Reviews.Content: The food is good but not good enough for me to wait for over 30 min.. Outside in the cold, sit elbow-to-elbow with the next guy, AND deal with the horrible service, again. From the moment we stepped into that place they rushed us out. The waiter was sooooooo rude. I'm guessing they justify bad service with their "good" food.By the way, it's cash only.

Reviews.Author: Jenna A.
Reviews.Content: The fried calamari is delicious, but Zuppa di Pesce is the best. The lobster is already split, the best. Everything I have had in here has been very well cooked.

Reviews.Author: Natalie M.
Reviews.Content: Sitting here right now. And before we got i'n the woman yelled at us to shut the door. We sit i'n this VERY VERY small place with too many tables. Than our waitress yelled at us for not ordering enough. Not worth it!!'

Reviews.Author: Fahim A.
Reviews.Content: I decided to go to Giacomos while visiting Boston for a day.  It had over 1,000 yelp reviews, so I thought, why not.The restaurant opens at 4:30 and we got there about 4:45 - only one other party when we entered but that changed within half an hour.  We ordered the fried calimari appetizer to start ($10) and was more than enough for a party of 4.  It also took about 5 minutes for them to prepare, which was awesome.  Some of the best fried calimari I've had.For the main dish, I ordered the Chicken parm, which came with a side of spaghetti.  (~$14).  Chicken Parm can only taste so good, it has a peak.  Theres pretty much not much else this place could have done to make it better, which is why I'm giving it 5 stars.  Also 5 stars for the service, because they were so quick to prepare the food, we were in and out in about 35 minutes.  Service was great, prices reasonable, great food, would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for great Italian food in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Austin T.
Reviews.Content: I was visiting Boston and staying in the North End. Because it's a heavily Italian neighborhood, there are lots of choices for Italian food. Some of those choices are authentic but, unfortunately, some are tourist traps. Giacomo's is, absolutely, the real deal. Outside of Italy, this is the best Italian food I've had. I had a shrimp entree with the fra diavolo sauce. The shrimp was incredibly tender, and the red sauce had a really nice level of heat. I had a glass of the house Chianti, which wasn't bad for the price. The service was top notch. The waitress didn't hover or interrupt constantly. She simply got things done--brought plates, cleared plates, filled glasses, etc. with a polite but no-nonsense attitude. Had a great time here, and I will make a point of going back when I visit Boston again.

Reviews.Author: Joshua G.
Reviews.Content: So I went here about 2 years ago and loved it, and I was traveling back to Boston looking forward to going here again (I had forgotten the name, but was hoping I could find it again).  I was traveling with a co-worker and she said she had little Italian place she wanted to go to, as it was her "go-to" place whenever she came to Boston.  Low and behold these places were one and the same.  I don't even remember what I had the first time ... I think I had the veal picata, but I just remember it being delicious.  Last time I was there the guy I was traveling with had the Shrimp and Lobster Fusilli Special with Fra Diavolo Sauce.  It looked AMAZING, so I got that this time.  The fresh fusilli are TO DIE FOR!!!  It is one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had.  It's got a bit of kick to it, so for those who don't like it too spicy, I think the "Giacomo's" sauce is a less spicy version of that, as it is mixed with béchamel.  This is automatically on my itinerary for any trip to Boston now at this point.One tip is its cash only, so come prepared.

Reviews.Author: Anuja B.
Reviews.Content: Saw the reviews and hence decided to wait the 45 minutes to get in. The wait would have been worth it had it been 20 minutes shorter. Had their pumpkin ravioli. Good food, but absolutely great service. Makes you feel right at home! Would go back but wouldn't mind trying the other Italian places on the street as well.

Reviews.Author: Dave S.
Reviews.Content: Another review from a tourist's point of view.Having eaten quite a lot of good food in the prior weeks, we chose Giacomo's to finish out the trip.  As expected, there was a line outside when we arrived 10 minutes prior to opening.  Even the google maps street view shows people waiting.  We started with the caprese salad, which was good, but it's kind of mess up a caprese.  I opted for the mussels and clams with the spicy lobster sauce over linguini.  It was pretty good, but the kid wasn't too happy about the butternut squash ravioli, which she thought was too sweet.  I won't go into further detail because of all the other reviews.  Overall, not bad at all!

Reviews.Author: Laura A.
Reviews.Content: I am typically skeptical of Little Italy restaurants in any city. They often disappoint. But Giacomo's was a terrifically Italian and Boston experience rolled into one. We strategically planned a late 9 p.m. dinner to avoid waiting in line and were happily rewarded for our decision by only waiting about 15 minutes (a miracle just about anywhere without reservations on a Saturday night!). Our waitress Rosemary, was the greatest -  very Boston and very helpful with recommendations. Caprese salads are mostly the same everywhere, but the freshness of the mozzarella really makes or breaks it - and this Caprese salad was awesome and accented with olives. We ordered one of the specials: lobster, shrimp and fussilli dish with the fra diavolo sauce - perfecto!Great, authentic Italian food, excellent service and very reasonably priced.

Reviews.Author: Frank K.
Reviews.Content: My son and I took a trip last May and were headed to Maine's Acadia National Park from Dallas, TX. Upon returning back to the great city of Boston my son Yelps some restaurants. This place had a solid 4.5 stars, 1200 reviews and my son turns to me and says, "these people know about this place".  We used our GPS on our IPhones, we rolled into the restaurant area only to see a waiting line about 50 yards long.  That further reassured  ourselves that this is the place we would come back to tomorrow and get get here earlier!! We did! I had the Butternut squash ravioli, we split a bottle of wine. Nothing but 5 stars!  I'm planning my next trip back and will certainly be at "G's"!!

Reviews.Author: Bill S.
Reviews.Content: We haven't been here in years but the last time is still burned in our memory. It's fantastic food at a frenetic pace. This isn't where you want to be if you're looking for a sleepy wine & dine by candlelight evening. The velocity is as much a part of the experience as the out-of-this-world fare. It is ABSOLUTELY well worth the wait (and there is always a wait). Believe me, you'll remember Giacomo's forever!!Additional tips: I would take the T or walk from a parking garage or lot. The parking close by is crazy.

Reviews.Author: Gretchen M.
Reviews.Content: From the moment you pile into the line outside to the moment you finish your meal, Giacomo's is delightful. Looking in the window makes you even hungrier; standing near an open door means that the scents of garlic and tomatoes wash over you. Rosemarie, Giacomo's sister, is a highly capable waitress and has an amazing personality. She'll tell you the restaurant's history while bringing out calamari, cheeses, wine...and you haven't even seen the day's specials, handwritten in her perfect penmanship. We ordered the fusilli with Giacomo's spicy sauce, lobster and shrimp. Incredible. As you look out the window, you realize that now YOU'RE on the inside, warm, cozy, garlicky and happy. You're in the North End, and it was worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Kat W.
Reviews.Content: Delicious, top notch food at an affordable price. Easily, hands-down, one of the best Italian food I've ever had. The food is utterly fantastic. Super tight seating and long, long, long wait. After eating any of their authentic dish, you would be speechless after your first bite. Totally worth it! The pumpkin tortellini simply exquisite. Soft mascarpone cheese in the center but balanced round with nice round flavor of pumpkin. Didn't think delicate yet full of flavor could happen in one spoonful, but this is it. Many of their dishes, like their house sauce, was meat or fish based, so there's plenty choices. As a vegetarian, the choice to eat the pumpkin tortellini was an easy choice, and did not make me feel left out of the food action. Taste was perfect and portions were just right.Definitely builds up the anticipation when you see the open kitchen and the chefs bustling about. The service doesn't hover. The waitress gets your order quickly, and let the party chat while checking in once a while. She's always host and the waitress there when we go. Appreciated that she is a no-bullshit kinda gal. All the orders and daily special are written in beautiful cursive by her so she knows what's best. Try not to take her slight sarcasm as insults.It's a small place, but it certainly has it's charm. A bit loud but I think is a good date spot because of the good food, but you will be waiting in line for what seems like forever. I think they move to fill the larger parties sooner, so they can move the customers in and out. Friend said that her party of 4 were seated quickly, and skipped some of the line, when they came around 2-3pm on a weekday. I've always went with my boyfriend around 7pm, for dinner and always allotted 40 minutes minimum for a seat. From my experience, be nice to the mascot waitress and she'll definitely try to seat you asap.No reservations, cash only. Still worth it! Located in Little Italy in North End of Boston, this is the real deal.

Reviews.Author: Lillian C.
Reviews.Content: This is the best Italian food I've had. Like most North End joints, the restaurant is tiny with enough seating for about 10-15 people max. They do not take reservations, and the line outside can be a 30-60 min wait. However, the food is a great mix of Italian and seafood! My favorites are: the squid ink pasta with ground squid meat. Littleneck clams broiled in a white wine sauce. Portions are decently-sized, some dishes are pretty heavy so bring an appetite. The atmosphere is...cramped- you come here for the food, and that's it. I would not come here with a large group since you'd likely have to wait awhile to get seated.

Reviews.Author: Jose S.
Reviews.Content: 4 years living in Boston and since year 1 I was mentioned to eat this restaurant... I never went. Then 7 years after that first year, I finally went. Why didn't I listen!?!?!!To give you my best review of this place, Just read any other 5 reviews from other yelpers. I'll basically say almost the same things. The Chicken Alfredo Pasta topped with Broccoli is the number 1 Chicken Alfredo Pasta topped with Broccoli plate I've ever had. Since I'm not a huge seafood eater and this place is known more for it's fresh seafood, I also loved their gnocchi my friend ordered. Also, a bottle of white Pinot Noir for $9 was the cherry on top of the Burj Khalifa (Tallest building in the world).Definitely coming back here when I visit Boston again.Tip: Arrive 30 minutes to 1 hour before your hunger kicks in. You'll most likely  are going to wait outside for a table. This place takes no reservation and it get's packed fast.

Reviews.Author: Jen L.
Reviews.Content: Yes, get here early, and by early, I mean well before they open. We got there about 15 minutes after doors opened, and we snagged the very last seats of the first dinner round. We were tucked in a corner of the small brick walled space, at the bar next to the open kitchen. Although tiny, like all good real estate, it's about location, location, location. As the servers were right up in our faces, yelling out orders to the nonstop commotion of boiling water, frying pans, and sweaty men going on in front of us, we felt completely relaxed and at home. We ordered the fried calamari, which was very good, and we shared one of the spinach ravioli specials. We opted not to go for the traditional things that everyone raves about, which we regretted towards the end. Since they are so busy, the only allow you to order once, rather than take up valuable table space with a long drawn-out meal. Luckily, that real estate came in handy when we struck up a conversation with our amazing server, RM. She's the best. I won't tell you what she did, but let me tell you, we left with bellies full of the best homemade Italian dishes and mouths full of praises for RM and the food. We had such a memorable dining experience that we even hugged good bye. Seriously, who does that? Who hugs their restaurant server?Don't come here expecting some fine dining experience where every clink of your fork resounds embarrassingly, but come expecting to tuck that napkin into your neckline and embrace the screeching forks trying to scrape up every last lick of unmissable sauce.

Reviews.Author: Carolyn P.
Reviews.Content: Everything I could possibly say about this restaurant has already been said so I am just going to bullet point the highlights of this very tiny and super busy restaurant that I ate at twice over the course of two days!-Calamari.... Heaven on a fried plate, the calamari was crisp served with a lemon wedge and a spicy red sauce.-Lobster ravioli special in a pink cream sauce, I have NEVER had ravioli like this. The seafood was present, not hidden with cheese. There was a lovely tomato cream sauce that went with it and I was terribly disappointed that this ravioli was not on the menu the following day.-Fresh spaghetti with mussels and half a lobster in red sauce, this was good. I think it could have benefitted from something more, maybe fresh herbs or perhaps salt?-Ravioli in a fra diavlo sauce- Spicy!-Ravioli in a garlic cream sauce, I am going to say that this one did not work for me. The pasta was fresh but the garlic was very over powering and the cream was all congealed ten minutes in.Come early and be prepared to wait in line. You cannot really dawdle in this restaurant because you can see the line of hungry customers outside waiting for you to get up and get out! The line moves fast and again, this is a cash only establishment.

Reviews.Author: Tim H.
Reviews.Content: Monday night.It's raining enough for you to require cover.I walk into the crowded place as expected and ask the waitress for a seat for two.She tells me it will be a 15-20 minute wait. Cool. She didn't have a clipboard or piece of paper to ask for my name.i'm talkin' outside with my co-worker and shootin' the poop.20 minutes pass. Two other groups who waited behind us march up the stairs to get seated.I investigate. I ask 'When could we get seated as there were two other groups you seated who came after us.'. She says 'If I don't see you outside the window waiting, you won't be seated.'I walk outside to tell my co-worker the situation.5 minutes pass.Another group of 4 marches up the stairs to get seated.I march up the stairs right behind them to investigate.I finally see a table for two clear up and wait for the waitress to seat us.Another waiter comes by 5 minutes later to pour water into our glasses.5 minutes later, two people who waited behind us get seated on the bar stools and salad is already served.10 minutes later. No bread or menu is presented to us.2 minutes afterwards. Our glasses are refilled with water. The table right of us with a group of 6 that just sat down gets waters poured and a menu.1 minute later. Me.  'Hey Ryan, that was not cool.' Ryan - 'That was really uncool.'Me. 'Let's get outta heeya'.Ryan. 'Let's bounce'.Little missy: You just lost my business for the next 2+ years along with my co-workers business that could've made your boss at least $252,435.00 each year.Sadness.:(

Reviews.Author: Neha A.
Reviews.Content: Late review but a great find in Boston! My friend and I waited about a half hour in line on a Sunday night which in our heads was a long time especially because we arrived at 530pm, which again we wrongfully presumed was early enough to barely skip a line haha. Ah well. Also, it's cash only, but the pricing is reasonable :)The spaced is definitely veryyy crammed. When we were finally seated, turned out the couple right behind us was seated immediately after... at the same table. I don't understand why they couldn't have just separated our tables a few inches to make it a slightly more private but comfortable dining experience for two. Food wise- the butternut squash ravioli was fantastic!!! They were so kind to make it vegetarian and I have absolutely no complaints :) my friend got the fusilli siciliana which tasted a bit undercooked and underwhelming- nothing special about the flavors. Should have opted for the pumpkin tortellini perhaps; sounded intriguing and perhaps richer. But all in all, it made for a quality night.

Reviews.Author: Clementine C.
Reviews.Content: Coming from NYC, I am not insanely impressed with Giacomo's, but I WOULD recommend it - here's why:WAIT - typical hotspot wait between 1 hour and 3 depending on when you get yourself in line.  I have to say that this is not an issue for a popular place in a big city.SERVICE - The host is TOP NOTCH.  He is very good at getting people in as quickly as possible, and he even took our order and explained the dishes very thoroughly and efficiently.  Despite the crowd outside, they in no way rush customers, which is very professional.  FOOD - OK.  Here is why I say only a 3-star rating.  We had the special buffalo mozzarella caprese.  It was extremely fresh and flavorful with roasted red peppers, large beefy tomatoes, and a gigantic ball of mozzarella and cream.  This might have been the best caprese I've ever had.  Bread - not feelin' the olive loaf... it was bland.  The PASTA was most disappointing :(  I ordered the linguine with pesto and calamari.  The pesto had NO SALT or flavor!  The Parmesan they must have used was clearly low in salt.  The basil was fresh, but there was far too much oil.  Way too much.  It was not balanced with the other ingredients and made the plate hard to eat.  The calamari was chewy, and I was counting on Boston's seafood!  I ordered the Cabernet, and it was bitter and thick to drink :(  I was very disappointed.To note, my friends were all entranced by their dishes... but they are not Italian, not raised on authentic Italian cooking, don't hail from NYC's italian neighborhood, and can't cook...................DISCLAIMER: I am extremely picky about my Italian... I think most people love this spot!TIP: On a weekend, get in line at 4pm or earlier to dine at 5 when they open!  Cash only!

Reviews.Author: Jim G.
Reviews.Content: Great foot but remember to bring cash.

Reviews.Author: Duna R.
Reviews.Content: Went on a Friday night. Waited for almost an hour which we expected. Rude hostess. Calamari was good but nothing amazing. Garlic bread was great which is why I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1. Caprese salad was good but really how can you screw that up? Entree: My fettuccine was way overcooked (I was sooo disappointed by this because I came here for the pasta!), the garlic sauce was bland, and chicken was dry and in enormous pieces. I feel like an Applebee's would have made this dish better.  My sister's pasta was al dente and tasted good so maybe my dish was a fluke. Very sad :(

Reviews.Author: Ryan L.
Reviews.Content: I was not impressed with this place.Is the food good? Definitely. However, the experience sucked. You wait outside (usually there is a line down the street) for a table and then once you get in there, they pester you every 3 minutes if you're ready to order. The food is rushed out and the check dropped off. Maybe its just me, but when I go out to eat, I like to enjoy it and take my time and visit with people. Also, dont buy the cheap wine. $17 per bottle may sound great but it tastes terrible.

Reviews.Author: Cyrus C.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian ever, hands down. The muscles appetizer melts in your mouth with a garlic white wine sauce that literally would be served as a stand alone soup or sauce for dipping (we dipped our bread and finished it all) for only 9 dollars!As a main we tried the blue crab. The butternut squash and the lobster ravioli all to die for. And the service was top notch too! Worth the long wait outdoors.

Reviews.Author: Tian Q.
Reviews.Content: While the fried calamari were some of the most flavorful I've had, the much-raved-about lobster ravioli and the butternut squash ravioli were both very predictable and overall lackluster in taste.I'm puzzled by Giacomo's popularity and crazy high user-ratings. There must be tons of other noisy/claustrophobic mediocre italian dining spaces that you wouldn't have to freeze your ass off waiting in line for.

Reviews.Author: Tyler S.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's has been my favorite spot in the North End for years. I've spent many freezing nights standing in line and it was always worth every minute. Not good for groups(hole in the wall) and cash only but come on, if you want that then go to a chain. I've tasted most of the menu and to be honest everything is amazing. But yes the lobster ravioli with the fra diavolo sauce is to dieee for. Always good specials too! There is a reason there is always a line...hop in it!!

Reviews.Author: Francesca H.
Reviews.Content: There's something particularly charming about the Italian man who ushers me to my seat and sells me too much food for one person to consume. After waiting in the sweltering heat in late August, I finally get inside the restaurant and get a quick lowdown on what I should be ordering. And this is all before I get my water glass filled. Efficiency---Giacomo-style.I'm glad when servers give me their honest opinions between two dishes, so I end up ordering the Salmon and linguini with lobster cream sauce and the fried calamari to share with my friend. The calamari comes out a few minutes later, hot and unbelievably crispy. The batter is light and the ratio between that and the squid is perfectly balanced.
