I appreciated the jalapenos.One tip for eating at Giacomo's: you better come HUNGRY. This is not a little pretentious tapas bar; here, you get exactly what you pay for. Quality. Portions made to feed two. And why must you be super hungry? Because you will have a days' worth of pasta to eat in 20 minutes before the impatient line outside starts staring at you to make you uncomfortable. Your meal will be quick, maybe rushed, so remember to plan for post-dinner festivities. Giacomo's may only take up 30-45 minutes so it's not the main event for the most part, but it will be the highlight of your night.

Reviews.Author: Gonzalo B.
Reviews.Content: It's 9 degrees outside, the wind is whipping it silly in yo face and the line for Jocky's is around the corner. It's 97 degrees outside with 80% humidity, you're parched and dizzy and...the line goes around the corner for Jocky's. There's a blizzard with snow whipping and piling up, there's a typhoon coming, a meteorite is hurtling toward earth and the 'experts' say it will land on Hanover street and, naturally, there's a line around the corner halfway down Fleet Street. To quote the great Tom Waits: "Sane, sane - they're all insane..."You begin to think about your faith in humanity. You question how people could be so completely stupid. There's a line longer than a football field and...getting longer. There are a hundred other joints within punting distance and...still...they wait. For what? Because people are sheeple and don't know any better. Maybe there is a theory to conspiracy theories after all.

Reviews.Author: Rachel H.
Reviews.Content: Be aware: cash only. Small space and fills up quickly. Service is quick, they will get you in and out. However, this is the best Italian food I have ever had (though I have never been to Italy).

Reviews.Author: Alice O.
Reviews.Content: Love this place best food ever!

Reviews.Author: Lisa I.
Reviews.Content: Giacamo's is good, but I don't think the lines out the door in the North End are warranted. This review is only for the South End location since they take reservations. I have tried a few dishes including the pumpkin tortellini and butternut squash ravioli. Both are good, but a bit too sweet. The gnocchi filled with roasted red peppers and goat cheese, on the other hand, is AMAZING. I never order gnocchi because it's usually really doughy, but this one is the opposite. It is packed with flavor from the goat cheese and the awesome sauce that has mascarpone and plum tomatoes. Definitely worth going to just for this dish!

Reviews.Author: Molly L.
Reviews.Content: 3.5 stars.I was really excited to come here with all the Yelp reviews, but I question if its worth the long wait. My boyfriend and I arrived at 5:20, 20 minutes after Giacomo opens and we waited for a little bit over an hour to get a spot on Saturday evening. By the time we got in, we were freezing, tired and hungry. We ordered a frutti di mare with Giacomo sauce (for some of the pasta dishes, you can choose the sauces) and the lobster ravioli. The food was good- don't get me wrong- especially for the price of around $15- $20 per dish, but the hour wait.... not so much. My advice would be to GET THERE REALLY EARLY or GET THERE REALLY LATE and it'll definitely be worth it :)

Reviews.Author: Kristina K.
Reviews.Content: Getting in the door is a bit hectic.  You MUST have everyone in your party with you when you're seated.  You'll stand in line, which goes unexpectedly quick.  Then they only give you a couple minutes to decide on what you want to eat.  Seriously, they will tell you you only have a minute left to decide.  Then you eat, and leave.  Do not think you're going to have a leisurely meal here.  This is not the place to go with family or friends that you're trying to catch up with, unless you don't want your visit to last long.However, this is a great place to get a good meal.  It's definitely an experience, but the food is worth it.  The staff seems a little harsh, but once you sit, the servers are pretty nice.

Reviews.Author: Lindsey A.
Reviews.Content: Love Giacomo's!  The atmosphere is wonderful and the good is the same.  Well worth the wait!

Reviews.Author: Valentina C.
Reviews.Content: Definitely to avoid on a weekend night. Had been there before on a weekday and had fonder memories of this cash only affordable place. Solid portions do not offset the bad acoustics - it is almost impossible to have a conversation without shouting... No great service... Clearly they want you to order, eat, pay and leave so that they can accommodate fast another client... Not sure we will go back

Reviews.Author: Zehao X.
Reviews.Content: Over exaggerated! Pasta served is not even fully cooked! Mediocre food and bad service !

Reviews.Author: Anna G.
Reviews.Content: Big portions, affordable prices, cheap wine = i am happy!  It takes a bit more to wow me with pasta dishes because, although limited in the kitchen, i am capable of boiling my own noodles. This is a favorite for big groups and definitely worth of 4 stars.

Reviews.Author: Liz C.
Reviews.Content: They do not take reservations therefore you may have to wait in line especially on a nice weekend night. Their food is reasonably priced for the North end and also tastes like something out of Nonas kitchen! Yum!

Reviews.Author: Bill P.
Reviews.Content: OMG! What a place. The lady and I went here in pursuit of an authentic North End experience.  Doing this many times before we have had our fair share of mixed experiences from tourist traps to local gems.  This place ranks among the best in the city for me.  We got there at prime time on a summer time Saturday so the line was down the block (unfortunately normal in North End that time of year on a weekend night) so we patiently waited in line like everyone else.  A few minutes later the host came down the line looking for a couple to fill the next small table and it turns out everyone in front of us was a party of 4 or more.  So we slipped right in! Luck of course but we took it. Inside it's so small you can barley move your elbows to look at a menu so you just look up at a chalkboard for what they offer...I suspect some folks would feel uncomfortable so crowded but oddly I enjoy it...and a short but good wine list.  Both of our dishes were spot on and by the end we felt like we got our authentic North End experience we were looking for.

Reviews.Author: Michael L.
Reviews.Content: Great Food. I read about and was worried about poor/slow service and found it to be untrue, in my experiences. I have eaten here, (at the south end location), multiple times and found the food to always be excellent. my Only complaint is the level of noise, due to he tables being on top of each other.

Reviews.Author: Peggy S.
Reviews.Content: I have rarely left an Italian restaurant so contented!We arrived at 5:30 pm on a Monday night (a pretty early time on a quiet weekday to avoid the infamous long lines) and were seated right away. My friend and I ordered a house special appetizer with beef tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, and olives covered in spices, basil, fresh olive oil, and balsamic vinegar. We followed this up with the Zuppa di pesce for two with a bottle of pinot grigio for only $65. Having grown up in a predominantly Italian town, I will attest to the authenticity of the food. The entree was a monster of a dish with linguini cooked perfectly al dente, covered with scallops, mussels, clams, shrimp, and a whole lobster. Ask for the Giacomo sauce with di friavolo- a delicious sweet tomato cream sauce with a tinge of spice!To top it off, the service made us feel at home. A member of the staff (who wasn't even our waiter) even crossed the room to help me with my coat before we left and wished us a happy evening. Come here for a fun night in Boston's north end!

Reviews.Author: Naomi B.
Reviews.Content: I've had the pleasure of dining here twice and I can't wait to go back!Pros: Amazing garlic bread (rustic bread topped with fresh garlic and butter), calamari that is deliciously and lightly fried and authentic Italian entrees.  Efficient kitchen, pleasant wait staff and a cozy, clean dining room.Cons: Cash only, no reservations and tight seating if you visit during peak hours.  These slight inconveniences should not stop you from eating here!  Recommend: Going to eat here immediately :D. Being first in line or dining late at night so that you don't have to wait in line.

Reviews.Author: Julia H.
Reviews.Content: My sister and I have been here probably a dozen times over the course of our time in college, and I look forward to each and every meal.Get there early and on a weekday if you don't want to wait for hours. It doesn't have the same ambiance as some of the other restaurants in the area (crowded tables, people waiting outside watching you eat), but the food more than makes up for it.Start with a calamari appetizer - the calamari is light and crispy. For entree, get the giacomo's sauce or the giacomo's sauce mixed with fra divalo if you like it a little spicy. I've watched several nearby customers opt for different sauces (which are fine, just not as good as the giacomo's sauce), with disappointing results. The shrimp and scallops is an excellent combination - juicy jumbo shrimp and tender scallops. The only thing that is even slightly disappointing is the bread (cold and dry), but the food is so good, it doesn't really matter.I have never left this place unhappy.

Reviews.Author: N.N. R.
Reviews.Content: as I walked into Giacamo's and saw the groups of people waiting outside, I thought well, good thing i'm just a party of one...The place is small, seating no more than 40 people (?) if that! However, this place is somewhere that you want to be. The ambiance is as if you're sitting in someones large dining room, surrounded by the conversations and laughs of all the other patrons' tables around you. It's quite lovely. The kitchen is somewhat open, so that you can see over the counter and watch the chefs behind it cook up a storm. There is just one waitress, one waiter, and Giacamo himself. I was seated at the bar (party of one) within 15 minutes of arrival. Not too bad. I ordered the calamari to start - uhm, can you say, amazingly delicious? I can, because it was! The fried peppers in there are perfect. The sauce is killer. I didn't want this to end, but I had to leave room for my main course: off the specials menu: linguini with 1/2 lobster, mussels & clams. I chose the Fri Diavola sauce - red sauce with a hint of some spice. AWESOME. The food was phenomenal. The pasta was perfect, the sauce was a home run, the seafood was ...amazing. Giacamo even came up to remind me to get off my phone and eat my supper. I'm glad he did because trust me, this food is worth eating!Giacamo is wonderful and the energy he brings to his restaurant is truly unmatched anywhere else I've ever been. Traveling from California to Boston and getting to enjoy a meal at Giacamo's was really icing on the cake. Giacamo's is CASH ONLY, so come prepared. The prices are reasonable and the portions are plentiful. I cannot wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Jim c.
Reviews.Content: One of the best deals in  the North End. Here you can still get Northern Italian comfort food. The seafood fradiavlo is awesome! Also try the gnocci, Giacomo sauce or marsala. Really you can go wrong!  Be ready to wait outside for a table as the place is tiny and there are no reservations or bar to wait in. Also bring cash as they don't take credit cards. One of my favorite meals in Boston!

Reviews.Author: Alex A.
Reviews.Content: I hate giving out positive reviews. It forces me to say Nice Things™ about places I go, and I'm terrible at it. That said, here's my assessment of Giacomo's in North End:The food is great. The service is great. The location is - you guessed it - great. So, provided you can brave the 30-minute wait on low-traffic days (or 45+ minute waits on high-traffic days), you will be in for a real treat. And if you, for some obscure and highly contrived reason, do not like it, then Vinny the Enforcer will be inclined to deal with you accordingly and severely. And he finds absolutely no joy in his job.

Reviews.Author: Pallavi B.
Reviews.Content: This restaurant is all that the reviews say.We loved our experience there especially the food. We were even lucky enough to wait only 10 minutes in the line and then ushered in as it was closing time already.Do make a visit whenever you are in the North End/Boston area.

Reviews.Author: Ariel Z.
Reviews.Content: This was definitely  a fun place! But for how long you wait outside, you are rushed in and rushed out (which is understandable considering there are other poor folks waiting out there for you to finish). Not the type of place to sit and have a relaxed, long conversation over a few glasses of wine. Other than that, the food of course was to die for and the staff very vivacious and cracking everyone up. Best time to go would be during the week early dinner and during the holidays when everyone is on vacation (given that they are open too, of course).

Reviews.Author: Celeste M.
Reviews.Content: I love Giacomo's, in theory.  Well, I did.  I would be the first one to defend the looong lines.  And we brought so many people here when they came to visit us in Boston.  Walking down Hanover Street (and waiting on the sidewalk) provided such a nice North End experience to our out of town friends and family.  All Giacomo's quirks were part of the charm, until they weren't. The first bad experience was when my mom misheard me when I told her how much our total bill was plus tip and so we accidentally forgot the tip.  The waitress, a long time staple there, practically threw the money back at us in disgust as she loudly scolded us that gratuity was not included.  That was embarrassing.  The second bad experience was when my mother in law joined us for dinner and we made a party of 3.  Well, Giacomo's decided that the only table they would place us was one particular table, and so they sat many 2 person, four person, six person, and 8-person tables before us.  It was pretty bad, to the point where my extremely mild mannered MIL was insulted and it ruined everyone's night.  I love the fra diavolo pasta dishes, the calamari, and the fun atmosphere.  But those two really bad experiences have put me off of my favorite spot.  I haven't been back in almost a year.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer S.
Reviews.Content: Just like getting a bowl of clam chowder, you can't come to Boston without some good ole Italian food! I'm so happy this place was the pick for our trip this time...YUMMMM!! What to eat:Burratta - Fresh Italian cheese with tomatoes, olive oil and basil. REALLY good. It was fresh and really creamy gooey cheese in the middle of the cheese ball. The tomatoes were so flavorful. We ordered more bread so we could eat it, but it tastes good just on its own.Butternut Squash Ravioli - This was definitely worth the hype, but not in terms of quantity. There were only 8 ravioli..which is standard, I think, when you order legit ravioli from an italian resto. There usually isn't too much. It was a creamy sauce that was a little bit sweet which complemented the savory ravioli filling. Noms, I definitely liked it and was perfect for me because I wasn't that hungry.Lemon Fettuccine - I actually didn't like this dish that much. It had scallops that were really yummy, but after two bites, I was getting too much for the lemon zest. It was really making it difficult to taste the pasta without little bitter pieces of lemon getting in the way...Chocolate Bomb - OMFG. This was really good!! It was a chocolate brownie topped with ganache and SPRINKLES..and served with a whipped cream perimeter. It was really rich and decadent, so if you're too full from the meal and want something light, this probably isn't the best idea. HOWEVER, if you're sharing and you want something chocolatey..this is definitely the pick for you! The only thing that would've made this dessert better is if the brownie was hotter and came with a giant scoop of vanilla ice cream!! ahhh, so good!I'm only giving it 4 stars because its CASH ONLY! For a $70-80 meal, this can pose a problem for people who only have credit card and don't carry much cash. Fortunately, I just went to the bank, so all was covered. Still..make sure you bring enough cash for this spot!

Reviews.Author: Eric L.
Reviews.Content: If you only had to pick one Italian place to have dinner in Boston, this is the place to go.  There was a line at the door and the restaurant is ridiculously crowded, but it is clear this was the most popular restaurant on the block.  At the recommendation of the waitress, who looked more like the owner, I ordered the lobster fusilli with the diavolo and giacomo sauce - a terrific combination of spicy and creamy.  The pasta was al dente and the lobster was sweet and tender.  The restaurant is bustling with activity and there is hardly enough room to maneuver between the chairs, but that just adds to the cozy family style ambience.Eat at Giacomo's, you won't regret it.  Afterwards, grab a cannoli at Mike's Pastry down the street.

Reviews.Author: Christina B.
Reviews.Content: Every other reviewer has said what i'm about to say. This place is pure perfection.BEST fried calamari i've ever had and that's coming from a girl who orders it everywhere in NYC!-The 30 minute wait is worth it, folks.-Very fast and helpful service-Your tummy will thank you for a great meal:)My favorite place in the North end, it lives up to the hype people!

Reviews.Author: Calina N.
Reviews.Content: Love this restaurant! We arrived at 5 p.m. and the line was wrapped around the building. Worth the wait!  The restaurant is tiny and pretty crowded but the food and service was exceptional.  This is a cash only restaurant.We shared a platter of fried calamari which were flavorful and crisp.  Definitely a decent size portion for the price you pay.  You order the dish and you can choose from a selection of sauces for your platter. I ordered two seafood pasta dishes both with garlic wine sauce and it was to die for. Our waiter Chris was the best! He took care of us and was quick.  Thank you Giacomo for an excellent dining experience.

Reviews.Author: Kris D.
Reviews.Content: Another great impulse idea in the North End! It was a late Friday night when we walked up to Giacomo's. The line was about 5 couples deep, we didn't mind because we heard such good reviews. Everyone in the line was friendly and making the best of the situation. It is a very intimate restaurant with a open kitchen. Every table is snuggled in the dinning room with no room to spare. The menu is also posted on a large chalk board inside on the wall and is readable through the large front window while waiting outside.   Our food came out fresh and hot. We ordered the calamari to share and it did not disappoint!  I ordered the pasta dish with pesto & swordfish. Very tasty. The service was great! I loved all the different pastas and sauces! The portions are hefty. The wait was worth it. I can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Chris N.
Reviews.Content: Best food in the North End. The only negative is there is always a wait, no matter what time of the day you go. It's mostly because the place is small. But it is worth the wait. Super fresh and delicious food. The menu is written on a big chalkboard on the wall. The waiter staff is super friendly and make you feel like your over their house for dinner. I recommend this place to all my friends that come in to town. Can't go wrong.

Reviews.Author: Nicole V.
Reviews.Content: Love Giacomo's - family-style Italian and fab take-away. Pumpkin tortellini is to-die-for.

Reviews.Author: terry g.
Reviews.Content: Ordered fried calamari butternut squash ravioli and linguine & clams.  The best!  Worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Nicole D.
Reviews.Content: HOLY CRAP! This. Place. Is. Worth. The. Wait.Giacomo's ALWAYS has a line outside of it (well everytime I've been here) but the line moves pretty quickly. I've only ever waited for an hour max. The inside is extremely small, it probably only seats about 25-30 people at a time (maybe even less than that). But trust me, you'll want to wait to eat here. You may feel rushed but thats because they're trying to get you out in order to get more people in.The fried calamari is HEAVEN!!!!!!!!!! Seriously the best I've ever had in my entire life. It's fried to perfection, not to rubbery, and the amount of breading is PERFECT. I think Rachel Ray named this place as having the best fried calamari.I got the Special #2, (homemade fusili with lobster and shrimp meat in the Giacomo sauce), omg this was soooooooooo delicious!! There was ample lobster and shrimp meat, which I was very pleased with. Seriously, get the Special #2. You will not regret it. It's like a party in your mouth with every bite.

Reviews.Author: Jessica A.
Reviews.Content: Were here a few years ago from a recommendation. It was 90 degrees, we waited in line, it was cramped and even hotter inside but completely worth the wait and the sweat! The food was phenomenal and waitress entertaining.

Reviews.Author: Ray J.
Reviews.Content: If you are planning to try Korean traditional tofu soup in Boston, you should visit this place. This place is the best Korean restaurant among any of Korean restaurants in Boston. Even the atmosphere is really romantic. They serve even sushi that you can taste with tofu soup at the same time.The Hwe dub bab which is a combination with rice, miscellaneous vegetables and raw fishes. YOU SHOULD GO FOR THIS ONE. Personally, for the tofu soup menu, I like the seafood tofu soup over there.If you want to eat in a restaurant where provides high quality of foods and atmosphere, try to visit with all of your friends. Actually, Most of Korean foods are known as spicy foods, but when you go this place, you can choose how spicy you want with your tofu soup from white to extra extra spicy. This is so cool.I recommend all of your guys to visit this place :)

Reviews.Author: Jaclyn R.
Reviews.Content: Heard this was the best Italian place in Boston from so many people and sure enough it lives up to it's reputation.  Not only was the food delicious but it was very reasonably priced.  My only regret about going here was not getting the butternut squash ravioli.  As much as that does not sound like the most appealing thing on the menu, my friend got it and it was amazing!

Reviews.Author: Rachel R.
Reviews.Content: "Love on a plate," as described by our waitress, was enough to convince me to order the pumpkin tortellini... although in retrospect, she should have said something more like sex on a plate. Buttery, mascarpone sauce with fresh sage smothering sweet, creamy pumpkin filled morsels. Seriously, try this and tell me food isn't an aphrodisiac. I'll fight you.After that dessert-y pasta, we needed a dinner pasta (naturally), so we ordered the salmon fettuccine with lobster cream sauce. The symphony of textures from perfectly done noodles and ultra-tender meat combined with the tangy, creamy tomato and lobster sauce.... really, the amount of eye rolling and moaning that occurred during this meal verged on ridiculous.The wait is worth it, I promise [insert innuendo here].

Reviews.Author: Justine B.
Reviews.Content: OUT OF TOWN REVIEW - Was here 2 weeks ago during a short trip to Boston and my mouth still salivates when I think of the House Special - Zuppa Di Pesce ($55).  And for $10 more, we also got a bottle of red wine.  This dish says dinner for 2, but it can easily feed 4 people.  It's linguini covered with all the seafood one can ever dream of - came with a full lobster and so much shrimp, scallops, calamari, clams and mussels that we had to dig to the bottom of the plate just to get some pasta.  The calamari was also sinfully delicious!  I'm getting hungry just writing this review and angry that it is sooooo far away.The place is tiny and cramp and there is a bit of a wait, but it is definitely worth it!  If ever I get a chance to go to Boston again, I will definitely come back (every single day for the duration of my trip) to eat at this place.

Reviews.Author: Semi Chef S.
Reviews.Content: Passed through Boston for a night of street parties, late night movies and maybe one of the best Italian meals I've ever had.It's loud, gritty and crowded but the food is f'n great. Grab a cold beer or some wine, try the homemade pasta specials and walk out with a fat belly and a smile. Everything from the veal & prosciutto to fra diavolo, Fuhgeddaboudit! it's all great. This place is awesome and the staff are a bunch of characters. Looking for fine dining? Look elsewhere. This place is about food and fun. Trust me on this, go with two and you'll fly right through.

Reviews.Author: Lauren D.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is one of the best Italian restaurants in the city. Their butternut squash ravioli is to die for! There is typically always a line outside as the entire place is maybe as big as a walk-in closet, but it is most certainly worth it. You can sometimes avoid the line by going at off hours, but not too off, they're actually not open! Cozy up at a small table with a bottle of wine and some pasta made earlier that day and you can't find a better evening in the North End. Just remember to bring cash! (not sure if they use credit at this point!)

Reviews.Author: Tom M.
Reviews.Content: I ride a bike around town, and you cannot believe the lines at this place.  I've driven by as early as 4:45, and they're lined up like it's free.  I even asked someone once "Hey, you got a 2 for 1 coupon or something?"  No, they don't.  It's that good.I think they do a nice job, and I'm not sure I would stand in line for an hour.  That said I'm sure you'll enjoy it if you go.

Reviews.Author: Ali H.
Reviews.Content: Can't ask for more, one of the best Italian food in the city of Boston.Dont miss any pasta with tomato cream sauce.

Reviews.Author: Angie L.
Reviews.Content: Great:  House special All kinds of seafood mixed into your pasta... I don't eat pasta often, but when I do, it better be good.  We waited on a Friday night at 4:50PM in 32 degree weather for dinner and thank goodness it was well worth it! Our server was gracious and she loved us because we 3 little girls can pack a mean stomach... we cleaned house for sure.  The house special is technically for 2, but we 3 had this + a house salad + calamari.. so lets just say, we were stuffed. Best thing I had in Boston, would recommend!

Reviews.Author: Justin E.
Reviews.Content: Loved this place. Great food. Great service and great wine(cheap). The calamari was great and the lobster ravioli was amazing. I would eat here again in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Author: J Spencer B.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is delicious. I've been twice--once to the South End location and once to the North End one. I really enjoyed the food. The Zuppa will leave you full and wanting more!

Reviews.Author: Clayton M.
Reviews.Content: Holy Calamari! Ate here for the first time tonight. Waited outside for about 10 minutes freezing my butt off, but oh buddy was it worth it! Sadly, I was out of town by myself on business, so I sat elbow to elbow with a few other strangers. Luckily they were all hygienically sound and didn't throw any elbows.Let me first warn you that Giacomo's is the smallest restaurant that I have ever been in. Don't let that deter you though! I had the Lobster Ravioli with calamari and a glass of wine. Not only was it absolutely delicious, but it was brought out fresh in under 10 minutes. Service was prompt, no BS and friendly.Remember to bring cash! no cards accepted. Would definitely be back if I'm ever in Boston again.

Reviews.Author: Karina L.
Reviews.Content: This place really doesn't need any more reviews. But I'll write one anyway SO I CAN YELL AT YOU AND TELL YOU YOU NEED TO GET THEIR CALAMARI.It's clear that Giacomo's doesn't give a crap about what you think about them. Their website is made on Blogspot and their service is curt, rude, and you're rushed out of the restaurant the minute you've paid your bill. Despite all this, we left so wonderfully in love with this place and swore that we would have to come here again.We came here on a weekday night and ended up waiting around 20-30 minutes. They stuck us at the counter -- space was tight, but it was cool being able to see the chefs hard at work in the kitchen. We started off with the calamari, and it is hands down the best calamari I've ever had. I'm assuming everybody orders it so our order came out immediately and piping hot. The calamari's lightly breaded so it didn't have that weird fried gunk bad calamari always gets. Still, it was refreshingly crunchy and completely addicting. Get the $10 Large order -- you'll regret getting the small the moment you finish the last calamari. For the entree, we got the butternut squash ravioli and the mussels over linguine with their giacomo sauce  ($15 and $14. respectively). The butternut squash ravioli came with a asparagus, prosciutto and a mascarpone sauce. We didn't really taste the prosciutto, which was alright since the squash did all the talking in the dish. The ravioli and the sauce had a sweetness to it, which was a great foil to our linguine with giacomo sauce (a creamy tomato sauce). We rotated between the two dishes for the whole meal and finished up the sauce tidily with the freshly baked bread provided to us.Overall, this place is well worth the wait. Plan accordingly and don't expect good service! Not that it'll' matter since your mouth will be full of food the entire time.

Reviews.Author: Hanna G.
Reviews.Content: I love this place... the only thing is the line can get ridiculous sometimes, but if you come on an off hour you can walk right in. The food is always good the pasta is always fresh and the prices aren't bad!

Reviews.Author: Steve L.
Reviews.Content: The butternut squash almost lives up to the hype.  The fra-como sauce - this time on fusilli and lobster - does.Waited for half an hour on a Wednesday night and was seated without incident.  Given recommendation upon recommendation, we ordered strategically - fried calamari, butternut ravioli, and the lobster fusilli special.The wine list was a bit less Spartan than that of the Daily Catch further down the street.  And our bottle of pinot grigio was a real winner - unfortunately, I neglected to snap a photo of the label.Calamari was good, even refrigerated the day after.  Then again, it's really difficult to screw up fried calamari.  The butternut squash ravioli was terrific - toothy, with a sweet kick that lingers in the mouth.  Oddly, I've had better at the Italian Corner, East Providence, RI (serves dinner Saturday night only).  The winner was absolutely the fusilli.Fra-como sauce is a melange of Fra Diavolo sauce (red, tangy), with their Giacomo sauce (creamy), to create an excellent, layered flavor for the perfectly prepared fusilli and sweet chunks of lobster.  Every last smear of the sauce was taken care of, either by food or by finger.I'd like to try out their South End location.  I hear they take reservations.

Reviews.Author: Sap A.
Reviews.Content: I prefer the South End location for convenience, but either one is a good choice for a consistently delicious and affordable meal with quick service (although if you go to the North End, build in some time to wait outside to be seated). Notable items on their menu include their calamari with spicy fra diavolo sauce (mmm, my mouth is watering just thinking about it) and their homemade fusili special (when they have it)with lobster, shrimp and "Giacomo sauce". Staples like chicken parm and marsala are also good - really you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The Beer and wine selection is small, but decent. At $18 a bottle (even though the wine isn't stellar) the markup on their wine isn't as bad as most of their peers in the neighborhood. Overall, I highly recommend Giacomo's; however if you're not patient, make a reservation in the South End.

Reviews.Author: Mary L.
Reviews.Content: We braved the weather and the wait to try Giacomo's on a Friday night. If you are looking for a nice, romantic, sit-down, this isn't it. The tables are a little too close, the place is loud, and the servers aren't very refined, but it has the North End charm you expect. We ordered a bottle of reisling for $17. It was cheap table wine, but we were a few bottles in by then and it served its purpose to keep the buzz going. I had the shrimp and scallop pasta with the Giacomo sauce, The scallops were fine (not very large in size), but the shrimp were overcooked. The sauce? Devine.Personally, I prefer places where I am able to enjoy my meal without being rushed.

Reviews.Author: H. S.
Reviews.Content: Great food and the Giacomo's South End has a wonderful neighborhood feel to it.  Of all the restaurants around here, these guys are the ones who will always recognize you, especially Joe, the manager.  It's always crowded, but you'll get a table if you go early (5-530) or late for the last sitting.  What I miss most about living nearby is how Giacommos was always open during a snow emergency.  It's great to grab a neighbor and sit by the window watching the snow come down while you share a 15 dollar bottle of valpolicello.

Reviews.Author: Karen W.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is a tiny restaurant in the North End.  The first time I went there, my friends and I raved about the butternut squash ravioli and the seafood special.  However, looking back, I think that after waiting in the cold for 2 hours, anything would have been phenomenal.  I went back a second time and asked for take-out because I didn't want to wait in line.  I know I ordered the butternut squash ravioli and another dish (can't remember which one), but my friend and I were left disappointed and still hungry!  So we're not exactly motivated to try again.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie S.
Reviews.Content: Great food!  It only gets 4 stars because it's such a pain to get into. Who wants to wait outside in a line for an hour or more?  Recommendation:  Get take-out and have a picnic al fresco down by the North End park (if it's warm enough, of course!).  The take-out is MUCH faster and that view of the city is beautiful at night!!  Perfect for a date!

Reviews.Author: John P.
Reviews.Content: This is probably my favorite place in Boston. There is nothing better. Their pasta is fresh. Their sauces are amazing. I especially love the Giacomo sauce and the fra diavolo. Whatever you get is going to be great. For apps, their calamari is excellent as well as their fried mozzarella. The place is small and if you don't get there early you will have to wait in line. They don't take reservations, but its always worth the wait. Also for the portion size and quality the prices aren't bad at all.

Reviews.Author: Ryan L.
Reviews.Content: There are so many reviews for this place, almost all good, so I'll be very brief.The food is AMAZING.  The service is good, but don't expect any chitchat.  The place is tiny, and there's always a line outside, so if you want blather and mediocre Italian, go to Olive Garden.There is no A/C.  We ate there in July and it was 90+ outside and in.  Didn't matter.  The calamari will make you forget where you are, it's that good.  Get a cold Peroni, order another one with your entree, and enjoy the deliciousness.Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Casey S.
Reviews.Content: After 3 great dinners it's easy for me to say that this is one of my favorite places to eat in the South End.The menu covers just about everything that you'd expect from an italian restaurant. I tend to stick to the seafood dishes, but whatever you order just make sure to get the lobster sauce with your dish. It stands up to the hype.For me what makes Giamcomo's stand out is the physical space. It's intimate, small, busy and rather loud. It feels like your hole-in-the-wall-neighborhood-don't-tell-your-­friends italian restaurant with a big name backing it. It's well worth a visit.Just make sure to bring cash or you'll be hustling down the street to the ATM and your date won't be impressed. Don't be that guy brah.

Reviews.Author: Celeste C.
Reviews.Content: Came here because I was in Boston on vacation and Giacomo's is a North End tradition. I'd been to the Back Bay location the year before but wanted to see if going to the "original" was worth it. In a nutshell, no. The wait at Back Bay was much shorter than the 45 minute wait at North End. In addition, service at this location was pretty subpar. Our server had an attitude problem during our entire dinner, and when we went to tip, she refused to give us change because she felt entitled to a certain percentage of tip. When we asked her why we were not getting our change, she not only refused, but also whipped out a calculator to show how it was however much percentage of tip and therefore we would not be getting any change. The food was good, but the service, especially the tiff at the end of our meal, kind of ruined it.

Reviews.Author: Joe R.
Reviews.Content: by far the best Italian outside Italy.  I've never had marinara sauce this good.  do yourself a favor and shove your entire face in the chicken parm.

Reviews.Author: Kemberli P.
Reviews.Content: Best. Ever. So good that we've waited the 1 1/2 hours that is often times necessary. No reservations. No call ahead. No idea how long the wait is just have to judge by the line outside. We've had the...Butternut squash ravioli - ridiculous flavor & sauce.. I always clean my plate of the sauce with the bread. Fried Calamari - served with fried pickled jalapeñosShrimp & scallops with Giacomo's sauce & pasta - so fresh and perfectly cooked. Sauce is awesome and perfect flavor... Not too overwhelming as I find a lot of red sauces to be. Pretty sure this is the best in the North End. Worth the wait. Prices aren't even that bad either. Service is quick and water glass is always full. It's not a sit around and chat place at all though! Get in and out so everyone waiting can get in... We can see you taking your time through the window while we wait outside in line. :)

Reviews.Author: Robert F.
Reviews.Content: Great Italian meal at reasonable pricesNo credit only cash.We had a great meal at this old fashion italian restaurant. The wait staff is very attentive and helpful in selecting the dishes. The pasta dishes especially the gnocchi was exceptional. Great salads and appetizers. The marsala was too sweet for my flavor but a nice order. The parmigiana was also very good. Dessert of pane cotta was great.Will be back

Reviews.Author: royal r.
Reviews.Content: This place is ridiculously great - I love the food - EVERY TIME. The only thing to know is that you go here to eat, drink, and leave - if you linger you will be told to hurry it up - they turn tables like crazy because people are outside waiting to get it. Its very small - BUT I'm telling you get there before they open 4:45 pm - don't eat lunch - be the first to get seated and stuff your face with incredible food. Definitely 'last meal' worthy. Bravo Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: Kelsey J.
Reviews.Content: Great food and great price!

Reviews.Author: Sandy N.
Reviews.Content: The portions are great for sharing and the dishes were full of flavors but not all of the dishes were that great.I highly enjoyed their fried calamari and their peanut butter dessert.  Their dessert was so good that we order a second serving. It is quite loud in this place but very cozy.

Reviews.Author: Cate S.
Reviews.Content: I recently went on a double date here.  I cannot believe I haven't been here before, and cannot wait to go again.  It is a cozy spot, with amazing food, and wonderful staff.  This is how Italian food should be!! We had the calamari, bruschetta, my friend had the lobster ravioli and I had the butternut squash ravioli.  These dishes were so wonderful.  (I dont remember the other two dishes)  I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Author: Mike A.
Reviews.Content: Another reason why we love Yelp.  We were wandering around Boston during our first-ever visit and found ourselves wrapping up our Freedom Trail adventures for the day in this area of the city.We lined up 4:20 and found a couple of others outside waiting for it to open (sign said 5 pm, but we were told 4:30).  We almost left but decided to stay when the owner(?) came out and forced us to properly queue alongside the front window.  Mass swarms of diners suddenly appeared out of nowhere as if on cue, and we were ushered inside shortly after 4:30 rolled around.  It was jam-packed faster than my Aventador on the autobahn... the whole restaurant, while not large, really accommodates a lot of patrons, making for a great experience for us.  We had to sit in back near the kitchen entrance due to our party of five, but that made for great people-watching.I had the shrimp and scallops fra diavolo - excellent with a $5 glass of red vino.  The wife and kids enjoyed their chicken and shrimp ziti.The staff was friendly and professional.  Can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Lucy X.
Reviews.Content: There are reasons why restaurants have the reputations that they do and Giacomos is not the exception. The butternut squash ravioli and pumpkin tortellini were both pasta dishes I've never had, or even imagined before (I suppose I'm a newbie at Italian food). Unlike the typical pasta dishes, they were both on the sweet side. If you're not too into that, I'd at least go for the butternut squash ravioli, it is less overwhelming hence easier to eat than the tortellini. But don't get me wrong--both were amazing dishes. Also a tip from our very nice waitress, if you end up getting the ravioli, you must dip your starter bread in the sauce! So so good ahh

Reviews.Author: Alex A.
Reviews.Content: Love this place!!! Food is always fresh, they work w/seasonal ingredients and everything comes out piping hot. Their buttersquash raviolli is amazing. I believe it's cash only and they don't offer dessert, but the wait is worth it!

Reviews.Author: Ashley V.
Reviews.Content: Great food, cheap wine, hearty portions.Line: Arrived at 4pm, was 3rd in line. By 4:20pm, the line was ridiculous so if you have a big party or want to get seated right away, come early. Food:1) Calamari: very good, well-seasoned, tender.2) Garlic bread: a little too oily for me, left a funny taste in my mouth afterwards. 3) Homemade fusilli with lobster and shrimp w Giacomo sauce: FANTASTIC. Pasta was al dente, sauce was amazing, generous portions.4) Special seafood over linguini for 2: my dad and brother ordered this. Came with generous helpings of lobster, clams, calamari, mussels, shrimp, scallops, etc. Very big, very good, lots of delicious seafood.5) Scallops and shrimp over linguini in white sauce: the white sauce is one of my favorites. Very light, very tasty white whine sauce with garlic.6) Bottle of wine for $17: Enough said.  Overall, a pleasant dining experience. The seating was really cramped but the friendly staff, cheap wine, good food and generous portions win it for me. I'm not sure it's a place I would wait over an hour for in the cold Boston winter though.

Reviews.Author: Kristina F.
Reviews.Content: Yes I waited in the cold for 30 minutes and yes, it was worth the wait.  The food here is fresh, authentic, and delicious.  The service isn't pushy, but they definitely keep your meal moving along due to the popularity of this place.  Go here.  You won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Chris P.
Reviews.Content: The Lobster Ravioli was amazing. Shrimp and Chicken pesto penne was also delicious. Overall the food was great, service was Ok. Tiny establishment. I would definitely recommend it.

Reviews.Author: Michelle T.
Reviews.Content: Despite the 1 hour wait on a Sunday afternoon for our party of 10, the wait was definitely worth it. Besides, food tastes better when you wait for it anyways!Our group arrived at Giacomo's at 5pm (when it opens) and waited in line for an hour (or more), watching parties of 2 get seated WAYYYYY before we did. But that's ok, we entertained ourselves by staring at the food ordered by customers sitting near the window. Service was great. There's a 20% gratuity for parties of 5+, but the servers at Giacomo's were absolutely wonderful. Fast, friendly, professional and we never lacked bread/water all night. They even made sure all 10 entrees made it to our tables within a 5 minute window so we could all eat together!Food! SOOO YUMMY. But did I mention I was starving by the time we sat down? - Refillable bread basket -- Ask for that hot minced garlic. So delicious on a fluffy, chewy, crusty bread. - Fried Calamari -- ($10 for a large) shared between 4 people, our squid disappeared in about 3 minutes. The batter was crunchy, rich but not overly heavy, a tad on the greasy side. The squid itself was super fresh, light, gentle-chewy (i know it's not a word) and spot. ON. Breaded and fried red peppers/jalapenos = perfection. Only complaint was that there wasn't enough marinara dipping sauce that came with. - Frutti di mare w/ fra diavolo sauce -- ($19) Absolutely delicious. Bright flavors and fresh seafood! Al dente linguini in a slightly spicy, well seasoned tomato sauce. The seafood in it was wonderfully fresh, though I didn't care for the mussels. The squid was the highlight but shrimp were a tad overcooked and I definitely would not have minded a bit more seafood. I couldn't finish it and had to take 1/2 home. Overall, I would love to come back to try different dishes. Seems a bit of a rushed place for a date (if you feel guilty for making people wait in a super long line, that is) but an awesome place to eat at the North end. One of my favorites so far. :)

Reviews.Author: Alexandra S.
Reviews.Content: Clearly, with 500-plus mostly rave reviews to its credit, there's not much more to be said about this North End favorite.  However my meal was so delicious and there was absolutely no wait to get in, that I just had to add my voice to the crowd.Yes, it was a cold night in Boston but it was clear and starry out...really kind of pleasant actually so it wasn't really the kind of weather that would preclude standing in line if you had to.  But miraculously there was no line!   Even more surprisingly, it never really got filled up inside for the hour and a half we were there.A friend and I ordered our meals off the extensive list of specials.Mine was the squid ink pappardelle with mahi mahi and puttanesca sauce. Everything about this dish was luscious and well executed, from the perfectly al dente and devilishly black pasta to the heat of the puttanesca sauce.  The mahi mahi was cut into chunky morsels and mixed into this spicy, briny, comforting dish.My friend ordered a frutte di mare type special with a half lobster and clams over linguine topped with Fra Diavolo sauce.  Both of us scraped our plates clean even with the large portions they serve.  It was that good.We ordered a bottle of prosecco which was delicious. It went down oh so easy.Our friendly, helpful and lovely waitperson was Julie.  It's a tiny place but cozy and comforting with it's red brick walls, tin ceiling and open kitchen.Before tip and including the bottle of prosecco our bill came to a wallet-friendly 66 dollars.  Do remember, (I did not), that this place only takes cash.And because there was no usual mad rush last night, we felt like we could linger a bit over our wine instead of guiltily peering out the window at a waiting line of hungry diners.  We started up a friendly chat with the couple at the next table; two young and fun CPAs here from Florida for a pre-Christmas vacation before the busy tax season hits them.Their enthusiasm for being in Boston in December was infectious and added to our nice night.There has always been something special to me about a hearty Italian meal in the North End on a cold night.  Last night at Giacomo's fit the bill  and we were thrilled to finally get into this place without waiting in  line.

Reviews.Author: Jess L.
Reviews.Content: Had dinner here last night during a visit to Boston - small place, decent wait outside but truly worth the wait even in the cold.They have a variety of pasta's and sauces to choose from. Great Italian family vibe with the chaos and boisterous shouts to the cooks which adds to the experience. This is not a fine dining place, your not going to get overly nice servers - its a no nonsense good food place. The hostest asks your party size on the sidewalk and you go in when a tables free. Space is a bit tight, but fun.I had the shrimp and mussels with the Giacomo combo sauce - the seafood was fresh and perfectly prepared, and the sauce was incredible. Im typically not a pasta person necessarily but I was very impressed.Ate most of it, saved the rest for later - good size portion. Overall a great night out.

Reviews.Author: Ligaya T.
Reviews.Content: If there was one place, any place in the entire city to spend your last dinner in the city where would it be?The ultimate conundrum. Face scrunch. No close my eyes, restaurant roulette this time. Oh, the pressure! Well, obviously it's got to be good. So some place consistent. Nothing lavish, just a solid, filling meal and quality, cheap wine. Giacomo's, I've got my sights set on you. And no forty-five minute line will deter me. Cozy and familial with hearty, enormous portions of fresh made, deliciously al dente pasta (pumpkin tortellini with mascarpone sage cream sauce, my love, I'll remember you always) goes down the gullet with goodness. The chalkboard menu will not do you wrong. Carb comas of this caliber will sorely be missed.To the man behind the pans, want to move away with me?

Reviews.Author: Leighann F.
Reviews.Content: Oh look at you, Giacomo's! With your daunting line wrapping around the block, that pesky no reservations policy, your gruff service and cramped, close eating quarters. Still, after 215 reviews, you're going strong...boasting 4.5 stars all the way. You must be doing something right.And that something right is butternut squash ravioli. And ridiculously cheap wine. And simple dishes like chicken parm and fra diavolo. Consistent and delicious. Affordable and plentiful. I know, I know...tell you something you don't already know.There, I got nothing. Giacomo's is North End legend. Sometimes branded as a tourist trap. Sometimes labeled not worth the hype. Often heralded as the best Italian food in Boston. While I cannot confirm nor deny, fully, any of these suppositions, I can say I really like eating here. The food is filling and the sometimes surly, quick-paced, get-in and get-out service is all part of the charm.I would totally eat here more often, if only I didn't have a life and interests and a job that kept me from waiting for the better half my night just grab a bite!

Reviews.Author: Nicole M.
Reviews.Content: Reasons why it took me over 9 years to get to Giacomo's:1) I lack the chromosome that gives people patience.  I spend a good amount of time in the North End, and I can't even fill one hand with the number of times when I've seen this place without a ginormous line.  Me and lines don't go well together.2) I was told it was pricey.  Sometimes, I can be a real tightwad.  And I know of plenty of other very affordable places in the neighborhood without the dreaded line.3) I was told it was extremely seafood heavy.  Me?  I'm 1/2 italian (my mom's side) and in all my years growing up, seafood and italian dishes didn't go together. Italian dishes meant pasta e fagiole and just pasta, period.  Plus, I can't eat shellfish.  I'd like to, really, but I just can't.  I'm a texture girl.Fast forward entirely too much time to when I actually planted my ass in Giacomo's line to wait for a table.  Got seated after about 20 minutes, and as I reviewed the menu, thinking that I was going to be that annoying customer who makes modifications to every single piece of the meal, I was overjoyed.  Sure, there's a lot of seafood, but there's a helluva lot of other stuff too.  Not to mention the specials.I ended up going with one of said specials.  And I beg, PLEAD for Giacomo's to put this dish on the menu as a regular item.  Roasted red pepper and goat cheese gnocchi with chicken, baby spinach and mushrooms in a slightly spicy sauce.  I got mine sans 'shrooms. And when I took the first bite, I nearly died and went to heaven.  But not before I inhaled the $15.95 bottle of cabernet sauvignon.  Seriously, $15.95?!!  Anyone who eats here and does not order a bottle of wine should be hung.1) I will gladly take out my rarely seen patience hat and wait in line again.  And again.  And again.2) People are on crack.  This place is one of THE most affordable places to eat in this city.3) Roasted red pepper and goat cheese gnocchi.  That's just music to my ears.

Reviews.Author: Daniel A.
Reviews.Content: By far the best Italian place in Boston! Seriously, this place is as close to the taste of Italy as you can get without buying a plane ticket. I know there are already enough reviews to put this place on anybodys list of places to eat, but I want to make sure you don't miss this amazing gem. With about 30 different places to eat within a 2 block radius, you will still see a line of about 30 people waiting to get in to Giacomo's. It usually takes about 20-30 minutes to get in, so don't let the long line scare you. Yes, the food is that good, the prices are ridiculously low ($12-$20 for huge portions), and the experience is perfect. It is hard to tell you what to order because there are about 30 items on the menu and they all look and taste amazing. I went for the gnocchi special and the linguine dish which came with mussels, clams and half of a Maine lobster in Fra Diavolo sauce (slightly spicy). Everything is good, seriously, everything! All the specials and a huge menu selection is written on the walls of this quaint restaurant. With only 15 tables in the whole place, packed with excited guests hungry for authentic Italian food, you will feel like you are part of something special. I didn't even mention the fact that you can buy bottles of wine for only $16. That's right, $16 for some Chianti, Merlot, Chardonnay, etc. I love this place!

Reviews.Author: Brian D.
Reviews.Content: Native Bostonians might cringe at this, but I really think Giacomo's is the best Italian restaurant in the city.  That's because it's become quite the tourist trap over the years and now regularly has hour-long lines out the door on Thursday-Saturday.  And because of these 2 factors, the service isn't great because they want you to leave soon after you get done with your food.The food, however, is pretty amazing.  Giacomo's fried calamari with spicy peppers is fantastic.  The showstopper, however, is the lobster fusili special with "Fracomo's" sauce.  My favorite is to have them mix the Fra Diavolo and the Giacomo's sauces, which they call the Fracomo's sauce - a creamy, slightly spicy red sauce that is to die for.The prices are pretty fantastic at $15-25 per entree.  Wine and beer are incredibly cheap.  I know most people in Boston refuse to wait in line for food, but in the North End, lines signify a great restaurant.P.S. Save some room for a cannoli and Mike's Pastry after Giacomo's!!!

Reviews.Author: Jim D.
Reviews.Content: Succumbing to my curiosity that surrounds the madness over at Giacomo's, we decided to brave the insane lines to see what all the fuss is all about.  The stories are indeed true.  Lines wrap around the corner, composed of a mixture of patiently waiting tourists and locals alike.  I listen amusingly to stories from locals in line next to us insisting on how wonderful Giacomo's is despite its touristy appeal (thanks Rachel).  Could it be that great?!After waiting for a little over an hour, we finally get seated.  We arrived around 4:25pm and got seated around 5:40ish.  Yeah, we were among those who were waiting around the corner.  Curiosity and hunger can make you do silly things like that. We ordered the calamari with house sauce (awesome), the fruitti di mare fra diavolo (delish) and the veal parm (superb).  Their house red sauce (lobster base) is something you truly do not want to miss.  It's so flavorful and delicious!  The other reviews are not kidding when they talk about massive portions.  Wearing elastic waist pants is probably not such a bad idea after dining here.  I think one of the most delightful and entertaining aspects of our experience here was the service.  Our waiter, whose name escapes me, made the whole experience memorable.  He was friendly, lively, efficient and energetic.  He kept us and the folks around us laughing and smiling the whole time.  The atmosphere was a controlled chaos.  If you're not comfortable dining in extremely cramped quarters, this is probably not the place for you.  I personally didn't mind as it only made the whole experience a more communal dining experience. Prices are surprisingly very affordable.  Dishes range, on average, from $15-$20.  Wine is also pretty inexpensive.  I didn't notice any beers on tap but I wasn't really looking.  Definitely check Giacomo's out.  It's definitely worth the wait.  The immense and loyal clientele would vouch for this place anytime.  So would I.

Reviews.Author: Robert Z.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian food I've had in a long while.  There, I said it.  The Little Italy, North End portion of Boston has me completely enamored, this part of town is truly meant to be walked.  We took the subway from Copley to Haymarket. (A first for me using public transportation, outside of Tokyo, it was fun, like a Universal Studios ride)  The walk to Giacomo's was short & scenic.  The restaurant was identifiable by a line, fret not, it moves quick and you can huddle together with the other customers for warmth.The number of reviews, and the rating, was what drew me to this place, now I can recommend it on taste.  I'm trying not to sound like Bourdain here, however good food makes me speak in prose; The menu is expansive without being cumbersome, the wine selection is what you would expect from a great Italian establishment.  (People who don't drink wine with Italian food need to be ejected from Italian restaurants on principle, when in Rome don't order water or tea, learn to like wine)A family-owned Italian restaurant, (A dying breed) hospitality was clearly evident, if you have a chance to talk with a member of the family I highly recommend getting a recommendation on a wine to pair with the meal, and to just talk with them in general, they really are great people, as most restaurant owners are.  (They are after all, doing what they love)  Speaking of love, they make their own sauces and the pasta is "al dente".  The seafood was superb.  (I had the lobster ravioli with diced tomatoes in a garlic cream sauce)  The lobster was soft and flavorful, perfection.I can't wait to return.  And the same can be said for those who came with me.  And from someone whose father came from "the best part of New York" (New Jersey), to say you can't wait to return to an Italian restaurant in Boston is saying a lot.

Reviews.Author: Jenny S.
Reviews.Content: GO EARLY ENOUGH TO GET FIRST SEATING, or you'l be waiting in line for quite a while!!! (they open at 4:30 pm not 5 pm)although service is quick here (w/o being rude) & food comes out FAST in attempt to compensate for their tiny restaurant spaceFINALLY tried giacomo's after years of it being bookmarked!----free bread: its okay, ASK FOR THE GRATED PARMESAN to flavor it up!----fruitti de mare over linguine w/ giacomo sauce (pink lobster sauce): CHOCK FULL OF SEAFOOD! loved the big scallops & yummy mussels & clams! but the shrimp were a lil overcooked AND the sauce was too thin.. (we had to thicken it by loading on a ton of grated parmesan) ----lobster ravioli in garlic cream sauce: YUMnot the best italian i've ever had, but definitely good italian!! i probably wouldn't wait for it if i didn't get first seating again!CASH ONLY

Reviews.Author: Kevin S.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is a true classic--a restaurant that transcends its category, transcends the norms of the fine dining rat race--the chasing of trend after trend.  It's a place that can celebrate its quirks and oddities and downright stubborn limitations.  If you take the time to play along, you will celebrate with your tastebuds, and your heart.You don't come to Giacomo's to be impressed by the creativity of the chef, or the beauty of the dining room, or the finer points of the service.You come to Giacomo's to experience a restaurant that is all about the food, and just the food; the food and the eating of it are the only things that matter.  I absolutely treasure places like this and am so, so glad we came here rather than some other newfangled, fusion place.If you read enough in this list of reviews you will know the drill, but they bear repeating:  Cash only.  You are going to wait in line.  The luck of the draw in terms of which tables open up will determine how fast your group gets seated.  When you finally get to enter, you need to enter the doors one at a time, like an airlock, so as not to freeze your fellow diners when you enter with a wintry blast from Hanover Street.Once inside, I hope you are waited on by the sassy and savvy Rosemarie, a lovely lady who brooks no nonsense but wants you to enjoy every bite and appreciates customers who appreciate good food.Your first move is obvious:  large calamari, please.  To pass these up is criminal, and I come from a part of the country where calamari are caught by fishermen by the tons.  You will quickly find yourself addressing a plate of perfectly breaded, perfectly fried, perfectly tender calamari accented with little chunks of fried sweet red and spicy jalapeno pepper rings.After ordering your appetizer, focus on the big chalk boards, and order up a plate of pasta with seafood.  I picked a special, lobster and shrimp on homemade fusilli with Giacomo's spicy, creamy house red sauce, a lovely savory combination.When you are face down in that pasta you will forget that the wine list is just mundane, and there is no dessert to be had here--Mike's is across the street with the cannoli of all cannolis, so why would you even think about dessert here?  Finish up, there are hungry people out there standing in line.  Share the wealth, share the warmth.I hope Giacomo's is open forever, and those who don't really get it don't clutter up the line.  The rest of us will cherish places like this.

Reviews.Author: Jaye B.
Reviews.Content: If Yelp had 100 stars, that's what I would give Giacomo's. I knew I wanted Italian because Austin lacks Italian. I mean, we're talking serious deprivation to the point that I'm pretty sure no Italians who can cook have ever stepped foot in Austin or else they'd have flipped the f out by now and opened a real restaurant. Or maybe they just cook at home and don't tell me. Bastards. But I digress...Searching Yelp for places in the North End to take a small group that includes vegetarians, I came across a metric-shit-ton (that's a lot to you non-Texan's) of amazing reviews for Giacomo's so we hopped in a cab and took our place in line (about 20 minutes, not bad at all), and waited for our feast.And our feast? She did arrive. Holy mother of GOD. The meat eaters all had the linguine with 1/2 lobster, about a dozen mussels and clams and a mix (as suggested by my favorite waitress ever in the whole world Donna) of the fra diavolo/giacomo sauce for $18.95. Seriously.I am not even kidding. And it was hands down the best pasta dish I have ever eaten in my life. The veggies had fusili with red and a goat cheese mushroom ravioli in pesto and were just as happy as the meat eaters. Top that off with 15.95 bottles of Chianti and we were a happy group that had to be rolled down to Mike's for dessert.The place is small and crowded and the staff knows how to turn a table like you wouldn't believe. The efficiency of this place is amazing. You can tell these people have been together for years because they move like a ballet. Like a big, fat ballet of food that's so good it makes you cry. The staff yell at each other, and talk trash, and make you feel like you're at a family dinner. I want to move in here. I want my family to be like this. I freakin' LOVE this place.I was toasted, high fived, thanked and generally revered. Later, a parade was thrown in my honor. And then I was carried to my hotel room on a big carpet thing while being fanned by nubile young studs dressed only in loin cloths...All for reading the reviews and listening to my fellow Yelpers.Will I go back to Giacomo's? What do you think?

Reviews.Author: Anthony P.
Reviews.Content: Hands down the best Italian food I have ever had in the United States. In fact, it's vying to be the best Italian I've had anywhere! You do have to wait in line out front for a table in the very small restaurant but you'll be glad you did. The homemade sauces, pastas, and other dishes on the regularly changing menu are amazing. If you can't decide, ask Rosemarie to help you! She along with the rest of the staff provide a thoughtful service and do a nice job of getting you in and out without feeling rushed.

Reviews.Author: Kenny B.
Reviews.Content: Now this is what I'm talking about - great food, excellent atmosphere, reasonable prices. Let's just say that I'm still salivating over my meal and next time I'm in town, I'm going to visit.There were plenty of great restaurants on the North End that fellow Yelpers recommended, and this one was amongst the rest. Thank goodness fate happened to help me out with this choice. We had walked past it and saw that there was a long line outside. But my mom wanted to check it out. Just as we got in line, the people in front were given tables, up until us. And luckily, there was one more table for our family; the last one in the restaurant! So, we didn't have to wait and were give a front row table looking at the kitchen area. Mom and Dad facing the kitchen, my brother and I craning our necks to look back every few minutes at the action behind us. It is quite a small restaurant, but its quite intimate and lively to see the chefs throwing ingredients together. Makes it feel more cozy.Calamari? Excellent, with the peppers included it added a little kick that was great. My meal was one of the daily specials - 1/2 lobster with clams & mussels over linguine. Now, I don't really care for clams & mussels, but the thought of lobster was overwhelming. Requesting the pesto sauce and thinking I could hand the shellfish onto someone else while I reveled in lobster & pasta, I was set. But when it came, I just had to try a clam. I did, and it was like none other I had tasted - I actually liked it. So I ended up eating up almost the entire meal, which was ginormous. (Of course, I had to share the goodness with the family). Each family member really enjoyed their individual meals and really kept raving about this place. Prices were quite reasonable and I did expect to pay a lot more for the quality of food I received.Even though I despise R.R. and her inane way of thinking every food she tastes is an orgasm of goodness, I have to agree with her on this one. I didn't read the article posted on the window, but am sure that her opinion of this place was genuine. Cash only, yes. But I would gladly hit up an ATM and pay a fee (which I never do), just so I could have some money to eat here. I compliment the fellow Yelpers who directed me here; this dining experience was the best I've had in a while.

Reviews.Author: Knox K.
Reviews.Content: WOW!  WOW!  WOW!  If  you are in Boston, you MUST eat here!Be prepared, though.  There is always a wait.  On a Wednesday night, we waited 45 minutes for a table.  But it was well worth it!!!!  The gnocchi was superb!  The scallops were to die for!  And the prices were super reasonable.  For example, we got a good bottle of wine for $16.00!  Yes, $16.00!!!!  Total price for 4 people with a bottle of wine was ~$80.00.  If I could, I would eat here every night.Be prepared for the wait when trying Giacomo's and bring cash as they do not accept credit cards.Enjoy!

Reviews.Author: Angela C.
Reviews.Content: I'm not the biggest fan of Italian food, but this place was excellent.  We ordered family style and shared.  Giacomo's separates their menu by type of pasta - so there's a linguine section, fettuccine section, vegetarian section, etc.  You choose your pasta, your seafood, and the type of sauce you want on your pasta (there's Giacomo's, Fra Diavolo, Pesto, and some others).Frutti di Mare with Giacomo's Sauce ($19): we got two orders of this because everyone said this was the best thing here.  It's the best Frutti Di Mare I've ever had!  Chunks of mussels, clams, shrimp, and scallops mixed with linguine in a creamy tomato based sauce.  Next time, I would want to try the Frutti di Mare with the Fra Diavolo sauce because I actually liked that more than the Giacomo's Sauce!Homemade Fusilli with Lobster and Shrimp in the Fra Diavolo Sauce ($26): this isn't on Giacomos' regular menu, but was on the Specials menu on their blackboard posted in the restaurant.  The fusili is homemade.  It had a very chewy texture and you'll see very few similarities from those sold at your typical market.  It came with large chunks of lobster and shrimp.  At first bite, this dish doesn't taste as good as the Frutti di Mare, but upon further inspection, I found the tomatoey Fra Diavolo Sauce to be quite amazing.  Next time I'm putting that sauce on linguine, which would probably pick up more of the flavors in the sauce.Butternut Squash Ravioli ($15): creamy and sweet (maybe a bit tooo sweet) and comes smothered in a delicious mascarpone cream sauce.  I bet it'd be spectacular to dip bread into this heavenly sauce.We also got the Large Fried Calamari appetizer ($10).  The batter was crispy and it came with a nice tomato dipping sauce.  They fried the calamari along with some peppers to give this dish a nice little kick.  Everything at Giacomo's was fresh and delicious.  The pastas were all perfectly cooked to Al Dente and the sauces were flavorful.  There's probably not a bad thing on the menu, but if you were to get ONE thing, get the Frutti Di Mare.  My favorite sauce though, was the Fra Diavolo.  So next time I think I will try the Frutti Di Mare with the Fra Diavolo sauce.Note: CASH ONLY!!!

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: I was walking around the North End, looking for a sfogliatelle and a dinner to go with it on a Saturday night at around 5:30 pm.  After browsing the menus at several places, a doorman at a restaurant across the street from Giacomo's recommended it as his favorite family-style Italian restaurant in the neighborhood.  I decided to check it out.I felt a little funny paying $3 extra for homemade pasta at an Italian restaurant but I did it anyways and it proved to be the right choice.  The texture of the cavatelli was great, and the sauce was good but unremarkable.  I went with the basic marinara but would try one of their more exciting choices next time.  The boyfriend's gnocci from one of the restaurant's specials were the perfect texture too, although I thought putting fried chicken into a heavy cream-based dish was a little excessive.  All in all, it was decent Italian food and generally better than what I expected from that part of town.

Reviews.Author: Roni S.
Reviews.Content: Short and simple:pros - one of the best Italian restaurants in Boston, amazing dishes (especially their ravioli) cons- can sometimes be impossible to get seated unless you go during an off peak timeI would recommend eating at the bar if its just a few people. You'll get seated and served faster.

Reviews.Author: Heidi H.
Reviews.Content: If you are concerned about portion control, then split your meal with a friend - or two. Huge but tasty caesar salad. Chicken parm was delicious but could have fed three. It upsets me to waste, and because it was the last night of our vacation, there was no way to take home leftovers. The 45 minute wait was tolerable, but the service was gruff tempered with a little over familiarity. Had to ask for water. Had to ask for menus. Will probably not return but we're glad to have had the experience.

Reviews.Author: Kam S.
Reviews.Content: SAMMY 5 STAR CERTIFIED!!!Look, you don't get over 900 reviews with an average of 4.5 for no reason.  This is one of the highest rated yelp restaurants I've seen anywhere with as many reviews as they have, with good reason; food is awesome.Sangiovese wine, killer.Bread and O.o. standard.Fresh mozza infused with creme fresh, in a  caprese salad drizzled w O.o. 5 star. unbelievable.  especially with the crust of their fresh italian loaf.Linguine marinar putanesca or whatever it was called: linguine, olives, capers, plum tomatoes, shaved parm :outta the park good.I sat at the bar so i got to see so many dishes go out and all i thought was i wish i could try the fruit di mare, calamari, ravioli, cesars, and everything else.This place is too good to be true.  Rightly priced.  I don't want you to go there bc that means less space for me.BOOM

Reviews.Author: Elizabeth S.
Reviews.Content: This place is a machine.If I had to describe Giacomo's (pronounced JA-ka-moz) in one word, it would be "efficient." Four of us arrived at the infamous spot halfway down Hanover Street at about 7pm on a Saturday - not exactly the wisest decision when hoping to dine at a Yelptastic restaurant that doesn't offer reservations.We waited outside in the cold about half a block down. For twenty minutes. Twenty minutes! That long a line, and we got seated in twenty minutes. Some restaurants can't manage that even when you've made a reservation!That said, definitely not a place to linger. You get in (by flashing four fingers at the woman inside to indicate four people), you sit, you order, suddenly your plate is gone and you leave.Ambiance: 2.5 stars. Tiny, crowded, certainly not encouraged to stay and have another drink.Service: 3.5 stars. Julie was fantastic, and I was very impressed that she seemed to wait on the entire restaurant by herself, but it's hard to devote too much time to each table when the entire restaurant's food orders are your responsibility.Food (the most important part): 5 stars. I had a special, which included pasta, chicken, mushrooms, and GOAT CHEESE. Looks like Giacomo's has learned the secret weapon: add goat cheese to everything to make it instantly amazing. I also tried the garlic bread (mmm) and the lobster ravioli....mmmmm good.I'd love to see a wider beer selection here, as they only serve wine and beer, but alas.Also, cash only. There is an ATM right across the street, fret not, but, don't say I didn't warn you.

Reviews.Author: Sherry S.
Reviews.Content: Went here for dinner.  Got there at 5:30 and had to wait outside for about 22 minutes for a table.  Once we got seated, there was suddenly no line, but it built back up again while we were eating. I wouldn't wait over an hour for this place, so get there early or make other plans.NO CREDIT CARDS...NO RESERVATIONS!Christian, our server was fantastic.Get the Calamari.  Get the Caprese We had the Fruit de Mare with the "spicy sauce".  Very goodIt's cramped and noisy...not romantic so don't expect that.  It is really good Italian food though.Calamari/Caprese/one Entree/3 glasses wine = $65 with tip.

Reviews.Author: Kirs P.
Reviews.Content: This is the location to go to!  (Avoid South End location at all costs- unless you enjoy being treated like a serf).  You will have to wait in line outside, but it's worth it.  Great Italian seafood at great prices.  The service here was wonderful- very friendly and helpful.  I took my brother and his girlfriend here on their first visit to Boston and they still rave about it.And definitely get the special Giacomo sauce!  It is heavenly!The only downside is the no credit card thing- who doesn't take the visa nowdays?

Reviews.Author: Sarah J.
Reviews.Content: I'm kind of ashamed to admit this, but I found out about Giacomo's via Rachael Ray's $40 A Day. *Runs for cover from the die-hards*  As a native, I feel such guilt that I didn't know about this place before.  But now that I do, I am a big fan.  Big.  Huge!Yes, waiting in a loooong line and not being able to put your name down makes zero sense.  And yes, the servers are *very* abrasive ladies with thick Boston accents, but you better listen to them or you will miss the sauce list!  And don't try and ask them anything before they get their shpeel out or it will be lost to the question gods.Long waits and visceral reactions to hot tempered servers aside, this place is friggen good.  The food comes out super quick and hot and delicious.  We had the calamari with hot peppers (ashamed to admit again that this was a RR recommendation) and caprese salad as appetizers.  Both were delicious and fresh.  For entrees, three out of six of us got the special: seafood over fusilli with a combination of fra diavolo and giacomo sauces ("fracomo").  Both are lobster based red sauces with a little kick and cream.  Went perfectly over the pasta and seafood.  Sooo much seafood!  Lobster, scallop, shrimp...delicious.  The butternut squash and sage ravioli was super sweet, but rich and delicious nonetheless.  But I think the winner might have been the lobster ravioli.  Large chunks of lobster in fresh ravioli with a rich and creamy sauce, but not too rich that you can't eat the whole plate!Speaking of plates, the servings are HUGE.  You can order one for 2 people, or order one each and have lunch and dinner for the next day.  Either way it's a win because prices are super reasonable for the amount of food you get.  Don't forget to hit the ATM on the way in--CASH ONLY!

Reviews.Author: Aretha B.
Reviews.Content: I wish I could give more than 5 stars. Maybe 6 stars with several exclaimation points in the mix!HOLY LORD.A co-worker recommended this place, and naturally I poured over the glowing Yelp reviews... my expectations were extremely high going in. Gaicomo's TOTALLY delivered.We first had the calamari and a 16 dollar bottle of chianti. The calamari was cooked perfectly with a light crumbly batter. SO GOOD. Little fried hot peppers set the whole dish off.For an entree I was completely torn between the pumpkin ravioli and the clam scampi with linguine. I am a huge fan of both dishes, so I had to ask the waitress what to eat for my first Giacomo's experience, it was hands down the Pumpkin Ravioli... and... WOW it was AMAZING... this maple-y flavor.. perfectly textured and seasoned. The asparagus was tender and cooked perfectly. Service was attentive but naturally hurried as the place is small and it was FREEZING and people were waiting out in the cold for a seat. In an area with several good restaurants, it's a testament to the quality of the food that people would stand outside in the cold just for a taste. All the surrounding restaurants had empty tables.No dessert, but afterwards we went to Modern Bakery down the street. I had the most delicious cookie AND creme brulee of my life. I am not kidding.

Reviews.Author: Evgenii B.
Reviews.Content: One of the best restaurants serving Italian food, and not just in Boston! I don't know weather I'd have been same satisfied if I had waited for couple of hours, though. If I want to go to Giacomo's, I plan it ahead and arrive 30 minutes before the opening, so my waiting time is really minimal:) no reason to describe any particular dish-everything is just super tasty. I doubt you can find better food in the North End

Reviews.Author: Ian W.
