Reviews.Content: If there is one ristorante in the North End I'd take my family to, it would be Giacomo's since the food is very good, the prices are reasonable, and the turnaround time is quick. There's usually a line outside waiting to get in since they do not accept reservations and the dining area is very crammed. The menu offerings are posted on a large blackboard and for many dishes, you can choose your sauce. My buddy and I had dinner here on a Sunday evening and the wait wasn't too bad, about 20 minutes. My buddy had a special which was a half pound lobster, clams & mussels over linguine with fra diavolo sauce ($18.95) and I had the Frutti DiMare ($17.95) which was mussels, clams, calamari, scallops, & shrimp with Giacomo sauce (cream & tomato) over linguine, both were very good and tasty. The seafood was fresh and the pasta was al dente! The basket of bread and oil was good with the meal. A very nice Italian dinner here and we walked over to Café Vittoria for gelato and espresso afterwards.NOTE: Cash only, no credit cards accepted.

Reviews.Author: Beth E.
Reviews.Content: So my birthday is in April. This year I turned 30. I went to dinner with a bunch of friends, but some of my work folk couldn't make it. One of those work friends has been saying all along that we should go out again to "celebrate" and so it was that I came to be having my 2nd 30th birthday dinner at Giacomo's nearly 7 months after my actual birthday.I had heard a lot about Giacomo's, but had never been. I heard the food was good, that there was always a line out front. For some reason I was envisioning something a little more fancy, and definitely something bigger. We showed up, and yes, there was a line, but we got there just as the first  seating of diners were finishing up, so our wait wasn't that long. I was surprised at how small this place is, but I like the intimate feel. After seeing the size of the place, the line out front make a little more sense. Our party of 5 was seated, and the waitress came over. She worked with purposefulness. She was matter-of-fact, and friendly, and moved with the efficiency of someone who's been working there for decades. Specials are up on the wall, oh, and here they are handwritten and laminated as well. That's a detail that made me smile.The food comes, and after tasting not only my own dish, but others, the line outside makes even more sense. My butternut squash ravioli were amazing. I even tried the fried calamari appetizer, and up until that point, I always commented that eating fried calamari was like eating rubber bands. That's not the case here. Apparently I had just never had good calamari.This little place is cash only, though when you're the "birthday" girl , no cash is necessary. Not when you have friends like mine. I'll definitely be back.

Reviews.Author: Adam R.
Reviews.Content: I live in the North End and have always seen a line at Giacomo's. Never wanting to wait on the super long line I was able to catch the restaurant on a rainy day when the wait was shorter. I waited about 30 minutes on a Tuesday night at 6pm. The decor inside is intimate and well suited for a date or small party. Once seated the waitress immediately asked for our order which was attentive and nice. However, once the entree was ordered and the food came out I felt very rushed. The waiters came over to my table twice to take the plates before I was done eating. I had leftover sauce from my pasta (lobster ravioli - which was wonderful) but - the waiter took away my plate before I had a chance to ask for more bread. Overall - The food was great. The prices were awesome. On the down side, I felt like my meal was completely rushed and I came home and ate two cookies because I could not stuff myself the way I usually do at an Italian dinner with lots of bread and sauces at the end of the meal. They pack you in like sardines and try to flip the tables as quick as possible (which makes sense because the meals are cheap so they need a way to make money).  If you are okay with this meaning...you already live with your significant other and know you re not going to get any at the end of the night then fine. If you are on a first date and need to wine and dine and pay attention to what the girls is saying then this is not your place. .

Reviews.Author: Babs D.
Reviews.Content: I'd heard about this place for as long as I can remember. My dad went to Harvard years ago, and when he and my mom would visit Boston they would always go to Giacomo's (North End location). They always would tell me although they had waited hours in line it was worth it.I can't imagine anything worth waiting HOURS in line for except maybe a first class seat to Paris. I had some pasta dish with chicken, broccoli, and a fra diavolo sauce that was to die for! Anyone going must also have the broccoli rabe with garlic-UNREAL-and the garlic bread...omg! So delic! Just don't eat HOURS before coming. Sidebar-all the employees were SUPER nice. I felt like I was in a hidden gem tucked away from the rest of Boston. Although I'd hardly call this a hidden gem considering how many times it has been written about or featured on tv.

Reviews.Author: Mary T.
Reviews.Content: This is why, when travel was a huge part of my job, I got fat! Ok, Giacomo's isn't personally responsible, in fact I never ate anywhere nearly as good.* BUT traveling means eating out a lot and trying to scout out gems. Giacomo's was the second half of my North End do-over. Last visit, I didn't plan accordingly and was gobsmacked by the huge line for a table. I highly recommend trying to dine here earlier on a weeknight; on a Monday the throngs of tourists were noticeably absent and the wait for a table was only about 10 minutes. Giacomo's reminds me of a cross between two of my favorite Italian places back home; one a no-frills cash-only place with a chalkboard menu that specializes in the Italian staples, the other a tiny little space with amazing food and a selection of more creative dishes. Personally, I would not recommend this place for a group of larger than 4-6 people. There are maybe 10 tables and everything is close quarters; the chef's table (for 2) is even wedged in corner at the bar. I also think you'll be disappointed if you come here for a romantic date or long lingering meal; they're always busy and turn the tables quite fast. I was in and out in no more than 40 minutes. My server reminded me a lot of my late aunt; a no nonsense little Italian firecracker. Any question I asked her, she answered quickly and definitively like no other option existed. Fortunately, she didn't steer me wrong once. If you go in expecting your server to provide small talk and pleasantries, you may find the service curt or cold; not being one for idle chit chat, I liked it. For a place that's so busy, service is fast, efficient and attentive; everything runs like a well-oiled machine. In hindsight, my only misstep was ordering the house salad; compared to the other starter options available, this is skippable. The dressing was good, but the big hunks of iceberg killed it for me. On the upside, the bread was quite good and useful for sopping some of the house dressing up off my plate. For my meal, I ordered the linguine with mussels and clams in the Giacomo sauce, a lobster-based tomato sauce with a touch of bechamel. My meal was fabulous, I was so glad I was steered toward the Giacomo sauce over the fra diavolo. I received a mountain of linguine with a healthy portion of mussels and clams. Since I didn't have a way to store or reheat leftovers, I cleaned my plate; though there was a genuine concern that I might pop a button or bust a zipper - it totally would have been worth it. Giacomo's offers not only great food, but great value for the money. My tab was $25 for a glass of wine, salad and entree. The next time I'm back in Boston, this is on my short list of places I need to return. *That's what happens when your job regularly sends you to hotspots like Fort Wayne, IN. TIP: Try the Fra-Como sauce - it's amazing!TIP: There's an ATM directly across from the restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Andrew R.
Reviews.Content: I'll make this quick.Food: Not any better than other North End places.Service: Not particularly fantastic at all. Nothing exceptional and a little rushed.Price: More or less typical.Cash only: That's a BIG problem. When you spend over $50 at dinner and have to run to the ATM because nobody tells you they're cash only, that's unacceptable.Sorry, Giacomo's. Your wait ain't worth it.

Reviews.Author: Fenny G.
Reviews.Content: I apologize in advance to 500+ reviewer. I don't usually give 1 star or write bad review unless it was really, really, really bad! Unfortunately this restaurant to be one of them that I would dare to give 1 star.Me and my brother (from oversea) were visiting Boston for a very short of time and we were very excited to have a chance to go to this restaurant on the very last day in Boston.  Before we went to this restaurant, we went to Neptune (only 2 mins away walking) to try their fresh oysters and very deliciouse lobster roll. After we finished eating at Neptune, we decided to go to this place. We realized that we had to wait for about 30-45 mins in line, under the cold and snowing weather (no problem) except that we got yelled by the waiter  because we were waiting behind the door. I wish that they asked us politely or put a sign written "please do not standing in front of the door even it's snowing or raining, thank you" instead of yelled at their costumers. After waited about 40 mins, We were seated by a lady who is very rude. We were already full at that time but but because of the 500+ review with 4.5 stars, we decided to go here, get one order of food, one glass of wine and shared it for both of us. The lady who took our order raised her voice and said "what do you want to eat for your dinner?" so I said we will share.Obviously, I was not very happy about the service. Our bill came out to be $24.8. If I were very mean, I would not give any tips but we decided give $5 tip which is a little bit more than 15% for a very bad service. I heard the lady who served us said "look at this (referred to the cash that we gave her and shake her head)"The pasta was ok. I would rather go to Maggiano'sI understand that Servers work on tips but in order to get a huge tip they also need to realize that they need to pay a price to serve their costumer nicely. Costumer are paying for their food and the service that is why they are sit down at the restaurant.Wont be next time for me and maybe you guys can go ahead eat here but please don't expect to have a good service. I don't want you to be disappointed as we did last time.From wikipedia (TIP/gratuity)A tip (also called a gratuity) is a voluntary extra payment made to certain service sector workers in addition to the advertised price of the transaction. Such payments and their size are a matter of social custom. In countries where tipping is expected (the United States for example), complicated unofficial standards and customs have developed over the exact percentage to tip, and what should and should not be included in this calculation. In other cultures where tipping exists it is more flexible and no specific assumptions of the tip amount exist.Some believe the custom of tipping helps to improve service, as workers may receive higher tips from satisfied customers. In the United States, some employers pay workers with the expectation that tips will make up the difference. The practice of tipping is controversial, with numerous criticisms. Some have criticized the inherent "social awkwardness" in transactions that involve tipping, the inconsistency of tipping for some services but not similar ones, and the irrationality of basing tips on price, rather than the amount and quality of service.

Reviews.Author: Liz D.
Reviews.Content: Let's start with the good part: The pasta is very good. Probably among the best lobster ravioli I've ever had.Now, why not give this place 5 stars? It's not because of the wait. The wait is annoying, for sure. But the wait isn't what deleted two stars off my review. This is: We finally get to the front of the line after about an hour, and a woman walks up and barks "Chef's table." She doesn't offer to walk us over to the table, so, all excited to finally eat, we walk in, expecting to see a couple of empty seats in this packed little restaurant. But the only empty seats are shoved into a tiny space at the bar, by the steamy kitchen, with a lovely view of...an industrial slicing machine of some sort. I was confused but not rude. I asked, "Oh, is this the chef's table?" Her response? "Yeah." Then, as my friend and I are squeezing into the seats: "If you don't want it, you can go. We got 5 other groups out there that'll take it."Um. Wait. That's not sassy. That's not joking with the customer who didn't even complain to you about the shit seats. That's just...mean. We stayed because we were starving, but between that little comment and the "hurry up" looks we kept getting from the servers as they counted out money two feet away on the counter...I don't know. I can't say it's worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Cherie C.
Reviews.Content: Alright.  Let's get this out of the way: the food was good.  Butternut squash ravioli was fresh and flavorful with a nice sweetness.  The broccoli was cooked a little longer than I prefer, but it was quality veggie with garlicky goodness.  The garlic bread was more like toast and had a lot of butter; I wouldn't recommend it.  The fresh bread on the table was quite good.On to the experience.  Isn't it cool when the waiter hassles you as you wait in the vestibule, figuring out who will go to the ATM for cash?  Don't you enjoy it when they rattle off bank names as though you are wasting his time even though no one else is waiting and there is an empty table?  Ain't it wacky when the server rushes you to make a decision and 'playfully' yanks your hair when you turn away from him to look at the menu board on the wall that he just directed you toward?  Me either.Isn't it quirky fun when he rushes you to order wine, then brings you a different wine, opening it as he says "this replaces that wine; they just didn't change the menu," never asking if the substitution is okay? Or when he stands by the table next to you to take your order, shouts it to the kitchen, then reaches through you to pour wine, never leaving his spot by the other table, balancing precariously with red wine?  Or how about the way he never gets close enough to the table (it is a tight fit, but really) to serve you, instead reaching toward you with plates, telling you to pass it to whomever ordered it?And oh, isn't it hilarious when he points to your last ravioli and says, "eat that" so that he can clear your place?Yeah, I didn't find any of it funny, either.  Our server was annoying and decidedly unfunny.  So who cares how the food tasted.  I'm going somewhere else.

Reviews.Author: Ina C.
Reviews.Content: Worth the wait.Got there at around 5:30pm on Saturday with a party of two and waited about half an hour!There are so many wonderful things about this restaurant. The most important, though, is the food (of course!).We had to go with the butternut squash ravioli with asparagus and proscuitto marscapone cheese sauce. When we discussed it, the woman at the table next to us leaned over and said, "It's delicious," pointing to her plate. I don't even like butternut squash all that much, but this dish was amazing. Slightly sweet, not to cheesy or salty, but just the right balance of everything - tastes, textures, etc. We also ordered the veal marsala with came with a side of spaghetti with marinara sauce. This was great, but not as good as the ravioli. It was extremely flavorful, and they didn't skip on that rich, unique marsala wine taste. We ordered it because it was only a dollar more than the chicken marsala, and we thought, "When is veal ever this cheap?" The veal was very tender and we liked this dish a lot.Another really fantastic thing about Giacomo's is the camaraderie you feel with all the people waiting in line with you but especially with the people you're dining with because the place is really that small. People had to move their chairs every time someone wanted to get by, elbows were hitting strangers' elbows and servers had to reach over diners to get food on the table. Sounds really annoying, but everyone seemed to have a positive attitude about it and just rolled with the punches. The last wonderful thing I have to say about this restaurant is that it's easy on the wallet. We paid $32 (not including tip) for two entrees and we were fully, fully satisfied. Tip: if you don't want to wait, get there BEFORE they open. Seriously. Another tip: every additional person in your group adds to your waiting time exponentially. Seriously. y = x^2. Because our group and the group in front of us had parties of two, we got seated before the 15 people in line ahead of us.But enjoy! It is seriously seriously worth it.

Reviews.Author: Sarah G.
Reviews.Content: Even getting here a little after 5pm on a Friday, isn't early enough to beat the line at this Italian place that since moving to Boston a few months ago, EVERYONE has told me try.Well after going here with Matt J. and my dad, I could see why, but I couldn't see why they didn't seem to have a sign on their door saying cash only!! With entrees on average around $20 each if not more, I was a little shocked to find that this place didn't take credit cards, so Giacomos, put up a sign, and if you already have one up, maybe it should be a little bigger, just like the portions of your food!!Yup, you will get A LOT of food here. It is definitely own and operated by a bunch of Italians too. We asked for bread, and in what anyone would think was stereotypical of Italian dialect, they responded with, "Umm, Mario could you please-a get-a them-a some more bread, eh?" My dad chuckled and was instantly excited that I had brought him to this place for his short weekend visit in Boston. He got their swordfish steak special with the BIGGEST CAPERS I've ever seen pretty much. And boy were those capers tasty, because I definitely found myself stealing a couple off of his plate! My dad was in heaven. The second he saw the word swordfish on their chalkboard menu from outside while we were waiting in line to get (since nope, they don't take reservations at this location, just the south end one) he was completely fine with waiting however long he needed to in order to get that swordfish.I got their giacomo sauce--all of their sauces are lobster based which I think is simply fantastic, and my pasta not only was piled up huge and high on my plate, but it was perfectly cooked. I wish I had gotten a couple more scallops in my dish though....The scallops were amazing! Way better than the shrimp that came in my dish, hence my yearning for some more of those thick scallops!And Matt got the salmon and sun dried tomatoes in tomato cream sauce. My sauce was better than his, but overall, the salmon and sun dried tomatoes actually had way more flavor than my dish, so overall his dish one our dish battle.

Reviews.Author: Nicole V.
Reviews.Content: Oh what to say that hasn't already been said... (probably nothing, but I'll just write a little blurb on my experience anyways...)our group of 5 arrived around 7 on a gorgeous Sunday.  I knew we were in for a wait, but with good company the line moved fast most the time.  When you're hungry, at the front of the line, and have to stop breathing through your nose so you're not salivating at every waft of delicious-ness floating out time feels like it stands still.Five of us got two appetizers (calamari and mussels), a bottle of wine, and entrees (most heavily weighted with seafood) for less than thirty bucks each.The food was outstanding and reasonably priced.  I went with the shrimp and scallops with giacomo/fra diavlo over linguine.  It was just the right amounts of spicy/delicious/creamy/lobster-y/heaven in my mouth.They also get bonus points in my book for not incredibly marking up bottles of wine.  A bottle that I bought last weekend at the store for $12 was $16.  Double bonus points were earned when they offered us extra bread to soak up the sauce that the mussels had been in.  They must have seen the lust in our eyes...(FYI - most of their red sauces are lobster based and you can REALLY taste it.  It's great news for us seafood lovers, but I'd be wary about coming here if you're unfortunate enough to be allergic to shellfish)

Reviews.Author: Josephine L.
Reviews.Content: I'll be honest. I came here because of the 4.5 star rating on Yelp. Considering how much I enjoyed 4-star North End restaurants, I figured I'd love this place.I liked it. But I didn't love it.Giacomo's is a casual, no frills Italian-American restaurant serving hearty pastas, hearty sauces and hearty wine. Yes, wine can be hearty. Especially when it's priced at an unpretentious $16/bottle. You can pretty much customize your pasta by choosing the sauce you want and everything comes out  piping hot on plates radiating steam like a geyser in Iceland. Or ash from a volcano. Also in Iceland.I had the homemade fusilli with lobster and shrimp in fra diavolo sauce, and the boyfriend had the black pepper pappardelle with broccoli rabe and sausage. Both were off their specials menu and just delicious. The fusilli was gorgeous to behold: thick, curly, long. The lobster and shrimp were generously apportioned and they don't hold back on the chili peppers in the sauce (thank God). The pappardelle was creamy and smooth, nicely offset by the crunch of the broccoli rabe. As with all dishes, the portions were quite generous.The big drawback to this place is the fact that they don't take reservations. Guys, you're not Coppa (thank God again). I get that North End restaurants are generally tiny, but plenty of other equally tiny places have discovered Open Table. This isn't a nightclub where you *want* to look happening by having people wait in long lines outside. So get on Open Table already.

Reviews.Author: Shachi B.
Reviews.Content: Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!Pumpkin tortellini!This place has THE BEST food evah!!! Fresh, flavorful and reasonably priced. Yes, the line usually wraps around the corner but hot damn, it's SO worth it! Thank you Giacomo's for enabling my pumpkin tortellini and peroni addiction. I love you.

Reviews.Author: Esther L.
Reviews.Content: I went with my friend during a super hot/muggy night. I don't recommend that, because we had to wait outside for 20 mins in the sweltering heat. But I'll have to say, the wait was worth it. The food is excellent. I went with other Yelpers' recommendations and got the calamari as an app. It was fried just right and tasted really fresh. I got the clam/mussel pasta dish (you can choose your own sauce: I chose the Giacomo's house sauce, which I really liked), and ended up taking half of it home because the portions are so big.Overall, a good experience. Would recommend going there. Remember that its cash only!

Reviews.Author: pete k.
Reviews.Content: I am not impressed with the North End.  I am very often completely disappointed in the restaurants, and cannot stand the fact that so many people flock to them thinking everything is soooo wonderful. If I can make the dish at home just as well - it likely is not worth the silly price that is charged at most places.  Anyway.. There are a few exceptions, and Giacomo's is certainly one of them. Its tough to get into, but on a bitterly cold, snowy night, you can get lucky. Or, you can get totally screwed and have to wait outside. We got lucky, and a table for 4 was available. I had a fra diavolo dish and it was as delicious as it was spicy  But really, as everyone here says.. Butternut Squash Ravioli. Butternut Squash Ravioli. Butternut Squash Ravioli. Its no joke. There's something wildly amazing in that dish. Service is friendly, prices arent bad and the wine is cheaaaap. Awesome.

Reviews.Author: Shuo W.
Reviews.Content: After trying many italian restaurants, I am still thinking that Giacomo's is the best!

Reviews.Author: Kathleen M.
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure I have ever actually entered this place sober. What's nice about the location of this place is there is a liquor store next door. You will be waiting in line for dinner, outside. Small place, and no reservations here!This place serves up some delicious food and is fantastically affordable. I always get pasta here, and I have to say, the Giacomo sauce is amazing! I typically get a dish with linguine, the yummy sauce, and a variety of seafood, including half a lobster. This dish is ~$15 (I think, but remember, not sober). Caesar salad is fantastically garlicky and huge enough to share. Wines are nice and quite affordable.Staff is sweet, but you'll be packed in like sardines, so choose your seat wisely, you're not getting up. One "table" for two is even set up at the bar--probably nice because you can watch them cook everything there. Giacomo's is definitely a place to hit when you are in North End, just be prepared for the wait and try not to get too upset when you are crammed in next to all of the other patrons, you're in for a delicious meal!

Reviews.Author: Jang David K.
Reviews.Content: I actually do not like Italian food that much.  I use to actually hate pasta and I hated eating out at a Italian restaurant....until I met Giacomo's.I want to first give you 6 stars instead of 5 because 5 stars does not fully capture your greatness.  You made me actually fall in love with Italian dishes and your pasta dishes actually changed my hatred towards pasta. Among the 5 star restaurants, for me, this is top 3.  Now, it seems like every time I'm passing North End, there is a long line outside Giacomo's...but when there was a snow storm with people  freezing to death, Giacomo's was the only restaurant with people still waiting outside to eat the food no matter what.  Now, this proves that Giacomo's is worth dying for (literally).Giacomo's, you just win in life.

Reviews.Author: Michael W.
Reviews.Content: Wait forever with other tourists (1 hour at 9pm on a Saturday). Get gawked at, pointed at, and lampooned by OTHER tourists. Eat great food. Pay cash. Walk out.Happy.

Reviews.Author: David C.
Reviews.Content: Is it true that Giacomo's has delicious Italian food for a reasonably affordable price? Yes. Does that mean it's worth waiting almost an hour and sweating your ass off at the two random seats they have next to the deep fryer? Absolutely not.Truth be told, my friend and I probably waited less time than most who come late to Giacomo's on a Saturday night (a little under an hour), but that wait was honestly one of the longest of my life, as we were forced to endure the noisome smell of the sewer on a sweltering summer evening. We managed to skip a couple of the larger parties ahead of us when a table for two opened up, but I think I would have waited a little longer had I known that we were going to be seated up on the bar between a sweaty fry-guy and a dirty dishrag. I don't even want to get into the multitude of health code violations this place is probably guilty of, so let's move onto the food, shall we?It was good. That's about all I have to say. The calamari I had for an appetizer and the pumpkin tortellini (in a sage mascarpone sauce) I had for my meal were definitely yummy, but I had trouble savoring them in that environment. My leftovers were actually more enjoyable, as I got to eat them in the comfort of my (air-conditioned) apartment.I do have to give the restaurant credit for its ability to turn tables, even if that means the servers have to rush around like crazy people drenched in perspiration. If I were to go back, I would probably go during the winter, and I would for damn sure be there before the doors open at 5.

Reviews.Author: Alicia L.
Reviews.Content: I didn't really care that I had to wait outside for nearly an hour for a table.  In the fall.  The cold, cold fall.  Okay, maybe I did...a little.  Hence only 4 stars.  Although there is a sort of camaraderie that develops among the lineholders, often standing in fierce opposition to meandering confused passers-by trying to get us to valet their cars or debating the wait.On the food alone, this place is easily a five-star experience.  I tried the butternut squash ravioli, which was incredible.  My Dining Companion had the special with all of the seafood thrown into it and loved it as well.  We both gorged on calamari, some of the best I've ever had...and I'm a girl who loves her calamari!  Great house wine too.The ambiance is cute and cozy (except for the narrow, dark Stairs of Death leading to the bathroom - maybe a bulb was out when I went), and the waitstaff is friendly, albeit a little eager to get you out of there.  But there is a line forming out there in the cold, if you haven't noticed.

Reviews.Author: Laura S.
Reviews.Content: We went to Boston recently (early March) and after having walked around North End, we decided to grab dinner at Giacomo's.  It was around 6PM on a Saturday and there was already a line out the door.  In fact, it had just begun to wrap around the block.My boyfriend and I had just finished a cannoli each, so at least we weren't starving while waiting in line, which surprisingly, wasn't too bad.  Although it looked daunting, the wait turned out to be only about one hour.  Unfortunately they do not take reservations, so standing in line is a must in order to eat there.The place itself is small.  Intimate would be an understatement.  Daily specials are written on a giant chalkboard on the wall.  The menu is simple (apps, salads, marsalas, parmigianas, pasta).  Our waitress wasn't rude or even brusque, actually she was friendly and would describe her service as very efficient.We ordered a small caesar salad ($5), small calamari ($7), the special of mussels, clams, half lobster over linguine with your choice of sauce ($20, and my boyfriend got the fra diavolo sauce), and the other special of shrimp and lobster meat over linguine with Giacomo's sauce (lobster based red with a touch of bechamel).  Can't remember the price on my pasta dish but it was under $20.Our salad and calamari arrived quickly.  Our lightly breaded calamari was great - wasn't greasy or oily.  The caesar was not bad, just a typical caesar salad.  It was nice to have some fresh, crunchy veggies though.Our pasta came out with perfect timing.  Two things warranted our jaw dropping reaction: the portion size and the heat.  The plate could hardly contain my boyfriend's pasta.  It was piled on, and the amount of pasta, mussels, clams and lobster were beyond generous.  There was a full half lobster nestled under the pasta (full half? Oops.  You know what I mean).  Although my food was served in more of a bowl-ish shape, it was still a ridiculously large amount (you can see the shrimp and chunks of lobster swimming beautifully in the whirlpool of pasta).  Both dishes were PIPING HOT.  As in wafting steam into our faces (look at my pics).  I LOVED that.  My biggest pet peeve with restaurants is lukewarm food.  Having that big, steaming bowl of seafood pasta placed before me was like seeing an apparition of Christ.  I heard beautiful choir music and felt like I was in heaven.  No joke.The sauces were amazing.  Homemade, bright, flavorful, fresh tomato sauces bathed the pasta, and the seafood was plentiful like sweet baby Jesus' love for me.Cash only, no dessert available.  Oh, and they DO offer take out as soon as they open.  The South End (Back Bay) location DOES offer reservations though.If you have the time to wait in line for their food, do so and be rewarded.

Reviews.Author: Rebecca R.
Reviews.Content: One of the best cheap restaurants in Boston.My favorite things are the plain red-sauced spaghetti that comes as a side with the grilled things and the calamari.My least favorite thing is that if you go with only one other person you will always end up stuck at the side of the bar, and one of those seats is right under the air vent, so if anyone's allergic to cold, you'd be well advised to bring a blanket. Along with cash, of course.Second least favorite is either the wait, or practically being kicked out before you're half finished so the wait doesn't get even longer for everyone else... but it's worth it.Sometimes there are call girls in line.I like listening to those conversations best.To Whom It May Concern: Please send/take more call girls to eat here.

Reviews.Author: Tee D.
Reviews.Content: The wait sucked but it was all worth it. Great food and great staff!

Reviews.Author: Michelle S.
Reviews.Content: My friends took me here for my  birthday and it was a great time.  But...THE MAJORITY OF THEIR MENU IS SHELLFISH AND SEAFOOD.  I happen to be allergic to shellfish and lots of seafood....right...As so many of the other reviewers explained, you have to go into the restaurant one at a time.  This is great when you're already sitting down, but a pain in the ass when you're outside.  The place is really tiny and I felt a little claustrophobic.  We  had a group of 8 and we were squished a bit around 2 smallish tables, which wasn't ideal.So we all sit down and get our menus and the waiter (who was really cool, by the way) starts explaining the sauces.  Apart from the pesto, it was shellfish fiesta.  My friends decided it would be a smart idea to tell the waiter about my allergies.  He looks at me, asks if I'm the birthday girl, I say "yes," so he asks me, "and you picked this place??"  to which I said, in a really small voice, "noooo?"  They were really great there though and I loved our waiter; he was hilarious and super friendly.My friends did feel really bad about the seafood thing, but I had never been to the north end before, despite being a local girl, and they knew I really wanted to try it out.  None of the other yelp reviews mentioned the shellfish fiesta, so I decided to make it a major part of my review.Anyways, I ordered the chicken, broccoli, ziti in garlic sauce and it was AMAZING!  oh my god it was the most fresh, crispy broccoli, tender pasta, tasty chicken, and delicious sauce.  Everyone else I was with was equally impressed with their meals.At the end of the night, they brought a chocolate cake out for me and the entire restaurant sang me "Happy Birthday."  I couldn't stop grinning.I highly recommend this place.  The only reason it's not getting 5 stars is because of how tiny and claustrophobic it is.

Reviews.Author: Jerry B.
Reviews.Content: This was the first place we tried when I visited Boston for PAX East.Looked on yelp and seen so many good reviews here.  Sadly I was very disappointed! I'm not going to take long to talk about the negatives but here we go:Venue:  Place was small and cramped.  I like to enjoy my meal with enough elbow room and breathing space.  This place was like a sardine can.  Other guest were literally a head turn away.  I hear there conversation and they could here mine.  We had a table for 3 and it was just too small.   Food:  BIG LET DOWN.  I ordered one of the specials which had Lobster with pasta and The Giacomo's sauce.  I have to say the sauce was good and the lobster meat was decent but the dish as a whole sucked ars!  I paid for a $28 plate to have my pasta way over Al dente.  The pasta is what ties the dish together.  Without it, it would have been just a Lobster dish with Gaicomo's sauce.  This was a big let down!Service:  Was ok nothing spectacular.  So the reason I actually gave it two stars was because of the Calamari and the fact that they served Canada Dry Ginger Ale!  Any place that serves ginger ale gets a star automatically!!! Ginger Ale in a cold class with ice.....refreshing.   If it wasn't for those 2 things, this place wouldn't have never gotten any stars!  I'm sorry but this was not all thats hyped up to be.....I should have went to Rino's!

Reviews.Author: Karyn V.
Reviews.Content: Ah, Giacomo's the place where all the lemmings and sheep of Boston go.  I lived less than a block from this place on Hanover Street for 10 years (moving out in 2011), and I can't tell you how much this place drives me crazy.  This place does live up to its reputation as far as having consistent, fairly inexpensive food, that is decent.  But that's it, it is just decent, never bad, never great, usually not very good even.  Their seafood dishes are I think the big attraction, and they like I said are just ok.I don't get why people line up outside of it in the dead of winter while it is snowing.  It is not that good.  It is not even close to great.  There are so many restaurants in the neighborhood that are as good.  And on Valentine's Day, it is absolutely ridiculous how many people wait outside, forever, in the snow.  They don't take reservations.  CASH ONLY.Seriously, do yourself a favor and try Assagio, Antico Forno, or Trattoria di Monica's, which have a similar price point, and will take a reservation.  I lived here for 10 years, I know what I am talking about.  I would give them one star because of how much I dislike the place, but I think that is unfair and their food is not horrible, nor a rip-off.If you must try Giacomos, go to the one in Back Bay.  All comments below apply to that location.  Their food is better, and the line is shorter.  You can make a reservation.  They take checks there. There is more parking and a valet at the BB location too.  It is also more spacious, so you are more comfortable and less rushed.  You can get dessert at this restaurant too.One note, they do take-out here, so that is probably your best option.  I have gotten take out a few times, when I felt like some decent seafood pasta to eat at home.  Like I said, the food is decent.  It wasn't great.  For take-out, it is expensive compared to other options like Express.

Reviews.Author: Eunice K.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's was recommended to me by several people that found out I was visiting Boston. Located on Hanover St with all the other cute Italian restaurants in North End.. it's hard to miss since there is usually a long line going out the door! Even though me and my friends came on a random Thursday, it was NO exception.. and we endured a good 30-40 min before being seated. Basically Giacomo's specialty is in pasta and seafood. The menu gives you the freedom of choosing the fish, noodles, and sauce that can be altered to your liking. I ordered the "Swordfish and Tuna Pieces in a Pesto Cream Sauce" ($15) - except I switched out the pesto sauce with red tomato sauce. My dish was SO disappointing. Noodle to fish ratio was too big - not enough fish!! AND my fish was dry.. (I know sword fish is a dry fish.. but nonetheless.. it was dry). And everything was SO bland. I used my salt shaker with EVERY bite. That's pretty sad! Might have been due to the LACK of sauce on the dish. I was presented with a big pile of noodles for dinner :( My friend ordered the "Salmon and Sundried Tomatoes in a Tomato Cream Sauce" ($15) - pretty much the same problem. Way too much noodles, not enough sauce, and too bland. We put the salt shaker between us and shared in between bites. My Bostonian friend did a little better when he ordered the Frutti Di Mare ($19). This had a nice variety of seafood including shrimp, scallops, calamari, and mussels. However, he also got the red tomato sauce and suffered the blandness :( One big mistake we all made that night was that we ordered the regular red tomato sauce instead of the spicy red (diavolo) sauce. We all suffered the BLANDNESS! Plus I really dislike the cramped environment and the way the waiters really try to turn the tables by pushing service. We were rushed to order then some of our plates were taken away before we really finished. But both my friends told me that Giacamo's is usually VERY good and today must have just been a off night. Plus we got a bottle of wine for 16 bucks. Can't complain about that :)

Reviews.Author: Tiffany W.
Reviews.Content: The food here is so authentic, for a brief moment between bites, I thought I was dining in a trattoria off the rugged coast of the Italian Riviera. Giacomo's is a cosy little restaurant tucked away between a flower store and a sandwich shop but you can't miss it because of the line that begins forming outside as soon as the doors open for dinner. However, the food is definitely worth the wait! I ordered the butternut squash ravioli in mascarpone cheese sauce and the calimari. They were both AH-mazing! I was extremely impressed with how speedy and attentive the servers were. The owner, Tony, was constantly running back and forth between the kitchen and the front of the house making sure all his guests were taken care of. Despite the ever growing line out the door, they never rushed us through our meal. Giacomo's earns 5 stars all around from me. Highly recommended! Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Laura K.
Reviews.Content: When one sister turned 25 yeterday, the fam' decided it was time to brave the crowds and have a go at Giacomo's. All-in-all -- considering my frequent consumption of Italian in the 'hood and the rave reviews I'd heard over the last two years of living in the North End -- Giacomo's was just alright for me.Spacials and Facials:Eight tables crammed into a space bigger than a breadbox but smaller than a school bus, situated contiguously with the fully-exposed kitchen offering a nice view of the action and complementary steam facials with each fresh pot of pasta. Mood and Food:Friendly, friendly, friendly! and free-flowing with the water pitchers -- seriously, china buffet style. Our waitress was all about the Giacomo's experience, which I may have appreciated more had I waited in the cold for two hours. The food was good, but not great. My chicken parm was tough and lacking much flavor, while my sister's pesto dish seemed to indicate a restaurant-wide shortage of pesto.Wrap-up:We showed up at 4:45 and had our pick of tables. Giacomo's was inexpensive ($120 for a bottle of Santa Margherita, two apps and four entrees) and adequate, but certainly not somewhere I'd wait two hours to eat.

Reviews.Author: Doris K.
Reviews.Content: Don't go anywhere else! This is the place to be for Italian. On any night, the line is usually out the door. If you can I would suggest having a friend do the waiting while the rest of the group goes and has coffee or drinks, I know that sounds kind of mean. This place is small, maybe ten tables at most. The staff, depending on the day that they've had, is friendly sometimes mostly rushed. The frutti de mar is out of this world if you like seafood. Everything is reasonably priced for the North End.I plan to bring all my friends that visit Boston, here....IT'S WORTH THE WAIT.

Reviews.Author: Lauren F.
Reviews.Content: Holy garbage i JUST remembered this place existed and how phenomenalogisticasticly wonderful it was.  I had some sort of butternut squash mouth heaven.It is the tiniest most packed restaurant i have ever been in so you have to be willing to stand in line outside waiting for a table and then be willing to rest your elbows on your neighbor's table while you eat.  The food is worth your willingness.Mouth heaven.

Reviews.Author: Kimberly B.
Reviews.Content: The wait is so worth it!There was a long line when we arrived at 8:30pm last night, but the wait wasn't as bad as I thought it would be. My Bostonian friends told me that the wait is normal and expected, and people are willing to stand outside in the pouring rain to eat here! The restaurant is super small and you're pretty much rubbing shoulders with all your neighbors, so this is not the place to go to if you want to ask a girl out, break up with your boyfriend, or disclose horrific news to your party member.We ordered the lobster ravioli, butternut squash ravioli, and the chicken and shrimp pesto pasta. All the dishes were tasty, but my ultimate favorite is echoed by all the other reviewers on this restaurant - the butternut squash ravioli is to DIE FOR. This is probably the best italian food I've ever had in my life so far.

Reviews.Author: Sameer N.
Reviews.Content: This place is definitely not 4.5 stars sweetie pies.  This place deserves a 3 at best.  You guys probably love the Olive Garden too.  Look, the food can be spectacular at times but sometimes it's iffy.  I've had some creamy raviolis up in this joint and then I've had some boring chicken parm with a spicy linguini.  I guarantee you there's better italian places in the city.  Artu is pretty banging (that's in the North End).  There's two locations for Giacomos and both are WHAAATTTEEEVVVVSSSSS.The place gets crowded and seating is limited in the south end.  You can get surrounded by people talking about complete nonsense or their soap operas for lives and it gets annoying.  Then again, you can toss your bluetooth headset on and dine alone and talk about stuff like you're really important and piss everyone off as well.  It's tasty but not the best.

Reviews.Author: Esther W.
Reviews.Content: I take visitors to Giacomo's every time they are in town. My two friends from NYC who visit me often specially request Giacomo's when they come. And none of my guests have every been disappointed! True, the tourists do flock there (probably thanks to Rachael Ray) but there is a reason for it and that doesn't turn me away from taking my own tourist friends there!First, best fried calamari I have ever had. Ever.  The butternut squash ravioli is definitely one of the favorites and a must-try. But I always always get the Frutti de Mare (clams, mussles, scallops, shrimp, calamari) over linguini with the Fra Diovolo sauce (the red sauce with a spicy kick). I think that is their best sauce, although their lobster-based Giacomo's sauce is good too, the fra diovolo is the most flavorful. And there is always a special that gives you a 1/2 lobster with mussels/clams over linguini for about the same price, which is amazing too. The flavors are fantastic, the portions large, the food fast and consistently delicious and all much more reasonably priced than other restos in the north end.And, wine and beer are cheap.There are a few downsides -- the potential for a long wait outside in line (which sucks when it's cold) because it's quite small and they don't take reservations... and cash only. But clearly these deterrents have not kept me from returning again... and again...

Reviews.Author: Eric L.
Reviews.Content: Awesome Italian food.  Probably one of the best I've ever had.  Went for their Frutti Di Mare + a bottle of wine, enough to feed 3 or 4 !!!

Reviews.Author: mike r.
Reviews.Content: I only went here once and was very dissappointed. We waited in the tres rigeur line outside in the rain (yes, I'm an idiot) with friends who just HAD to go here. Once inside we were crammed into this table and could barely move my arms to eat. I had the swordfish al fredo over linguine. It was fine, but nothing spectacular and the fish chunks were the size of dice, so you know it came from tips, condsiderably cheaper than steaks. Pricey and noisy and the help acted as though they were doing you a favor just being there. I'm sorry to disagree with all the other posters but I just see an over hyped North End tourist trap. Take me to Federal Hill any day.ps. I became violently ill on the way home and just barely made it to the latrine. Was the sickest I have ever been for the next 2 days.

Reviews.Author: Debby L.
Reviews.Content: You have GOT to be kidding me. This place is insanely small, insanely packed, and insanely delicious. On our seafood craze, we had to hit Giacomo's in Little Italy. Although one of my friends was surprised that they have NO MEATBALLS in an Italian restaurant, he was soon compensated by the amazing seafood and side dishes. We ordered the House Special with lobster, mussels, clams, shrimp, and pasta. uhhhhh...the menu said that thing was for TWO people. IT IS NOT. It can feed at least 4 people. The lobster is ginormous and sits on top of a bed of mussels, clams, and shrimp...which sat on top of a layer of angel hair pasta. Everything was marinated in an amazing Fri Diavilo sauce. [it isn't spicy, it just has a nice kick]. You must order this dish to share! It is so good! We kept small dishes to put shells in, and the waiter was great at clearing the dishes as soon as they were done to help clear room at the table.Since we THOUGHT the special was for two people, and we had 4...we also ordered the fried calamari and eggplant parmigiana.The calamari was tasty and crunchy. Great appetizer to start off with...if you can handle more food. The eggplant parmagiana was the best I've ever had. It was made perfectly, and the cheese just melts in your mouth. There is no room in the restaurant. You must come dressed to stand outside for at least an hour, no rsvps, and then you must take off everything when you get inside. The tables are small so I recommend just eating straight out of the big plates instead of getting your own small one. You are also likely touching the person behind you or next to you. We got quite a number of exclamations when our special came out. I was so incredibly stuffed, but somehow, we managed to finish off all 3 plates.  I was a little peeved that the server did not warn us about the amounts of food we would get...but we made it our mission to finish everything...and we succeeded nicely I thought.Also, the artwork is fantastic in the restaurant. Make sure to take a look around and enjoy that as well.

Reviews.Author: James A.
Reviews.Content: I think you can tell a lot about a restaurant by what they leave out. Giacomo's doesn't do bookings. It doesn't do credit cards. It doesn't do fine linens on its tables, or expensive looking menus. It doesn't do fancy service. And damn, it's going to make you wait ages in a line outside to get in (Saturday night, 7pm, we waited an hour and a half to get a table for two).But: what Giacomo's does do is great food.Appetizers were fantastic: calamari was cooked to perfection, and the ingredients of a caprese salad were fresh and flavorsome. Of the mains, a lobster fusili off the specials board was amazing (and huge), but the lobster ravioli (on the regular menu) was not as good as it sounded. From the other reviews, I'd suggest if you're after ravioli go for the butternut squash.With the wait, the feeling like we were rushed, and the not-quite-great ravioli, it's only getting 4. But it's definitely worth doing. Get there early, and prepare to feast for a very reasonable sum!

Reviews.Author: Rianne D.
Reviews.Content: Was it worth waiting 1 1/2 hours in 43 degree windy weather for a place that takes no reservations and is cash only? Absolutely, YES!Not being a seafood pasta fan, I'd have to say that Giacomo's (or as the locals sound JACK-A-MOES) has the best seafood pasta ever!Definitely try any of the following:Zuppa di pesce (for two) - shrimp, scallops, calamari, claims, mussels and lobster over linguine with the giacomo sauce for $55. Add the bottle of wine for an additional $10.Butternut squash ravioli with asparagus and cream sauce for $15.Homemade fusilli with lobster and shrimp in the Giacomo sauce for $26Toss in any bottle of wine for $17...deal!!Only advice I have - do not try to go there with a party bigger than 4, if you can avoid it. It is that tiny. At least I didn't have to wait in the snow. Cuz that would really suck.

Reviews.Author: Nate H.
Reviews.Content: Well, i didn't know how i felt when my macho Italian waiter yelled at me when I wasn't sure which appetizer I wanted, and I REALLY didn't know how i felt when he poked my girlfriend's arm with her plate from across another table... but man that pumpkin tortellini was good, and enough to eat for lunch the next day. The place is, without question, authentic.  I ordered two "beer of the week", and after placing my order I see my waiter waving beer bottles in the air from across the room attempting to tell me that there was only one "beer of the week" left. This left us in a predicament, and as this waiter obviously had no patience - he decided what our second beer would be, and still charged us the "beer of the week" price. Nevertheless, the beer was good - especially the special, an organic porter -, both meals were more than solid [the second meal was the lobster ravioli] and well worth the unconventional service.

Reviews.Author: Ashlee C.
Reviews.Content: Overall, I have been thoroughly unimpressed with most of my restaurant visits in the North End, with the exception of Giacomo's.  It is the only restaurant that I will continuously go back to in the North End.I will preface the rest of this review by saying that I fucking hate lines, waiting, and become a cranky-ass bitch when forced to endure hunger.  Thus, I only come to this restaurant after 9 on weekdays or around 10 on weekends to avoid the massive line.  I have only had to deal with a 10 minute wait so far and I have been 4 times. On to the food.  I am a complete sucker for ravioli and I can tell you that Giacomo's makes a mean one.  Sausage filled, Lobster filled, Spinach filled, they are all really good.  I also had a chicken gnocci dish here with mushrooms that was very tasty.I will be straight forward with you though, the way the waitresses rush the customers when there is no line outside pisses me off immensely.  I go at off-peak hours and they still push me in and out in a half hour.  I like to enjoy wine with my food, but at Giacomo's I never have time for a second glass.  That crazy gaggle of women they have working the floor really know how to turn a table like no other.  At 10:30 sharp, they start rolling the place up so they can sit down and cash out.  Once this happens, you better head for the door before your waitress starts personally force feeding you the remainder of your dish.  If the raviolis weren't so good, Giacomo's would be a 3 for the abysmal ambiance and service.  Not worth the line, but the food is consistently good, well priced, and worth a try if you do not have to wait!

Reviews.Author: Kelly H.
Reviews.Content: Why oh why do people wait in such a horrendously long line in 90 degree weather or freezing temperatures in the winter months? Word of advice before coming here. Bring a tent to camp out like you're buying Bruins tickets. Oh and cash because we all know the deal with North-end restaurant owners if you get my drift...Its great that their dishes are not over priced but there is nothing special about their special sauce. Food is good but not great. But if you're hungry from waiting in line for a couple of hours anything will taste phenomenal. 0_o

Reviews.Author: Skip W.
Reviews.Content: Don't think I can say it any better then the rest. IT's AMAZING!!! Guess not having a point of sale system keeps this place ol'school. Cash only and delicious.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie H.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is amazing. I am certainly not the first to make this statement, but I'll say it anyway. I took my family, who were visiting from western Pennsylvania, and my boyfriend here this past weekend. Our group included myself, my sister and mom, who are always up for trying something new, and my dad and my man, neither of whom like the city or like waiting and would really rather just stick to what they know and love. Our wait was about 40 minutes on a busy Saturday night (near impossible for the mensfolk). We were fortunate that we had such a lovely weather evening while outside, however I will mention that the line was formed right along a sewage grate.....pew! Once inside I think the boys' tensions eased up considerably with the amazing food smells. The cozy 10-table atmosphere contributed to our close family outing....very casual, borderline noisy (which was totally our thing, being loud part-Italians ourselves). Our waiter was a local Bostonian, complete with Southie drawl and macho funny guy demeanor. He was quick and efficient but provided awesome, thorough service and kept us laughing throughout the whole meal. Now food....We started with a large order of calamari, which is lightly breaded and fried with hot pepper rings, was the most tender and delicious calamari I've ever had! My mom usually swears off calamari because of what it does to her stomach, but couldn't help herself with Giacomo's appetizer. The large order was perfect for our party of 5 as a little tide-me-over. It came while we were still deliberating over the menu which helped ease our grumbling bellies and unsure minds (like many other reviewers said, it was so hard to pick just one meal for each of us!) We ordered 1) clams and mussels fra diavlo, a perfectly spicy marinara (the heat can be customized) with super fresh shellfish over nice firm linguini noodles, 2) two orders of shrimp and scallops with Giacomo sauce, a light lobster and tomato cream sauce that was neither too heavy or too wimpy, also over linguini, 3) veal marsala, super tender meat , not too heavily breaded with proscuitto and the most fragrant and delicious marsala sauce (served with linguini marinara on the side), and 4) lobster ravioli, the perfect sized portion with an amazingly light garlic and (really fragrant!) basil cream sauce. There's nothing any of us would have changed about our entrees The flavors were perfect and there was plenty for each of us to share. My dad, who came into the restaurant wanting lame-o spaghetti and meatballs (which Giacomo's doesn't make regularly) so as not to be difficult, was blown away by the food, saying he'd never tasted Italian food like this before. He also didn't complain about the prices, and this man ALWAYS complains about restaurant prices, especially in Boston. My mom, who is full Italian, said she hadn't tasted food this delicious since before her nanna passed away. And my boyfriend, who can be a picky brat of an eater and who also won't usually put a bite of seafood in his mouth, sampled all of the entrees and said there wasn't anything he wouldn't want to gorge on. My sister and I, the least picky of the group, of course loved every bit of it, including the crowded sidewalks getting to the restaurant, and we weren't even too bothered by the sewage grate or the wait outside. All in all, a kick-ass place. Well worth the wait. I'll be back, even if it's by myself!

Reviews.Author: Danielle A.
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying this: If you hate waiting to get in somewhere to eat, if you have severe food allergies,refuse to carry cash, or if you absolutely despise small, crowded spaces no matter what and in all circumstances - Giacomo's is not for you. Having said that, our experience tonight at Giacomo's was - in true Bostonese - freakin' awesome.We arrived at about 5:00-5:15 or so and got in line. We knew from reading the Yelp reviews and having walked by several times in the past that this was normal, and we ended up waiting until about 6:30 before we were seated. The restaurant itself only seats maybe 20-30 people in a very cramped area. Normally this would have lost points with me, but truthfully it ended up lending to the charm. Because of the open kitchen set-up and the casual attitude of the staff (our waiter - Tony - asked us "What do you kids want for supper?" when he took our order), it almost feels like you're at your aunt or grandmother's house for dinner. I come from a large family, so this did not phase me at all; it felt almost relaxed and normal to be in that atmosphere. The menu is simple - appetizers, entrees, a simple wine list, one beer (right now they're serving Sam Adams Summer), and some soft drinks. No dessert - but truthfully with all the Italian pastry options in the North end, it's not necessary. Besides - once you eat at Giacomo's, you'll understand why they do not have dessert. They KNOW they have a line outside, and dessert/coffee only makes people loiter. I've never seen any restaurant turn over a table as quickly as they do after people clear out to get the next people in. Never mind the fact that your food comes out pronto - hot, quick, and delicious. It's almost like a fancy Italian dinner diner in terms of speed & service from the staff.Anyways - the food. The freaking food. It was amazing overall. To start, we ordered the fried calamari because the Yelp reviews raved about it. The calamari is served with a side of red sauces and some fried/battered peppers (jalapenos?) mixed in. Our order of friend calamari had minimal tentacles and was slightly overcooked (but not too rubbery) which was awesome for me because I like my calamari slightly overcooked and HATE the tentacles. The sauces was hot and it was a perfect compliment to the calamari. I would say it was *good* calamari, but truthfully I worry the Yelp reviews are overhyping it.  Then it was on to the entrees. My husband ordered their Fruiti de Mare with the Giacomo house sauce and I partook in one of their specials: Gnocchi stuffed with roasted red pepper & goat chese cooked with chicken, mushrooms & basil in a tomato marscarpone sauce. I can't speak to my husband's dish (but you can read his review - he's Steve A.) but I will say that mine was phenomenal. The sauce was absolutely to die for; the sweetness of the marscarpone is a great balance to the tomatoes. The gnocchi was about perfect and unlike some restaurants I've been to - they did not skimp on it at all. Too often I've seen restaurants skimp on the gnocchi when they serve it up with other things mixed in with it. There was a good amount of basil without overpowering the dish, and the flavors were just out of this world. Side note - they do offer bread with what tasted like a high-end olive oil on the table. The bread itself is your average crusty bread. One other tip (and why I say this is not for those with severe food allergies): There didn't seem to be a ton of wiggle room on the menu  - what's on the menu is what you get with the only switch out option being if you get seafood entrees you can pick your own sauce - and when your food comes out they immediately dust it with grated parmesan cheese. There was a sign someplace that said something about inform your server if you have an allergy, but with some of the folks I know having severe allergies to one thing or another - I wouldn't risk it if you do. Just my thought, I could be wrong though.Anyways - overall this place was awesome. I felt comfortable, right at home, I loved our waiter Tony, I loved how the staff interacted with each other and the patrons, and I absolutely adored the food there. I could not think of a place that I would willing wait 75-90 minutes for on a second occasion, but I would ABSOLUTELY wait that long for Giacomo's again. No question.

Reviews.Author: Byron B.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is by far the best Italian Food I've ever eaten in my life. Period.While the wait can sometimes be a bit long (expect at least an hour), and you're going to be standing outside (so plan accordingly to weather), but it is absolutely, most definitely worth the wait. Also, they do not accept credit cards so make sure you have cash.The food is nothing short of astounding. Caesar salads can be split, and make a great way to start a meal. The wine list is great, and very cheap too!If you're in the North End and do not stop by Giacomo's, you've seriously made a big mistake.

Reviews.Author: Sarah W.
Reviews.Content: A destination in it's own right, Giacomo's is a star of Boston's North End. There's a lot to cover, so I'll break it down for you:1) The waitYes, you will have to wait. On a recent weekend, I arrived with a group of five at 5:30pm. We were inside in about an hour. That seemed typical of most parties, through groups of two and three were able to sit a bit faster. It was chilly, but definitely worth it. We met some very interesting fellow diners in line--great bonding experience with strangers! I suggest picking up something to enjoy while you wait, maybe a pastry from one of the North End's great bakeries.2) The foodThis is what really matters! The food at Giacomo's is pure heaven. I was a dedicated Daily Catch fan until this trip, and I do not hesitate to say that Giacomo's is better. I'm not sure which was fresher--the pasta or the seafood! Here's what we ate:-Pumpkin tortellini-sweet nuggets of pumpkin in a firm but light dough. The sage sauce is killer.-Lobster ravioli- salty-sweet chunks of whole lobster meal bound together with strands of mozzarella. The garlic cream sauce is rich, not sharp.-Seafood pasta (mussels, clams, scallops) with white sauce- I make a fine white sauce myself. This is better. The tangyness of white wine and depth of roasted garlic draw out that hint of ocean flavor in the seafood. Simple, but perhaps the best thing on the menu--a meal that dances.-Fried calamari- Tender and juicy.3) The atmosphereNot exactly a leisurely dinner. Between your own hunger and the line outside, you may devour your dinner whole. It's okay, no judgement passed. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable, happy to get extra sauce, bread, or water, or just to chat about how awesome the food is. They keep things moving without hurrying the patrons. The stairs to the bathroom are precarious, hot, and loud, but it was clean and comfortable.4) The tips-Don't eat the bread as soon as you get in! You'll need that room for your dinner, and it's much better used to soak up the last bits of delicious sauce from your plate.-Don't get the Parmesan cheese on top of your dish. A matter of personal choice, I recognize, but the quality of the sauce is far better than the quality of the cheese. -Share with friends. That way, you can try more deliciousness!-Have dessert first. Something to eat in line, and I promise you, you will not have room after dinner.

Reviews.Author: Ashley H.
Reviews.Content: It was well worth the wait.  It had a slow start with the odd waiter, but quickly exceeded my expectations.  You must try the butternut squash ravilio

Reviews.Author: Monica F.
Reviews.Content: Our last dinner before flying back to California... We had to experience an Italian dinner. Giacomo's was perfect for that goal.Such a homey, romantic, and cozy atmosphere...and you've got some hands down Italian servers (well, most of them) with the accent and everything. It's amazing. You enter and you salivate with the smell of garlic, butter and herbs being sauteed in the open kitchen bar, facing the diners.The tables are too close to each other as the space is kind of small. We could actually overhear 2 first dates as we dined. One was cool, one was really nervous. It was funny. The tables were wonderfully set with plates and glasses and utensils. We were greeted right away...and as we sat, our server (Italian lady with a thick accent) went over the menu, the specials, the types of sauces in like.... 2 seconds. Super fast... She zoomed right in. It felt really rushed. But..we didn't really care as the menu was pretty much self explanatory unless you're a ding dong. The specials are posted on the left board, and the daily full menu, posted on the right board.We ordered:*Frutti Di Mare: mussels, clams, calamari, scallops, squid with Giacomo red sauce. Wow. This is really good. the pasta, al dente...and the sauce..thick and creamy...On the menu, it included shrimp on the pasta, but i didn't find any shrimp on my plate. I found squid instead. The serving is huge, I couldn't kill it all... However...the trip from North End back to the hotel...with all our jump shots on the way home, and the walk.... I killed it anyway... savage style. with coffee stirrers as chopsticks... it was tough. so i shifted  using my hands.  I know. gross. BUT really worth it.  i was drooling for it. And i was lazy to call for a fork at 4am. I paired this with their cheapest chardonnay..and it worked.*Spinach Porpadelle: This was on the Specials board. It came with grilled pork tenderloin and portabello mushrooms in a plum tomato sauce with crumbled goat cheese. I said goat cheese. Any pasta with goat cheese is already an Oomph. The pork tenderloin was cooked to perfection. and the mushrooms.. oooh..just flavorful. but not overpowering. Being that it was Valentine's Eve, we were given a long stemmed rose..each!. How nice...Good to get a flower after braving a room filled with "couples".

Reviews.Author: Amy B.
Reviews.Content: I have liked, maybe even loved, every dish I've eaten at Giacomo's. My favorites are the homemade fusilli with lobster fra diavolo (often a special), the butternut ravioli, and the calamari (fried pepperoncini!). The entrees are mostly around $15-20, and the wine list includes many choices at the same price point.And now the usual Giacomo's spiel: To avoid lines, consider eating early or late. Remember to bring cash (there's an ATM in the convenience store across the street if you forget). They don't serve dessert, but God's own cannoli shop, Mike's, is right across the street, so make haste.

Reviews.Author: Chris S.
Reviews.Content: Prepare for the legendary line.Once we came here on a Saturday and waited in line in 25-degree weather for over TWO HOURS. That's how crazy this place gets.Since then, we've learned to come here on slightly less chaotic occasions (weekdays, and dine either really early or really late).I had the best risotto I've ever had here. It was a seafood risotto - white, creamy, with chunks of scallop, and a heavy accent of dry white wine, for $25. It was on their seasonal menu, and I never saw it again :(I love the texture of their linguini - I don't know how restaurants do it, but they always get the perfect al dente bite, and this place is no exception. Somehow, they are able to make their linguini so that you don't get sick from eating massive amounts of carbs - that is truly the mark of an excellent Italian restaurant when you can gorge yourself without feeling sick at all (compare to Olive Garden, hahaha).I like their red sauce, and their red+spicy sauce (don't remember the actual names) - try their big seafood pasta that has everything in it once (it's enough to feed 2 people), and then in following visits pick and choose the type of seafood you want (shrimp only, shrimp+mussels...etc.). I've always thought their mussels are subpar, but that may be just me. I've consistently thought their pesto sauce is the worst sauce they have there.Their CALAMARI is fantastic - the tomato sauce that comes with it goes extremely well with the fried calamari, and the peppers are the kicker that pushes the dish over from excellent to mind-blowingly excellent. We've continually ordered a serving per 2 people, because one for 4 is simply not enough - everything is going to be gone in less than 10 minutes -_____-I've tried their butternut squash ravioli, but found it to be too sweet for my taste. It almost felt like eating dessert...imo.Funny story: Once we were waiting in line here and a couple left the restaurant. About 30 seconds later, the manager came out of the restaurant and yelled after the couple, "THANKS FOR BEING SO GENEROUS!" The couple came back to the restaurant, threw $5 at the manager, and left again. Waiting in line that day wasn't so boring that day due to the unscheduled excitement, hahaha.This restaurant is really 5/5, but one star off for the extremely longggg wait all the time. I must say though, it's a pretty good way to meet people - during the times I've waited in line, I've spoken to tourists from Greece, law students from Harvard Law, bankers from the Financial District, and an elderly couple celebrating their 45th anniversary. What gets more diverse than this?! :)

Reviews.Author: Meg T.
Reviews.Content: As a Hawaii born and raised, Southern California current resident, I hate the cold, aka anything lower than 60 degrees.  BUT I waited, outside Giacomo's, for an HOUR in 37 degree weather.  And boy was it worth it.My sister and I went during Halloween weekend, the first Nor'easter of the season (which was the 3rd time I've ever seen snow fall in my life), and stared forlornly into the windows which were steaming up from being so warm at the delicious food.  I literally was staring down a 5 year old korean kid willing him to eat faster so we could get a table.I loved the lobster sauce with the homemade fuscilli with lobster pieces in it.  DELICIOUS.  The appetizer we had was the creamy buffata with tomatoes and balsamic top, a little twist on the caprese salad.Yes it's cash only, yes there's not reservations, yes, it's crowded, but it's worth it.

Reviews.Author: Adam C.
Reviews.Content: I wouldn't recommend waiting half your life for a table but if you happen to get out of work early or something you could do a lot worse than stopping in for delicious Italian food at Giacomo's. My personal favorites include the calamari (crisp and nowhere near as greasy as many others') and linguine with the namesake Giacomo sauce. This ranks very high on the best sauces in Boston list. Cream and lobster broth along with acidic punch make for an absurdly rich and savory final product that is well worth the caloric guilt. Speaking of guilt, the serving sizes are immense. I'll be damned if anyone has ever left here hungry in all the years they've been open. I don't know if he's the owner or not but the old Italian man that served most of the tables there is a total class act and straight up hilarious. The only downsides are cash only and the absurd wait for a table, so much so that I wouldn't even think about coming on the weekend...although they do offer take out so that's a slightly better option if you're in dire need of a massive plate of pasta.

Reviews.Author: Lana N.
Reviews.Content: We got the last seat in the house before they closed up shop. The shop owner didn't seem pleased to still be there, but our waiter was very nice and helped to make us feel at home.We had the burrata caprese (delicious!) to share between the 5 of us and the lobster fusilli between my boyfriend and I. Against a few other reviews, our lobster fusilli actually did come with lots of chunks of lobster, however the lobster chunks were somewhat rubbery and bottom of the barrel type... possibly because it was the end of the night? And not sure if it was just me, but I thought our pasta was also a little under cooked. If anything, the $10 bottles of wine kept our party all very happy. But overall, Giacomo's doesn't leave me screaming for more or understanding of the hype... I'd pass if there were ever a long wait.

Reviews.Author: Susan D.
Reviews.Content: We pass by this place as we're searching for a parking space. There were about 8 people waiting outside the door. Twenty minutes later after parking and walking over, the line has grown over 15 ahead of us on a Wednesday at 6:30pm.Luckily, the queue moves somewhat quickly because the wait staff really turn those tables. We get seated about 30 minutes later unfortunately next to a really loud annoying couple. The dining room is small and tables close together. The waiter was clearing the table next to me and even dripped sauce on the boob of my dress. That's how close all the tables are.Fortunately, the food made up for the annoying atmosphere. The calamari appetizer was amazing. Best darn bites I've had since eating by the ocean off the Maine coast. Nothing like the rubber bands at Vinny T's. I ordered the frutti di mare with giacomo sauce (red sauce with a splash of bechamel). And hubby got the scallops with pesto. The plates came out piping out. It goes from sauteed pan to plate to mouth in less then 30 seconds. Beware of burning your mouth.Anyways, the pasta was tasty but slightly overcooked (not al dente like how I liked it in Italy). The sauces were fresh and delicious. The seafood in my dish were fresh from the ocean, except for the overcooked shrimps. blah. Hubby thought his scallops were slightly undercooked.Our server was super informative introducing the menu, specials, and recommending the correct portion of calamari. Overall, I really enjoyed my meal and would return to try different plates.

Reviews.Author: Camille R.
Reviews.Content: ZERO stars for service, ONE star because the food is good.I've been to Giacomo's a handful of times and everytime the service has been awful. It's always packed, so the water pitcher and server always misses my table. I've sat at the bar where the bartender would even ignore us.The worst experience was the last one I had at this nightmare: Made a reservation and had to wait for over an hour to get seated. What's the point of having the option of  making a reservation?? Each time we asked about our table, they would just tell us to hold on, never coming back with an answer.The staff are always really rude, and demeaning. I'm not asking for fine dining service, whatever that is, but rather to just have a decent meal. There's always a line, it's always packed, and I think they use this to undermine the importance of service. The food is good, but not good enough to be treated that way. I could never again give my money to these jerks.

Reviews.Author: Michael D.
Reviews.Content: Hmm, I have mixed feelings about this place. It was hyped up to the point I thought I'd have an orgasm in my mouth. BUT I was let down... I mean its GOOD, but it wasn't MINDBLOWING nahmean? AND i came on a weekend, waited in a line that DIDNT MOVE FOR AN HOUR, and had to come back the next day. NOT A FAN.My brother and I shared the calamari (yelp.com/biz_photos/2u_w…), lobster ravioli (yelp.com/biz_photos/2u_w…) and the butternut squash ravioli (yelp.com/biz_photos/2u_w…).The calamari was good.. it came with fried peppers as well.. and personally, I enjoyed the sour crisp peppers over the actual calamari.. Both the raviolis came with SUPER SUPER creamy, buttery, rich sauces that were so good I wanted to lick the plates clean. Portions are a little small so I didn't feel FAT and SASSY afterward. BUT i did think that the butternut squash ravioli was a little too sweet for my taste. I'm a fan of savory, not sweet, but I guess I shouldnt complain.. after all, it IS butternut squash..OH, and GO ON WEEKDAYS for a shorter wait.. AND THEY OPEN AT 4:30 NOT 5:00 LIKE IT SAYS ON THE DOOR. AND BRING CASH.. IT'S CASH ONLY!!

Reviews.Author: Hannah K.
Reviews.Content: Alright I hate to say it, but this place is most definitely not a 5 star restaurant.  I wanted to like Giacomo's, I really did, but I just...can't.  It really is small, and when I say small I mean my living room is larger then this restaurant.  If the food was really that great then sure, I'll deal with small; but sadly the constant bumping from waitresses running around, and shuffling of chairs when other parties enter, along with the 45 min--1 hr wait outside is just too much to handle.  I've been to Giacomo's 3 times, and maybe this makes me a bad reviewer, but I can't remember what the hell I ate on any of those occasions.  In my mind that equates to forgetful/uneventful meals.  The North End has amazing restaurants, all within 2 feet from each other, so if the line is long and the restaurant packed just go somewhere else.  The only pro here is that it's pretty cheap eats.

Reviews.Author: Nikki T.
