Reviews.Content: I hate waiting in long lines - especially when I'm hungry.  Even more so, I hate waiting in long lines where I'm forced to do nothing but stare through the windows of the restaurant, smell the fresh aroma of herbs, wines, and sauces that emanate from within the premises, and watch as people scarf down copious amounts of freshly cooked pasta and bottles of Chianti.  After all this built-up anticipation, I have only moved yet another foot in line.  Under no other circumstance would I tolerate this torturous gastronomical experience - but it's all worth it for a seat at Giacomo's.A few months ago, my father was in town for my graduation, and being the host and loving daughter that I am, I felt it necessary to take him to the highly recommended Giacomo's.  My father, despite having traveled halfway around the world the day before, waited ever so patiently in line during the 1.5 hour wait on that Saturday night.  We were eventually seated at the bar, but we didn't complain.  We were so famished at this point, we would have sat anywhere.  The food here is delicious.  I've tried the lobster ravioli and a seafood pasta dish with Giacomo's sauce, but I'd have to say I enjoyed tasting my friend's butternut squash ravioli the most.  I'll remember to order this dish for myself the next time I feel like waiting two hours to satisfy my appetite.My father had nothing but great things to say about this place - and he made it quite clear.  He insisted on tipping the chef $50 and our waitress $40.  Never have I ever seen my father - a man of cool and collected demeanor- become so ecstatic over pasta and proceed to go tip-crazy at a restaurant.  I guess it shows just how great Giacomo's truly is.  Or maybe it was the wine. All in all, this restaurant is amazing - huge portions, low prices, high-quality Italian cuisine.  I highly recommend this place - and be sure to try the butternut squash ravioli and/or pasta with Giacomo sauce.  Friday nights and Saturday nights are especially busy, so be mindful of that - and it's cash only!

Reviews.Author: John H.
Reviews.Content: Best Calamari EVER!!  If you go to Giacomo's you have to order the calamari.  And the large portion at that.  It is a generous portion.  The batter is a hearty but not heavy.  It's the correct crispiness without  being a crunchy mess.It's an Italian seafood restaurant so expect lots of shrimp, mussels, clams, and lobster.  All of that seafood goes perfectly with the spaghetti pasta.  I would suggest the Giacomo sauce with the pasta.  I think it's made from a tomato and seafood broth.There is a catch to all this deliciousness.  They don't take reservations and there is a long line to the food.  If you want to get in faster, then go with a small group.  This place is definitely not a good place for large groups.  Also, the tables are very close together so expect to get to know your neighbors.

Reviews.Author: Kat V.
Reviews.Content: After trying to eat at the place next door and being unsuccsessful, we put our name on the list at Giacomo's for a party of 6 on a Friday night.  Shockingly impressive, they sat us within 15 minutes.  They even let us stay at the bar next door with our drinks and the hostess came and got us when our table was ready!!It is a pretty small place that is tightly put together.  The wait staff seemed knowledgeable, yet annoyed with our questions on food and wine pairing.It took a while for them to take our order, but once they had - our food came out incredibly fast, and exactly as ordered (always a plus).  Also, while we had to wait for our order to be taken, to tide us over, they gave us some yummy bread!The food itself was amazing!  I had the chicken broccoli in the garlic cream and it was spectacular!  The appetizer was a seafood mixture that everyone seemed to like as well.REASON I DID NOT GIVE 5 STARS: The downside was that place was incredibly loud and the waiter seemed ruder than necessary (which, in the service industry - should one ever be rude...I mean really?!).  Also, another place that is beer and wine only.  What does a girl gotta do to get some quality vodka drinks in this city?!  :)

Reviews.Author: JD S.
Reviews.Content: Just Go, you will never be disappointed !!!Best Italian food in US ever, I have travelled to most places in US and this is by far the best Italian restaurant there is. Do try 'Pumpkin Ravioli', my favourite. Remember they prefer CASH.

Reviews.Author: Theresa T.
Reviews.Content: **ANNOUNCEMENT: it is still possible to find truly authentic and great Italian food without traveling to Italy. You just have to go to Giacomo's! Knowing locals is great. My friend insisted on going to Giacomo's for dinner on a Monday evening and I chuckled when she said we should line up at 4:30pm and eat right at 5:00pm. What!?!? Is there like an early-bird special for 20 somethings? That's way too early. NO IT'S NOT!There was a line 15 peeps deep when we arrived and then a cute little server came and tallied up the parties standing in line, so she would know where to cut off the first batch of lucky eaters. The tables are close, it gets loud, and a warm garlic aroma quickly fills the small dining room. The menu is on the wall and there is a small wine list on your table. The house Chianti @$4.25/glass is a good pick. Places are set and bread is already waiting for you on your table. Despite the overload of people coming in and out of this restaurant the staff remains positive and is happy to help.The menu consists of so many good options it is ridic. For appetizers the Caesar for 2 is a great start. Everyone raves about the calamari (didn't have but will next time). Onto the entrees......... you can choose a variety of seafood such as shrimp, scallops, halibut, etc and then you choose your own sauce. Pesto, red, spicy and more. The Giacomo is the house sauce and delish! I cannot wait to try the fradiavola (spicy) sauce with scallops on my next visit. Giacomo's is authentic and everything is homemade! Cash only..... fast, fast, fast...but good, great, AWESOME place!!!

Reviews.Author: Jen C.
Reviews.Content: The whole dining experience was kind of surreal. First of all, there is no "list" to put your name on, you have to stand outside and wait in line, rain or shine. OR... meet nice folks who will hold your spot while you go get Mike's Pastries and a flask of Cap'n Morgan (Bostonians are really nice people!).It's about an hour wait from the corner down the street. The restaurant has about 10 tables and two seats at the bar. We got lucky and were seated at the bar, right next to the chefs! The waitstaff is no nonsense, true Bostonian Italians with attitude. Loved it. We ordered the House Special - Zuppa di Pesce, which is every kind of seafood imaginable piled on top of a huge dish of linguini. The shrimp is jumbo sized and the lobster is extremely fresh and tender. You get your choice of sauce and we went with a mix of a creamy Lobster sauce with a spicy sauce. Heaven in my freaking mouth.  The wine selection is also no-nonsense. With the house special, a very decent bottle of Chianti came out to an additional $10.You feel really rushed to eat b/c people are standing outside the window glaring you down. But this restaurant is a MUST! The only downside: CASH ONLY.

Reviews.Author: Layla P.
Reviews.Content: Someone in your party must get the*butternut squash ravioli*lobster ravioli*gnocchi with vealYou will not be disappointed. You will wait in line. Send a friend to get you a pastry from Mike's and have a sweet appetizer while you wait. :)CASH ONLY!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Lena N.
Reviews.Content: When anyone asks me how to spot this restaurant, I simply reply "just look for the one with the ginormous line in front." I have never seen Giacomo's without a line outside of it, even in the winter. But if you have the patience, the wait's worth it. Just arrive close to opening time and you should be golden.My friend was in town visiting so we decided to snack on a cannoli to hold ourselves over while waiting in line. 30 minutes later, we were finally in! We quickly sat down and wasted no time with useless conversation and got right to ordering. After all, this was not a date and we could talk after food.She had the special of the night, which was pasta with a half lobster. And I had the butternut squash ravioli. The ravioli is amazing. I loved the sauce so much I wiped my plate clean with the bread. And my friend ate her whole meal and only spared me a little bite to sample. Her verdict? She was in love. If Giacomo's was a man, she would marry him.I've been there a few times since then and the food was just as amazing so it was not a fluke.

Reviews.Author: Alex S.
Reviews.Content: The restaurant opens before 5. I showed up with my wife at 4:45 and the restaurant was full. We had to wait about 40 minutes to get in.The food was excellent but honestly it is not worth the wait. The place is always full to give the appearance of popularity. But really the place is just small and cramped, thats all.

Reviews.Author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.
Reviews.Content: Another fav place I always try to hit up when I'm back in town.I hate the cold so it's absurd that I've stood outside to wait for a spot at this tiny restaurant. But that just shows how good the food is.WHAT? Yelp says they have another location?!? So there.

Reviews.Author: Ray N.
Reviews.Content: Best Italien Food!  Coming from an Italien family, I've had my fair share of amazing home-cooked italien food.  I have only been to two resteraunts in my whole like that could match the quality I was feed at home: a place in NYC in the Village AND GIACOMO'S!  I have always had to wait in line for their food (and yes, it is annoying when a party of 6 behind you in line gets seated just because a large table opened up) BUT WHO CARES!  Have your partner/s hold your space in line and go and buy some canolis from Mike's Bakery 1 block away for after dinner.  I promise you it is worth the wait.  The wait staff is extremely  friendly also.  Always rushing around, but very friendly.  Be patient and look forward to your food and you will have a great time.  And do not come starving and grouchy or else you will have a horrible experience.And lastly: Don't be a jerk and wait in the doorway/vestibule.  Wait out side, in line.  This is so the waiters/waitresses can look and see the groups and how many and plane accordingly.  Not to mention you are in everyone's way! The people can't leave and you might get overlooked.  Suck it up and deal with it like everyone else.

Reviews.Author: James C.
Reviews.Content: Listen, this is as close to a 5 star joint as I will ever eat at without giving it a 5. The small percentage that takes away is the fact that the place does not accept credit cards. Cash only! It's 2010, they need to get with the program!That said, the food and service was a 5 all the way. I had the shrimp with the spicy red sauce. It was amazing. My cousin got the butternut squash ravioli. Let me say that under no uncertain terms, I would NEVER order this plate before last night. I tried one and I can honestly say it was one of the best things I've ever put into my pie hole. So much so, it's now called my Giacomo's butternut squash ravioli hole.That said get there about an hour earlier than you want to eat. The joint is small and very popular... there was a line outside.

Reviews.Author: Erik H.
Reviews.Content: Visited Giacomo's this past weekend for a romantic dinner with our expectations set a little too high. Was greeted by friendly staff who quickly lost interest in us after we said we did not want to purchase a bottle of wine for dinner, although, their wine selection was very cheap ($18 a bottle). Started with fine Italian Garlic bread followed by our entree's consisting of Butternut Squash Ravioli and a linguine special topped with lobster, clams, mussels, shrimp and Giacomo sauce. The butternut squash ravioli was highly touted and ended up lacking flavor. Tasted more of the asparagus than the raviolis and sauce. The giacomo sauce on the linguine special was bland. The seafood was okay and lobster portion was small.All in all, we may have fell victim to the tourist trap that is Giacomo's. It is worth the wait if you will be drinking their very reasonably priced wine. Otherwise you can find better Italian food elsewhere. Don't forget, Cash only!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Maggie H.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food and pleasant busy atmosphere.  However, even with a reservation, you may need to wait, and it can be difficult to have a conversation because of the noise -- as with many popular restaurants in Boston's South End.

Reviews.Author: A. L.
Reviews.Content: After seeing the high rating on Yelp, we decided to come here during our visit to Boston over the 4th of July weekend.  It was around 8:15pm when we arrived, so the line waiting outside wasn't that bad (yes, the line is outside because the restaurant is too small and packed to have anyone waiting inside).  We waited outside for about 30 minutes before we could get a table for 2 inside.  It was definitely cramped, hot, and stuffy inside the restaurant.  It was almost 90 degrees outside, but I would say it felt about 10 degrees hotter inside!  I heard a few customers asking them if they had AC, and they replied they did, but it just doesn't work well.  With all the business that they get, I wonder why they just don't get a better unit that works well.  And what's with the cash only?  I don't mind it that much, and I know other Italian restaurants in the area do the same, but really, this place gets enough business that they can take the small hit of the credit card fees.Anyway, the service seemed very rushed.  We were brought to our table.  We asked for menus but they just said they didn't have any and said their menu was on the wall.  Surprisingly though, they gave other customers menus, and those customers were even seated close to the wall with the menu.This place really does seem like a factory.  All the workers seemed very rushed.  I felt sorry for the cooks who had to cook all the food in that hot stuffy restaurant all day.  It seems really chaotic with the waiters and waitresses moving tables and chairs around so much to accommodate all the customers coming in.  You order your food, the food gets brought to your table.  You eat it quickly since it's too hot in there to eat slowly anyway.  The waiter refills the water a few times, but does it in a rushed manner and sometimes spills water on your table or on your food.  As soon as you get done eating, the waitress takes the plate away and hands you your bill.Now, on a positive note, the food really is good.  I liked being able to pick what seafood and sauce I wanted in my pasta.  It definitely was a tasty meal.  Unfortunately, even if I gave the food 4 stars, the fact that I can't enjoy it properly because of  the service and the hot and stuffy restaurant would bring my overall rating down to only 2 stars.

Reviews.Author: Blair S.
Reviews.Content: This place is OK but probably given high ratings because of the herd mentality: people see the line outside and assume it's good.First the good: The fried calamari was excellent.  I highly recommend that.  The fresh pastas are far superior to pastas you'll get a many restaurants, even in the North End.Now the disappointment: You're likely to wait in line (I waited over an hour on a windy, 30 degree Saturday evening) if you have a table of 3 or more.  This means wait staff don't have to be welcoming and will rush you out.  Our waitress had a real attitude problem.  The Giacomo sauce was good but not five stars.  My lobster and seafood linguine had half a lobster that was over-cooked and rubbery, but the clams and muscles were OK.  The tiny, crowded dining room means you'll constantly get bumped and the distorted 60s music drowns out conversations.Go when there is little or no line but otherwise it's not worth it.

Reviews.Author: James H.
Reviews.Content: This is likely one of the best Italian meals you'll eat.The pasta is cooked to perfection - we ordered the butternut squash ravioli and the the pumpkin tortellini. You seriously can't go wrong with either - the ravioli's a bit more salty but the sauce in both dishes is absolutely perfect (and extremely buttery - it won't be the healthiest meal you'll ever eat!). We didn't order it but we saw another table order the lobster which looked massively filling.Service was friendly and very fast - important for a place that is so small and has such limited seating. They don't even have a dessert menu; everything seems to be optimized for speed. Which to be honest, I really liked, but might not be for everyone.As other yelpers have mentioned, be prepared to wait a long time to get in. They don't take reservations, and even though we got in line at around 4:50pm on a Sunday night it still took a good 45 minutes for the 2 of us to get seated. But having been skeptical while waiting in line on a very hot July day, I'm relieved to be able to write: it was so worth it and I'd do it again!

Reviews.Author: Kevin L.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is a great little restaurant in the North End.  It's quite popular and often has a line.  I must say that the food is very good but not great/excellent.  I've been spoiled by Little Italy in NYC and this was not on par with those experiences.  I will say though, the pricing is far cheaper and well worth the money. My wife and I shared the Seafood Pasta for two with Lobster.  I wasn't a fan of the lobster but I'm starting to think I'm just one of those weird foodies who is not a lobster fan.  We had another couple directly beside our table who we hit it off with.  They were great and the wine was flowing.  Made for even more fun.  Service is authentic and very kind.

Reviews.Author: Becky M.
Reviews.Content: I came here after hearing a ton of great things about it.  We got there relatively early - around 5:45 and didn't have to wait in the line outside.  We crammed into our table and the waitress came over and explained the menu/specials.We ordered a small calamari and Caesar Salad to share, the calamari was the best I ever had.  If you're going, you have to get it.  The salad was very good also.For my entree I ordered the special with the Giacomo Sauce - it's linguine with mussels, clams, and 1/2 a lobster.  It was ok.  I definitely liked my appetizer and salad more.  The lobster was overcooked but I think it's impossible not to when you make it this way.  The mussels were good, the pasta was cooked right but I thought the sauce I ordered would be more creamy.  We both decided next time we go we'll go at the same time to avoid the line (they don't take reservations) and we'll order something different.  I noticed the butternut squash ravioli AFTER I ordered!  It wasn't too expensive and had a nice atmosphere even though it's tiny.  Worth a try!

Reviews.Author: Nicole S.
Reviews.Content: I lived in Boston for five years and Giacomo's is hands down the best Italian food in the city. I'm originally from lower NY and I always felt food from Boston just didn't compare to what I ate at home, but Giacomo's is a major exception. I've had some of the best ever Italian here (NY or Boston). I'm absolutely in love with their lobster ravioli in a savory cream sauce. Their fried calamari is also amazing. And the friend I brought, a vegetarian, even decided to take a break from his lifestyle to try some of the food at Giacomo's, and he didn't regret it! Now Giacomo's is great, but there are a few hurtles you need to overcome when you make the choice to eat here.1. You will wait in excess of an hour most nights, even as a party of two. The line always stretches down the block and around the corner almost every time I go. Weekdays are a bit more tolerable. And you will be waiting OUTSIDE summer or winter, because this place is the size of a closet.2. They only take CASH, come prepared because on one occasion my boyfriend had to run down the street to an ATM to get cash to pay the bill.3. Guard your food with your life! Because these waiters will try to snatch it away when you're not paying attention in order to turn over tables quickly to accommodate the suffering customers outside (especially if it's cold, it sucks to wait outside). They will also bring things out fast and attempt to rush you through your meal, so if you're looking for a romantic spot go elsewhere because this is all about the food!!!All in all if you're in Boston Giacomo's is an absolute must! Don't miss out.

Reviews.Author: Wesley C.
Reviews.Content: Calamari is the one you have to try. Very delicious home made Italian food. Prepare for waiting in a long line though.

Reviews.Author: Mark G.
Reviews.Content: There's not much I can say that hasn't been said. Arrive either at an odd time (early or late) or be prepared to wait. The South End location -- near back bay station-- takes reservations, but you can expect to wait a little to be seated after you've arrived. Honestly, there's no wait that's more worth it in the city. Quality $10-20 bottles of wine and the best Italian food I've had in Boston. The waitstaff is attentive, but you have to understand that you're in a tiny restaurant that is very popular. It lives up to expectation every time I return. Even if you opt for Valet parking, this is an inexpensive night out in both locations. The Shrimp Lemon Papardelle is my favorite dish -- consistently awesome, while the Calamari is legendary as well.

Reviews.Author: Jonathan R.
Reviews.Content: I love this place....authentic italian food, great service, reasonable prices.  Last time I visited, I brough 2 friends from work the South, I highly recommend brining folks from Louisiania here.  Hilarious.  Watching them get accustomed to fast pace Boston is good in itself, but Giacomo's is the final exam.  Service is fast and efficient...hang tight. Calamari is excellent, I haven't been disappointed with any dish.  Bring cash (no crdit cards accepted last I went) and be prepared to wait in line.  No reservations.  I'd recommend brown bagging a bottle of wine from across the street for the wait in line.  Enjoy.

Reviews.Author: sophie l.
Reviews.Content: Seriously, as good as it gets. The best Italian I've had in the states. It's a very small restaurant so be prepared to wait-- it's worth it. It was packed (with a 30 minute line outside) on a Tuesday night. Inside is noisy and cozy with a great Italian, vintage, artsy feel to it. Our waitress was wonderful! Service is great. What we got:-calamari: made well. -Butternut squash ravioli with gorgonzola cream: they are famous for this and it lives up to all the talk..absolutely delicious (coming from a non-fan of butternut squash) -Spinach & portobello mushroom ravioli with sundried tomatoes in a pesto goat cheese sauce: this is what I ordered. every bite was an orgasm in the mouth. amazing combination of ingredients & great execution..so delicious!-Ziti with shrimp, scallop and broccoli in a garlic cream sauce: my least favorite but still a solid seafood pasta. my boyfriend loved it I want to go back and try everything on the menu. I wouldn't be surprised if everything is amazing.

Reviews.Author: Aez A.
Reviews.Content: I've been wanting to try out Giacomos for a while now. My sister was in town so I figured why not today?.\ Heeding the advice of other yelpers about the long wait times, we scampered over early (530). There was no line so we walked in only to be rushed out by a waitress before we could find the host.NOTE: there is no host and no where to wait inside, this place is smaaaall. Protocol is to wait outside the door if there is no line- you become the line, someone will come out when ready. Everyone from your party must be present at that time.-After about 10-15 minutes of waiting, the line had now grown to 3 more parties of 2-4 people. We were then seated. woo hoo.-be prepared to make nice with your neighbors! the tables are super close together, it makes maneuvering and jacket taking-offing awkward.- Our waitress was nice but busy. she brought out some bread- room temp wheat bread w/ olive oil... good thing it was just bread, right? no big whoop.-We ordered some calamari as an app. super good, I 100% recommend it. the breading is light and the calamari isn't rubbery. -We took our waitresses advice by ordering the lobster ravioli and pumpkin tortellini. My cousin ordered the shrimp linguini with the diavolo sauce.--the lobster ravioli  really good, the cream sauce was great.  Initially I didn't think it would fill me up, but boy is it deceiving, after I had finished, I was surprised by how satisfying it was.--My sister loved her Pumpkin tortellini, I wasn't a big fan of it that night or the next with the leftovers, I thought it was way too sweet.--My cousin's dish was by far the biggest portion. She loved it, especially the sauce. If you are super super hungry- I'd suggest the linguini- it's a mountain of food; but in the end it is just pasta, sauce, and shrimp... tough to mess up, no?- the entrees range between $15-20. with the specials priced higher but still all below $30. Not bad, right?-It's cash only but there is an ATM across the street- I'd suggest going before you are seated because it's tough & awkward to move around the place.-We noticed that by the time we were seated and about to order (6330ish), the line outside had extended beyond the restaurant; easily to beyond 15 people. SO come early or bring some hot chocolate and extra mittens.

Reviews.Author: TJ M.
Reviews.Content: Don't be fooled by the lines out front.. it's not b/c the food is incredbile.. This place is super popular becuase they only mark up the wine 2x vs. the standard 3x.  In addition, most meals are under $20.Overall the food is good, but not great.  Some people wait outside for an hour waiting for a seat.  From my perspective time is money, so whatever you saved on that bottle of wine, you just lost waiting in the rain.With that said, this place is a steal if your wait time is under 10 minutes.  Good luck and bring your umbrella, b/c there is no standing room.

Reviews.Author: Ellen L.
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for good, italian seafood, this is the place to go (I rate this equally with Daily Catch.  This place is a teensy bit more rushed, but there's definitely more seating so the line moves rather quickly.  It's also slightly cheaper...)Caveats:You might have to share tablesNo reservations-must wait in lineNot an "atmosphere" placeThis place is about $20 a plate and totally worth the wait.  You will see people lining up outside this restaurant summer and winter waiting for a seat.  My brother and I came here on Sunday around 6pm, so the lines weren't horrendous.  -Fried Calamari- absolutely the best fried calamari i've had.  It melted in your mouth and wasn't overly breaded like many that I've had.  -Butternut squash ravioli-this ravioli came with a white sauce that was absolutely divine.  The sweetness of the butternut squash perfectly complemented the sauce and wasn't overly sweet as i've found with other butternut squash dishes.  -Fruitti di Mare with Fradiavolo sauce - what can I say?  A pile of seafood with linguine and a spicy red sauce.  It's hard to go wrong with a pile of seafood, but the sauce blew me away.  It married the flavors of all the seafood together.There was something about this place that was absolutely perfect.  The waiter, though rushed was very nice.  The pasta was perfectly cooked al dente.  I mean PERFECTLY.  the flavors were just amazing.    Definitely a must in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Susie A.
Reviews.Content: I've only been to Giacomo's once, but it's already high up on my list of favorite restaurants in Boston. Yes, the line gets out of control, but I promise you it's worth it! Monday evening at 7:45 and the wait was only 5 minutes, so either plan on waiting or go at a random-ish time.I've never had such a hard time deciding what to order. I finally settled on clams and mussels in the scampi sauce and LOVED it (but was later told I should have gotten the Giacomo's sauce??) Other things I desperately wanted to order: Butternut Squash Ravioli, Pumpkin Ravioli, Fettuccine with swordfish and tuna in a pesto cream sauce, and goat cheese-filled gnocchi with mushrooms and mascarpone. Which obviously means I need to go back immediately.The prices are very reasonable for the amazingness of the food- entrees are about $12-$18 and most bottles of wine are only $16!!! Woot!The host/owner was super nice and sat down and chatted with us and pinched my cheek when he found out I recently finished grad school (ha). It's a tiny little place, but I kind of just think that makes it feel more authentic.

Reviews.Author: Gregory I.
Reviews.Content: Preface: Be prepared to wait. Even in sub-zero temperatures, people will come wait in line here. Food: The butternut squash ravioli is orgasmic. You better get at least one order of those just to have the "Giamoco experience." The seafood specials are also amazing since they are pretty reasonably priced and they come with loads of fresh lobster, etc. Whatever you do decide to get as a second dish (Because you need to at least get the ravioli), remember to get the Giacomo's sauce. The server described it as a creamy red sauce, but it really was not that creamy. It just a really solid tomato sauce. Also, as an aside, the pasta is cooked al dente. Also, there is no dessert. Atmosphere: The restaurant is extremely small, but very very nice. There are two seats near the kitchen which are kind of cool because you can watch the kitchen crew make your food. But you will most likely end up sitting near the window, in which case you can try to ignore the hordes of people outside watching you eat your meal. Service: The servers here are really nice, especially to new comers. And they have a great sense of humor. Really old school Italians.Takeaway: If you are prepared to wait on line for at least an hour, then this place is totally worth it.

Reviews.Author: Daf M.
Reviews.Content: The food was just ok. The coffee and the tiramisu were excellent. Wouldn't go back.

Reviews.Author: Helen G.
Reviews.Content: I got the Fruti  di mare (with half a lobster) with a sauce I don't remember, it was recommended by the waiteress when i asked whats the most flavorful. Overall delicious seafood pasta dish but could have more flavor. The veal Marsala has an unique taste if your into trying new dishes(it's pieces of cut up meat and mushrooms in a sweetish sauce). My favorite was the fried calamari, golden crispy yum in your mouth.

Reviews.Author: Kurt H.
Reviews.Content: What can one say about this place? there is always a line to get in and whether it's snowing, raining, freezing rain or blistering heat, the line persists. Why, you may ask? It's totally worth the wait. Giacomo's is very, very small in size. The total seating capacity is about 35 people including the bar. They have some signature dishes like pumpkin tortellini and butternut squash ravioli that must be tried to be believed. I found the shrimp to be a little on the tough/overcooked side recently, but overall the food is exquisite. if you don't mind a wait and you're a visitor in Boston for the first time, this should be your first stop in the North End.i was too harsh when I originally reviewed this place. It's honestly the best Italian food I've had since moving to Boston and my top choice in the North End.

Reviews.Author: Caitlin B.
Reviews.Content: I dine in the North End fairly often and was always put off by the long line outside of Giacomo's. Recently a friend and I decided to brave the line and see what all the fuss was about. Would it beat out Saraceno's as our new favorite? No. After being called into the small, cramped restaurant we were greeted by a rude, condescending older woman with a braid that was so long, it went to her butt.If you have a party of 2, be prepared to be sat with at least 4 others, as they do not have many tables in this restaurant. If you're looking for romance or a place to take your time as you are eating, go somewhere else. We were sat next to a group of 3 loud teenagers and their mom. They were sitting so close, we might as well have been sharing a bread basket.   As it turns out, Condescending-Braided-Hair Woman was our server. She pointed to the chalkboard instead of briefly going over the specials and rushed through everything. I understand that there is a long line outside, but it would have been nice to not feel like her goal was to turn as many tables as she could. Her braid kept swinging around and brushing up on my arm. I wouldn't be surprised it it's been brushed up against, or in, someone's meal.The menu is a decent size. For some meals you can pick and choose which sauces, pasta, and/or protein you'd like. I chose the lobster ravioli. It was cooked just right and was overall really enjoyable. When the waitress came to check on us my friend asked if they make their own pasta. Turns out they don't. It's purchased from a distributor.    I'm glad we finally tried it out, but I can't say that I'll be back. I could have went to my local grocery store and picked up some Buittoni pasta. I'd have saved $15 and the hour in line. The end result would have been the same.If you decide to try it out for yourself, bring cash! They DO NOT accept credit cards!

Reviews.Author: Carin C.
Reviews.Content: Sometimes with good food, you often build it up in your mind that it's better than it actually was. Unfortunately it wasn't the case with Giaccamo's. I came back into town for the weekend and brought my friend here and was pleased everything was still the same after 4 years.My friend and I shared a small Calamari appetizer. I love that the calamari on the east coast always comes with fried peppers. This place serves one of the best calamari I have ever tasted. It was nicely coated was crispy and not oily. It comes with a marinara sauce that goes so well with it. Since I haven't been back in ages, I got the lobster pasta special with the Fra Diabalo sauce on their special menu. As far as I can remember, this is always on the menu and should just become a part of the regular menu. When the pasta arrived, I got this huge plate where I had half a lobster buried under a pile of pasta with mussels and clams. The only bad thing about my meal my clam shells were smashed, so I was concerned that they were broken and weren't edible. My friend had the Squid Ink pasta with Swordfish and Tuna that was also on their specials. picture: yelp.com/biz_photos/2u_w…  I had a bite of it and it was so good. I love that more Italian places are serving squid ink pasta. It used to be so hard to find. I know the line can be intimidating, but the line moves pretty quick. When I was in school, I would use the line to catch up with people, because by the time you get your food you are just going to devour it and won't want to talk anyway. It might now be the touristy thing to do over the years, but I still love it.

Reviews.Author: Rachel K.
Reviews.Content: I'm a little bit sad that I have to give Giacomo's 3 stars.  I would honestly prefer to give them 4, but can't quite seem to do it.  Ten years ago when I lived in Quincy, I took my sister to Giacomo's based on a some good reviews and word of mouth.  This was prior to Rachael Ray's endorsement (the kiss of death for transforming a decent local joint into the ninth circle of hell teeming with loudmouth tourists.)  What I remember is a lobster linguine with sauce so sublime that I licked my plate.  I'm the consummate slob, but that's even a mite disgusting for me.  In other words, this was some good freakin' sauce.  This is a family-style joint with big plates and a basic menu, where you choose a sauce, meat, and noodle.  But unlike other paint-by-numbers places, the food was actually good.  The Macaroni Grill this was not.  Is not?  My dad and I are back east right now, and I couldn't wait to take him to Giacomo's. Should've heeded the warnings.  Every local that we spoke with practically rolled their eyes while giving us directions to Giacomo's.   I considered the possibilities:  The food is crap now.  The service is crap now.They are just sick of tourists asking about this particular place.  I'm an optimist about food, so I went with option 3.  The wait wasn't very long (it was a rainy Tuesday night) and the waitress looked like she wanted to put me in a headlock when I asked her what the "Giacomo sauce" was before she got a chance to complete her menu explanation spiel.  Otherwise, she seemed like a nice lady that would probably take in stray animals and babysit your kids on a moment's notice.  The caesar salad was just average.  It didn't exactly suck.  The dressing wasn't too tangy, too thick, or too anything.  It wasn't bad, but it was far from memorable.  The very middle of meh.  My dad ordered a plate of the fried mozzarella.  This was a little bit better, the batter was very light which and the mozzarella wasn't rubbery which (in my determination) are the only factors that prevent this dish from tasting like it came from TGI Friday's.  Too bad they slathered it in marinara sauce that wasn't unpalatable, but was of a similarly unmemorable variety.  We moved on to the pasta special with fusili in the "Giacomo" sauce (bechamel and marinara combined)  with chunks of lobster and shrimp.  I don't know why everybody thinks that a 20 dollar and beyond price tag on pasta is such a bargain.  I don't.  And I don't care if it is topped with gold leaf and truffled Harvard diplomas.  That said, the lobster was delicious and the folks at Giacomo's do not skimp portion-wise.  I only ate about a quarter of the pasta and I felt painfully bloated afterwards.  Generosity is not a problem here.  The sauce was good, the pasta al dente, and the shrimp decent but overcooked.  This was good stuff, but not the Giacomo's pasta of my memory.  It was not a transcendent experience, but merited a few Mmmms.  I got plenty of time to consider the virtues of this meal as it repeated on me until midnight that night.  Go to Giacomo's and don't expect to be blown away by the appetizers. My guess is that they do fried appetizers well, so stick with those, and any entree involving lobster.

Reviews.Author: Julia H.
Reviews.Content: My husband and I brought an out-of-town guest to Giacomo's because we heard it was a great place and there are alway line ups outside. This was a particularly cold rainy February evening, so not much of a line up outside on this night.The three of us were seated fairly quickly at a cramped table that would normally seat two. We craned our necks looking up at the menu pondering what to order. After we had decided, we finally got a normal menu to look at.I had a creamy pasta with seafood. It was way too salty! My husband said the same about his dish as well. The portions were very large, but I felt the pasta was over cooked. This is an american styled italian restaurant. Is not authentic!Don't forget to bring cash. They don't accept credit cards.This place is overrated.

Reviews.Author: Jay W.
Reviews.Content: Disappointing.    If you want fine Italian food, don't go. If you want large portions of pretty good food for $14 to $20 per dish, with a 45 minute to hour wait for a table, then this is the place for you.I'll start by saying it isn't a bad restaurant, but why it is so popular is a bit of a mystery.The restaurant basically specializes in large portions of food that tastes fine but are really not true Italian dishes.I, however, prefer to taste the components of a dish, have my pasta al dente, and for the chef to compose the dish rather than allowing me to pair the pasta, protein, and sauce.  Seriously, I thought about walking out when the waitress asked what kind of sauce I wanted and gave me a card with an option of six, one of which was called "giacomo sauce."  I knew at that point that I was not about to have a fine dining experience.  The giacomo sauce was basically alfredo sauce and marinara mixed together.  The alfredo sauce was poured out of a pitcher.The majority of the menu is seafood based, so my girlfriend and I tried the "house specialty" zuppa di mare.  NOTE: this is the "house specialty" not the house "special" and I double checked with the waitress that it was something that the kitchen was proud to present.  It was huge, with a ton of poorly cooked shellfish (lobster, overdone; muscles, overdone; clams, overdone; scallops, waaay overdone; calamari pretty well cooked).  It was advertised as dinner for two, but easily could have fed six. Again, not my thing, but if you like large portions you may enjoy it.  Overall, the taste was decent, it just wasn't anything special, and I find it offensive that sooo many people told me how great this place was after I expressed that I had been disappointed by many North End Italian places in Boston that I considered to be faux Italian.The wine list is small and consists mainly of mediocre California wines, none of which are truly appealing. Also, the restaurant itself is just hot.  It was 15 to 20 degrees warmer inside than outside, which made it about 102 degrees while we were there.  It probably lends some authenticity, but seems more like a ploy to keep turning the tables over and get people in and out of the door.  Additionally, the table behind me was a four top, and none of their food came out together.  The first pasta dish was delivered to one of the diners at the table at least 10 minutes before the last entree was brought out.Most of the diners were eating pasta, which was cooked roughshod on a flat top boiling pot, and often left on counters for far too long to maintain the integrity of the pasta or the texture.  Basically, al dente is not going to be an option.  None of the pasta is handmade, which I understand, but they should at least try to cook it properly.The staff is very friendly, but after quietly inviting each table to join in, they did sing happy birthday to a customer. Had a bit of a Joe's Crab Shack feel about it. Basically, if you want a lot of food go there.  If you want truly good, authentic Italian food, go someplace else.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer B.
Reviews.Content: You will wait to eat here, every tourist on yelp will come here due to the plethora of good reviews and reasonable prices.  It's a tiny place with maybe 15 tables, they don't serve dessert, probably to hurry the turn-around.The food was delicious, we had the lobster ravioli, caesar salad and the calamari.  I would definitely eat each one again.  Everyone there seemed to enjoy their meal.  If you have some time and don't want to break the bank, come to Giacomo's for a great meal.

Reviews.Author: Jiyea C.
Reviews.Content: Why don't they crank up the AC or at least TURN ON THE FANS here? That would probably be my only complaint. It was a ridiculously hot and humid fourth of July weekend and one person in our party was visiting Boston for the first time, so Giacomo's was pretty high on our list of must-visit places. (TBH, I suggested it because I wanted to try it myself! xP)We waited a little less than an hour for a table of 3 on the Friday after July 4th, which fell on a Thursday this year. (We had been told that we'd have to wait longer but there was a party of 9 in front of us, and the restaurant decided to seat us first.)Anyway, our party of 3 decided to get the mussels with linguine with the giacomo sauce  and the house special for two with the Fra-something I think (forgot the name, but it's the one with a mix of giacomo sauce and one with a spicy edge). The special comes with a bottle of any of the $17 wine. We got the Savignon Blanc and it was refreshing but not the best white wine I've ever tried or anything. The mussel dish came out first (we were sharing everything, although we never told our server Donna that) and while it had great flavor, we thought the linguine was undercooked. I'm not talking al dente, I'm talking borderline crunchy/hard to chew. OK you're busy, but you're an Italian restaurant. you CANNOT mess up pasta. Why couldn't you spare another minute or two? The special arrived at our table about 10 minutes later, and WOW it was an impressive looking platter! (Not plate- it's a HUGE PLATTER of pasta.) It was topped with all kind of seafood (clams, mussels, TWO LOBSTERS, squid, etc) But like the first dish, this one tasted rushed also. The wine in the sauce had yet to evaporate, and the pasta here was also a little too al dente, though not as undercooked as the first dish. we all agreed that it tasted better about 15 minutes after it arrived at our table, when the pasta had cooked in the sauce and the alcohol had dissipated.Oh, the complimentary bread and olive oil is completely unremarkable. Kind of disappointing.For our party of 3, the bill came out to about $100 after tax and tip. Very delicious, but the wait and dining environment leaves much for improvement. I understand the reason to rush your patrons when there is a line of potential customers outside, but if we're sitting down and paying for the food we're hopefully enjoying, it wouldn't hurt to let us relax and enjoy it. Don't get me wrong, the food was amazing, but I just don't know if it's worth waiting forever on a scorching summer evening, sitting in a crowded/non-air conditioned dining room, being served hurriedly-prepared (though flavorful) food, and feeling rushed by the wait staff.  CASH ONLY. I believe that there are ATMs for most major banks within a couple blocks on Hanover St, and you have plenty of time to withdraw some cash while you wait in line.

Reviews.Author: Dave W.
Reviews.Content: Thank you Yelp for this one.  I just happened to be wandering around the North End looking for some real Italian. Opened up the Yelp app (NOT on an Iphone) and Giacomo's was on top of the list.  We were only a block away, and I have to trust my fellow yelpers (even if they are not on the best coast). We actually walked right past it because we were looking for another neon sign.  There were people waiting outside when we did find it, but luckily they were waiting for a big table, and there was a two person one just waiting for us. ONE STAR!  We were seated by a curmudgeon-y old lady who either smoked for fifty years or just was Italian for sixty five, or both.  But our boisterous, bubbly server arrived with the specials, explained the menu a little excessively, and got us some pretty good bread.  TWO STARS!  Bottled beers were three bucks, so I got a local IPA.  Not quite as hop forward as a Seattle IPA, but they don't grow hops in Massachusetts. Maybe there is a shortage. I ordered a Caesar salad to share and one of the specials, the half lobster, with mussels, clams, linguine, with Giacomo sauce.  Caesar salads usually do not warrant comment, but this one was perfectly dressed, with a real homemade dressing, and the lettuce was hand torn, not sliced or chopped.  It really had an improbable depth of flavor. THREE STARS!  The main came out and it was easily enough for two people.  Rare for a seafood dish, especially lobster for under $30. The sauce was a lobster broth, tomato, and cream base which was simply delicious.  The flavor of the lobster was right up front, and it was light and delicate despite the cream.  I did not ask if the pasta was fresh, but judging from other reviews, it was, and it tasted as such.  FOUR STARS!The lobster was bordering on overcooked, but was still succulent and not very rubbery.  I prefer Penn Cove mussels to the ones I ate, but I cannot expect a twelve table place to fly mussels 3000 miles, and these were very tasty despite their birthplace handicap.  The clams were also great.  And mopping up the sauce at the end with the bread brought the whole meal to a perfect close.  The bill came to $37 bucks with two beers.  Very reasonable.  FIVE STARS!  We also had desert at Mike's Pastries one block down, but I couldn't take another bite when a guy started puking into a US Mailbox three feet from me.  And St. Paddys is a week away!

Reviews.Author: Jonathan M.
Reviews.Content: Not that this place needs anymore good press, but it was so good I had to yelp it!I live in the North End and have been to most restaurants on Hanover/Salem. The reason why we went there last night was cause it was a major snow storm out and figured the usual long line outside wouldnt be there. I was right and we sat down right away. What a meal we had..-Fried Calamari Appetizer: Very good, better than most -Ceasar Salad: Good-Linguine with Chicken/Shrimp n Pesto:Very good-Linguine with Clams w Scampi Sauce: Unbelievable!!! The absolute best!!! I am a tough critic and expert on linguini with clams and this by far is better than anything I have ever had. The flavor of the sauce and fresh clams are fantastic. The sauce is a perfect mix of olive oil, garlic, white wine, and garlic and maybe some other ingredients. I used to say that THE DAILY CATCH had the best white clam sauce but this place actually beats them!!I highly recommend this place! Wine is cheap and good and service is fast and friendly. Yes on a normal day you will wait in a long line but it usually goes fast...Also I have gotten in the past the lobster ravioli, shrimp scampi, and squash ravioli and all are delicious as well......

Reviews.Author: Robert A.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely No Question - Worth the Wait !!!!!!  The best Italian we've ever eaten, it was amazing!Note: It is a cash only restaurant

Reviews.Author: Binh L.
Reviews.Content: There are not many places I would wait in a long line before 5pm to eat dinner. This place is so worth it. The Zuppa di pesce is the best deal that I've ever happily paid for. They say it's for 2, but really.. you could feed a small family. The plate took up my whole tiny table. The seafood is so fresh, the sauce holds the delicate balance of complementing the food, but not overpowering the freshness of the seafood, and the pasta is just right (seriously, you would be surprised how many places overcook or under-cook their pasta). Cash only and come with patience. You're going to probably be in a line, and then, stuck in a table in this extremely cozy restaurant. Hopefully your neighbors have interesting conversation.Giacomo, I know you've got a line full of suitors, but won't you dine with me?

Reviews.Author: Mabel S.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is easily some of the most delicious Italian food I've ever had. And the wait in line was easily the longest I've ever waited to be seated in a restaurant. They do their best to get people in and out quickly, but be prepared to wait for at least 30 minutes before getting inside. Also, be prepared to see people trying to pull favors to get inside or to the front of the line. Ridiculous! The wait staff seems very rushed and you may also feel a little rushed into ordering (by the way, they don't have menus. Their entire menu is on the wall), but the food and ambiance of the place is lovely. The owner, or what I presume is the owner or manager, comes around pretty often and checks on you or makes conversation with you. He likes to ask where you're from, and literally knows every single place a person mentions. It's pretty funny. He seems like a friendly guy, and he tries to make every customer happy.The food was amazing, and myself and three friends cleaned our plates. The sauces were tasty, the seafood was fresh, and the chicken was perfectly moist and tender. My friend got pumpkin tortellini and said it was better than his mother's cooking! (The manager didn't take too well to that, haha.) It's a great place to go in the North End, but it's very small and the wait is very long! Worth it, though.

Reviews.Author: Sara M.
Reviews.Content: I could take the smelly garbage days, the hapless tourists, and the crazy locals in the North End IF I lived by Giacomo's.This place is amazing.  I grew up in an Italian family and know authentic when I taste it.  This place is reasonably priced for such amazing food!  The butternut squash ravioli - divine.  The frutti di mare - absolutely delicious.  The customize your favorite combination of seafood, pasta, and sauce (generally get calamari, mussels, and fra diavolo) - perfection.  The wine is decent but who cares about that when you have a steaming bowl of succulent, al dente pasta with gravy in front of you!  The only downfall is that they don't serve lunch and the place is teeeeeeny.  You will always wait because there is going to be a line - rain or shine or snow or hurricane.  Because it is totally worth it.Their South End location is good as well AND they take reservations!

Reviews.Author: Lynn C.
Reviews.Content: zomg, did I really just finish that gigantic plate of clams, mussels, 1/2 lb of lobster, five fistfuls of linguine covered in delicious pasta sauce? OMG I really did. But it only cost $20...My mom tells me I only have to finish an entire meal if it costs a gajillion dollars...so why, WHY did I do it?seriously, i'm going to have to detox the rest of this week after actually finishing their lobster special that was drenched in half giacomo and half fradiavolo sauce. I still can't believe i ate that much. unlike the south end location, this one definitely deserved its hype. To be honest, I wasn't even going to get in line to come to this location because I had such a horrible experience at the south end, but this meal definitely made up for it.For the food:- i enjoyed the fra diavolo sauce mixed with giacomo over the giacomo alone (which was what my bf ordered). - the sauce is heavenly- the giacomo sauce is a red creamy sauce (lobster extract) while the fra diavolo is a red spicy sauce (also lobster extract). Mix together you get creamy and a tiny little kick!- the sauce was heavenly- their portions are gigangartuan- the sauce was heavenly- unfortunately, their seafood actually was not that fresh- the sauce was heavenlyBut would I go back? probably not. I'm just not interested in having to stand in line for 1hr+ outdoors for food that's not five stars-worthy. And cash only? Get with the times!

Reviews.Author: Elaine C.
Reviews.Content: wow wow wow. So worth the 1 hr and 40 minute wait. SO worth it. I want to come back here.Calamari - best best calamari ever. I stopped eating calamari for a while because I had been repeatedly disappointed, but I thought I'd give this place a show since there were such great reviews on it. Am I glad I did! It was so crispy and the jalapeno was the perfect kick.The pasta and seafood are both so fresh. I tried the Giacomo sauce and it was great! Such an amazing house pasta sauce! I can't wait to go back to Boston to eat here again!!!

Reviews.Author: Annie S.
Reviews.Content: My first 5 stars goes to this restaurant!I came here when I was visiting Boston, and wowwwwwwwww... Best pasta I've ever had in my life. I want to fly to Boston just to eat here... The line was longggggggggggg because the seating is very limited inside, but the wait was worth it. I really wish I can find an Italian restaurant as amazing as this place in the Bay Area...

Reviews.Author: Claire J.
Reviews.Content: So it's been about 5 months since I went to this awesome restaurant and I still can't stop thinking about it.  My friend Star B. and I still talk about it until now.  Star B. pretty much wrote my review so I'll just add some tips I guess.  Get there early.  Good thing we got there 30 mins. early coz we were one of the groups that got seated when the restaurant opened.  They know how to do a turn around but withouth rushing you.  Food came right away.  Service was good.  This place is small so it can get cramped, but it's not that loud.  You must try Zuppa di Pesce!  You must!  Ok if you don't like seafood (gasp!) or allergic to it, at least get their Giacomo sauce.  They need to sell that sauce.  Oh yea such a great deal!  And I don't think it's for 2 people, unless you really eat a lot or you want a leftover.  Oh yea you'd want that leftover.  Calamari, order that one too.  It comes with fried peppers and yumm.  One of the best I've tried.  I'd definitely love to come back!  Now if there's one like it here in SF, I'd be happy.

Reviews.Author: Claire Y.
Reviews.Content: Yes, we braved the outrageously windy cold for nearly 40 minutes for dinner at the famed Giacomo's.  Witnessing the less determined folks in the line give up and leave rendered us weak at moments, but we made it through and got seated at the "VIP" table --- the bar.Quite simply, the food was WELL worth the wait.  Between the ultra fresh mussels, scallops, and calamari in pesto and Giacomo sauce - paired with a few glasses of delicious Chianti and white Zinfandel - we were two happy diners visiting from NYC.  I'd fly back to Boston just to have another meal at Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: Sara M.
Reviews.Content: This place is excellent for several reasons:-  Really delicious food-  Reasonable prices!-  They will do take-out.  TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE TAKE OUT!!!...But there are a few negatives:-  ALWAYS a wait for a table and the restaurant always feels so crowded-  Cash only-  You will absolutely feel rushed through your meal. They need to turn over tables as quickly as possible so I suggest you don't order a bottle of wine unless you mean to chug it (and yes, I did this with a friend during our very first visit to this place!  They actually cleared our table and were setting it for the next people before we could finish our wine).  Do take out if at all possible!!!

Reviews.Author: Eric L.
Reviews.Content: We arrived at 4:15PM on a Wednesday night and were first in line, by the time  it opened 4:30, it was a line. Almost long enough to fill the small place.  The bread was ok, a little too chewy.  I ordered the calamari and it was ok, a little to plain and not enough peppers.  My wife ordered the fried Mozzarella and it too was a little bland.  My entree was the Fruitt Di Mari and it had a good amount of seafood but the sauce seemed dead.  The atmosphere was lively and the waitress was very good... Prices are very good.  I would recommend it but don't expect it to be the best Italian you have ever had.

Reviews.Author: Kevin K.
Reviews.Content: Let's do a quick summary:Pros:+ Service was amazing (Thank You Julie)+ Lobster Ravioli - the best thing on their menu. For ~$16 you get at least 10 - 12 pieces of Lobster Ravioli.       5 / 5 Stars+ Special - Half Lobster, Clams (got extra clams instead of mussels), Linguini w/ Fradiavolo sauce. I felt the sauce could be be improved. Generous portion for $20.   3.5 / 5 Stars+Calamari - Good, but I don't see myself craving it.   4 / 5 StarsCons:- Long lines (No Reservations). I waited approximately 1 hr and 30 minutes for dinner for 2. - Small Restaurant. You're seated very closely to people. This can bother some people, but its definitely not a positive.I absolutely recommend getting the Lobster Ravioli w/ Cream Sauce. Expect to wait at least an hour, from what I heard, there is always a wait.

Reviews.Author: Christina P.
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a place to linger over apps, and wine & take your time-this is not the place. However, if you are just interested in great food, fast & entertining service and reasonable prices, this place is a gem.It is TINY. If you do not arrive by 5, be prepared to wait. The wine list is short 7 cheap but good with about 10 selections of red or white wine by the bottle for $16 bucks. The atmosphere is warm and inviting & the servers are friendly & unpretentious. our server Christian was amazing, and we took his recommendations on wine (sangiovese) and he was kind enough to steer me towards the non seafood based vegetarian options. A bottle of wine, fresh bread & oil, caprese salad and two entree's for 58 bucks- totally a score! Can't wait to go back(BTW- This place is CASH only)

Reviews.Author: Kristine H.
Reviews.Content: okay so, i almost froze to death waiting outside in the line for this tiny famed italian pasta place.and i thought, what am i doing waiting in line for some poisoning pasta (gluten-intolerant folks, you get me yeah??)BUT THEN I DISCOVERED GRILLED TUNA STEAK with extra grilled veggies to sub for the pasta on the side - and omg its like italian sushi. NEVER have i EVER had such an amazing fish steak, i wanted to savor every single heavenly bite.OH and a whole bottle of wine for $16? not to shabby, share with the group and it comes out to be reeeeal cheap!just beware its cash only. one of the ladies at this location is BOSS at regulating the double door policy so even though we were sitting next to the door it was warm throughout our whole dinner! and we had the cutest sweetest waiter with a true boston italian accent that made our whole night a real treat.

Reviews.Author: Mariko W.
Reviews.Content: Ok, so to be fair, it's been a while since I've been here, but I'm really hungry right now and sometimes you just get that craving for a good plate of pasta.  I really enjoy this place.  It's small, it's fairly authentic, there's a crapload of food, and it's reasonably priced - especially for what you get.  Remember to have cash on you, and if it's nice out, be prepared to wait for a while outside, but it's definitely worth it.  Mmm... I could really go for a plate of pasta right about now...

Reviews.Author: Andrea P.
Reviews.Content: Haven't lived in Boston since 2006, and I *still* dream about Giacomo's.DON'T get the pasta with Giacomo Sauce if you ever plan on moving out of Boston. It's kind of a dick move to pull on your taste buds, and they won't forget it. No other Italian will measure up after this; they know the meaning of payback.

Reviews.Author: Ashley G.
Reviews.Content: UMMMM I just don't understand? I mean, I had wanted to go here for years; the long line that was always outside had always made me curious. However, my curiosity got the best of me! HA!!!Service: Horrible/rude/ bitchy. The waitress was more interested in turning her tables... I could give two shits less about the line outside... I waited 45 minutes to get in this hole in the wall, I want to take my time and enjoy my shitty glass of box wine!. We sat 2 inches away from the people next to us... awkward. Food: Sucked. I got pumpkin tortellini's. Why? I don't know - I'm in the North End.... should've maybe stuck with a staple... red sauce?  The waitress admitted they have them brought in... so they're not home made. Calamari was as bland/basic and wicked boring. The prices aren't bad... but honestly, go across the street to Sarenceno's, or down the street to Fiori.... any place but this.Tourist's beware! NO NO NO!

Reviews.Author: Leslie F.
Reviews.Content: You will wait in line, but you won't regret it. This is not a place to expect to sit and enjoy a lengthy dinner for a long period of time, there is a quick turn over of tables. It's a small restaurant, there's always a line (In November I waited over an hour), and it's cramped seating. This is the best italian I have ever had. (Not that I'm extremely cultured in Italian food) but it's almost ruined my enjoyment of italian anywhere else. haha. Their house sauce is amazing.

Reviews.Author: Paul N.
Reviews.Content: Took a couple female friends from So Cal on a rainy/snowy Sunday in Boston, we waited at the door about 5 minutes while the party ahead of us was seated and another 5 for our table. Waitservice was prompt and all-business but the place was very italian and the food was great.Two of us had shrimp & scallop plates over pasta; both were excellent and the accompanying broccoli tender and as al-dente as the pasta - something I appreciate. The third plate was swordfish, also done very well for someone who is not a fish enthusiast by any stretch. An affordable DOC Chianti helped everything down quite nicely.And we were out of there in comfortable time, not rushed, but we were definitely not kept waiting for anything either. Definitely recommend for small parties (2-4/5 people); any more than that, the wait will be considerably longer; no reservations.

Reviews.Author: A V.
Reviews.Content: Amazing and authentic italian restaurant! I felt like I was back in Italy while eating here. I had the calamari and lobster ravioli which were amazing. I didn't order any drinks - but they have several bottles of wine for $18. It's a small restaurant but cozy. It's true that they don't take reservations and it's cash only, so keep that in mind when you go. My friend and I skipped lunch and decided for an earlier dinner, and showed up around 4:15 thinking there'd be no line since it opens at 4:30... nope - sure enough there were people in line and we barely made it in when they opened the doors. Well worth the wait though, this place definitely gives you the feel of a real italian restaurant and a great place to go if you're not familiar with the north end.

Reviews.Author: Nadine P.
Reviews.Content: The wait went much faster than I expected, and once inside I found that the service was prompt, but not not rude, and I didn't feel rushed. Our server was very nice and had some great recommendations since it was our first time.The calamari is really that good!! Everything we had was delicious and the portions left me with enough to take home and enjoy a second time. Overall, a great experience!

Reviews.Author: Andrea M.
Reviews.Content: The wait on line is longer than other places in the North End, but the food is absolutely worth it. As a party of two, we waited for 25-30 minutes and were seated at the bar which is cool and different. We had plenty of time to look at the menu while we were outside so we ordered immediately after sitting down.Since the restaurant is so small, the service is quick and efficient. Food comes to your table within 10 minutes. We ordered a small calamari, the pumpkin tortellini and the scallops in the Giacomo sauce over linguini.  The portions were just right for the price and the quality was fantastic. I enjoyed every single bite of the entire meal. I also took some of my pasta home and the leftovers were fantastic the next day. I wish they sold their Giacomo sauce because its one of the best "pink" sauces I've ever tried.I can't wait to go back and I recommend this restaurant to all ages, all ethnicities for fabulous Italian food!

Reviews.Author: Augie C.
Reviews.Content: Great place.  My co-worker and I walked in off the street.  Our jamaican cabby dropped us off on Hanover from the airport.  I thought it looked interesting.  We left our luggage by the little alcove.  I ordered the linguini with half lobster, clams, mussels with their Fradiavolo sauce (spicy tomato based sauce with a lobster base). Their fried mozzarella is an excellent appetizer.  Friendly staff.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Author: Cynthia L.
Reviews.Content: Out of Town Review...4.5 Stars...This place is def everything people describe it as:  amazing Italian food at the North End.We ordered:(...before you say anything, yes, we were fatties and ordered 3 entrees for 2 people and the waiter asked us the same question, but hey, we don't know if we'll ever be back, so we decided to try things we were really interested in.)- Calamari - Hot, crispy batter and tender squid...everything other yelpers have said.- Lobster Ravioli - I thought this was ok, a bit too much butter, but the bf loved this dish.- Butternut Squash Ravioli - This was amazing; I've never tasted anything like it.  It was like a dessert and main dish into one (says our amazing waitress)...the sweetness of the butternut squash (with a hint of almond/hazelnut liquor) was perfectly offset by the asparagus and cream sauce.- Gnocchi stuffed with pesto & cheese and sauteed with mushrooms in a red sauce (their special) - It was ok, nothing spectacular compared to the other dishes.Pointers:- Cash ONLY- Do come here early, we got here at 4:15pm and there were at least 15 people in front of me and by 4:30pm there was a line to the corner of the street.  We were lucky enough to get in on the first round so not a long wait, but I suspect the average wait is about an hour.- Food comes out hot & quick!- It is a super tiny place with the bathrooms being downstairs after the food storage room (I felt like I was in a dungeon down here).- But because it's a tiny spot, you get to see the chefs cook.- Park on the street or in a hourly parking lot (1 street behind if you want to be on the safe side).

Reviews.Author: SatisFahYing A.
Reviews.Content: Tightly packed tables are angled to maximize capacity NOT PRIVACY but still crowds of people must bravely wait 45 minutes or more through rain and snow to eat at little Italy's most "typical" restaurant. Allow the gravelly voiced waitresses to bully you into the mounds of massive lobster stuffed ravioli ( ask for combo Fracomo diavolo house special red / cream sauce- much better delicious) or the mountains of small twisted butterfly pasta smothered in the red lobster-based house sauce Fra diavolo. Pumpkin tortellini!!! Add Garlic bread and a bottle of the cheap wine they stock and you will feast. Large portions make it perfect for sharing.As mentioned CASH only.  Parking was a bitch.

Reviews.Author: Lawrence C.
Reviews.Content: Just fyi, this place is OM NOM NOM NOM worthy. Giacomos was freaking amazing! I'll admit the line was pretty long and watching the patrons inside tease us with their wine glasses, long strands of noodly goodness and savory pieces of seafood delight (as we only inched our way closer to salvation) was rather unbareable. HOWEVER, the payoff was so worth it. All in all our wait was a good 45min-1hr.When my buddy and I finally sat down, we had so many great options to choose from. One wall had the main menu while the other had the special for the day. We decided to start with the fried calamari. Fried to a golden perfection, each piece was evenly crusted and had a hint of salty taste. The kicker that stuck with me was how fresh the dish was. This, I later realized, would be the theme of the evening. I decided to order the shrimp and scallop linguini with fra diavolo as my sauce. This was a great choice as I enjoy spicy foods. My friend got the special for the evening that included half a lobster, mussels, clams, and scallops all on the same fra diavolo sauce and linguini. Like other yelpers mentioned, the portion was huge! Definitely enough to fill anyone up for 2 meals but the long line took a toll and our stomachs grumbled with hunger.I thoroughly enjoyed the fra diavolo sauce. Hearty and rich with just enough kick, this was a perfect compliment for my seafood ensemble. Though I didn't taste my friends dish, I took his empty plate as a sign that he also enjoyed the meal.Line or no line, I will definitely have to visit Giacomo's again the next time I'm in Boston. It's just too great to skip!!

Reviews.Author: Jenn S.
Reviews.Content: I've passed this place a million times but never had the time to wait in line. I wanted to take my girlfriend out for dinner - we've been to the North End a couple times before but it'd been awhile so I figured we'd go big and check out Giacomo's.We got there around 4:45 on a Monday night and were seated immediately - there were two tables left and the line formed shortly after we arrived, so there was already a good start to the night. We chose to sit at the bar; watching all the food come out of the kitchen was pretty cool. (We actually changed our appetizer to the caprese salad after seeing it come out for another table, definitely worth it) It appeared that they specialize in seafood, but it was great that there was a vegetarian section of the menu (regardless of the fact that it contained three items). I was planning on ordering the butternut squash from what I read on Yelp, but the pumpkin tortellini was an unexpected contender. My girlfriend ordered one of the specials, spinach mushroom ravioli. Service was quick and our waiter was very nice; I never once felt rushed while dining here. The food was absolutely delicious and in large portions so we took the remaining bits home. Spent $50 (cash only) for the appetizer, two entrees, and tip.Overall, the food was fantastic, service was good, and I would definitely come back. However, definitely come early and good luck if you're in a large group of people, since the seating area is small.

Reviews.Author: Bianca T.
Reviews.Content: DELICIOUS! Well worth the hour plus wait, but they will rush you out as soon as your plate is empty. Just expect it and dont let them bother you! Enjoy!

Reviews.Author: Andy S.
Reviews.Content: The best pasta place in boston. The calamari was great and i really like the 1/2 lobster with clams and mussels. The wine prices are not bad either. The only bad thing was the long lines.

Reviews.Author: Melody N.
Reviews.Content: Love, love this place!  Have been here multiple times.  The first time we went we waited 45 minutes before it opened for dinner in the middle of winter.   Well worth the wait.  A neighboring customer suggested getting the butternut squash ravioli with mascarpone cheese sauce is heaven and it has been my go-to staple ever!  I have not seen another place that has made a sauce like that with butternut squash ravioli.  Delicious!  My husband has had a fra diavoli dish with seafood and it came with a ton of seafood(including a lobster tail) at a reasonable price.  The portions are usually generous and the food is delicious.  Service:  Can feel rushed at times but they are very quick to get your food out.Things to know:  Very, very tight space, feel prepared to be up close and personal with your neighboring customer.  Cash only(very important!)  There are a couple of ATMS on Hanover street, so make sure your wallet has some green in it!  Lines are long and no reservations(and they don't seat you unless your whole party is there!)

Reviews.Author: Abegail A.
Reviews.Content: A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!  Went here on my last night in Boston and had the BEST seafood pasta ever! After recommendation from a friend who used to live in Boston, I thought I'd give this place a try.  Boy was I glad I did!  I walked up to the restaurant to find a line.  The wait on a Sunday night at 7:30pm was 30-45 minutes, not too bad.  Since there was two of us, I decided to head over to Mike's pastries and grab a couple cannolis to go (since they don't serve dessert at Giacomo's) while the other stayed in line.  I returned after about 15 mintues, and what do you know, we were seated right when I returned.  Perfect timing!  All parties before us had three or more people, so it's a plus to not come with a larger group.We started off with the caprese salad with bufala mozarella, fresh tomato, basil and virgin oil ($9).  You could tell the mozarella was homemade, and everything tasted fresh and delicious.  For the main course I ordered one of their specials of the night...a green, spirally pasta with creamy pesto sauce, shrimp, and lobster ($20).  So DELICIOUS!  The pesto sauce wasn't too heavy and there was a generous portion of shrimp and lobster.  Nom nom nom!  This was definitely worth every penny and the (short) wait in line.If you are ever in Boston, be sure to visit this place.  When I'm in town again, you know where I'll be getting Italian food!!!BTW- this place only takes cash and doesn't accept reservations.

Reviews.Author: Victor C.
Reviews.Content: This place is delicious. I don't know why everyone goes on and on about the butternut squash ravioli but I loved the shrimp pasta better and the lobster ravioli. The butternut squash is unique but it tastes more like a dessert. This place usually has a long wait and is small so everyone is crammed together. Getting the waitresses attention for water was hard. You're better off going up to the counter and getting it yourself.Going downstairs to the bathroom was like entering hell. No joke.The food made up for all that though. Was almost just as good the next day.

Reviews.Author: Shannon M.
Reviews.Content: Get ready for the life changing experience that is Giacomo's...Reasons to come here:1.  The butternut squash ravioli.  The asparagus on top was my favorite part...2.  The ceasar salad.  The dressing is so good and the croutons amazing.3.  The linguine with shrimp and half Giacomo sauce, half  fra diavolo sauce.  With those powers combined you get a lobster-based, creamy AND spicy marinara sauce.  It.  Is.  Perfect.

Reviews.Author: Belle L.
Reviews.Content: if you're not a fan of waiting to get seated, possibly sharing a table w/ strangers, having in your face service...well then sorry yelpers, this isn't the place for you. BUT it certainly was the perfect dining place for me & 2 others!!!came here on a thursday night and we were prepared to wait in the cold for our italian fare. maybe it was the chilly weather, but lucky for us there was only one other party ahead of us. so our wait time was only about 15 mins, not too bad. our party of 3 ended up at a shared table with another couple - no matter to us, we were here for the grub! the place is small, cozy, warm & just like the hole in the walls hubby and i found while visiting italy. i loved it! we were quickly told the specials of the day, all the different types of sauces, and if we need any help ordering our server would be happy to help. ha, i did my research and was quick to get our order in. between the 3 of us we split:mozzarella marinara - came with 3 pieces which was perfect for us. picture a mini breaded mozzarella steak. the breading was perfect and the cheese just ooozed out. loved the simple marinara sauce.large calamari - another plus! the calamari didn't come out all oily and nasty like some other places we've been to. the calamari was the perfect texture and was mighty tasty with just a squeeze of lemon. and since i'm a fan of spicy, i enjoyed the breaded peppers that were mixed in w/ the calamari.seafood special - a whole lobster!!, mussels, clams, shrimps, scallops, & calamari over a bed of linguine and your choice of sauce. we picked the giacomo red - lobster red sauce mixed with bechamel sauce. the menu board says it feeds 2, but really i think it can feed at least 4 people. the special was $55 but add a bottle of wine and it was $65. so of course we added a bottle of cabernet to top off the meal.the seafood special was AMAZING. ha we were all fighting over the scallops and the lobster meat was yum. seriously, everything was good. i think i could've poured that lobster red/bechamel sauce in a bowl w/ a side of bread and would've been happy - it was that good!i loved the service too. our waters were constantly filled, they cleared our plates quickly and always got us prepared for the next course. would totally recommend giacomo's to any of my friends/fam visiting boston. it's been said repeatedly, but remember 2 important things:1) CASH ONLY2) When entering/exiting Giacomo's, make sure one door is closed before you open the next door! you'll see what i mean when you get there=).y'know the mantra: good service + good food = thumbs up giacomo's!!

Reviews.Author: Jin Y.
Reviews.Content: Now I know where I'll be returning to when I go back to Boston for whatever reason. We got in when it wasn't too crowded (30-40 min before closing) so we got a table right away. We ordered a bottle of wine because it was $16. Perhaps it wasn't the best wine but if it's $16, I'm ordering it. You only see wine prices that cheap in Europe.We started with the fried calamari, which was good (not spectacular, but good, and in great quantity - we couldn't finish it - and we ordered the small one, $7). I got the seafood paella with the red sauce, which was made with lobster essence and Bechamel and my hubz got the butternut squash ravioli with asparagus in a cream sauce.
