I was astounded by the amount of mussels and seafood on my plate. I had to take half home. My hubz cleanedddd his plate. Both our dishes were in the teens and with the wine and calamari, our bill was in the low $50's. How can I not give it 5 stars?I won't say any more than what's already been said except this: go really late to avoid the dinner traffic, or really early. We closed down the resto, the last ones to leave but they were more than nice about it. mike's pastry's was closed by the time we got out though, so be aware of that. This isn't a nice, elegant or upscale restaurant but it feels like a hole in the wall.

Reviews.Author: Nadia B.
Reviews.Content: I didn't ABSOLUTELY love it.. but I liked it. (I have a funny feeling I MAY get hate mail from fans who swear by this establishment). But, I really have had similar in NY or NJ (other Italian-swarmed states with amazing food).. and didn't offer a NEW type of "wow" which I expecte after seeing hundreds of reviews! The line/wait was not too bad on a Thursday November night, so don't let the wait sway you, it does go by fast. Food- I had homemade a home-made fusilli with a mixed sauce of fra diavalo and Giacamo's cream sauce. The dish needed a bit more seasoning I think... I think I would have enjoyed it if I changed the pasta to a linguini or something without so much texture (it reminded me slightly of gnocchi). The shrimp and lobster were absolutely delicious and fresh, as was mussels I shared with a friend. One of my friends ordered a mussels & lobster dish but said her meal was very watery--- perhaps the sauce was too light, or when the lobster and mussels were being transferred water came along with it.Another friend ordered salmon- and she enjoyed it. We all did like the fried calamari-- PERFECTLY seasoned coating. Wish there was more marinara sauce for a large plate.I think it's a romantic stop and will definitely bring my hubby here for a 2nd shot.... Service was GREAT--- our waitress was VERY nice, smiling-- I wish I remembered her name... but, if the manager is reading this, she was doing the window spots Thursday  (11/2) at 7 pm-- get her a raise!

Reviews.Author: Lannie L.
Reviews.Content: The trek and wait is well worth it (parking = nightmare)Once inside, the service is efficient and friendly.  Space does get tight but that close atmosphere lends to why it feels like a huge family outing.  You know that everyone is loving their food.I always go with pasta w/ Giacomo's house sauce and change up what goes in it.  Regardless, everything is so fresh.Portions are huge and leftovers are almost more delicious.I prefer the North End one over the South End one.  The food tastes better imo but that might just be psychological.Friendly tip:  If you go for dinner and expect a wait, stop by somewhere to grab an appetizer to eat in line while waiting (ie.  I go to Ned Devine's and get clam chowder to go to enjoy in line and it's awesome).

Reviews.Author: Cy C.
Reviews.Content: Worth the wait, worth the money, worth the cold weather and worth the trip all the way from Hawaii for AMAZING Italian food.I recently took a trip to the east coast for Boston and New York. Before I left of course I did my research on yelp and wrote down all the top places to eat.  Lets see while on the east coast I need to have pizza, chowder, beer, bagels and Italian food. Now we planned a visit to Little Italy in New York but after reading the reviews for this place we had to check it out.  Having a hard time finding this place just look for the line.  One advice be prepared to wait.  In my opinion the place must be good if there is a line.I honestly don't remember how long we waited, but after you stand in line and see the happy faces walk out the door and take a whiff of the food you are not going anywhere.  Just stay in line and you will be happy!  Our excitement grew when we reached the window to peak through.  You will notice its a small place with tables nestled close together. Its always nice to have an open kitchen to allow you to see the magic in action.  Now I noticed on some of the rare negatives review they complained about the wait, the small tables and the service. First of all let me just say you don't wanna wait and you wanna sit in a nice comfortable table? Then there are a bunch of other empty restaurants with a lot of tables for you to sit on. We don't want to hear your complaints about how bad the food was.  You need to sacrifice if you want good food. Regarding the service, we had the waitress someone complained about. If you can't handle sarcastic humor then just eat your food and don't talk. Our waitress was awesome and just a pleasure to talk story with.  Now the food....ohhhh the food.  Be aware you will have difficulty deciding what to eat.   Everything on the menu sounds so good. After a reviewing the menu we couldn't decide so 6 of us decided to do it family style so we can try everything. We ordered Lobster ravioli, fried calamari, Fusili, Pumpkin ravioli, butternut squash and garlic bread.  I'm not a Italian food expert but this was definitely amazing food.  My favorite was the lobster ravioli but honestly I would be happy to eat everything else. I would suggest eating family style if you have a big group. If you have a small group then order a lot so you can take home.Just a perfect night of amazing food, wine and great company. Thank you for being one of the highlights on my east coast tour.   Yelpers my hats off to you, thank you for guiding me to this place. If you are reading this review get off your but and head on down. No reservations and cash only. If you take out you still have to wait in line. Lets see 9 hour flight and 1 hour wait......ah still WORTH IT!!!

Reviews.Author: Carrie C.
Reviews.Content: Thank you Yelpers for leading me to this gem on a random night during my visit to Boston! Obviously, Giacomo's has fantastic reviews on Yelp, but I had no idea just how popular this place was.  When my boyfriend and I arrived, the line was out the door, around the corner, and then some.  However, we were more than willing to wait to see what all the fuss was about, and it was completely worth it.We ordered the butternut squash ravioli and  Fruiti de Mare with the Giacomo house sauce.  Both were absolutely delicious and I would highly recommend them.  However, almost everything there sounds delicious, so I probably would not get it again if I came back to Giacomo's next time I'm in Boston because there's so much else to try!Keep in mind how tiny this place is--you can expect it to get pretty hot in summer and to sit pretty close to other diners.  Also, our servers seemed to be quite rushed, which is not surprising considering the huge line outside.  So it may not be the most romantic place in the world, but the food is phenomenal!

Reviews.Author: Ambrose C.
Reviews.Content: Are you looking for some tasty seafood served with pasta in a casual, small and quaint Italian restaurant? Are you willing to wait in a long queue for a while so you can sit inside? Do you have enough cash to pay a little less $20 for your dish? If you said yes to all of the questions above, this place has your answer. If you are looking for just the one and only place for a seafood pasta dinner in the Italian North End, where the prices are moderate for a meal, then this is probably one of the best choices. It's been about two years since I last ate at this place, but I finally got a chance to revisit again after hanging out with a couple of people I know from the Toronto area that were visiting. I decided to get the $19 Fruitti di Mare, which had mussels, shrimp, calamari, clams and scallops. I decided to get Fra Diavolo Sauce, which is a red tomato sauce with a little spice. The people that I know got the $20 special dish where you get half of a lobster, with mussels, clams, and shrimp doused in the Giacomo's sauce, which is a red tomato flavored sauce similar to the Fra Diavolo sauce, but with no spice at all. The pasta served was linguini, which is a thin, flat, wide, but curvy noodle-shaped pasta. Pasta portions continue to be excellent. One pasta dish should be enough to fill the stomach of a very hungry man. The seafood is freshly cooked and tasty. I liked the Fra Diavolo sauce more than the Giacomo's sauce mainly due to the spice in the flavor. The Giacomo's sauce was good, but tasted almost like an ordinary but good quality tomato sauce. The shrimp was meaty and plump, and the calamari had a nice tender texture. Lobster is freshly cooked, and I spent a considerable amount of time eating every piece of meat on my lobster piece. Scallops were tender and also tasty, but were not too big. The clams and mussels were tasty, but are really small. We also had a small plate of Calamari as an appetizer, and it is probably one of the tastiest calamari dishes I had. Nice and crispy on the outside, and tender and chewy on the inside. The sauce provided made the calamari even tastier. Bread portions are a little small, but I got my stomach full from eating a lot of the pasta.Since this place is really popular and the queues are long, I think a good time to come here is probably on a weekday at around 8:30 PM and not on a Friday or a Saturday evening. The wait was considerably shorter on a Monday than on a Saturday. Service is actually good, the server was really nice and able to answer any questions you may have. They are really nice enough to give you some tools to help you eat your lobster. They only take cash, so make sure you have some $20 banknotes in your pocket. The bathrooms are small, and it feels like you are actually going down the deck of a boat when you walk to the bathrooms. Overall, this place continues to be a representation of Boston's seafood pasta dishes at its finest. If you are looking for a spacious and big restaurant, this is probably not the type of place I would recommend, but if you are looking for an almost excellent seafood pasta dish at a moderate price, and you are willing to sit at a small table, then this is a great choice.

Reviews.Author: Molly W.
Reviews.Content: Oh Holy GOD how I wish I was Italian.Waiting in line is not something I do when I am hungry, but I am glad we did for this place. You feel like you are in grandma Lisa's kitchen all squished between Donna (our server) and Giovanni (hot italian man I am imagining as my dining partner) midst the steam, amazing pumpkin ravioli and a glass of vino.I may have unbuttoned my pants to finish that last ravioli. And then I dipped the bread in the sauce. I was practically rolled out of this place.Rushed, busy, and really really f-ing good.

Reviews.Author: Elaine Y.
Reviews.Content: My first night and first meal ever in Boston - and I was SO pleasantly surprised! Giacomo has a small space with small tables, and some (including mine) were close to the door so it got cold at times. But our server was very attentive and nice despite the crammed space.I came early around 6:30pm so there was no wait. The wine list had a lot of $16 bottles and some by the glass. We had a bottle of Chardonnay and it wasn't bad. The price was unbeatable! I didn't really look at the menu but it seemed to have all the staples of a good Italian restaurants. For pasta dishes, you can pick the pasta and one out of five sauces - Pesto, Fra Diavolo, Red, Giacomo and Scampi. I had one out of the five specials of the day - 1/2 pound lobster, clams, and mussels with linguine with the scampi sauce for $20. My friend had the same with the Fra Diavolo sauce which was slightly spicy. And oh boy, they were goooood!  The whole steamed half lobster was amazing! It was a little messy to crack the shell but I managed. The portion was huge for the price!! Yum! It was definitely great value for the price!When we were done, we had no room for dessert. We wanted to sit around for a while to enjoy the rest of our bottle, but the line outside was LONG! Granted it was 8pm on  a Friday night, I couldn't believe people were waiting in the brutal Boston snow/ wind for food! We were given the check without asking, and the table was cleaned very promptly. I would usually be turned off by this, but with all those people waiting outside and I can see them through the huge glass windows, I couldn't just sit there and take up the table! I have to say, I left the restaurant very happily that night. In the nights to come during my trip, there were lines outside that restaurant every single night even during the week.

Reviews.Author: Blair H.
Reviews.Content: They're ok.  My linguine was almost over-cooked.  Bread was typical Bostonian.  Service was quick, friendly, and efficient.  Give it a try and don't be put off by the long line, it moves rather quickly.  I'd say 10 min/10 ft of line for a party of 2-4.But who cares what I think.  There are like 800 reviews for this place.  So seriously, try the spicy tuna rolls.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: We decided to eat our last meal here on our trip to Boston and luckily got a good spot in line before they opened for dinner (the line gets pretty long outside). The restaurant is pretty small and maybe only has a dozen or so tables, so it fills up very quickly. We were worried about how long it would take to get in and out of here because we had a flight to catch, but the service here was excellent and it seemed like our food was on the table before we knew it.Based on all the positive recommendations on Yelp, I decided to go with the lobster ravioli. I'm not even a big lobster person, nor do I order ravioli very often at restaurants, but this was one of the best Italian dishes i've ever ordered. The blend of cheeses inside the ravioli was incredibly flavorful, and the pasta was cooked to perfection. The garlic cream sauce was amazing as well, I don't think I left a single bit of anything on my plate by the end of the meal. This place had been hyped up to me by a couple of my intern friends who were Boston natives, and based on the reviews on here I had pretty high expectations as well so I was a bit worried that this place had been talked up too much and that i'd be disappointed. Giacomo's lived up to the hype, though, and I hope to be back here someday when i'm back in New England.

Reviews.Author: Amanda L.
Reviews.Content: This place has many good memories since I used to come here with some of my very favorite boyfriends. But I digress.I hope to God they still have it since I moved to CA, because their pumpkin ravioli changed my life.  One time I was taking a class and starting chatting with two classmates. We got on the subject of best meal ever. The guy said, "Pumpkin ravioli at Giacomo's."  The other girl and I said, "ME TOO!" at the same time. Coincidence? I think not.The guy said he went there for the first time, ate the ravioli, and got goosebumps.  He went back a second time, ate the ravioli....goosebumps again!God I wish I wasn't 3,000 miles away. I LOVE YOU, YOU CRAZY BASTARDS!!!!

Reviews.Author: Loc H.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely my favorite restaurant in Boston. Do yourself and come before the dinner rush or you'll be waiting in a massive line.. but you can always just have a snack at Mikes if you want.ALL pastas are good.. menu changes constantly so I can't pin a dish that stood out because all of them were good.Service was great and my fave? THE BATHROOM! it's like this little nook.Random, i know. but go here, you wont regret it!

Reviews.Author: Raj B.
Reviews.Content: Food was great.  Butternut squash ravioli was top notch.  Even the garlic broccoli was incredible. Our waitress was very friendly.  My new favorite Italian place in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Amber H.
Reviews.Content: Yes, you will wait for a long-ass time, and yes, it's cash only, and no, they don't take reservations, but it is so worth it!My friend took us here while we were visiting Boston from California. She insisted that we bear the wait in the cold (probably in the 30s that night, and no, that's not really cold if you live in Boston, but yes, it is very cold if you are used to California weather) and that it would be totally worth it -- she even missed some event she was supposed to go to to wait with us.After about a 30-minute wait in the freezing cold, even with a homeless man pestering the couple next to us (and pestering us on occasion, except we just completely ignored him -- we're accustomed to that in Berkeley), we got in and quickly put in our order. We started with the calamari -- hands-down the best calamari I have ever had in my life. My friend got the butternut squash ravioli, I can't remember what J got, and I got that Giacomo's house sauce (a creamy tomato-based red sauce) fettuccine with shrimp. All of it was so, so amazing.The restaurant itself is a bit crowded inside, but if you just ignore that and concentrate on the food, you'll enjoy it that much more. And who cares if the waiters are a little rude? It's the best damn Italian food in the world.

Reviews.Author: Claudia H.
Reviews.Content: I know, you can only pay cash ... and Giacomo's does not accept reservation... and I had to wait 20 minutes to be seated (the restaurant was absolutely packed) on a Tuesday night in late February... and the waiter asked me to stand up while I was eating so that other people could get to their table (the place is tiny)... BUT where can you eat homemade fusilli with lobster meat and Fra Diavolo sauce for $20??? My friend got linguine with half lobsters (both were specials for the night) and the sacrifices were worth it! Overall food is great (an Italian friend of mine says it's not authentic Italian, but it's definitely tasty!), prices reasonable, and the place is tiny but feels authentic. Wines are really cheap (we got a "special" bottle of Gavi from Piedmont for $23, most wines are $16 per bottle!). And if you forgot the cash, there are 4 atms in the area...

Reviews.Author: Patty W.
Reviews.Content: It was a cold evening and it was like looking at the fish in an aquarium.  You look through the glass at the people enjoying their evening...drinking, socializing, eating........you see the waiter staff weaving in an out of the tables......and all you can do is smile and think....I can't wait to get in there.....The pumpkin ravioli was delicious..the atmosphere was fun and the company was fantastic! I thought it must have been weird for the people sitting at the window to have all these people drooling and examining their food......but it's not.  You can feel their pain......:) We were there in the winter and it is funny when everyone must squeeze into the foyer...close the door...then are allowed to open the second door.

Reviews.Author: Caroline C.
Reviews.Content: Very delicious old school italian. I got the chicken parm which was really good. The piece of chicken was really unnaturally large though so it made me worried. They must use some heavily hormone injected meat to get a single piece of chicken to that size. I would have preferred the marinara and provolone on top of non-mutant chicken.

Reviews.Author: Michael D.
Reviews.Content: I recently went to G's with a group of friends for my birthday.  I had never been before -- travesty! -- and couldn't resist its lure any longer.  I am completely glad we went.Hands down, I can say I was happier with the food here than I have ever been anywhere else in the North End.  Not that all the other restaurants are bad, but this one takes the gold.  The wait wasn't bad, as we had sent someone in advance to hold our spot in line.  Once most of our party had arrived, we were seated within fifteen minutes.  I also saw the hostess arrange to fit a party of 13 or so into the tiny restaurant without making them wait much more than half an hour -- pretty impressive.  Starters came quickly, and tasted great.  Same goes for the wine.I'm allergic to crustaceans, so all the lobster-based sauces alarmed me at first.  I'm usually upset when there are only a few options without shellfish, but I had a hard time choosing an entree here because several sounded delicious.  I went with the pumpkin tortellini, and loved it.  Everyone in the party was thrilled with the food: we definitely had that moment where all the conversation stopped because we were so busy enjoying and swapping.  High marks.

Reviews.Author: Min Y.
Reviews.Content: Very Crowded.  Very limited space, and a long wait.  However, The food was worth it.  I got a shrimp linguine with Giacomo sauce, which was excellent.  Giacomo is a tomato based cream sauce with a little spice.  My friends got seafood, which they thought was good.  (Note: I;m not a big seafood person).  Wine was affordable, which is a great plus. Gives you a glimpse of Italian atmosphere. Loud and lively :)

Reviews.Author: Lil Ms. S.
Reviews.Content: My person took me to this restaurant the first time we were in Boston together to celebrate my belated birthday and to end our beautiful vacation.  It was perfect! The food was delicious and well worth the wait. But be prepared to wait. The service is quick. People do watch you through the windows while you eat. It was a quick hustle and bustle but still very intimate. We had a great time! It was a great evening that turned out to be very romantic. I wouldn't change anything. Rating: One my favorite restaurants ever. Will always go back for the food and the ambience.

Reviews.Author: Maya I.
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I came here early on a Sunday a bit after it's opening time and there was already a line to the corner of the block (a good sign). Giacomo's at the North end does not take reservations- so get here early! Also, it's cash only. We waited about 45 minutes for a table to open up, about double the estimated time, but it was well worth it. It's a small, intimate place. Quite loud and the atmosphere is always bustling. We were seated by the kitchen and got to see the chefs in action, which was pretty cool. The Fried Calamari we got as our appetizer was perfect, we had to ask for more marinara sauce as we ran out. It was so delicious! My boyfriend ordered the Veal Marsala and loved it. It was tender and I would have been a fan as well but personally, I don't love Marsala sauce in general (not my dish, not my problem). I ordered the Butternut Squash Ravioli and OH MY GOD. It is a must have. I'm not generally a huge fan of Italian, but I love Giacomo's. As soon as the weather gets a bit warmer, we will return.

Reviews.Author: Mandy Y.
Reviews.Content: huge portions. delicious. a bit squishy but the service and good makes up for that. one of my favorite italian restaurants!

Reviews.Author: Tom S.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is an experience all the way around.  This place is CASH ONLY, no reservations!  When you find the place, there will most likely be a line.  Just get in it.  Periodically someone will come out and go up the line asking for the number in your party.  No names or anything else.  You sit as a table of your size becomes available. The best odds of getting a seat are for a party of two (or one).  Tables of 4 are ok.  Above 4 in your party and you will have a longer wait.  The physical restaurant is very small (as are many in this area of Boston).  From my experience, when you get to the edge of the restaurant in line (with the full width left to go), you are about 30 minutes from a seat. Is it worth it?  In a word - YES!!!!!Giacomo's was features on a Rachael Ray show for their calamari appetizer.  It is some of the better calamari I have eaten.  It has some hot peppers thrown in and fried as well and is served with marinara sauce.  Be careful, food at Giacomo's comes out hot so don't burn yourself.  A small calamari is $7 and feeds one hungry person or two average folks nicely.  All meals come with bread which is to die for.The dinner menu has a little of everything.  Vegetarian, grilled fish, traditional italian basic foods, and seafood.  Most people eat the pasta with seafood.  The basic pasta is linguini and you pick seafood protein and a sauce (there are five to choose from).  The plates are good sized and could stretch to two people if you are trying to sample around your table.  I LOVE the lobster and shrimp over home made fusilli pasta with Diavolo sauce which seems to be a very common special at $26.  There is always a bunch of lobster meat and shrimp on it.When they seat you, the staff will ask if you have been before.  If you haven't they will explain the menu.  The service is crisp but friendly.  I have always been very happy with the speed and quality of the service.  This last time, my calamari hit the table before I finished ordering my main.  Giacomo's does not serve dessert.  Not a big deal since you are a block away from Mike's Pastries where you can get whatever you want.If you are looking for a Michelin star dining experience or high end experimental cooking, this is not your place.  If you want to spend three hours on a meal in an intimate dining conversation over five courses, also not your place.  The food is basic but really well done in my opinion.  If you want really high quality food at good prices and a fun dining experience this place is for you.

Reviews.Author: Bora K.
Reviews.Content: You know the kind of meal where the table is dead silent because everyone's too busy eating to talk? That's the kind of meal you'll be having at Giacomo's.The wait is going to be a long one and in the winter time it's no fun since you'll be outside in freezing temperatures. The place is tiny too so that adds to the wait. However, the food is so so worth it.Our waiter was so funny.. We each ordered a glass of pinot grigio and the chardonnay. Our undershirt clad  suspender wearing waiter came over with our wine in identical glasses and asked me to identify them without tasting them. When I identified them correctly, he gave me a big kiss on the top of my head. What a way to start off a meal!We had the lobster spaghetti with the house marinara sauce and the spaghetti with clams. So good. The entire meal was utterly silent. The only sounds you could hear were the slurping of noodles and little moans of happiness/contentment.Giacomo's is the best Italian meal I've ever had. Go go go!

Reviews.Author: Lauren A.
Reviews.Content: I went here a while ago while my mom was in town, and I got the butternut squash ravioli.  I have. never. tasted. any. ravioli. that. good.  The sauce complemented the sweet ravioli perfectly.  Like our server said, it's like dinner and dessert all rolled into one.  My mom and her boyfriend had seafood dishes, and while they were also good, my ravioli and fried calimari were definitely better.

Reviews.Author: Fern H.
Reviews.Content: We arrived around 5:15-ish on a Sunday afternoon and already the line was about 20 people long.  Luckily our wait was only 25 min. and we were in!  I ordered the lobster ravioli and hubby got the seafood ziti.  Got two apps (Caesar salad and small calamari) and two glasses of wine.  Food was extremely tasty, definitely worth the wait.  Not to mention prices were quite frugal.  Total on bill with taxes and tips came out to $60.00.  Definitely not a place to go if you want to take a long time to eat, lounge and enjoy a bottle of wine.  There was no dessert or coffee menu offered but we just picked up some stuff from Mike's.  Would definitely go back without a doubt!

Reviews.Author: Shannon L.
Reviews.Content: Everyone and their mom seems to know about Giacomo's.  And if they don't, then they'll wait in line as soon as they see a line forming.  Monkey see, monkey do.  Regardless, their experiences will always be superb!You have to have everyone present in your party to be seated unless you can order for them.  We started waiting about 30 minutes before opening and got seated right when it opened.  My friends raved about the Frutti di Mare and you can get an individual platter of this or a two-person platter (which includes lobster for $55 or for $65 you can add wine too).  See my pictures for comparison.  It was heavenly.  Definitely get the half red and half white sauce.  The seafood was fresh, the pasta was cooked al dente, and the sauce had depth (they don't just throw cream at you).We also got calamari as an appetizer and they deep fry the peppers in addition to it (similar to Rhode Island style).  Good but didn't surprise me as much as my main dish.  I don't normally go out of my way for Italian food but this blew my mind.  It was my first time to Boston but this is definitely a place I'll come back to... no doubt!

Reviews.Author: Alison C.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is a famed destination in Boston's Italian food mecca, the North End.  Crowds of people linger on the sidewalk with their faces pressed against the warm windows, counting down the moments until they too can enjoy the large plates of succulent pasta.  While on a recent business trip, I thought an unseasonably warm Monday evening would be the perfect occasion to brave the potential line.  I was shocked when I arrived and was informed of the 25 minute wait on such a typically slow weeknight evening.When my brother and I were finally ushered into the cramped space, we were stuck with the only free table, right in front of the doorway.  The tiny dining room was overwhelmingly loud, making it hard to hold a conversation.  In addition, the daunting line of patrons kept the servers busily dashing all about the space.  My chair was constantly getting knocked into, and each time a new group of diners entered or exited, I was hit with a blast of cold air from outside.  The rude staff and constant activity was distracting and stress-inducing, which tainted the enjoyability of meal.As if that was not enough, our nasty waiter had forgotten to put in our order, causing us to linger at our table longer than most.  He did apologize and grant us a free bruschetta, but that did little to ease my anxiety.  Our entrees were rather tasty, but the cuisine was still overrated in my opinion.  The Fruitti Di Mare only contained a few shrimp, scallops, and clams, but was heavily induced with calamari and mussels.  The fresh shellfish was fantastic and was served over perfectly cooked pasta, but its red sauce was bland, dry, and scarce on the plate.  What could have been a typical Chicken Marsala was jazzed up by added strands of spicy prosciutto and plump, fresh mushrooms.  This added kick was much appreciated, but sorely missed on the accompanying side of pasta, which was mismatched with a marinara sauce.  Giacomo's provided a meal full of fresh, home-style Italian flare.  However, its uncomfortable space and tense dining conditions should discourage you from joining the lengthy line.  There are plenty of more convenient, and just as tasty, options in the neighborhood.

Reviews.Author: Dustin F.
Reviews.Content: LEGEN --- wait for it --- DARY  .....So I guess we were lucky and there were two spots at the bar right when we walked in (around 7p.m. on a Wed night) - based on the reviews, I was expecting an hour wait....which based on the fact that I had just gorged at the Barking Crab wouldn't have been the worst thing in the world.  Anyway....my friend and I ordered two apps - the Caprese salad and Antipasta platter.  Neither were special or memorable - in fact, I was a bit concerned about what was to come.  Just to clarify, they weren't bad, but just not unique or great.  So you might ask....so why the FIVE STAR rating - well just wait for it....I ordered the Lobster Ravioli and my friend ordered the Gnocchi stuffed with goat cheese and other deliciousness....and then we ordered the garlic bread to sop up all the creamy mess.  How do you describe heaven - well it may just be these two dishes.  I mean, I couldn't believe the literal ecstasy I was in.  Remember that scene in What About Bob? - we were two guys sitting at a bar recreating that scene - and not just because - we were doing it because every bite WAS that good!  This place is a must!Oh and btw - service was hectic, but very friendly and definitely mostly attentive.

Reviews.Author: Al C.
Reviews.Content: No exaggeration when it comes to waiting outside for an 30 mins to an hour before this place opens.  It is the real deal and totally worth baking in the hot humid sun.The door opened at exactly 4:30 and a smallish lady with a slightly mean accent walked out and got the number of guests for each party.  She went back into the dining room and quickly rearranged tables and seats to make the most optimal configuration for the first load of guests.  At exactly 4:35 we were let in like a wild herd of overeager children.  Mild organized chaos ensued.  Our waitress was a nice lady, very efficient and got us going quickly.  The calamari and the burrata came out fast.  The calamari was better than probably any calamari I've ever had, and by a fairly wide margin.  The burrata was awesome, the obvious shining star of that dish was the mozzarella.Wild mushroom ravioli was delicious.  And then I discovered the small mound of goat cheese in the middle and that suited the ravioli even better.  Others in my party were satisfied as well with their dishes.  Brother got a killer plate of linguine with half a lobster underneath.  Massive quantities of tastebud pleasing food. Pumpkin tortellini was good, for about the first ten tortellinis.  Got a bit repetitive and somewhat lackluster after eating several of them.  We switched plates amongst ourselves and solved that minor dilemma.Lobster ravioli won unanimous praise and was probably our group favorite.Feeling sorry for sweating patrons outside, we scurried outta there after the main entrees and opted to get dessert elsewhere.

Reviews.Author: Ziyan C.
Reviews.Content: Decent Italian spot. Solid food w/ nice sauces and good seafood, but the texture is more on the al dente side (I like my pasta softer).We got:* fried calamari (with marinara sauce) small 7, large 10- You can never really go wrong with calamari.. this was good, nice textured breading, fresh sauce. Giant serving with the large.* caprese (tomato, fresh mozzarella, basil ) 9- Can't quite go wrong with this either. Liked that there was plenty of balsamic dressing.* Linguine entree with choice of sauce & seafood. My friends got giacomo (their house special - lobster) sauce, with mussels & calamari. 15- Giant, giant serving! Linguine is softer. The Giacomo sauce is unique & pretty good, not too strong on the lobster flavor.* squid ink papardelle with swordfish and tuna (putanesca) 16- Definitely definitely al dente. May also be due to the squid ink changing the texture of the papardelle. But that really ruined what I usually love about the soft flow of papardelle. The fish & the sauce were good.* chocolate truffle bomb- Lots of chocolate! Not the highest quality. Just too much sweet.. you feel kind of gross after eating this.* special: lemon mascarpone cake- The mascarpone cheese seemed a little stale and hard. The cake while moist and dense seemed a little stale as well.Not sure what happened but I had a progressively worse stomach ache all night after eating here and ended up throwing up at about 1am that night. It was all black from my squid ink papardelle. I'm not detracting stars for this but.. not a happy night for me.

Reviews.Author: Cassy H.
Reviews.Content: For my 300th review, I decided to save it for Giacomo's! I've wanted to try this place ever before I moved to Boston, but every time I walk by, there's a long, long line out the door. So, given its popularity, my friends and I decided to go early, around 4:30 pm (before it opens) and wait in line. Yes, waiting in line before the restaurant opens.. the crazy things we do for food.Anyway, we weren't seated immediately, because we were a party of four, but missing one person. Note taken, please have all members of your party present, so you can be seated.. otherwise, they won't seat you and will take in the next available and present party in line. This place is tiny, but homey inside. You will probably end up sharing a table or sitting very close to another group of people. You might even spill your glass of water, because everything is so cramped in that knocking things over is almost, always expected.We decided to share everything, so here's what we got.1) calamari: delicious, large, perfectly battered pieces of calamari with spicy peppers, adds an extra kick2) fresh mozzarella ball with tomatoes drizzled with evoo and balsamic vinegar: I absolutely love mozzarella, so this was a definite win for me. Great app to share with people.3) Pesto pasta with mussels and clams: Very solid pesto pasta dish with perfectly cooked seafood4) Fusilli with lobster with Giacomo sauce: Fresh tasting fusilli with special Giacomo sauce is a must-try for this joint.. I wish there were more lobster in the dish though.5) Lobster ravioli: Another great tasting lobster dish, but again, I wish there were more lobster!By the end of the meal, we were super full, satisfied, and happy (very happy for me). The bill wasn't too bad either, but it's cash only (like many other places in the North End).

Reviews.Author: Chris T.
Reviews.Content: Pasta is well cooked, and the wait time was shorter than expected. Service was almost clichéd in its warmth and generosity, and while the derisive comments regarding the "touristy" vie are certainly true, there's a reason for the long lines.The food is nice, but not amazing. Shrimp and scallops fradiavolo was good, but shrimp were overlooked, and the promised chilli was decidedly muted. Lobster ravioli is coated in a sauce of such epic strength that any hint of lobster is removed. Luck the sauce is delicious.For an appetiser, two pastas, and a bottle of wine we spent $80 (including tip)--this presents great value. My tip for those looking for a seafood kick is to head to the Daily Catch just down the road.

Reviews.Author: Austin D.
Reviews.Content: We were lucky to get there before the rush, and to sit in the best seats in the house at the bar, from where we were could see everything, including the kitchen. It's as close to a "chef's table" as you can get in this tiny North End institution.Had the lobster special over linguine with half diavolo (spicy marinara) and half giacomo (marinara w/little cream). Unbelievably good!By the time we left 90 minutes later, there was a line 20 people deep. On our way out, belly full, we smiled and parted the crowd, off to walk off some calories, and to find a a nice gelateria.

Reviews.Author: Keri M.
Reviews.Content: In an area where the food tastes substantially the same from restaurant to restaurant, this one stands out above the rest.  Don't be fooled by the small and simple menu.  Everything here is good.  The sauces are the key behind the quality of the meals here.  I've never been disappointed.  The service is great.  The atmosphere is not formal or pretentious, as north end restaurants like to be.  Comfortable eating environment.

Reviews.Author: Melissa W.
Reviews.Content: Finally!  I've tried so many North End restaurants and this is only the 2nd one that impressed me. Actually, it made my night. I understand why there is always a line out the door now... (go early!)I had one of their specials - the chicken & cheese ravioli with sauteed red peppers and a creamy pesto, for about $15.  Delicious!  Afterward my breath reeked something terrible, though.  But that is the price you must pay, my friends.  Other members of my group were impressed with their lobster and the chicken eggplant parmigiana.  The staff was a bit rushed, but relatively speaking, not too rude.  (This IS Boston, after all!)  I'll gladly go back any time.Remember - cash only!

Reviews.Author: Lissa -.
Reviews.Content: The bf and I found this place while walking down the street. It also seemed appealing because it was featured on Rachel Ray's "$40 a Day" show. The place is small and seating is a bit tight when it's busy, but the food was good. Expect extra large portions!

Reviews.Author: Jason G.
Reviews.Content: People like Boston because of Larry Bird, Tom Brady, Samuel Adams beer or the chowda. I like Boston because of Giacomo's. I highly recommend you get there very early or very late because once this place opens its lights out. The food is extremely memorable. Very fresh and the small intimate setting really adds to the experience. It's like eating in your Italian grandmother's kitchen, only you're not Italian.Gnocchi is out of this world and I would say skip dessert and walk down the street to Mike's Pastry for a cannolli afterwards. There are two Giacomo's but I prefer the North End. This place is a top 5 restaurant in Boston, no question.

Reviews.Author: Solomon C.
Reviews.Content: Came here the other night for the first time and this place is absolutely incredible! The menus are written on blackboards on the walls, one side is the main menu, the other is their daily specials and our waitress was super friendly and attentive. I had the half lobster, clams, mussels on linguine with their "fracomo" sauce (that's combining two of their sauces) and it was delicious! you know how some places have a big pot of pasta and just slap it on a plate, it ends up tasting bland because it never soaked up the sauce? Well NOT HERE!  I slurpped up every strand of savory linguine goodness! Totally worth a far drive into town.Cons: their clams were mighty scrawny. don't know if they fell out or boiled off but there wasnt much of it in there. I'm willing to over look that because their mussels, lobster and pasta were delish!no valet parking! if you come for dinner, you're screwed because you can't park in the north end unless u live there. I ended up parking down by quincy market for $17CASH ONLY! Learned it the hard way. A little embarassing.

Reviews.Author: Connie S.
Reviews.Content: A North End favorite for generous heapings of pasta with fresh seafood, in a cozy space. Note: Don't be intimidated by the line- it moves must faster than expected.Before you decide anything else, you must order the Garlic Bread. It's the best garlic bread I've tried in recent memory, the fresh baked bread (still warm) is doused in olive oil and is wonderfully garlicky.  And, as for entrees, you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. I thoroughly enjoyed the Linguini with Mussels, Calamari, in Fra-como sauce (hybrid of the spicy Fra Diavolo sauce and the slightly creamy Giacomo house sauce)  If you like filled pastas in cream sauce, both the Butternut Squash Ravioli and the Pumpkin Tortellini are a delight.Even though our server (Rosemarie) was very no-nonsense, she was super patient and attentive throughout the meal. The food came pretty quickly, but we didn't feel rushed to eat faster than normal-- it was still a lovely dining experience despite the high-energy bustle of the restaurant. I wish Giacomo's served dessert, but I suppose its neighboring bakeries can satisfy that craving well enough already.

Reviews.Author: Albert D.
Reviews.Content: YUM.All I can say is: fusilli with lobster meat (!!) in a lobster-base beschemel creme sauce. huge dish, I got full, which is saying a lot.This place is Boston's saving grace. Cash only, make sure you have money. It's worth the wait outside. Bring a jacket. Save room for a canolli at mike's pastries afterwards!

Reviews.Author: Insun M.
Reviews.Content: Favorite casual italian in all of Boston!I've been to both locations and I think the North End location beats the South End not only because of the general atmosphere but when I eat there I can tell in my soul that the cooks and the waiter truly cares about what I am about to eat. Of course part of the entire experience is to wait in the long line and look longingly at the people inside. Once my dining partner and I sat down and started to strategically decide what dishes we would order I noticed a group of about 5 people being served the seafood pasta for 2. Immediately one of the girls took out her camera and started to take pictures of the beautiful dish and the waiter snatched her camera away and yelled in a good natured way "food is for eating! not taking pictures!" the entire restaurant (all 15 tables) laughed and that is when I knew I was going to have a fantastic meal. - calamari appetizer: it was so good that we regretted not ordering the large- seafood pasta with a combination of the giacomo sauce and their spicier sauce (as recommended from the "food is for eating! man" : as soon as it was set down in front of me the man asked me "do you want cheese?" and before I could answer him he quickly said "yes, you need cheese. I will get the cheese." By now, I just wanted to ask him if I could be his adopted korean granddaughter. The pasta? Lets just say it was so delicious I have dreams about that dish- chicken marsala: it was good, no complaints but not as memorable as the previous two. Next time if you have about an hour or so to kill before you think you'll get hungry go to Giacomo's. You will not regret it.

Reviews.Author: Mike M.
Reviews.Content: WOW!First of all, I was in Boston for business and had a Monday afternoon off.  I walked to the North End around 4:45pm that day and saw a couple of people waiting outside a restaurant.  When I walked by the place, I noticed the place was packed too.  I thought, "I need to check this place out when I am hungry!"  Well, about 6:15 or so I made it back to that area of the North End and now the line was around the corner.  I thought, I need to look this place up on Yelp.Whoa!  865 Reviews and 4.5 stars?  I'm waiting in line.  I was alone that night so I went in to tell the host and he said my wait would be much shorter and it was.  About 30 minutes or so.I had the calamari appetizer and it was amazing!  I wondered what the red and green rings were in my calamari.  Come to find out they were jalapeno rings!  I loved it.  Then I had shrimp and scallops over linguine with their spicy red sauce.  It was phenominal!It is worth the wait!

Reviews.Author: Kitia F.
Reviews.Content: Long overdue, but I'm on a roll today so here it goes!delicious food and decently price, but come ready.The lines can be pretty long, but if you come at the right time before 5, you'll be good to go!Don't try to be in the line without your party because you'll just get left behind. The lady won't even write your name on the notepad!it can be loud, it's small, but it's also delicious!!Oh CASH only!!

Reviews.Author: Jenny L.
Reviews.Content: I ate here two years ago and I STILL dream about this meal. BF and I got the best seat in the house - right at the bar where we could see the amazing chefs at work. I had the scallops in their tomato sauce(made with lobster) and it was HEAVEN. Hands down the best Italian food I've ever had and nothing will ever come close. The next time I'm in the area, this is definitely on the itinerary. GO HERE!!

Reviews.Author: Heidi E.
Reviews.Content: The North End makes my head spin in ways that are both very good and very bad. The very bad is mainly a result of being overwhelmed by restaraunt choices. And my luck randomly picking places in the North End is usually 30% good 70% really not worth it. BUT- Giacomo's bumps up the good percentage.This is a great option if you're looking for down and dirty Italian food at a reasonable price. If you're scanning the web and entering "delicate" "refined" or "upscale" as search words, close this review and continue on.I went on MLK day for an early-ish dinner. Giacomos was packed as usual, but we were lucky enough to grab the 2 seats at the counter. The food was very tasty- mussels, fettucini with salmon, and the butternut ravioli (shared between 2 people- I'm not THAT much of a pig). Real crusty Italian bread. We had a prime view of the kitchen from up there. I kept on wondering where they were pulling all the food from. But in this magical juggling act, they got the orders out...mahi mahi, chicken parm, mussels, pasta...on and on.   What really made the experience though was our waitstaff. She was funny and attentive from start to finish. The consumate saleswoman. Seemed as though she really enjoys what she does. If you decide to stop by, consider the character of the place. I've been in here other times and in restrospect, I've realized that it's just like dining at your Italian Grandma's house (my Grandmother wasn't Italian- but roll with me here). If she's in a good mood- you'll be fed and pampered till you burst. If the stars aren't alligned, however, you'd better order and eat because there are people waiting for your precious table.But for me, that's the character of the restaraunt...just one of many things that makes this place worth a good review.

Reviews.Author: Tammie P.
Reviews.Content: I came here last November for my friend;'s birthday.  We had reservations, but were seated about 30 mins later.  The place was packed, and there were only 2-3 servers.  We had the fried calamari, which was good, but nothing extraordinary.  The butternut squash is really good here, but the cream sauce can feel a bit heavy towards the end of the meal.  My friend got the fruitti di mare fra diavolo and it was pretty good.  Despite the slow service, the food made up for it.  I saw a  lot of dishes I would want to try the next time I come back.

Reviews.Author: Ro P.
Reviews.Content: So my friend and I are young. We're two 20-somethings walking around in jeans and in the rain. But we're also paying customers who came in looking for a fine dining experience. And there were no other folks around. We weren't pierced in every ying-yang and makeup-up like hookers.So I expect to be treated nicely when I go to a lovely restaurant. Don't treat us like immature children because we're young and casually dressed. There's a reason we're here and not Gino's Pizzaria.

Reviews.Author: Star B.
Reviews.Content: Can't believe I haven't written a review for this place. SMH.My friend who moved to Boston earlier this year took us here when we visited in Feb. Got in line around 30 minutes before they opened up for dinner because we heard about the line and thank sweet baby jesus that we did!The line got long super fast! As soon as they opened up, we got in with the first wave of people. We were so hungry at that point and we ordered the house special for two: Zuppa di Pesce - shrimp, scallops, calamari, clams, mussels and lobster served over linguine with your choice of sauce. We got the Giacomo sauce and DAMN, that ish was soooooooo good!!!!!!!! $55 for that and we also got the bottle of wine for an additional $10. What a great deal!!It said "For Two", but the serving was HUGE for my friend and I and we literally took it home and it took us 3 days to finish it. And YES, it was still delish after you nuke it surprisingly. LOL.My mouth waters thinking about it, I personally think that the Giacomo sauce really completed the dish. I think they put crack in it or something. This place makes me want to go back to Boston all the time. I'll definitely be back. *drool.....

Reviews.Author: TM O.
Reviews.Content: The wait was forever and a day!  We had to stand outside and wait for about 20-30 minutes before being seated, they are so busy!I had the Lobster special with the spicy Giacomo's sauce.  It was so much better than I expected.  I'm usually very picky with Italian food because mediocre Italian food is so rampant.  Also because you can easily make Italian food at home.  HOWEVER, Giacomo's really hit the spot.  The sauce wasn't too tomatoey or bland.  It had something in there that coated the noodles perfectly.  I have to say that the lobster so very fresh! It was sweet and complimented the sauce perfectly.I will definitely eat here again when I go back to Boston.

Reviews.Author: Kate Y.
Reviews.Content: When I was in boston last time for a visit. I checked the review of Giacomo and deicided to come to check it out. When my friend and I got there no surprise there was a long line but not that bad. we waited like 20 mins and a waitress came out to confirm how many people for each group. however,my friend left to go to restroom during the waiting unfortuntely few mins later it was time for us to get in for a table. The waitress was so  impatience and was kind of rude to me when she couldn't understand why I got 2 but i am the only person being waiting. I mean i could totally understand you gotta do this every evening and repeat the same question for 6 or 7 days a week. ***HOWEVER,could you please being a little nicer to your customers? If you gonna take us a shit then i am not gonna buy it next time or recommend to friends.The waiters inside are much better but I gotta say  its not a place for romatic and slowly eating place. They want you eat fast and get out of thereASAP because they need more tables to other groups. I was dispointed about their service eventually.***They dont accept credit card.

Reviews.Author: Krista W.
Reviews.Content: This was the destination of our first Valentine's Day in Boston last year, and it was a DELIGHT. The butternut squash ravioli is divine. The pumpkin ravioli kicks booty. The calamari has just the right amount of kick and crunch. Go expecting a line, (unless you show up at 5pm) to pay in cash, a small- if not tiny- dining area, your food to be dished up fast, helpful and fun(ny) wait staff, and not to sit and chat for hours at your table- save that for the next little coffee/pastry shop you go to in the North End that evening.

Reviews.Author: Wendy H.
Reviews.Content: Scrumptious pasta sauces and generous portions for an unbeatable price!(There are other restaurants that are just as good but charge 2x as much!)Dishes to highlight:1. Lobster Ravioli, one of the best Boston has to offer2. I wouldn't recommend the Chicken Pasta3. Butternut pasta- tasty!4. Seafood sampler: Generous portions for under $20We waited an hour but it was totally worth it!

Reviews.Author: Joey H.
Reviews.Content: Superb Italian experience, much like Limoncello, but more free to talk loud and dress a little more casual type place.  The menu was on the chalk boards, as well as the specials.  The big entree around that place was the giacomo linguini, which unfortunately I did not order.  I ordered the pesto style penne with chicken and shrimp.  Sooooo creamy, and tasty, and oh sooooo yummy.  Everything about this place screamed eat here.  The service was amazing, the price was less than what was served, and the wait is worth it all.  ORDER THE CALAMARI!!!!!  I'll add 5 more stars just for this appetizer!

Reviews.Author: Ed C.
Reviews.Content: This place is getting overran.  Our wait was 40min for two people, which isn't horrible, but not entirely pleasant either.  We had the shrimp and scallop pasta in giacomo's special sauce ($16, which was a bit over thick and heavy on cream for a pink sauce), and the 1/2 lobster pasta special with the spicy tomato sauce ($20).  The lobster was undercooked, and part of the claw still came out semi-transparent.  We had to send it back to be cooked over again.  The house pinot grigio was cheap and what you might expect it to be.   We also had the fried calamari to start, and that was really nice, but a bit too oily in the plate.It's all just adequate, but the undercooked lobster left us not too impressed.  It's just okay overall for us.

Reviews.Author: Patrick W.
Reviews.Content: Excellent experience!We went on an weekday night with 7 people and were seated in 20 mintues!Appetizers and wine were out within minutes of orderingPlenty of variety on the menu, including vegetarian, all done wellMy favorite was the pumpkin tortellini, but the eggplant parm was well doneAbsolutely great Italian food at an unbeatable price

Reviews.Author: Maria A.
Reviews.Content: Wait a second!  I have been to Boston 3 times in the past 2 years.  Each time, I went to Giacomo's, and I hadn't written a review?!  Shame on me!!I absolutely LOVE this restaurant!!  Before going the first time, I first heard about this place on Rachael Ray's show, and was excited to try the food.  After my first time here, I knew I was going to come back, each time I'm in town.After reading about the long wait, we had made it a point to go there right when it opened, and each time, we were able to get a table no problem.  However, wait about a half hour after the restaurant opens, there's a line outside.  So, yes, this place is small, but I do like the intimate setting.  The third time we came here, we got to the restaurant about a half hour before it was to open, and there were already two other couples waiting.  It was freezing outside, and they let us in before they were scheduled to open - AWESOME!The hostess and servers are REALLY REALLY nice.  The servers were patient and answered any questions we had.  The fried calamari is delicious; I just love the sauce for dipping, perfect touch of sweetness ($7 small, $10 large).  The lobster ravioli is very good ($16); a delicious creaminess that just makes you close your eyes and say thanks to its creator.  My absolute favorite dish to order is the linguini with a mix of giacomo's and fra diavolo's sauce and with shrimps and scallops ($16).  If you're not into spicy, then I recommend not getting the fra diavolo sauce, but if you're a spicy lover like me, GET IT!!  Sheesh, my mouth is watering just thinking about it.  Not to mention, very affordable.I went to the bathroom once here, and just have to warn you all.  The bathrooms are downstairs, and the staircase is pretty narrow.  Strange, the floors were very slippery/greasy, so be very careful!  I don't know if it was just that one time, but that was enough for me to seek bathrooms elswhere.If I lived closeby and went here often, I would love to try the other items on the menu, but since I hardly go to Boston, I'm going to stick with my fave.I cannot wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Jeffrey K.
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were here this past week and it's fabulous. Italian at its best! The frutti de mare in scampi is what I order in every Italian restaurant. It was among the best I have ever had! Our server seemed like he was running the place. The tables are packed so tightly together that watching the service is an act the likes of which can only be seen in performance art. We definitely recommend this place to anyone who is in the north end! Get there early and have cash... Particularly some smaller bills for tip.

Reviews.Author: Amy L.
Reviews.Content: I definitely love this place, Giacomo's.We've waited outside in line for about an hour on Friday night but absolutely worth it :) We started with their popular calamari appetizer and the garlic bread then we had the butternut squash ravioli and veal Parmesan dish....The calamari appetizer was fresh and good and the garlic bread had a great flavor but unfortunately resembled the texture of hardtack.....The butternut squash ravioli was rich and delicious... I personally thought the sweetness over took the dish but overall I enjoyed the dish as well as the veal parmesan..I would go back here next time to try some more dishes!! maybe...lobster ravioli or special seafood platter :D

Reviews.Author: Matt C.
Reviews.Content: We waited for 45 minutes to get into Giacomo's on a Sunday evening, but let's face it: Where else would you rather be outside on a beautiful summer evening than in Boston's North End, surrounded by the sights and smells of Italia?  Without a doubt, it was well worth the wait.The caprese salad was wonderful, with large fresh tomatoes and fresh mozzarella, drizzled with balsamic vinegar and diced basil.  The butternut squash ravioli were by far the best I've ever had, and the sauce managed to be creamy and flavorful without being heavy.  My friend let me try the seafood pasta special from that night, which was also incredibly well done.For this high quality of food at their (almost) absurdly reasonable prices, Giacomo's simply can't be beat.

Reviews.Author: lisa v.
Reviews.Content: You can believe the high marks. Giacomo's is all that. After living in Boston the better part of forever, I finally got to the North End location last night with some friends visiting from the Midwest. The wait for a table of 5 was something along the lines of 45-60 minutes, but we had expected that. We got the two appetizers people rave about: a large order of calamari and an order of broccoli in garlic butter. They were stellar. The broccoli was fresh, al dente, and the sauce was sublime. The calamari was light, meltingly tender, crunchy and just outrageously delicious. For entrees, we had four entrees. One was the pumpkin ravioli with mascarpone sauce that everybody raves about. A friend put one of those suckers in his mouth and just had to close his eyes and tilt his head back in bliss. You too will be whisked into another intergalactic dimension-cum-nirvana of yumminess if you order it. I had to slap the wait staff's hands so I could lick the plate clean before they took the dish away. We also got the eggplant parmiagana. Now, this is the right way to cook eggplant: You get a deli meat slicer and you shave ultra-thin slices of eggplant so that the layers in this dish are distinct and light, as opposed to the globby blob wonders that come out of some kitchens, with eggplant slabs in a congested confusion of tomato sauce and cheese. What I'm saying is that Giacomo's does it right, does it perfect. For the other entrees, we got two dishes of pasta: one had mussels and shrimps with Giacomo's sauce, which we think was some type of pleasant, light tomato with perhaps a touch of cream sauce. It was nice, but not eye-rolly nice. The final entree was fettucini with tuna and swordfish chunks in a pesto cream sauce. The pesto cream sauce was delicious, but the fish chunks were meager. I think next time I'd just order the swordfish steak. We got two bottles of Sangiovese off a delightfully affordable wine list that had a good selection of serviceable wine for $17/bottle. They do have reserve wines for the deep-pocketed, but the Sangiovese suited us just fine. It's crowded, it's homey, the chalkboard has the menu handwritten (but it's the same menu as the paper menu, so no need to squint or sit close to it), the service was brisk and competent, we got stuffed. We thanked our lucky stars that we hadn't fallen prey to our starving-artist cheap-ass impulses. We could have gotten a Groupon or Yelp deal to Davide, or another one to some other North End restaurant with a ton of mediocre reviews, but we said screw it, let's go get some food we know we'll love. After all, Giacomo's prices are absolutely reasonable, particularly given that it's in the touristy North End, and particularly given the quality of the food. For a party of 5, we paid $137, which included an 18% gratuity and two bottles of wine. Go, by all means. Don't compromise your dinner out in the North End by being in a rush or wanting to save a few bucks with a coupon to an inferior restaurant.. Be prepared for a long wait. Order the calamari and those sublime pumpkin ravioli. Wowee wow.

Reviews.Author: Michael L.
Reviews.Content: This was a perfect place to take my girlfriend for dinner on the last night of our stay in Boston. We got there at about 6:00 and we were seated at 6:30. The food here is amazing. My girlfriend had the lobster ravioli and I the seafood pasta special. When you come here make sure you add Giacomo's Sauce to whatever entre you buy. It is the tastiest marinara sauce I have ever had. The only downside to this place is that it is very small (10 tables). We had to stand outside in the cold for 40 minutes before we can enter and be seated. I suggest heading to dinner early if you decide to dine here.

Reviews.Author: kwala t.
Reviews.Content: Five stars may seem a little overenthusiastic, but Giacomo's stands out as a uniquely Boston place and one of my favorite finds in this town.  The wait can be long during prime-time dinner hours, as they do not take reservations, but it's worth it!You cannot beat the hearty, seafood-heavy Italian dishes here, from homemade fusilli with lobster fra diavolo sauce, to the ravioli (both butternut squash and lobster rock!!).  I love that they offer a variety of combinations of seafood (mussels, shrimp, lobster, clams, fish) in your choice of sauce and pasta.  I'm from San Francisco, and as a big fan of cioppino, this means heaven on a menu.  I haven't had any of the meat dishes, but have heard good things about those, too.  The appetizers I've had were merely the backdrop for a stellar main entree, although I still have to try their calimari.  And because the entrees are so huge, you may not even want to order a starter.  If you do, you'll most certainly be heading home with a doggie bag.  Another plus is the super cheap and totally drinkable wine list - nothing that'll knock your socks off, but at $16 a bottle the price is recession right.  Giacomo's is crowded, cramped and staffed with a sassy but warm staff that do their best to navigate the ravenous crowds and tiny space.  I give it the highest rating for the quality of their food and the reasonable prices, as well as the fast-paced ambience.  This is what I want when I crave italian!

Reviews.Author: Neil Y.
Reviews.Content: Food here was good but wow, when you go somewhere where they are at the TOP of the yelp reviews , you'd better be ready for a crowd. Went there after a full day of doing that on/off bus touring of Boston.  Got there a bit early 4:50ish on a Thursday.  I figured they weren't open but they let us in after they saw us hovering around the entrance.   So we were the first ones in!  It was kind of hard to get in, as all the tables and chairs are crammed together, but that's ok.  Started with the Calamari and some beers.  Pretty good.  Looked up halfway through it and saw that the restaurant was full.   About this time my Scallops with Linguine with fra diavolo sauce came.  I was like huh, thats a little fast, but ok.  Parents got their dishes soon after, but by that time it was packed.  Now I eat fast, but I mean, within seconds of finishing (BTW excellent), they picked up my plate and then dropped the bill off... I was like, couldn't they even wait a little for when my parents were done (or even close to done?)  Eventually when we did leave, there was maybe 5 or 6 groups waiting outside.  Damn.  After that I decided I had probably made the wrong choice for choosing 'an Italian spot' in Boston, even though the food was excellent.  If you're just out of college, you probably don't care if food places are simultaneously serving you and shoving you out the door, just as long as the food is awesome and fast and (relatively) cheap.  But I guess if you want to savor your food, you probably shouldn't go to #1 yelped place, unless that place has 3 or more dollar signs on it. :PStill, food is food so 4 stars (great food, ok value, 'efficient' service)

Reviews.Author: Sarodge D.
Reviews.Content: When visiting Boston, the tour guide just said, "If you're hungry, go to Little Italy, find a line and just wait. you won't be disappointed."And he was not wrong.So I waited close to two hours, ate, and it was the best Italian food I ever ate.  I got the calamari and gnocchi and it was awesome.Do remember that it's CASH ONLY.

Reviews.Author: Nicole M.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's always has a long line outside, and with good reason. The food is delightful, the drinks are terrific, and the service is efficient. I recommend multiple trips to give everything on the menu a chance. You deserve it.

Reviews.Author: Jieyuan W.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian in town.

Reviews.Author: Shanya K.
Reviews.Content: WORTH THE WAIT!!!I have waited up to an hour outside in the cold and it's worth it!!!  The food gets better and better!!! I went with my boyfriend (It's his favorite place in Boston) and I'm hooked.  The food is amazing.  I got the Homemade fusilli pasta in Giacomo's signature sauce.  It was great!  My boyfriend had the chicken parm.  It was HUGE!!! The portions were enough for both of us to have leftovers.  We also started with some calamari and it was out of this world!  The drinks and food are priced really competitively, especially for the North End.  Just remember to bring cash, cause they don't take plastic!!!

Reviews.Author: Greg Y.
Reviews.Content: Despite the two (2) hour wait outside that bent around the building, I can honestly say that the meal at Giacomo's was worth the wait. Our waitress, despite the busy crowd, was pleasant and attentive.  I ordered the butternut squash ravioli, as suggested by many Yelpers. GREAT CHOICE.  The firmness of the ravioli was spot-on; the cheese sauce was flavorful but not too heavy; the butternut squash filling was rich, smooth, and savory. Just oh so good.North End is quite a trek from where I am, but the journey is nothing compared to that wait.  If you plan on being seated fast, get there on odd hours (for dinner, 4pm or 9pm).

Reviews.Author: Moxie M.
Reviews.Content: It's an abomination to have lived in Boston for four years with never having gone to Giacomo's. I recently absolved myself of my gastronomic sins by paying penitence waiting for an hour in line to enter Giacomo's in subzero weather. Once I got through the proverbial pearly gates, though, I knew all was forgiven; I was in heaven. Not a place to linger without fear of being slapped in the back of the head by an Italian grandmother (at least as I like to imagine it), it's worth the wait and worth the rush. The place is small and therefore turnover can take some time, but this adds to the character. Plus, the hoard of people pressing their hungry faces up against the glass watching you eat makes you feel like a celebrity, or zoo animal, but the popular kind, like a panda or something. A simple, classic Italian menu is presented to you, and it's hard to choose which plate to try because they are all guaranteed winners. I went with a pumpkin tortellini with sage cream sauce which perfectly melded the sweet and the savory into one tender pastalicious bite. My beau enjoyed his linguine in Giacomo's sauce, a lobster-based red sauce, enough to practically lick his plate. (I am happy to report he refrained.) Every other dish was both delectable and decimated. Bottles of wine top out at $16 each, and appetizers are sizable and affordable. The table shared a plate of calamari, which my father still mentions in every phone call we've had since then. Everyone who ate it loved it, leaving not a tentacle or ring behind. If you're are looking for a throwback to the times of hunting and gathering and don't mind earning your food, then wait in line at Giacomo's for one of the more satisfying meals of your life.

Reviews.Author: Kara B.
Reviews.Content: I wanted to love it, I really did but it just didn't happen for me.If I am going to wait in a line for something it better be amazing. After a wait average just doesn't make me happy, especially with so many other restaurants that are average or better in the neighborhood that don't involve waiting in a line.The service was good and quick, it was clear they wanted you in and out.The food was fine. There just wasn't anything special about it. It was your average Italian food in a too small crammed loud restaurant. Just not worth the wait.Also, my Mom went in the bathroom and alas no soap, that's worrisome.Hint: go to Panza instead, same owners, better food, no line

Reviews.Author: Erik W.
Reviews.Content: Amazing Italian.

Reviews.Author: Catherine L.
Reviews.Content: WARNING: This is not place for you and your friends to eat and drink and get to know each other.That being said, it is a long wait to get in. Perhaps an hour or so for me and my friends. When we got seated, they took our orders and our appetizers were out in about 5 minutes. We were so hungry we ate the calamarri (delcious especially with the fried pickled peppers) within seconds. Before we knew it, our main dishes came out and again we ate that in like 10 minutes! Now I am a nurse and we are notorious for scarfing down our food. But I never ate that fast in my whole entire life. LOL.I had the spaghetti in the spicy tomato sauce with seafood. It was on point and I would love to go back whenever I take a trip to Boston.

Reviews.Author: Wendy L.
Reviews.Content: My favorite restaurant in the North End.  The wait is typically really long, but so worth it.  I went one afternoon at 4:45 p.m. thinking nobody would be in line for dinner (really, I wasn't trying to get the senior citizens special....I just hadn't had lunch), but we still had to wait almost 45 minutes.  It might have been even worse than waiting during normal dinner time since I primarily stood in line with tourists.  Generally, I haven't found the wait to be any longer than 1 hr 15 min, but I bet on a snowy evening (which I would never brave), the wait would be much shorter.It is really reasonably priced and the food is awesome - the specials tend to be good, but the lobster ravioli is one of my favorites.  I don't even think I've ever had anything but the lobster ravioli.  My friends and I typically begin with some fried calamari (yum!), and the wine is super reasonably priced.  If you're with a small party, there is limited seating at the bar which can definitely speed up the wait...

Reviews.Author: Jay N.
Reviews.Content: While the food here is good, it is hardly worthy of slobbering praise.It is a bit too crowded and each time we've been the wait for our order has been longer than what would be considered normal. Also, like many businesses in Boston, the owners seem to have a horror of accepting credit cards, unless that has changed in the last several months.We all know WHY you aren't accepting credit cards and, that being the case, such businesses prove they have no care or concern for the customer, they're simply there to get your money.For this reason alone I would recommend only patronizing this business if you absolutely must.

Reviews.Author: Eric F.
Reviews.Content: Was very excited to finally try this place after hearing all the rave reviews and Giacomo's definitely lived up to the hype!  My friend and I tried the small Fried Calamari app, Butternut Squash Ravioli, and 1/2 lobster, mussels & clams over linguini with giacomo sauce.  The calamari was one of the best I've had with exceptional tenderness and just the right about of batter.  The linguini and seafood tasted fresh and perfectly-cooked (it's actually pretty amazing how easily Italian restaurants can overcook pasta...).  As for their renowned ravioli, it was delicious and the sweet finish to each piece was a great change of pace from the usual cheese and/or meat ravioli.The interior was surprisingly tiny in person even after seeing all the reviews noting the small space.  The staff make the most of the limited square footage though and our server did a very nice job providing a quick run-down of the wall menus, taking orders, refilling water, and helping to arrange the entrees/providing extra plates for easy sharing.  Looking forward to coming back in the future to try one of the wines to go with the meal - $16/bottle just can't be beat!

Reviews.Author: Lisa W.
Reviews.Content: I am very impressed by this restaurant! I normally don't like Italian food, but this made me LOVE Italian food! We waited about an hour though (place is small) but a nice warm feeling inside, the food was AWESOME, I got the seafood linguine with their house sause and it was flawless. And I didn't have that "heavy" feeling when you eat Italian food.  We also got the wine (fair price), and it paired well with the pasta. Must try if you are in the area!!

Reviews.Author: Anne W.
Reviews.Content: After being to numerous bad restaurants in the North End.. finally, I was told by my friend that although there is a horrible line, it is an amazing find.  So unfortunately, there is no point in having a phone number listed because they don't pick up the phone.  I only called because I wanted to know if they were open on July 4th.. they were.The line was long.. about an hour.  When we finally got a table.. we were wedged right by the door.  The food is indeed amazing for the price.  Started with mussels in red sauce.. so fresh and the sauce was good.  Tried the half lobster, mussels, and clams on top of linguine.. $20!  We got lobster and shrimp with handmade fuselli.. also amazing with plenty of lobster meat.Only complaint.. besides the cash only, bathrooms downstairs is so hot (for some reason there is no a/c down there or ventilation), and incredibly long line (don't ever bring a date because she'll beat you up).  The food isn't really hot.. it's like warm.. but not hot.  That kind of bothers me as I think the food is premade and not fresh.  Service is great.. wine was cheap but a tad warm.  I am guessing it's not the best stored wine.  They probably stuck it next to the bathroom.Secret tip:  I have seen somebody order take out.  A great way to surpass the line and still get the amazing food!

Reviews.Author: Mike Z.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian food I've ever had! Not a very big statement since I don't eat Italian food that often, but I'm certainly quite picky when it comes to critiquing it.The place is extremely small and crammed, you can barely take off your coat without smacking the neighboring persons head.  They don't take reservations, so like everybody else said, come early or late because there will be a line out the door around the corner. We were the first in line, so the wait was only about 15-20 minutes.I ordered the lobster ravioli - it was very good, but for $16, I thought the portion was quite small.  Though, I've learned that it's true for most ravioli dishes anyway.  My friends dishes looked very good and as expected, they all enjoyed it thoroughly.The wine is very inexpensive, it tasted alright.  It's cash only, so bring cash.The wait staff were quite pushy and rushed us, but we were expecting it anyway.  The place was too small and there are always people waiting in line, so it's definitely not a place for you if you want to slowly enjoy your food and sit around for another 30 minutes after having finished.  We sat down, ate, and left in 45 minutes.I'll be back!

Reviews.Author: Vincent M.
Reviews.Content: man oh man!! I came back to Giacomo's after a long hiatus (just not being able to get into the North End etc.) with my squeeze for her birthday and the food was even better than I remembered!!  We showed up to Giacomo's around 6pm on a Monday- the line was out the door (as usual) half way past the window at 1800FLOWERS.  I reassured the lady that this place was worth the wait.  Half hour later, we're seated and ordered.  The food came blindingly fast- two glasses of wine, fried calamari (perfection- that Fra Diavolo sauce: mama mia!), the butternut squash ravioli for her (one of the best thing on their menu), and linguini with calamari and mussels for me.  The food was hot, fresh, delicious and inexpensive.  The place is cash only- keep that in mindOur waitress was delightful, really friendly, did not rush us out even though there was a long wait, she was very sweet.  The bus boys were funny; one took photos for whoever wanted them.Keep in mind, you will NOT get a quiet romantic evening here at Giacomo's.  At Giacomo's, you'll get a loud, exciting, cramped dining experience but you'll eat some of the best Italian food ever.  Just incredible.

Reviews.Author: Christy D.
