Reviews.Content: Can you imagine showing up at a place 15 mins before it opens, only to see a bustling restaurant where people are already eating, and with one table for two left?  That's what it's like at Giacomo's.My friend and I started with the calamari, which was good.  The marinara is perfect and I love the fried slices of peppers thrown in with the squid rings.  I have had calamari a lot and this was rather standard--it didn't blow others out of the water.  I would probably start with another appetizer next time to try something different.  I think if you skip this to save room for other dishes, you're not missing much.  I had the glass of chianti, which I would recommend.For the entrees, I had the homemade fusilli with the Giacamo sauce (their creamy tomato sauce) with lobster and shrimp.  The shrimp were great, but the lobster, not so much.  It was very chewy.  The pasta was wonderful though...nothing beats homemade pasta!  If I got this again, I'd nix the lobster and get the diavolo sauce (the spicy tomato sauce).  The cream didn't do much for the sauce and I think the spiciness would've put more zing in the dish.My friend had the linguini with clams and mussels and the Scampi sauce (white wine, garlic and olive oil).  Her plate was tastier than mine, but it's hard to find something more complementary to mussels than wine and garlic.  She raved about this dish for days, and rightly so.The garlic bread was nothing special.  It was lacking in the garlic taste and was pretty greasy from the olive oil.  Not that there's anything wrong with that, it's just not how I like my garlic bread (I prefer more garlic taste and butter).Would I come back here?  Sure!  Would I wait in line for hours...probably not.  I'd make sure to go early, as in, before they open.

Reviews.Author: Isabella L.
Reviews.Content: 4.5 stars for divine Italian food but 3 stars for service. Restaurant: Elbow to elbow seating ... I felt intrusive next to a couple dining together. I did enjoy the fact that you could see the cooks in the background. This isn't a fancy setting, just quality food. No reservations, no CC accepted. Cash only. Service: The lady was rude to our party after I asked if we could switch tables. She told us to go outside and wait. Of course, this is our first time being there.. we were totally offended and confused. No matter, we went outside and waited, while I reassured my friends that we'll get good eats soon. Our waiter, however, made up for the night and provided excellent service, offering recommendations and creating small talk. Food: So phenomenal! Ordered a large fried calamari! It was everything that you read.. melt in your mouth fresh! I also loved the fried jalapenos with it! I ordered the Salmon dish with the lobster sauce, and my other friends ordered the Seafood platter and scallop spaghetti. All of the pasta were fresh and the only complaint was that the scallops were overcooked. Everything else was on point.

Reviews.Author: Paul P.
Reviews.Content: Cold bread and unfriendly staff. We came here for dinner following previous reviews and were completely disappointed. The waitress behaved as if we distracted her from an important business of watching the wall. Mussels and calamari consisted of 50% pasta 40% empty mussel shells, and 10% cold and stiff calamari rings. The veal was exceptionally tasteless. And as a marvelous conclusion it's a cash only place! One star is too much for them.

Reviews.Author: Jacqueline C.
Reviews.Content: I like the food, but they don't make me 'wow'Went to Giacomo with a friend on a Friday night at around 6:00.The line was short. We waited for about 10-15 mins.The place is really small!You basically need to sit tight with other tables.i ordered the special(lobster,clams,mussel over linquini) It came with large portion, but I killed it because I was hungry.My friend ordered the second special, and I found that hers tastes better.Service was...i won't say BAD but definitely not the so good. I would give a 2 star max.I would definitely return to try out other dishes. But for now I think I will try out other restaurants in the North End first.

Reviews.Author: John W.
Reviews.Content: On any given night you will find a line gathered on the sidewalk outside this cramped North End joint, eager to dive into perfectly seasoned pasta dishes. It is worth the wait. The atmosphere is intimate and the portions are generous, however, the service can be hit or miss.There is no desert at Giacomo's, which is fine because there are a dozen cafes in the North End that serve tiramisu. And remember, it's cash only.

Reviews.Author: Lyndsay B.
Reviews.Content: Just adding to the rave reviews! This is a great place to go if you want pasta and seafood (or maybe chicken) with a tasty sauce. That's about all they offer, so be prepared.Calamari was good, not the best I've had, but definitely good.The specials are good, and the Giacomo sauce is absolutely delicious! YUM!The bread waiting at the table was a little tough, but had a nice crumb.Oh! And, our waitress was awesome! She was funny, engaging and even gave us great advice about what to order! She definitely helped make the meal.We waited for an hour on a Friday night at about 6. It was great to get to know some of the others waiting in line with us. Very worthwhile.As others have said, cash only.

Reviews.Author: Trip B.
Reviews.Content: This is by far my most important staple Italian place in the city. Its older brother hangs out in the South End and induces long waits for hungry tourist but this little guy, nestled in the South End a) takes reservations and b) does not get as crazy as a loon on a weekend night. As you might know the butternut squash ravioli really is incredible and the gnocchi is nap inducing and so very good. I'd say that this location is where the locals go and unless you have to eat Italian in the North End, stick to the South End location and the crowds won't make you nervous.

Reviews.Author: Michelle L.
Reviews.Content: If you're craving a true North End experience you can't afford to miss Giacomo's-- one of Boston's best values. From the hot open kitchen and tight quarters to the no-nonsense waitstaff and cash-only checkout you'll get what you came for when you eat here.I'll echo what everyone else has said. There IS always a line, they serve up huge portions, and the wine is economico!  I recommend my two favorites, which remain the butternut squash ravioli with diced asparagus in a proscuitto, mascarpone cheese cream sauce (to die for) OR the fusilli with lobster and shrimp, covered in a blend of fra diavolo and giacomo sauces. (Savory wonderfulness!)This place is NOT:  Great for people who "don't do lines". Not great for people who like to "charge it". Also not great for large parties. Really not great for sitting around reminiscencing with a long-lost friend over a two-hour dinner. Tables turn over quickly here, but you'll get what you order fast.This place IS: Great for a date with a person you really like. Great for eating alone (they'll have you out of there in a flash). Great for a sibling catch-up date. Great for people who know good food and are willing to wait for it.Giacomo's is Boston's best Italian dining experience from start-to-finish. But that's just the opinion of 200-something complete strangers...

Reviews.Author: Jeff K.
Reviews.Content: Dear Giacomo's,I give you my stamp of approval.When I got to this place, I realized that there was a line outside. Here on Hanover St, there are so many little Italian places that one would wonder there would be a line at this small italian place tucked in the back.Well first off, the place is small. But this is somehow a good thing - because the environment is like family. Every chair is back to back with another table, but no one seemed to mind. The vibe was great and the service was impeccable.As a Californian, I'm a brat when it comes to fresh seafood. I'm a big salmon junkie so I decided to go for it - GRILLED. Atlantic Salmon is much lighter than Pacific Salmon and it is served with a small portion of pasta. The rest of my table got pasta (which comes with a choice of 5 sauces). Overall, the meal was great and a bottle of Merlot was only $16!This is one of the more memorable places during my Boston trip and I definitely plan to come again when I'm in the area.

Reviews.Author: Kori S.
Reviews.Content: Insanely good. Yes, there is a wait and it does take around an hour even on a week night but go a little later with a friend and while one of you waits in line, send the other down the street to Mike's for a cannoli and you've got yourself a winning strategy.Got the large Fried Calamari as an app - totally delicious. Not at all rubbery but very tender with a good battered flavor. It easily fed 2 guys and a girl (moi). For entree, I ordered the Frutti di Mare (shrimp,scallops,calamari,clams and mussels) with a half and half of the Fra Diavolo and the Giacomo sauce (thank Yelp for the recommendation!). Freakin' amazing. The seafood was so fresh and cooked to perfection. No sandy mussels or clams, big juicy shrimp and again some of that tender calamari. Just thinking about it again makes my mouthwater. I can easily see paying more than double for this dish alone (huge portion!) but the fact that this was just $20, is just so awesome.I mean, clearly they make it up in volume and they don't have to shave 3% off the top due to credit card processing. This is such a prime example of great food, speaking volumes - it's the only marketing you ever need.Next time I'm in Boston, I'll definitely be back.

Reviews.Author: Michelle P.
Reviews.Content: I don't care if I have to wait 45 minutes for a table, I will keep coming back to this place for their food!Order the calamari or Mozzarella Marinara, or BOTH!  So good!Entree, I usually get the chicken parm, but I did try the lobster ravioli that was pretty darn good as well (although a bit too creamy after awhile).  You can't go wrong with the pumpkin tortellini either.  That is some amazing stuff, even for someone who usually hates all pumpkin byproducts (me).This has to be the best Italian restaurant in the North End.  And it isn't expensive to eat here too!  Cash only though, so be prepared.  Otherwise, you're gonna have to run across the street to the ATM.

Reviews.Author: Leila T.
Reviews.Content: Okay so a line outside the door doesn't always correlate with a good restaurant, maybe just how limited the seating is! In this case, the food is good but there is also limited seating which may inflate the popularity of this restaurant just a tad.The smell of garlic really permeates through Hanover street tho, helps keep up your appetite when your waiting in line in the cold and rain to get a table here! The cramped space just makes it a bit cozy- like youre part of one large italian family almost. The food is great and a definite must when you have friends visiting from out of town. Plenty of vegetarian options (pumpkin tortellini....eggplant fusili, etc). At times you can feel a bit rushed (get in and get out to get the next group in) but it makes sense with the long lines and people waiting I guess...

Reviews.Author: Mark M.
Reviews.Content: I am a North End resident. I go to Giacomo's frequently. This is the best value for the food in the area.The GF calls the ravioli with goat cheese "orgasmic". Yes, you will have to wait, and wait outside.... it will be worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Cindy C.
Reviews.Content: I am ashamed to say that after 4 years of Boston, I finally made it Giacomo's for the first time this summer.Hands down, best Italian food! After reading hundreds of reviews, my friends and I went right when it opened, so the wait time was minimal. Plus, people watching in the North End on a sunny day is fantastic. I got the special of the day, pasta with crab meat and the giacomo sauce. Absolutely to die for. The crab meat was so generous and more importantly, it was fresh. The flavor really came through, and the sauce complemented it perfectly. The bread as well as the calamari was also amazing. I loved the atmosphere at the establishment, casual and very family like. I felt like I was dining at some friendly Italian's kitchen. Comfort food made by the Italian mama. Yumm.

Reviews.Author: Danielle F.
Reviews.Content: CANNOT say enough about how much I loved this place.  Yes, there will likely be a wait outside if you try to go, and no, they don't take reservations.  Wait in the line!!  Best meal I had in Boston, and possibly ever.  The food was absolutely delicious and reasonably priced.  The ambiance was homey and cozy, and the service was wonderful (don't be put off by the seemingly brusque hostess and waiters - they treat you like you're family, not with kid gloves, which I think has led a couple other Yelpers to declare them rude. Take it as a sign of intimacy!).The food.  omg, the food.  The calamari was the best I've ever had.  I loved that it had peppers and jalepenos battered and mixed in as well.  Came with an amazing marinara sauce for dipping.  Best part of the meal was the butternut squash ravioli in a marscapone cheese sauce.  Tasted a sophisticated, rich, adult version of macaroni and cheese.  YUM.  The carbonera was amazing - some of the best I've had (and I consider myself an expert when it comes to carbonera). The type that you can't stop eating even when you are so full you feel like you may keel over.  The chicken marsala was pretty tasty, and probably really good for chicken marsala, but I just don't think it's my think. It did, however, come with a fantastic little bowl of spaghetti marinara. Nothing fancy, just simple, bright tomato-y flavors.   Love, love, love this place.

Reviews.Author: Mabel N.
Reviews.Content: Garlic bread and Fried Calamari. I thought I would never come back here due to the wait time but hey I am back.  Had the house special 1/2 lobster, clams and mussels over linguine fra diavolo sauce. Lobster Ravioli.

Reviews.Author: Eunice R.
Reviews.Content: I've been here way too many times for my own good. Every time I gone, I've regretted the amount of food that I ate. SERVICE: So each time I've gone, I end up having the same waitress. She turned me off a lot at the beginning but I think I'm starting to get used to her. She's pretty rude and pushy, but she's a good waitress. She knows what's good, and how to get the food out quickly.FOOD: You must, MUST start off with the calamari. Probably the best that I've ever had. Fried to perfection. And the jalapeños. YUMMZZ. Fried heaven. I've always gotten the Giacomo's Special for two. Honestly, the best part is that it's a good deal. For like $50 you get a whole lobster, more than enough mussels, clams, shrimps, and the occasional jackpot (scallops!). Other than that, I'd say that the dish itself isn't the best thing that I've ever had. For some reason, the sauce just reminds me of Buca's (chain Italian restaurant) Frutti di Mare pasta. Sad. Oh, the $10 bottle of wine is also a fabulous deal. I don't think I've ever been to a restaurant with such cheap alcohol! If you want the Boston experience, and the more bang for your buck, you should definitely consider going to Gaicomo's for dinner. BONUS: 1) The wait is always ridiculously/annoying long. It's NOT worth the wait. I'd recommend that you just go around 8-8:30PM. You won't have to wait. I've come here around that time on a Tuesday and Sunday, and I've probably waited at max 5 minutes on both occasions. Plus, if you come later they won't really rush you to finish your meal (since there is no one outside waiting to take your place!)2) CASH ONLY

Reviews.Author: Leigh F.
Reviews.Content: 1.) CASH ONLY!!!2.) Get there early! They open at 5 and start letting people in around 4:40 on the day we were there. Since we were waiting to meet somebody, we walked around and came back at 5:00.....and then waited an hour =(I came in town this weekend to visit my friend, and bookmarked this place after seeing it on the Food Network. I'm one of THOSE people that tries to eat at as many places featured on Triple D, Rachael Ray, etc. Here's what I suggest:You have to get the calamari. I got the special which had fresh lobster and shrimp, in the Giacomo sauce with fussili pasta. Amazing. I also tried my friends meals: Veal Marsala, Chicken Parm and Lobster Ravioli. All delish.I read a lot of reviews where people complained about being rushed...we didn't feel that way at all. If I come back to Boston I'll be back.

Reviews.Author: Melissa M.
Reviews.Content: LOVED this place.  Had a recommendation from a friend while visiting Boston and we are SO glad we went here.PLEASE NOTE: THEY TAKE CASH ONLY!!!!We didn't know and luckily had enough cash to cover. I had the mussels with their spicy red sauce and it was absolutely to die for. We also had some gnocchi and it was sooooo delicious! Good wine, pretty noisy but the place was adorable and we left feeling so full and happy. I highly recommend this to anyone who is visiting Boston that Giacomo's is a MUST HAVE!

Reviews.Author: Milena P.
Reviews.Content: The food here is amazing. However, sometimes the wait is a bit long (about 20-30 minutes, which go by very slowly if it's cold out), and they do rush you a lot when you're eating. So this would not be the ideal place to go to if you want to sit down and spend an hour or more having dinner. Their calamari are to die for, though, and the parms are pretty good too! Honestly I've had just about every dish there and my favorite is the lobster ravioli. Pretty cheap and big portions.

Reviews.Author: Stacy M.
Reviews.Content: The popularity of Giacomo's is apparent- not just from the line outside their North End location, but also from the copious 5-star reviews here on Yelp.  I'm sure the staff will probably curse me for recommending that people from around the world visit this place so they may finally understand what good pasta is all about.  But there it is.We started with the fried calamari, which was so tender I will forever judge all other restaurants' calamari by it.  I chose the linguine with salmon in a lobster cream sauce, which I  was a bit hesitant about but it turned out to be just  absolutely outstanding.  Indeed, the pasta is so baby soft and smooth I made inappropriate jokes about child food pornography.   The service, God bless them, is quick and patient, but no-nonsense.   While this isn't a place to linger, you won't want to.  With such a full belly, you'll certainly want to go for a nice loooong walk... down the street to pick up some cannoli's, of course!Cash only, no reservations at their North End location but I think they do at their South End location.

Reviews.Author: Monica C.
Reviews.Content: My goodness! Hands down, the best Italian food I've had in Boston. Yes, the wait is annoying but totally worth it. The place is small and warm, but this only strengthens the Italian family style cuisine experience. Note: literally have to wait in line for a table. You can't put down your name and wonder around till they call you. Cash only. Suggestions: get there right after it opens or near closing time to prevent a long wait. ALWAYS get the calamari.

Reviews.Author: Olivia P.
Reviews.Content: Wow - so delicious! Calamari was very tender and melts in your mouth. I couldn't get enough of the Baby spinach salad with caramelized onions, goat cheese, and spicy walnuts. The Gnocchi was so soft and tender. What a fantastic Italian meal in Boston!

Reviews.Author: Calvin C.
Reviews.Content: I came here with an old high school friend who is living in Boston, and boy was I impressed!  The place was packed, and we ended up sharing a table with another couple, which ended up being ok.We started off with the calamari which had some fried peppers in there as well which were quite delightful.  I'd order more of those if i could.  The calamari was a perfect texture of crunchy/chewy, and I could've continued eating it the rest of the night.At my friend's recommendation, i tried the frutti de mare with fra diavolo sauce.  Amazing!  Pasta was perfectly al dente, seafood portions were generous, and the sauce had a nice little kick to it.  Top it off with some inexpensive glasses of wine, and you have yourself a perfect dinner.Tip: Cash only, so hit up the ATM ahead of time.  Also, there's no waiting inside the restaurant for a table, so make sure you dress warm while you wait outside in the cold.

Reviews.Author: Jenna L.
Reviews.Content: There is so much delicious food in Boston we just had to have a real nice dinner while we were there, so we waited in line at Giacomo's, a place that everyone we talked to raved about, and that was featured on the Food Network as well (Rachel Ray's show). This was by far the best meal of the entire trip. The line was crazy, and we waited a while to get in (we came pretty late into the night too...) We actually had come to wait in line earlier in the night, but then the line was RIDICULOUS so we gave up, and it wasn't until later that we decided that we were going to have to try this place before we left no matter what. It was the best decision we made that trip. If you visit Boston, you have got to eat here, no matter how long you have to wait. I loved it so much.I had a really hard time deciding between the lobster ravioli and the butternut squash ravioli - the waitress recommended the squash to try something new so I got the Butternut Squash Ravioli in a Prosciutto, Marscapone Cheese Sauce with Diced Asparagus - BEST THING I HAVE EVER EATEN OMG SO GOOD! - I was surprised because I don't even like butternut squash - that's how good it is.To this day, I still get cravings, but all other butternut squash raviolis just can't measure up.

Reviews.Author: Kathy C.
Reviews.Content: Way too crowded inside. Got up twice to let people pass through to either sit at or leave the table that was literally right behind me. Had shrimp and scallops and Giacomo sauce over linguine.... my mom's spaghetti has a more exciting taste. Maybe I don't know how to appreciate authentic Italian pasta, but I don't see what's so special about the taste. Service is quick, obviously, since they have a line much of the time. Came here on a Sunday (Easter Sunday) for dinner around 5:45 and waited in line for about 15 minutes for a party of 3. We got lucky and jumped the line when a table for 3 opened up while we were waiting. Would I come here again and pay $20 for another pasta entree? Probably not. Went to see what all the hype was about and was kinda disappointed.Oh but one thing. Best calamari I've ever had. Includes fried peppers!

Reviews.Author: Kathy D.
Reviews.Content: Have to get here early so you won't have to wait in line!We got here about a half hour before they opened on a Sunday. We were seated right away and got a great deal, meal came with a bottle of wine.Food was great--the menu is written on a chalkboard. The place is small, so I wouldn't come here with a big group.

Reviews.Author: Marie B.
Reviews.Content: Ok so I've been coming here for years bc I love this place!!! You get large portions and its relatively inexpensive if your comparing it to the other Italian restaurants in the North End. Everything on the menu is excellent...and I would know bc Ive probably tried everything! lol Oh and the menus are on the walls.      The atmosphere is different than your typical Italian restaurant there but that's what I like about it good Italian food and you don't need to dress all fancy and spend fancy money, speaking quietly at your table like a library setting. Lol Its loud everyones talking, the waitstaff is yelling out orders you can here the pots and pans from the kitchen (mainly bc its right there) But I have a good time every time I go. There is a line, there is ALWAYS a line. If you don't get there right at 4:30pm/5pm your going to be waiting but its not too bad esp on a nice spring or summer night. Esp in August when all the feasts are going on, on the street. In the winter its definitely not as fun waiting in line but the wait is worth it. Its very small as well.         As for the waitstaff its your typical Italians...I try and sit at one of Tony's tables (hes the loud, bald waiter) lol hes the best!!! Who, when I first started going there thought was very curt or rude but learned hes really not. Hes just straight to the point and gets you food in and out quickly. Hes actually pretty funny. All the other waitstaff are great as well...sort of the same way. This place is not for the sensitive diner...theyre a little outspoken and its fast paced and they're rushing around serving their customers. But I think its pretty good entertainment!                       Now I'm craving some Giacomos! lol They don't have dessert but I always go to one of the cafes on the street Cafe Vittoria or Mike's Pastry. You can't go wrong, it's all good. Oh and btw no reservations and no credit cards...they have another location in the South End on Columbus Ave and they're more relaxed less face paced, bigger, have valet and takes reservations. And I don't think they have the long line ALL the time like the one in the North End. I could be wrong. But I'm committed to the one in the NE I just can't get myself to go to the other one!!!

Reviews.Author: Jennifer B.
Reviews.Content: This is my favorite restaurant in the North End, and I lived there for 5 years, so I got to know a lot of them!  There is usually a wait, but I avoided it on wekends, and it's not so bad during the week.  Also, it is cash only, which is practically unheard of nowadays.  Just the other day I recommended it to coworkers in on business, and they decided not to go because they couldn't use their corportate charge cards there.  No matter for us normal folks - just plan ahead.  Plus, while you are waiting in line, one of you can run across the street to the ATM!  My favorite is the Butternut Squash Ravioli.  I have tasted other meals there that friends have ordered, and all have been great, but I love that ravioli so much that I get it every time!  I can't help it!

Reviews.Author: Tim F.
Reviews.Content: Ridiculously good italian food.  Prices were very reasonable, and the wait was acceptable.  (1 hr wait at 5:45p on a rainy Saturday night)  The mood is very merry, even in April.  We ended up chatting with some folks which made the line go quickly.Our table got an order of calimari (~$9) which was solid, but not amazing.  My main meal was the lobster ravioli (~$16) with the house specialty tomato based dressing.  It went just great with their regular Chianti (~$15).Having enjoyed Italian in Italy for a month, and previously living in the Bay Area, I can say that this place provides the best value of the bunch.

Reviews.Author: Christine G.
Reviews.Content: Three words: Butternut squash ravioli.It's all you need. Granted the wait was a little lengthy . . but it was absolutely worth it. It's crowded for a reason.

Reviews.Author: Adam N.
Reviews.Content: Wow. Amazing pumpkin pasta. Was well worth the wait. Friendly staff, fun and authentic-feeling atmosphere, packed with people - truly a neat spot to eat. I would come here again.Be prepared to wait outside, 'cause there ain't much room inside. But trust me, it's worth the wait :).

Reviews.Author: Jeffrey B.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is probably the best Italian restaurant I've EVER been to taking into account both the food and the prices.  Located in Boston's own Little Italy -- North End -- this family-owned restaurant offers all the Italian classics without draining your wallet.The fried calamari is cooked with fried hot peppers and is an excellent appetizer to start with.  For your pasta, you can choose from among four or five different homemade sauces, mixing and matching seafood and meats as you please.  The red sauce is prepared with a lobster base, and the scampi is phenomenal.    As a warning, this place is tiny, so long lines are routine.  The staff is pretty good about keeping the flow moving, but don't expect to show up and eat right away.  Patience is a virtue, and Giacomo's is definitely worth the wait!Giacomo's is easily among the two best dinner spots in the North End (Neptune's Oyster is the other), and for authentic Italian food and flavor, Giacomo's is king!

Reviews.Author: Butcher B.
Reviews.Content: The food was great and the service was excellent. Can't wait to go back. We ordered the calamari which was well cooked and delicious, it even had an assortment of chili peppers thrown in the mix. I ordered a pasta plate with all kinds of seafood including lobster, it was great as well.  IF I go back to Boston, I will definitely visit Giacomo's again.

Reviews.Author: Paul L.
Reviews.Content: **CASH ONLY**  I've been a Boston resident and North End fan my entire life.  And, having grown up in a 1/2 Italian (Napoli region) and 1/2 Sicilian family, I'm a picky eater of pasta and Italian sauces.  So, finally, after a quarter century of wandering wonderingly past the 'round-the-corner lines that I'd see snaking out of Giacomo's every time I'd go to the North End for dinner, I've at long last sucked it up, and took my spot in line.  My family of four waited 40 minutes before opening, and fortunately managed (barely) to make the first seating of the night.  The restaurant seats about 35, elbow to elbow and knee to knee in small, wooden upright chairs.  It's tight.  Since there's no A/C, go only on cool evenings ... and be prepared for loud conversation and brisk (and brusque) service.  We didn't mind; we were there not to relax, but to see what the fuss is about.  I think it has to do with (1) value prices, by North End standards, (2) decent variety of mix-and-match sauces, pastas and proteins -- leaning more to seafood and chickens, with little if any beef or pork options and (3) tasty sauces.  Here's what we got, all of them recommended: CHICK PARM W/ LINGUINE IN RED SAUCE-a staple, well-executed with a very good base red sauce; SQUASH RAVS W/ PROSCIUTTO/MARSCARPONE SAUCE W/ ASPARAGUS-delicious, if you don't mind a sweeter-than-savory entrée; LOBSTER RAVS IN GIACOMO HOUSE SAUCE-red sauce with lobster bits is solid if unexceptional; ZITI W/ CHICK BROCC IN GARLIC CREAM SAUCE-they don't do an alfredo or carbonara(!), but the garlic cream is a well made replacement that is not too garlicky.  MY TWO COMPLAINTS AND A WARNING  #1) pre-powdered parmesan cheese!?!? Shame on you!  (Where's the fresh grated Parmigiano-Reggiano? #2)  And, the olive oil on the table for the bread was bland ... although the bread itself was fresh and tasty.  #3) Dishes are served when and as ready, meaning you won't all get your meals at the same time.  FINAL BILL: 2 wines, 2 apps, 4 entrees = $75 + tip.

Reviews.Author: Tim E.
Reviews.Content: After waiting in line (everyone does...) I thought I'd feel rushed.  But no, the waitress was great and welcoming.  The food was excellent and reasonably priced.  The only warning is that they only take cash...I'll definitely be coming back!

Reviews.Author: Christopher S.
Reviews.Content: This place is crazy, long lines, few tables, and they rush you in and out...oh, and no credit cards, cash ONLY!The food was decent (and cheap, $100 for four, including drinks) but I cannot understand why folks wait over an hour (standing outside) to get into this place...

Reviews.Author: Cat R.
Reviews.Content: I've been here numerous times with friends and family and everytime I leave happy, and so full.  I have some complaints though which is that is seats maybe 10 parties and you are so squished together it's a little awkward if you don't feel like being buddy buddy with your neighbor...It can also get pretty noisy, and a little chaotic with the small space and servers and everything else going on around you.  Not a good place to share personal stories of sexual conquests.....just sayin'.  Also the last time I was here, about 2 weeks ago, our server was so rude and brusque.  She told me not to touch the plate settings and leave the bowls alone she had placed in front of me (for my mussel shells).  It was blunt, awkward, rude and kinda irritated me.  The food is spot on, but with all the hype attached to this place I expect more than what I am given.  It's well cooked pasta, spot on sauces, and a pretty large menu of options that will probably be pretty darn good.  It's good italian food, but hey wait, youre in the north end and Giacomo's is not the only fish in the sea of really good authentic Italian food.  If there isn't a line for Giacomo's I will eat here without a doubt, but with a line I am happily going to walk down the street and find another delicious Italian meal...

Reviews.Author: Da W.
Reviews.Content: Oh my goodness this place is heaven!  I've been a few times and it's always been delicious.  A group of 8 of us went for St. Patrick's Day (early!), and we ended up waiting about 40 min for a table, which really wasn't too bad, especially with the gorgeous weather.  We were shamelessly salivating in the windows over the other diners' meals in anticipation...hopefully we weren't too creepy, but we really couldn't help ourselves.  :-)While the downside was our longer wait for a table, the upside was the variety of dishes we all got to try.  I ordered the ziti with chicken, shrimp, and a pesto cream sauce, which was AMAZING, but I also tried the chicken marsala, the butternut squash ravioli, and the chicken parm.  Everything was delicious, and so affordable too.  Our waitress was very nice as well.  The only "downside" I would cite aside from the wait would be that they tend to rush you out the door a little bit.  However, I personally can't really fault them for this, as I would really hate to make the other people in line outside wait any longer than necessary for such a yummy meal.  Love love love this restaurant!

Reviews.Author: J. Lynn T.
Reviews.Content: The food is great! Be ready to wait in line though.The butternut squash ravioli is a MUST try! Also tried to lobster ravioli and mussels in the Giacomo sauce (which both are deliciously savory).Pricing is more than reasonable, service staff is alright, but who cares, as long as they're decent at a super crowded establishment like this. Portions are very large, felt more than stuffed on my way out. I will definitely need to make a trip back here because the food was great!

Reviews.Author: T A.
Reviews.Content: 2.5 starsFor the last night of our trip from out of town we decided we would try an Italian place on the North End. Since this place had such great reviews and the price seemed right, we figured we'd give it a shot. For people who haven't been, beware that it is a TINY place that does not take reservations and is cash only. We knew this going in so it wasn't too big of a deal.We arrived and there was a line out the door, which is understandable since the restaurant is so small; we put our party size down and were told that it would be about 20 minutes (obviously about 40, in restaurant time). The wait wasn't too bad though; we were in no rush and more than willing to wait for what was supposed to be a superb meal. However, that was not what we got.Sure, the food was good, but 40 minutes standing in the cold good? Nah. The service was also so fast that it was actually a bit sloppy; the waitress was nice, but got impatient when one member of our party took more than a few seconds to order. I understand that they are trying to move people in and out rather fast, but the efficiency which which they took our orders, served, and billed us had the effect of making the meal feel rushed. This would have been fine if the food made up for it, but that sadly was not the case.I ordered the caprese salad for an apetizer and it was fine, but nothing spectacular. The roasted red peppers that came with it were a nice touch, but it seemed to be a little light with the mozzarella; there wasn't enough to go with all the tomatoes/peppers. Not a big deal. The real deal breaker of the meal was our entrees; my pasta came out fast, but literally floating in a pool of grease---- there was more oil on the plate than actual sauce! It tasted good, mainly because of the butternut filling, but I found it inexcusable that they would plate a dish that looked like a grease-soup. My girlfriend's was also similarly greasy, though not as bad (we suspect they cooked ours in the same pan and plated mine second, causing all the grease to pool on mine). Our friend's pumpkin tortellini was not greasy, but rather unremarkable. The sauce was rather bland and the filling just mediocre. If I could do it again, there's no way I'd wait that long for a meal thats just "okay." Thus, 2.5 stars. Decent food, but not worth the wait. If you do go, I would suggest sticking to one of their more basic pasta dishes and sauces; some other people sitting nearby had ordered them and they looked pretty good.

Reviews.Author: Michael D.
Reviews.Content: Don't come on weekends. Try to come when the C's and B's are not playing at the Garden. I also recommend avoiding the peak dining hours of 6pm-9pm. My wife and I have been here twice following those rules and haven't waited more than five minutes for a table. We anticipate going back often (and also doing take-out).The food is delicious and reasonably priced. The house sauce -- a red lobster-based sauce with a touch of béchamel -- has justifiably received rave reviews on Yelp. It's fantastic.Make sure you follow the door rules (open one at a time) in the winter or you will get yelled at! Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Katie W.
Reviews.Content: This was the well worth the wait!  We only stood in line for about 20mins, but then was seated at the "bar".  It's really small with about only 10 tables then 2 seats at the "bar" where you weren't bumped or constantly having to adjust your chair for others to get by and you got to look out at the restaurant and into the kitchen. The food and wine was VERY reasonably priced!! I ordered the pumpkin tortellini and it was amazing.  My mom ordered one of the specials a wild mushroom ravioli with goat cheese!  We didn't talk the entire time that we ate (it was that good)! We had a fabulous waiter Tony who kept the wine flowing and made our experience entertaining.  Next time I'm in Boston I'll be stopping by!!

Reviews.Author: Alysia M.
Reviews.Content: Love everything about this place minus the wait to get in!  Always worth it though- excellent food (some of the best in the city).  You have to try the "fra-como" sauce.  Fra Diavlo (sp) and Giacomo special sauce blended.  Goes amazing with the seafood dishes.  YUM!

Reviews.Author: Eve P.
Reviews.Content: Okay, so here's an actual honest review of Giacomo's. I've lived in the North End for 2 years and never got around to going here because the line was always so absurd. But last night, me and my boyfriend FINALLY decided to do it. We figured 5pm on a Monday wouldn't have the longest wait.So we ended up waiting about 30/40 min. Got to our little cramped table. And let me tell you - it was a VERY disappointing experience.I have never been so rushed at a restaurant in my life. We sat, ordered, ate, paid in a total of about 35 minutes.The waiter was SO rude. Literally walked away while we were in the middle of our sentences, dropped the plates on the table, barely said a word (until the end, when he probably realized we control his tip). At one point he even came over with cheese  and without a word, poured it all over my boyfriend's dish, which he neither ask for nor wanted. Food came super fast. TOO fast. We got the buratta cheese appetizer, which was pretty good but very small. There wasn't much to it. Bunch of diced tomatoes and a ball of cheese.My boyfriend ordered the chicken parm, and wanted it in the giacomo sauce, but we were told that you can only pick sauces for seafood dishes, and before my boyfriend even had time to decide if he wanted to keep or change his order, the waiter was gone. The chicken parm came - it was decent, nothing special. They actually forgot to bring his side of pasta until he was done with the chicken.I had their famed butternut squash ravioli. I must say, it was really good. But would I ever wait 2 hours in the cold for it? Absolutely not. Overall, it is so not worth the wait. The experience of a restaurant is VERY important, and the atmosphere and service ruined our dinner.I advise you guys go to Nico, right down the block. Delicious food, nice atmosphere, good service.

Reviews.Author: Todd O.
Reviews.Content: We went on a Friday night at 6PM, so perhaps it's our fault, but the overall experience was awful. We waited in line for an hour and a half. It is what it is, but we expected to be treated like we had just waited an hour and a half by the staff. No such luck. My GF went to use the restrooms and before she got back I was prodded for our dinner orders. I told the waitress we'd need some time so I ordered a bottle of wine and the soft-shell crab appetizer. When my GF arrived the waitress was on top of us asking if we'd decided. My GF asked for a few minutes as we had just waited an hour and a half to sit down. The waitress said "I tell everyone they wait longer in line than it takes to eat dinner." That's cute and all, but I don't really give a crap. I wait for a nice dining experience, I pay for a nice dining experience, I deserve a nice dining experience.So we get the butternut squash ravioli, as my GF has gotten for the past nine years, and I got the Fucilli in Giacomo's sauce. Both were terrific as was the soft-shell crab. As we were trying to enjoy our wine and talk, a woman came by the table and filled our wine glasses to the brim! Literally! Usually that wouldn't be so obnoxious to me, but because I knew they just wanted us out I was extremely annoyed. The entire meal may have taken us a half hour, and that's only because we were being stubborn about taking our time. We saw two couples come and go at the table next to us before we got up. The first couple came in at the same time as us after waiting just as long as us and were served their entrees as my GF got back from the restroom!!! How ridiculous. Overall: food is great, service is the worst I've ever had without someone spitting in my face. Do yourself a favor and head over to the South End location.

Reviews.Author: Zach and Jody G.
Reviews.Content: This was our first time to Boston and was recommended to this place.  The food was good, but our server was really rude.  He was an older gentleman, maybe even the owner, but treated us as if we were dumb, and when we asked if there were any nuts in the ravioli (just to make sure... could have Pesto in it, my husband could die if any nuts were in it) he looked at us as if we were retarded.  And then, of course, they don't take cards, which was an inconvenience.  Definitely need to get with the times.  Though the food was good, the EXPERIENCE itself was bad, which is why we will not recommend it to any of our friends. It's all about the experience.... As small business owners ourselves, we realize we are here to serve the customer and not treat them like idiots.

Reviews.Author: Suzanne C.
Reviews.Content: Saturday in the North End in Boston is something special. Add a feast to the evening, and you've got one heck of an upbeat multigenerational crowd. My best friend and I decided to bite the bullet and wait on line for what I described to her as "the best Italian food in the city." She is all about good authentic Italian cuisine, so it was an easy sell despite the 1-hour and a half wait up the street.We drank some wine and grabbed some bakery delicacies during our wait.  We also made some new friends as we let the time pass.Much to our excitement, the long wait led to a cozy counter seat where all the magic happened in front of our eyes.  We could see the calamari prepared, listen to the excellent meals being ordered and smell the amazing aroma of authentic Italian dishes.We started with a caprese salad which was out of thus world. The mozzarella was so fresh and the tomatoes laced with fresh herbs were crunchy and hearty.We ordered the special,  Fusilli with lobster and shrimp in giacomo sauce (tomato cream sauce) and chicken Marsala and a $16 bottle of chianti. The food was terrific and our seats were exceptional if you can appreciate kitchen side dining like your Grandma's house. The Marsala sauce lacked richness, color and mushrooms even though we asked for extra. It was tasty but not the best we've had. If you are looking for a lighter sauce, however this is a dish for you. The fresh Fusilli in giacomo sauce was absolutely amazing! The fresh seafood in every bite, the homemade texture and the flavors take your breath away.Some other points:- your appetizer is there within seconds of ordering- your meal shortly follows- and you never can drink more than one small glass of wine as they rush you in and out- the wait staff is very friendly- cash only and be prepared to wait an hour to an hour and a half; no reservations accepted, not a place to carry on an intimate conversationIf you can deal with some of the drawbacks and come here for a fantastic meal, it is well worth it!

Reviews.Author: Dan G.
Reviews.Content: Loved it!!  Really fun, tight, cozy place. REAL food. Great portions. Great prices. Can be a long wait. Get there early. Seafood was amazing. Bread was fantastic with the tomato basil mozzarella cheese appetizer.  Specials were so good. Pasta tasted so fresh I was in awe. Don't miss out - food is GREAT!  Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Beached W.
Reviews.Content: Fantastic.  Giacomo's has such amazing food.  It's a small (like, smaller than a 7-11) restaurant, and there's pretty much always a line outside.  Don't fear....it's worth it.  It's a busy place, so not the best for the quiet, intimate dinner date, but if you're looking for some of the best Italian food around, this is it.No cash, no reservations....come prepared!

Reviews.Author: Anni Y.
Reviews.Content: I am a HUGE fan of pasta. This place definitely has great home-style pasta with big portions leaving your tummy filled, warm, and happy :). Their dishes are simple yet tastes so good. I ordered the Butternut Squash Ravioli with prosciutto and asparagus! It was really yummy and filling. I don't have a very big sweet tooth so towards the end the butternut squash flavor was too sweet for me, but it was really savory. The ingredients tasted so fresh and didn't leave me feeling all greasy and bloated. Although I have to say, the bread that they serve before the meal is not very tasty :T. But other than that, I really enjoyed my meal :).

Reviews.Author: Jason K.
Reviews.Content: long line but well worth the wait.  Food comes in large portions and the best part, very reasonably priced.  Check it out.

Reviews.Author: Frank L.
Reviews.Content: Damn. I have to admit, I was skeptical coming in from NYC. This place is capital AWESOME.  The far diavlo is definitely the way to go, maybe mix it with Giacomo sauce. The calamari is tender like everyone said. They had a buratta-cream filled mozzarella that is creamy is hell. The lobster ravioli is absolutely divine. Just make sure you are hungry. Oh, and chat up Tony. He's a ball of fire.

Reviews.Author: Dia V.
Reviews.Content: If you are from Europe, this is a regular italian restaurant. Food is very good, but not as good as to be waiting on the street for 45 minutes. If you have never been to Spain or Italy, definetly you should go, if you are a european turist, visit another restaurant in the same area, the difference is not so huge

Reviews.Author: Andrew W.
Reviews.Content: Not impressed. Food was good enough, and service was terrible to mediocre. It seems that there is always a line to get a table (we waited ~40 minutes), and our waitress made it easy to see that she wanted us out as soon as possible. It started to get annoying when dishes were being removed before the food was even finished. As for the food, I got the ravioli special, which was tasty but a little small. The seafood pasta dishes were much bigger. Overall, I'd say it's good Italian food, but that I've had much better for less.Two friends and I chose to eat here instead of other Italian restaurants in the North End due to the high number of Yelp reviews. I hope others don't fall into the same trap and try out something else.

Reviews.Author: Alissa S.
Reviews.Content: A popular place with tourists and a good deal for the seafood.I went here as a visiting Californian when it was night in December and I waited outside in several layers of wool and still lost feeling in my fingers and toes, even though I had made a preparatory stop at REI just for this. We had about a 40 minute wait and I felt ill by the time I got inside, to be greeted by a rude waiter who looked at me and said, "Who's the puss?"This was a new phrase for me, and I had expected friendliness and warmth after finally reaching the inner sanctum, but I was too frozen to respond. Nevertheless, my scampi was fine (as good as anything in North Beach, where you don't have to wait in a line like a soup kitchen). My mom got the chicken pesto and it was really good, and my brother half a lobster over pasta with other seafood for $20, which is a real deal. And they got calamari which was excellent.The inside is really cramped, when full they have to lift up the tables to let you in and out, and you do feel rushed by the servers, and its a cash only deal. But the food is a good deal and done well. I think its marvelous if you happen upon it, but not worth waiting in the freezing cold for.

Reviews.Author: Chester N.
Reviews.Content: WOW!I am not a fan of Italian food and my girlfriend Gracie C always argues "that's because you've only had crappy Italian food." Besides my visit to Italy, this is the first evidence that she may be right (but don't tell her that).Coming off a red-eye followed by a string of meetings with a crappy Wendy's meal in between, my colleague Steve and I decided to try to find some real food and made our way to North End. The line was a bit intimidating at first especially when combined with our fatigue and the fact that I was completely unprepared to give my talk at the Software Industry Conference the next day. But, we waited. And damn, I'm glad we did.- calamari: I could not stop shoveling these super tender, juicy, crispy on the outside morsels of squid smack into my face- lobster ravioli: Incredible. Huge chunks of lobster interspersed in super soft ravioli with this amazing soaking in this unhealthy white sauce generously- Steve's dish: need to jog my memory or ask him as it was an amazing hand-made pasta (I think fusili) with tons of fresh seafoodA must visit in Boston, whether you like Italian or not.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: Sweet Jesus! If Jesus ever cooked Italian food, I swear it would taste like the pasta here.  Yes, you might have to wait in line... all things good comes when you wait really applies to Giacomo's.  I might not be able to really vowel and enunciate this restaurant's name but really who cares when the pasta is beyond yum.  We waited for around 15 minutes in line. We had this super jolly Italian man server that put all of us in a joyous mood.  Along with the bread, we started off with the fried calamari. With the crispness of the batter and the flavor of the seasoning was a perfect start to an amazing dish to come.  I had the Penne Amatriciana it was good... i felt like i was eating pure Italian pasta cuisine.  It has great flavor of the sauce and the veggies that were added.  No matter how awesome the sauce is, no great pasta dish will be great if the pasta isn't cooked well.  Mine was perfectly al dente!It was such a great price for the amount that they give you.  I ended taking the rest home and eating it for my next 2 meals.  I really didn't get sick of it even after eating it the 3rd time.  Extreme much? No I say! From sitting down, till a finished meal.  I had a happy smile on my face all the way through.

Reviews.Author: David P.
Reviews.Content: After researching very good places to eat in Boston, we came across Giacomo's on Yelp. I was excited to try this place since all of the reviews were so positive. Well, when we got there, there was a line out the door and I remembered that it was cash only (there's an ATM across the street) so I wasn't too happy. We finally sit down and we're elbow to elbow with another table and I'm thinking to myself, what the heck??? We ordered, and when the food came out, we had a revelation. All the baloney, standing in line, getting cash out, being a foot away from another table... was all worth it! This place is AMAZING! I'd do it all again a month later when my friend came to visit!! :)

Reviews.Author: Vera S.
Reviews.Content: Wow.  I am completely in love with Giacomo's.  I had the butternut squash ravioli last night, and I can't stop thinking about it.  I am obsessed with Giacomo's, and wish I could have it again every night.  What do they put in it?  Crack?I want it NOW!

Reviews.Author: Bryan P.
Reviews.Content: Great spot, my wife and I are from out of town and found this place online. Fantastic. If I lived in Boston I would be a very regular customer there. Believe the hype.

Reviews.Author: Chris L.
Reviews.Content: OMG the pasta here is wonderful.  I love their homemade spicy sauce.  I still think about our meal here and nothing else compares.  1)  Location - It's located on the North End and very close to Michael's dessert place (which has great cannolis).   It has a college feel and there are many other restaurants around.  Do not go there.  You must eat here. 2)  Service - Our waitress was an older Caucasian woman and she was very knowledgeable about the different sauces and what tasted good with which dish.  She even offered to take pictures for us.  The tables are very cramped but cozy so somebody was always around to take care of our needs.  Just don't sit next to the door on a cold day. 3)  Food - PHENOMENAL.  I had the Frutti Di Mare Spaghetti with the house marinara sauce.  The Lobster Spaghetti Special camewith the same sauce.  The portions are quite large and we finished both dishes, not to mention a calamari appetizer (okay, we had some bread and olive oil/vinegar too).  4)  Payment - Don't forget to go to the ATM before coming here b/c they only take cash.  That's why I had to pay for the taxi ride home (boo).  Honestly, after this great food, I had major food coma and had issues walking.  But, I managed to eat a dessert cannoli (chocolate) at Michael's.

Reviews.Author: Nicole S.
Reviews.Content: Oh...my...god. I was told to go here by a coworker after I moved to Boston, claiming it is the best Italian food in town.  Not only is it the best in town, it's is hands down the best I've ever had.  Every time we have out of town guests we have to bring them to Giacamos and everyone has been blown away.  Well worth the rediculous wait, even in the snow!Totallly recommend the lobster ravioli (although super rich) and the fruitti di mare with the fra diavolo sauce. YUM!!

Reviews.Author: Christopher M.
Reviews.Content: I've only eaten at Giacomo a few times, but every time it's been top notch.  Their fra diavolo is out of this world.  And if you can get the bar seat overlooking the kitchen, take it - it's a bit of a hassle having the waitress station right next to you, but it's fun watching the kitchen and chatting with the chefs.The only reason I don't eat at Giacomo more often is because I can't stand waiting in line on Hanover St for hours on end.  There's no reservations, no waiting list, everyone has to wait in line to be seated.  Too bad they're so popular, they can get away with a seating policy like that.

Reviews.Author: David A.
Reviews.Content: Arrived Thursday night right before closing. No problem! Jules, our waitress, made us feel at home. Awesome fried calamari with hot peppers. No grease. Not chewy. Perfect. Next we both had pasta. Should have ordered one. Massive portions but so good you will stuff yourself. Highlight was the black pepper papperdele with spicy sausage. Incredible, melt in your mouth pasta. Also had the gnocchi with red sauce and mushroom. Did not expect a stuffed pasta but very light and devoured the sauce.Boy do I miss great Italian food.Great start to our Boston culinary escapade!

Reviews.Author: David M.
Reviews.Content: A tiny traditional Italian seafood place... what better place to bring our birthday girl... who has seafood allergies. The high lights involved -the very vigorously enforced rule of entering Giacomo's: Keep one door closed before you open the second one.  If you disobey, you will be yelled at. Very annoying when you're out in the cold, very awesome when you're then seated next to the door.-a waiter that made fun of birthday girl for coming here while having seafood allergies. More bonus points for her not being at all disappointed in the food (their pasta is seriously awesome). -our order being yelled at from our table to the kitchen across the dining room-Perfectly done calamari served in fairly large portions. I almost enjoyed the red peppers as much as the Calamari its self. Almost. Great for groups, with a reservation, lots of fun and super fresh pasta and seafood. Just don't get the salmon... everything else was amazing, the salmon was just ok.And that concludes my lazy-mans review of Giacomo.

Reviews.Author: Nancy L.
Reviews.Content: Amazing food and dirt cheap (decent) wine!!! We had a special seafood entree for 2: lobster, mussels, clams, shrimps, etc etc over linguine with half Giacomo's sauce and half Fra Diavolo (such an awesome combo, btw!), along with a bottle of wine for $65! Now that is something hard to beat, especially when the food is super delish! Oh as for appetizer, we had their famous fried calamari. Simply put, it was the best fried calamari I've had in a very very long time!  Also, we ordered the mozzarella and that was heavenly as well. Overall, if you're a foodie, here's where you belong! Now there is a downside: we had to wait for about half an hour for seating. There's also that blonde waitress who has a very nasty attitude, and God bless  if you do get so unlucky to have her as your server. Ok,it's not THAT bad...just ignore that bi*ch.

Reviews.Author: Robert C.
Reviews.Content: Simply THE BEST Italian food I've had. Giacomo's is a pretty small restaurant; it's pretty mushed over there. They got extremely nice people working there; taking their time to explain each sauce & any questions you may  have. Let me warn you before hand... the line will be pretty long. We waited 1 hr and 45 minutes to get in (2 blocks worth of line) and it started raining toward the end. And let me tell you... it's worth every freaking minute!!!For our appetizer, we ordered the "Antipasto" ($10) - Imported Provolone Cheese,Sopressatta, Bresola,Roasted Peppers, Stuffed Peppers and Vinegar Marinated Vegetables. This dish's simply outstanding; the vinegar mixes sooo well with all the peppers and meat. You guys gotta try this, it's just bloody amazing...In Giacomo's, they only serve seafood for all the entrees, no other type of meat. For some of the dishes, they let you pick the sauce that comes with it. Listed below're some of their sauces:*Pesto - basil, crushed garlic, olive oil.*Fra Diavolo - spicy lobster sauce; tomato based with pepper.*Red - lobster sauce.*Giacomo - creamy.*Scampi - butter.1. Frutti Di Mare ($19) - Shrimp, Scallops, Calamari, Clams & Mussels. We had this with the Giacomo sauce. It's freaking awesome; the sauce's not too creamy or anything.  The sauce's a bit to lighter side, but not in a bad way; you can tell that there's plenty of ingredients put into the sauce. The portion's huge with plenty of seafood.2. Shrimp and Lobster Fusilli Special with Fra Diavolo sauce ($26) - out of this world. This is probably their most popular dish so I just had to try it. This dish's just bursting with flavor & all those ingredients mix well together. It definitely blew me away. Once again, the portion's humongous. They put quite a bit of lobster meat; it's definitely worth the price.  [Fusilli - long, crorkscrewed pasta]Conclusion: Bloody awesome. Delicious meal, huge portion, reasonable price & good service, what's not to like?!?! When you're waiting in line, don't cave in half way and just remember: You're only 1-2 hours away from food heaven.

Reviews.Author: Kamryn C.
Reviews.Content: This place is a gem, but everyone else seems to know that too.  My boyfriend and I decided to try the restaurant out on a recent trip to Boston.  We lucked out and  were seated right away, because all of the groups in front of us were large parties.  We were placed at the bar, which seemed like a negative at first, but I think we were the only two with a shred of privacy in the entire restaurant.  The wine list is cheap, we originally planned on ordering glasses, but after looking at the prices a bottle was in order.  The food menu was typical Italian specialties, with an emphasis on seafood.  We ordered the caprese salad for an appetizer, unfortunately they were out of buratta, but we settled on the buffalo mozzarella.  The tomatoes were delicious for winter standards, and I could only imagine how great they would be during peak months. For my entree I ordered the eggplant parmigiana, which was great.  I wish I had ordered a pasta dish though, because the side of simple spaghetti stole the show.  My boyfriend ordered a chicken special filled with things I can't particularly remember right now, and it was devoured with frequent exclamations of how fantastic it was.  The service was fast and brisk, and you're somewhat rushed through the meal.  However, with the growing line outside the door, it's fairly understandable.  They don't serve dessert, but you can stop at other nearby places to get your fix.  And it's cash only, but just in case you forget, they'll be patient as you run to the closest atm.

Reviews.Author: Dennis L.
Reviews.Content: You will inevitably look at the line outside Giacomo's and wonder...is it worth it?  The is a simple answer to that question: Absolutely!Giacomo's was good enough to get me to come back two nights in a row while on vacation in Boston.  I never have done that in my life.  So here is the breakdown:Night 1:  My wife and I ordered the antipasto plate to start.  It was a delicious array of meats, cheeses, and olives.  It was a perfect accompaniment to the complimentary bread.  For our meals, we went with the veal parmesan and the lobster ravioli.  Both dishes were excellent.  The veal was flavorful and tender.  The sauce was perfectly seasoned!  The lobster ravioli had the ideal amount of filling to pasta with a wonderful cream sauce.  We had an awesome meal!  As we were finishing up, we saw the table next to us order the house specialty, and we knew that we had to come back.Night 2:  The house specialty is simple amazing! Here's the description: Zuppa di pesce - for two - shrimp, scallops, calamari, clams, mussels and lobster; served over linguine with your choice of sauce: pesto, fra diavolo, red, giacomo or scampi with a bottle of wine.  Oh seafood heaven!  This dish for two was perfectly cooked and visually stunning.  We went with the giacamo sauce, and it was delicious.  The bottle of Blackstone Merlot was wonderful.  You cannot beat a deal like this at $65.Few notes:- The restaurant is cash only- Most bottles of wine are $16.  The list is small, but the deal is great!- The line does move...If you are at the corner, figure on about an hour.

Reviews.Author: Dana B.
Reviews.Content: If I could I would go back in time and give a big smooch to the gentlemen on our flight to Boston that recommended Giacomo's. We were in Boston celebrating our 6th wedding anniversary and I could not have asked for a better experience. I loved the little restaurant with the limited seating, the waitresses that are to the point, and I especially loved that we were helping support a local restaurant. We started by splitting a Cesar salad which was a huge portion with delicately dressed greens and super flavorful croutons. I ordered the pasta with Giacomo sauce, shrimp and scallops. The scallops and shrimp were cooked perfectly and were plentiful amongst the pasta. The house sauce was delicious, I wish I could find it in Austin. The husband ordered the lobster ravioli and I'll be the first to admit that I had dish envy. The ravioli were wonderful and very filling. I look forward to going back the next time we are in town!

Reviews.Author: Tyler B.
Reviews.Content: This place is great. No, it's not a 5 diamond restaurant and no, they don't have a diverse wine list (it's pretty much red or white) and yes, they servers will give you crap.BUT THAT'S WHAT MAKES THIS PLACE GREAT!I go out to have a good time, not to be serious. I like getting made fun of and I understand that a small establishment doesn't make the kind of margins that allows for there to be a credit card machine.The food is good, you can talk to the people at tables near yours (which is every one) and they have a great birthday song.I will come here on a regular basis and now it's my go-to place in the North End for affordable dining.I like it when a server will tell you what's good, what you should order and what you shouldn't. Every restaurant has plates that are better than others.  If a server tells you otherwise, they are lying.$5 glasses of decent wine and an $18 half lobster are unheard of prices. On top of it, you will have friends and the employees will remember you when you come back.Yay for the North End!

Reviews.Author: Erika K.
Reviews.Content: I did it I waited in that wonderful line that wraps around the block with no seats staring into the windows watching people take their sweet time eating there food drinking there drinks and sweating their little ___ off. Why Why would I do this you ask? Because my friends it is ohhh so delicious!The specials are def the way to go!Lobster Ravioli - creamy, lobstery, the best everBell pepper and Goat cheese Gnocchi - drool drool drool .... nuff said - it was the best thing I have had to eat in a while. The shrimp and lobster special with Fra Diavolo sauce. ---- YUMMYFried Calamari - some of the best I have had! No doubt!Yummy wineOne of my favorite things about this place is the way the service runs. They yell and smile and its all gravy! But it is hot! it is hot! HOT HOT HOT! Makes you wanna eat and run.GIVE IT A TRY!

Reviews.Author: Jen C.
Reviews.Content: Oh Giacomo's.  How do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...The food here is absolutely amazing.  Nothing pretentious, nothing extravagant - just good solid Italian.  With the rest of the North End turning into chic bistro territory (not that I don't love chic bistros...), it's refreshing to grab a meal where I don't have to pretend I know what something means ("Barbabietole?  Something to do with a... barber?").Some will moan and whine about the wait here, but I find it to be completely worth it.  Who can't keep up a 45 minute conversation with their friends while waiting for some of the best Italian food in Boston?  If you can't, you shouldn't be at Giacomo's with them anyway.  After all, when that gigantic plate of swordfish and tuna over tagliatelle with pesto cream sauce comes out, you might be hard-pressed to share with even your best friends.That being said, there's a South End location that I have yet to try out, but I hear the wait's better and they take reservations.  Satisfied?  I am.

Reviews.Author: Melissa D.
Reviews.Content: Even though that has been reviewed more than a 100 times, I would still like to put my 2 cents in.  Giacomo's is a great, famous establishment who do it old school with no reservations and cash only.  I always recommend this place if someone is looking for a restaurant in the north end, especially for visitors and I always come here for an after work dinner.  Yes the line goes all the way down the street and crosses a couple of blocks but once you have had their famous pink sauce, their frutti di mare, their calamari, you will be waiting in line.  Their lobster ravioli is so good as well as their antipasto display.  Service is great, they are fast paced however super friendly and welcoming.  The way that menu is set up is you have your choices of pasta with seafood, chicken, veal, etc.  Then you can choose alfredo, giacomo, fra diavlo, red sauce, etc.  This is great for picky eaters and it's a great way to get people back to try different combos.   They also have special fixed entrees.  Most of the time, I always need to get a doggy bag.  And it tastes even better after a night after the bars.

Reviews.Author: Matthew D.
Reviews.Content: Yeah, this place was good call. The wait was 45 minutes on a Saturday night after the Red Sox game but there were three of us so we took turns walking around the neighborhood. There are a lot of shops around so there was plenty to do while we waited.Two of us ordered the zuppa di pesce with giacomo sauce (red sauce w/cream) - a giant plate of linguini with shrimp, scallops, calamari, clams, mussels and a whole lobster. It's $55 and could easily feed four. For another $10 you can can choose a bottle of wine that normally goes for about $18. The seafood was on point. Everything was fresh and cooked perfectly. The cream in the sauce countered the acidity of the tomatoes for a very well balanced flavor.My buddy ordered the chicken parm and was giddy about it the rest of the night - I'm guessing it was pretty good, too.The dining room is tiny. I mean, really tiny so if you don't like crowded spaces, keep that in mind before you go. Our waitress was very friendly and attentive despite being slammed with other tables. She even took a few minutes to chat with us since we were out-of-towners.We all left happy and full. I will definitely make a return trip the next time I'm in Beantown.

Reviews.Author: Melanie M.
Reviews.Content: After reading multiple reviews, I settled for the butternut squash ravioli and was not disappointed. It's served in a prosciutto based sauce with asparagus. It was really creamy and just so tasty. My vegetarian husband got the pumpkin tortellini and really enjoyed his dish too. Everything just tastes so fresh.Wine was cheap with a simple wine menu. It's cash only and there is an ATM across the street. The restaurant is small and we had to share our table with 3 other people we didn't know. The service is fast and our waitress was "rough" but charming.

Reviews.Author: Ashley C.
Reviews.Content: Yes, we all stand outside the restaurant, in a line, waiting for 30-45 min. for a reason. It's that good. I've lived in MA for almost a year now and I bring my friends and fam here every time they're visiting for the Giacomo's experience. Their butternut squash ravioli is to die for (if you like a little bit of sweetness with your pasta) I've had the fettuccini with proscuitto and peas in a garlic cream sauce, I would give an 8 outta 10. And their calamari is very good as well. Gotta try Giacomo's if you're in the north end. & It is a very small, famous restaurant so you will have to get very cozy with your neighbors since all the tables are tightly close together. Pumpkin Ravioli = Life changing!

Reviews.Author: Stephanie S.
Reviews.Content: As we speak I'm craving Giacomo's Zuppa di Pesce for 2 with a bottle of wine. It's fantastic! Great experience at the North End location and almost just as good at the South End one too. North End: you have to wait outside for a table but the line moves quick. Intimate and cozy arrangement of tables and on the night we went the entire restaurant was being served by one amazing woman. She had great service and complimented us for finishing our huge plate. How could we resist really? The wine helped.The turnover is quick: good if you're waiting on the street, hungry and you want to sit down.  Maybe not the place to dwell on your meal for hours on end. Probably not the best for large groups (leave them at home)Follow it up with a cannoli across / down the street.

Reviews.Author: Vivien L.
Reviews.Content: Two friends and I arrived at Giacamo's at around 4:45pm for dinner and saw that there were only two other tables seated.  We lingered outside for a minute trying to decide whether to go in and sit down or to continue walking around for a while longer.  Luckily we decided to get seated because the restaurant filled up and a line began to form outside within 15 minutes  0.oThe woman who served us came off as no-nonsense and curt at first.  However her attitude softened up and became a part of Giacamo's charm as she took our order and began raving about the ravioli and giacamo sauce~  We ordered three items:- Half Lobster with Mussels, Clams, and Linguine in Giacamo Sauce- Butternut Squash Ravioli with Asparagus, Prosciutto and Mascarpone Sauce- Homemade Fusili with Shrimp and Lobster in Giacamo SauceSO GOOD.  I've never been a huge fan of italian food but I'm pretty sure I could eat that butternut squash ravioli all day every day.  The other two pastas were wonderful as well but I looooooove creamy white sauces (yea yea...I said it!) so the ravioli was definitely a standout.I'm not gonna lie...I think I just drooled a little on my shirt just thinking about it... =P

Reviews.Author: Jenn T.
Reviews.Content: 3.5 stars, but rounding down due to the offense of not cooking my fusilli thoroughly. =/This place is small and it's packed. I love the homey intimate feeling; the kitchen is like right there. Oh my. The old man taking our orders was sweet and straight to the point. "Hey kids, what's for suppah?. Ok sugah-pop, do you know what you'll be havin'?" Cute, indeed.Calamari came out quickly and we kinda devoured it quickly too since it was so good. I ordered the house special fusilli with lobster and other seafood, I don't remember at the moment, with giacomo sauce. I was happy they didn't skimp on the lobster meat and the sauce was so delicious. I know it's something I can't replicate in my kitchen. Unfortunately, my pasta was between raw/al dente status. I didn't want to be troublesome and send back my food so I kinda ate around my pasta and just ate the seafood in it. I ended up being the only one taking a doggy bag home and that night when I reheated it, it was cooked perfectly.

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's.  Oh.  My.  God.  This is my #1 place in the North End, and it is definitely worth the wait.  If you like fish and pasta, this is the place to go.  I always encourage people to wait it out--you're definitely ready to eat after waiting outside for an hour, staring at other people eating their food inside!The pasta is always perfectly cooked, and the sauces are superb.  The house sauce is slightly spicy, with just enough kick to make it interesting, while the pesto cream is much lighter than you would expect.  The fish is always fresh--I most recently had a fusilli dish with shrimp and lobster, and the lobster chunks were huge, succulent; in a word, perfect.  Portions are huge, but get the calamari appetizer anyway.  You can always take stuff home, even though you won't want to (it's just so good).One of my favorite parts of this place is the service.  Yes, they get you in and out as fast as possible, but I've never felt rushed or hurried here.  The staff are quite the characters, and are always friendly and funny--the perfect accompaniment to a delicious meal.  Giacomo's is affordable, too, which is especially great considering the massive amounts of food you get.Aside from the cramped quarters, I really can't say anything bad about this place.  Plus, no one judges me for talking with my hands.

Reviews.Author: Leanna L.
Reviews.Content: Aaaahh, yes!  Es perfecto!Love love LOVED this place.  The quaintness, the yelling Italians, the thick authentic Boston accent?!  Not only that, but the food was Ah--May--Zing!  I miss it already.I had the Frutti di Mare in the spicy Fradiavolo sauce, my sister had it with the house lobster-based Giacomo sauce.  Both equally superb.  Mussles cooked.  To perfection.  Take notes Maggiano's.  geez.  Scallops were also delicious.  It was easy to get to and we seated quickly.  Maybe because we went a little early and there were only two of us.  The line out the door did get longer and longer as we savored every bite.  ;)Only drawback....Cash only.  poo.  I love my credit cards.

Reviews.Author: Tiffany Z.
Reviews.Content: On an incredibly rainy evening following a wine tasting at the Wine Bottega a few doors down, I made my way into this establishment on a whim with a friend of mine.  Having never heard of the place beforehand, I had no expectations (which may have been a good thing -- I probably would have had very inflated expectations had I read all of these glowing Yelp reviews).  Luckily for us the pouring rain seemed to keep diners away, and we had no trouble getting seated immediately.We ordered the mussels with the fra diavolo sauce (a spicy tomato-based sauce that was very tasty) ($9) and the linguine with shrimp in a lobster cream sauce (this was a little too heavy for me -- I preferred the fra diavolo sauce) ($15).  The service was friendly (if not a little gruff) and efficient, and our waitress had a good sense of humor.  And, I thought the prices were very reasonable for such a famous place.I'd definitely come back but don't know if I could justify the (apparently) hour long waits in line for a table.  I suppose I could always save it for another rainy day :)

Reviews.Author: Jen S.
Reviews.Content: Totally Guido. And who doesn't think a place is better if there's a line around the corner? Makes you feel triumphant when you finally make it -- like holding out in a staring contest. If you're going to be cliché in visiting Boston and end up in the North End, at an Italian restaurant, like all the other douches looking for authenticity and ending up in a place full of tourists, at least pick somewhere good. And this place is pretty good. The calamari is awesome, fried guilt with a good kick to the red sauce you dip it in; the wine is super cheap; the pasta's as good as pasta gets. The best part is the service, which is quick and no-bullshit, but helpful and nice. Our waiter, who was running around like a madman, dealing with twice the number of tables as a normal waiter, never let our water glasses get half empty.

Reviews.Author: Andrea P.
Reviews.Content: This is the first time I've ever had to wait outside in the freezing COLD just to get seated. I came here with some friends for a convention recently and decided to come here to eat since a lot of people had recommended it. THE VENUE: The place is pretty small, when it's busy it sucks cause everyone is cramped all over the place but the waitresses know how to move around which is pretty cool.THE FOOD: I got the Lobster Ravioli and we ordered the fried calamari as an appetizer. I heard some good reviews for the ravioli but I was a little disappointed with the portion size, Normally I get full after eating ravioli but after this I was still hungry. But the ravioli over all was good, you could taste the lobster and the sauce they used with it was pretty good also. THE SERVICE: When we got there the waitress we had was on top of it with serving us, she quickly walked over to us asked what we'd like to drink and if we wanted any appetizer. After we ordered she brought our drinks right away and soon after that our food came. In the middle of us eating she'd drop by every so often asking if we're okay and if we needed anything else.
