She brought the salads over as soon as they were ordered while other couple waited for their entrees. When the entrees were ready she threw the plates on the table and said " want cheese" and proceeded throw a spoon full on top. Food was ok. Butternut squash ravioli with prosciutto and asparagus ha no prosciutto and the ends were chewy. As we were half way through our 2nd round she placed the check on the table ( never asking if we needed anything else) and starred at us across the room until we placed the money down. As soon as the money was placed she rushed over and asked if it was all set before we could put on our jackets we were pushed out the door. Very disappointing!

Reviews.Author: Melody R.
Reviews.Content: Our first food stop in Boston...we were STARVING and this place did not disappoint! There was a bit of a wait when we arrived and since the place is teeny tiny, we had to wait outside. Now, Californian me is NOT accustomed to this cold because outside was (as my father would say) "colder than a well digger's ass!" - so in short, the waiting experience could have been better. After bearing the cold for 20 minutes, we were finally squeezed (and i mean really seriously squeezed) into a corner near the kitchen. This place was at max capacity, if there was a fire, I wouldn't bet on all of us making it to the door. But don't worry, once you actually get in the place and sit, you won't be thinking of anything except the delicious smells filling your nostrils - and then you will look around frantically following your nose like a hound dog trying to figure out what exactly it is. Okay well that's how it went for me, maybe because I was so hungry I probably looked like a hound dog with drool dripping from the corners of my mouth. Well that's enough about the non-consumable aspect of the place...we ordered the special (Frutti di Mare with fracomo sauce) with a bottle of wine - $65 bucks...I thought it was a good deal before we got the dish since it was suppose to feed two. When it actually arrived I thought - HOLY MOTHER! That's a great deal!!! This thing was HUGE!!!! It should really feed 4....unless you're gluttons like us, in which case, all "feeds 2" portions should be like this. So needless to say, it was delicious. The red sauce had a hint of a spicy kick and you can really taste all the fresh garlic. The seafood was probably some of the freshest I've had. Now, the catch: I'm not sure if I thought it was so good because of how hungry I was or because it was actually THAT good....Okay, now stop reading and go try it for yourselves so you can tell me if it was my hunger or simply great food that made me love this place.

Reviews.Author: Formicas F.
Reviews.Content: I would do 3.5 if I could.  It is worth the wait but not because the Italian food is the best I've ever had (it can't beat Italy folks!) but because of the experience.  The waiters are authentic Italian servers, just as you would expect in Italy.  We were seated at the bar and it was so fun to watch them making the food/working.  We arrived at 4:50 and there was a line around the corner; I was shocked.  We waited about 45 minutes; and it took us about 35 minutes to eat and be out the door.  We had the tomato clam sauce chicken linguine and I had pumpkin stuffed shells with cheese sauce.  Mine didn't have enough sauce but Matt's was excellent. We are glad we ate here - not for the food but for the experience!Cash only (There is an ATM across the street) and no dessert here but just walk to Mike's Pastry and get the canoli from heaven :)

Reviews.Author: Joshua C.
Reviews.Content: I don't think I have much to add here, but I will confirm that the food here is amazing. I have one of their specials, a lemon pepper pappardelle with shrimp in a dijon cream sauce. Now mind you, I almost never remember what I order, so the fact that I remembered my dish and what was in it means something. It was really delicious. My wife had the butternut squash ravioli, and as you probably have already read, it's super awesome. Our friend had the lobster ravioli, equally good. The food is truly amazing!Crowded, long lines and at times pushy staff can be annoying...but hey, you were warned! Expect that and you'll be fine.

Reviews.Author: Heidi L.
Reviews.Content: Worth the wait?  Perhaps just once or twice.  I don't think it's worth the wait to come here often.Friday night around 7pm, the line was around the corner...which is AT LEAST 1+ hour wait.  So we came back Saturday night right when the restaurant opened (5pm) and guess what?  THERE WAS STILL A LINE.  It was shorter so we got seated about 30 mins later at this tiny table with shared elbow space with the neighboring table.  As for the food, the fried calamari was yummy.  There were bits of fried red peppers and jalepenos (?) in it as well.  I have to admit, the butternut squash ravioli was AMAZING.  The creamy cheese prosciutto sauce, oh man...we licked that plate clean, literally.  The lobster ravioli was delicious too, really cheesy with chunks of lobster in it.  I used the bread to wipe all that leftover garlic cream sauce up, it was goooood.  Our waiter laughed at how clean our plates were.However, this is definitely not my ideal date spot since there are 30 hungry people waiting outside the door giving you the stink eye to hurry your ass up and leave.  food = goodlong wait + no space + being rushed to eat/pay/leave + cash only = not so good

Reviews.Author: Gary H.
Reviews.Content: Giacomos is everything you expect of the place; noisy, over crowded and small.  That being said, if you miss this place, you missed out.  The vibrant feel of a neighborhood joint is here and if you sit at the bar (only two seats) you can watch all the people in the restaurant being shocked at the amazing quality of the food, which is the number 1 reason why you come there.Have the Calamari, Caesar salad and the fusilli (home made version).  It will fill you with excitement, flavor and simply, will fill you.Great joint and I am from the NE but I missed this when I was young.

Reviews.Author: Paul W.
Reviews.Content: Best meals in little italy. Good portions, inexpensive, and big on taste.  Reasonable price but as everyone says get ready to wait for meals if you go during traditional dining hours. I take or tell everyone to try and go here if they are looking to eat in the North End.  I fell in love with Butternut squash ravioli because of Giacomo's and I had never had butternut squash since I never lived in the NE area.  I've had more than just the butternut ravioli now and I have not been disappointed yet.Wine is inexpensive too along with the meals!

Reviews.Author: Lee H.
Reviews.Content: Wow this place is great. Something of an ordeal to get to and into, but the food is outstanding.The italian style seafood is fresh, delicious, and plentiful. You choose from the items on a blackboard, and a little bit of heaven comes to the table. The service is friendly.That's the good news.It's a tiny place, with few tables. The wait is usually an hour or more, standing in the street. Parking is hellish. And they don't take credit cards.But you really have to go.

Reviews.Author: Marcus S.
Reviews.Content: I do enjoy Giacomo's. A few warnings, though.This place is tiny. Expect a wait. Reservations are highly recommended. Oh, that's right. There are no reservations taken here. Ha! You're waiting outside, baby. That's because there is no waiting space inside. What's more, this place is not shiny and sparkly inside (in other words, this place is unpretentious), which is fine by me. I come here for the food.Once you get inside, though, be sure -- if you order nothing else -- to get the butter nut squash ravioli. It's served with asparagus in a proscuitto, mascarpone cheese cream sauce. Just outstanding.

Reviews.Author: Mnason M.
Reviews.Content: One word... AMAZING!Well worth the hour wait. I can say this was the best Italian food I've eaten. The prices were very reasonable for quality of the food. Not overrated.The fried calamari was very close to the best I've ever had if not the best... I got to try about 4 different dishes since almost everyone in my party ordered something different. Every dish was extremely good. I ordered the lobster ravioli. I have to say the butternut squash ravioli might be something one would kill for.A few things to note... expect to wait. The seating room is small. If you want to seat down and talk for hours when they are busy you may want to eat here then talk elsewhere. They tend to be a little rushy since it is so busy with limited seating. You may be very close to others. Again small room. Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Lindsay B.
Reviews.Content: The food is the only reason you come here, and it's worth the waiting and the hectic atmosphere! My brother and I took my parents here to celebrate a birthday, since my Dad had heard great things.  We were told to get there early - and we did.  The line started around 4pm and we were in the second group of people to be sat (the place is small - so maybe we were 15ish in line?).  When you get in, it's a tight fit and there's a lot of commotion - they turn things around really quickly to feed the line outside as fast as possible.  But our order was perfect, no confusion.  The calamari app was the best I've ever had.  My fra diavolo was outstanding and everyone loved their orders - not a complaint to be found.  Between the 4 of us, we ordered 2 apps, 4 meals, and a bottle of wine.  Dinner was quick and the bill was WAY cheaper than what I'm used to seeing in the city (especially for the quality of food that's served there).  This is not a good place to slowly enjoy a quiet meal.  If you're willing to tackle the line, it's a guarantee you will not be disappointed in the food.

Reviews.Author: Lisa D.
Reviews.Content: I'm giving it four stars, but after a return visits I might change it to a five. It was a nice summer day when my friend Ashley and I went to Giacomos. We arrived and there was already a small line and we just chatted until we got by the door so it wasn't too bad of a wait. the calamari was tender and crispythe lobster ravioli was amazing, i liked it better than my dish of mussels in a giacomo/fra diavolo mix sauce. the pasta came in a heaping large portion.So the above was the first time I ate at giacomos. The second time i returned in a freezing winter day with Ash again and this time with another friend. We froze our asses off waiting in line but we had already committed and staring at the diners inside. We were too close to give up and so we waited and were finally seated, ironically, at the same table we were gawking at through the window panes. The pasta here is divine, delicious, and ginormous. The food is fantastic here. The service is speedy albeit rude. I always have to throw some attitude around because the servers will say or do something I perceive as obnoxious (And I'm Chinese, I totally understand  rushed service) . Will that stop me from returning? No

Reviews.Author: aaron t.
Reviews.Content: Huge plates, great  priceFresh sauce, fresh seafood, great bread!Festive environment (especially when they yell out your orders)Great for groups or couples.When i have people asking me about italian food or pasta in north end, this is the place that everyone knows and talks about. There are others, but his place is just great. Nothing super fancy, but great atmosphere and food. It might get a bit messy, but thats why its fun here. Dont expect this to be the wear a tie place, because its all about families, fun, and food.

Reviews.Author: Roger W.
Reviews.Content: It has been several weeks since I went to Boston, and I finally got around to review Giacomo's Ristorante. This is probably one of the most popular restaurants in the area.  The restaurant was already packed just 10 minutes into dinner service.  By the time we got seated 20 minutes later, the line literally wrapped around the block.Restaurant space is limited, so it was difficult to maneuver around the area.  Frutti Di Mare was nicely al dente with quality seafood ingredients.  Good tasting but relatively average when compare with similar dishes from other restaurants.  I recommend the pumpkin tortellini.  A nicely balanced dish, where the sweetness wasn't overpowering.  Giacomo is a good choice for quality Italian cuisine, but not outstanding.

Reviews.Author: Cat S.
Reviews.Content: Love Giacomo's SO much!  Don't love waiting in the line but it is definitely worth it!  It moves pretty quickly - couples are seated much faster than groups.  Seating is tight but I haven't found this an issue.Giacomo's is everything that I love about simple, quality Italian dishes. I'd love to say that I have tried everything on the menu but I just can't stray from the seafood.  The Giacomo sauce is amazing.  The homemade fusilli is amazing.  I even love their house (inexpensive) pinot grigio!  If you have a good appetite, I highly recommend the Zuppa di Pesce - giant platter of lobsters, shrimp, scallops, clams, mussels over linguine with Giacomo sauce.The one time I didn't order seafood, I tried the butternut squash ravioli.  It was so delicious and rich - haven't tried this dish at too many places but I can't imagine that it gets much better.  Everything else on the menu looks great.Only downfalls:Because of the line outside this place is run very efficiently to get people in and out in a reasonable amount of time. AKA, don't expect a long, drawn out dinner. Also, I haven't been seated next to the window yet, but I wouldn't love the scrutiny from all those waiting in line.  If you are looking for inexpensive but incredible Italian seafood - go here.  One of the best values in the city.

Reviews.Author: Linda H.
Reviews.Content: Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Boston. All of the dishes that I've sampled here have been awesome, although some are pretty different from others.  I really liked the chicken marsala.  The butternut squash ravioli was good, but a lot sweeter than I had been expecting. It hit the spot, but made me glad that we were eating family style, so I could sample all of the other dishes that we had ordered, which were more savory.Service was good. The first time I went, the server forgot our calamari appetizer.  After we inquired about it when she brought our entrees, she quickly apologized and told us that she had forgotten to put that in with our order. We still wanted it, so they quickly made it for us and then gave it to us on the house.

Reviews.Author: Wen L.
Reviews.Content: A little late in review but... I heart Giacomo'sHands down great Italian food. I went for the first time in May, and then returned to Boston in June. Highly recommend the shrimp & scallop fra diavolo. I freaking love that sauce. Another winner is the calamari.Yes, cash only. Yes, no reservations. Yes, tiny small spaces. BUT DEFINITELY WORTH IT.Something to look forward to on my next trip to Boston.

Reviews.Author: Matthew H.
Reviews.Content: First off, I now understand why this restaurant has a line down the block. It is hands down the best restaurant in the North End. Every bit of food we had was absolutely fantastic. Especially the lobster ravioli and chicken parmesan. As a heads up, it is cash only, and it can get a little cramped inside, but it is well worth it. They do not take reservations, however the south end location does.

Reviews.Author: Alan C.
Reviews.Content: The food here is out of this world. There's a lot of reviews on here that talk about long waits. I came on a Sunday at about 6:10, and I was seated by 6:25 for what that's worth. I ordered the butternut squash ravioli and a special on the board - grilled salmon with lobster risotto.Butternut Squash Ravioli - This was amazing, one of the best things I've ever had. The savory sweetness of the squash and the creaminess of the sauce mesh together so well and give it the most wonderful flavor. And the diced asparagus added in provided a nice crunch inbetween bites of the ravioli.Grilled Salmon with Lobster Risotto - The salmon was tender and juicy. The risotto was nice and hearty - I swear that every other bite had a nice piece of lobster.The only complaint is that my salmon was on the grill for a bit too long, so the grill marks left more of an impact that I would have liked. tl;dr - The butternut squash ravioli will blow your mind.

Reviews.Author: Carolyn L.
Reviews.Content: It takes two to tango. First, there are the people who are so excited to see what all the hype is about at Giacomo's that they almost pee their pants waiting in line for approximately 1-1.5 hr on a Sunday at 4 pm. Then there are the over-worked workers who are trying to serve as many people as possible while maintaining some semblance of order on a Sunday at 4 pm. The combination of the two is not pretty. You're squished next to someone who talks about their crazy stalking ex-boyfriend (not kidding here) while pulling your chair in every 2 seconds to let the waitress or someone who needs to use the restroom through, until you've semi-permanently lodged yourself between table and chair you might as well be one. Neither pretty nor comfortable.To be fair, the food was fine. Like I had said about the Giacomo's in South End, it's nothing spectacular, although admittedly the food was much better here than at the South End location. However, the stressful and rushed atmosphere detracts from the experience and makes it difficult to actually enjoy your food. Well, you go there for the experience right? Because it's Giacomo's and you have to see what all the rave is about. There you have it. You have been forewarned.

Reviews.Author: Jeffrey W.
Reviews.Content: This place is NOT over-hyped. It is worth the wait.  The seafood is fresh because just before they open the restaurant, you can see a truck full of fresh seafood get unloaded into the restaurant. If you can, get there 30-45 minutes before they open at 4:30 PM in order to get a table quickly. Appetizer: CalamariCalamari is hard to mess up and it is hard to make extraordinarily well. Giacomo's does a good job with their calamari and even spices things up a little by putting some red and green pepers in the mix. A small portion is only $7 and the portion is for 2. Entree: Frutti di Mare with Giacomo SauceOut of my entire East Coast trip (including NY), this was by far the best entree I had. This entree had so much seafood it feels like you are eating the entire ocean. I ended up finishing all the linguine before finishing the seafood. Don't get me wrong there was a lot of linguine too. The mix of seafood in it included muscles, calamari, clams, scallops, and shrimp. The scallops were the freshest and biggest scallops I have ever seen. The Giacomo sauce was a good pairing with this dish because it was not overpowering and I could taste the true freshness of the seafood. I could not believe that the entire thing only cost $19!Entree: Mussels, Clam and 1/2 Lobster with Pesto SauceThe lobster...fresh and big. This dish trumps the lobster pasta at Daily Catch because it costs half as much and still tastes just as good. The pesto isn't the best pairing with seafood because it can take away the fresh seafood taste. I would go the Giacomo sauce. Still can't believe this entre only cost $20.The service here is fast and right to the point, just like the typical Boston attitude. Even though the restaurant was extremely busy, our waitress was still able to check up on us and made sure our food was made well. TIP: The G in Giacomo's is pronounced more like "Ji" instead of "Gee"

Reviews.Author: Christopher F.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's Ristorante is one of the best italian places in Boston that I've been to. Compared to the rest of Hanover St. it was great food for slightly cheaper prices. The fall back is that there are no reservations so you can expect to wait upwards of over an hour in order to get a seat in this rather small restaurant. I'm a patient person and I say that the wait was well worth it! After looking online for the opening times so that we could line up early, Chris and I got there half an hour early only to see that the house was already packed and a line had formed! At 4:30 when opening hours was supposed to be at 5! However, since it was still fairly early, we only ended up waiting half an hour before getting seated.For appetizers we shared a small calamari and antipasto. The calamari was fresh and hot with just the right amount of seasoning. The peppers and cocktail sauce added another dimension to the dish that made it some of the best calamari I've ever had; and even better, it stayed hot for our entire meal! The soppresatta in the antipasto was great. In general, the antipasto served as a good pairing to the calamari. Very good! For the main course we shared the house special -- Zuppa di Pesce in Fra Como sauce with White Zinfandel. This dish was a monster. It completely dwarfed the two seater table that we sat at. The waiter had to replate our appetizers and bread just to make sure everything fit. If you're a seafood lover you must get this dish! There's so much seafood and pasta that I was able to make two more meals out of the leftovers,...and this was after sitting there for two hours eating my heart out. If you like spicy red sauce definitely pair the fra como with the special, this spicy lobster sauce added to the savoriness and succulence of the dish.  The atmosphere was good. Everyone was obviously enjoying themselves and having fun conversing with their dinner partners. It definitely is cramped so if you're not comfortable with possibly getting overheard then that's something to consider. The waiter was very helpful in helping us choose our dishes and spot on in predicting when we needed his attention. One downside besides the wait is the cleanliness. I had to send back our water glasses because there were oil stains all over it -- only to get a glass that was just slightly cleaner. There was also a fly that spent a good hour trying to get a closer look at our food. Overall, I had a wonderful time at Giacomo's and will definitely be coming back. I would actually give it 4.5 stars if Yelp had let me. Don't let that long line intimidate you. It's a restaurant worth trying for yourself at least once.

Reviews.Author: Neil B.
Reviews.Content: Really nice atmosphere despite the noise and tight spaces.  Butternut squash ravioli was great as was the chocolate torpedo dessert.

Reviews.Author: Chris T.
Reviews.Content: Let's be honest: Giacomo's is a feeding trough, not a restaurant. You wait. You're in. You're out. Your stomach is full, your wallet is a little lighter, and you're left wondering what you had for dinner. Why can't you remember? Because--despite it's  reputation--this place is about volume and turn over. It's not about eating, definitely not about savoring, and there's little time to catch up with anyone worth talking to, so you're really best just going alone. Between the waitress pushing wine and appetizers, the ridiculously long line--(which is oddly reminiscent of the 1991-era lines for Hard Rock Cafe--an experience that was all about anticipation, not substance)--there isn't any time to really notice the food. Oh, and did I mention that subtle but persistent, now ever present nudge on the back of your chair? Meet "Donna." Is she from the North End? (As if....) Boston at least? Sorry, no again. "Donna" is from Omaha. She's large. And, she let's you know it. Say hi!

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: We arrived at Giacomo's at 4:02 this evening (a Saturday) and the line was already long. We decided to give it a chance and waited until they opened at 4:30. Miraculously, we got in on the first seating-second to last group in. We were seated near the kitchen. It was impressive to see how quickly the food could move out of that place! We ordered the steamed broccoli, scallops with a spicy cream sauce, and one of the specials--chicken, gnocchi, spinach in plum tomato sauce. The food was amazing! I especially loved my dish. We did not love the long wait in the heat and the noise inside gave me a headache! When we come back to Boston, we will definitely go back!!

Reviews.Author: Allison C.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely amazing, not pricey considering quality and portion size. Sitting in line is the worst so I typically go only at off-times. My #1 recommendation to people visiting the North End.

Reviews.Author: Peter W.
Reviews.Content: Good to Great  N Italian restaurant in Boston's South End. This an unpretentious restaurant with a nice neighborhood vibe. Wine is mostly inexpensive, so a meal here won't break the bank. Great for date when you want to eat and have fun, but not for showing off. Bring cash, as they don't take plastic. In fact, that sums up Giacomo's. Nothing is plastic!

Reviews.Author: Keith R.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food at a reasonable price. Our appetizers included caprese and sausage-stuffed musrooms---both celebrated table-wide. My entree, veal pizzaola with potatoes and broccoli on the side, was excellent. Actually, the potatoes were a little undercooked, but, man, do those people know how to do broccoli. Absolutely succulent.Despite the busyness (and it was only a Thursday evening) the service was very friendly and attentive, and our food was delivered quickly. The decor, while slightly kitsch, was a fun use of the space in the basement, where we ate. A little crowded but great ambiance nonetheless. Would enjoy visiting again for another  Italian treat.

Reviews.Author: Ben S.
Reviews.Content: This was the one Boston restaurant on our list that I wasn't originally thrilled to be going to.  Despite the good reviews, I just got the sense that the sheer number of reviews was due in greater part to the cheaper price-point than the actual quality of food on offer.  Although, I still think I'm right, I have to admit, it was better than I was expecting.The wait is interminable on a premium night - we were in line for about an hour (the teenaged daughter in the party behind us was hilarious in trying to convince the rest of them to go anywhere else), in the middle of a sweltering heat wave - and when we finally did get in, it was possibly hotter inside (by pure luck, we were seated near the kitchen) - what's with restaurants with no air conditioning?Our waitress was on the older side and definitely gruff, but as with all our other Boston restaurant picks, as long as you realize that's the way the waitstaff here treats everyone, it's fine.We started with the Calamari (competently done, but the best part were the unexpected hot peppers camouflaged in the plate along with the squid) - the marinara sauce was fine, but not the tomato flavour explosion I expect out of a really great Italian restaurant.  I had the special of the night, the Sea Bass with Asparagus on a mound of garlic mashed potatoes - the mash was actually really good, as was the fish, although it came in a sauce that was a bit too sweet for my liking (scraped it off everything).  Others enjoyed the Butternut Squash Ravioli, the Lobster Ravioli, and the Fettucini with Chicken/Peppers/Onions.  I tried them all, and was glad I picked the entree I had.Solid meal, not mind-blowing.  But factor in the price, for a lot of people, this would be a great dining experience (drinkable bottles of wine for just $17!).  Now that I think about it, I was the only one not drinking that night, maybe that explains why I enjoyed it the least?

Reviews.Author: sunny n.
Reviews.Content: Moderately priced Italian cookin up some great Italian favs ..small with limited seating..offering all your popular pasta dishes accompanied by a notable keen and unique flavor & selection of seafood...Depending on when you go, you may need to be prepared to wait...The service can be rushed during the busy hours..but the food is certainly good....I recommend the Ravioli..and Mussels!!!Cash Only..:-0

Reviews.Author: Liz E.
Reviews.Content: After hearing rave reviews from many sources, I was so happy to finally experience Giacomo's for myself.  We started with calamari (yum) and the antipasto platter (good, but eh).  I had lobster ravioli.  It was absolutely amazing.  The sauce was creamy but not too heavy, but very heavy on the garlic (just the way I like it).  I had the leftovers for lunch the next day and was so happy to wreak like garlic for two days straight.  Don't expect to have a sophisticated bottle of wine with your dinner (wine list?  what wine list?) but their food makes up for it.  I'm going to have to keep going back until I try every single thing on the menu.

Reviews.Author: Chris G.
Reviews.Content: i went there again a couple of weeks back and was waiting for my friend - hostess asked me how many I said "two" but friend wasn't here yet so she told me to tell her when my friend arrived.Meanwhile in 5 minutes the wait outside goes from 0 - 25 - I was not in line, just on the sidewalk out to the side - but I was there before everyone else. When my friend came I told the woman but she said I had to be in line. that was not cool - I have to be specifically in that line? Ok for that I will demote to 3 stars and go get my butternut squash ravs freshly made at Bella Ravioli in Medford and eat at home and prob save $70.

Reviews.Author: Aaron G.
Reviews.Content: Everyone who knows this place says there is always a line to get in here.  Always.  Except last night.  Apparently if you go around 9:30pm on a Wednesday there is no line.  We walked right in and sat down.I don't know many places in the North End and as was the case I was there with an impromptu date.  Given my scenario, I had hoped for a little more romance in the setting but it had to do.  The waitress was a nice older lady who swore she had seen us in there before; alas she was  wrong.  She warned us that they were closing at 10pm but if we put our order in right away she assured us we could hang out as long as we liked.Fair enough.  The shrimp linguine in the lobster fra diavalo sauce for me, and the salmon linguine in lobstah something-something sauce for her.  The food was good.  Really good.  I rather enjoyed her dish of salmon and something-something (white wine?) sauce.  I would go back for it.I would have preferred eating at a place with a little better ambiance for a date.  The lights were bright and the tables were close together.  Giacomo's seemed more like a cool place to get dinner with your friends.  But as it turns out when you have good company, the lights and the seating really don't matter.  I forgot about them and enjoyed my company- and my meal.We weren't rushed, but were silently warned that they were getting ready to close by turning off the music.  It was obvious.  Then the tell-it-like-it-is waitress asked that we settle the check.  We weren't forced out, but it was clear the staff wanted to go home.Great food and a good setting.  Just don't wait in line at 9:30pm on a Wednesday, you might be asked to pay your check as you enter.

Reviews.Author: Christopher R.
Reviews.Content: After reading reviews and seeing how hard it was to get into this place, I was not too sure when a friend wanted to go for her birthday. IN FEB!!! Luckily, we decided to get there early and we were the first people in and the first table seated.The food and service was out of this world. I had the eggplant parm and it was crispy and tender in the right spots. Everything really was suberb.Later we passed back by and the usual line had started to form. I would go again, but only if I didn't have to wait.

Reviews.Author: Sarah T.
Reviews.Content: So, we waited in line to eat at this restaurant - in the cold.  I had the famous pumpkin tortellinis with fresh sage marscapone cheese sauce.  I do love marscapone cheese!  The dish was good, but not outstanding.My fiance had a seafood pasta dish (Frutti di Mare) with mussels, calamari, scallops, clams, etc.  He said everything was cooked well and was good but not great - the pesto sauce was lacking in being memorable.  He also had better Antipasto plates at other restaurants.  I enjoyed the experience and tight dining room - he was not a fan.  I found it worth trying once and standing in the line - he prefers not standing in line for food, at least not this food.

Reviews.Author: Elizabeth F.
Reviews.Content: We got there just as it was opening for dinner, so we didn't have to worry about long lines or no reservations.The price was right, but the food was only okay. My mussels were cooked perfectly, but the pesto was bland and the fra diavolo had barely any heat.

Reviews.Author: Veence K.
Reviews.Content: WOW and my mouth just watered thinking about this place. I ordered the lobster, mussel and clam pasta with the Fra Diavolo sauce and it was amazing! The angel hair pasta was fresh and Doode! the Fra Diavolo sauce was amazing. It wasnt overpowering but just right. Its a spicy red sauce that isnt too spicy.I guess I can say this review can be short and sweet because this place is a must go if youre ever in Boston. The neighborhood is hopping with a bunch of italian restaurants but you gotta hit this place up. If you see a long line wrapping around the building, I recommend waiting in line!

Reviews.Author: Michelle L.
Reviews.Content: Perhaps I would have given it five stars if I actually got to experience eating in here.  However, with the line out the door, we decided to get our food to go.  We got the Salmon Fettuccine for $15 and it was more than enough to feed two people.  Very delicious.  I wish there had been more sauce, but that's nothing to really complain about.  This place is really great.  As long as you've got time to wait, then thumbs up all around.They don't take reservations.  But you can cut in line to order something to take out.

Reviews.Author: Maggie K.
Reviews.Content: Cute restaurant packed with people and a vibrant atmosphere. You can't make reservations so expect to wait if it's a busy night. Our waitress was very sweet and explained everything on the menu and even recommended a bar to hit after dinner.The food was filling, fresh and decently priced, which made for a good meal overall. The wine was also moderately priced. I wouldn't say this was the best Italian I ever had (granted I have been spoiled by the NY/NJ Italian cooks for years), but it was a great meal for a great price.

Reviews.Author: Jackie G.
Reviews.Content: Great food!I was in Boston for a weekend vacation trip in August 2010. It was Sunday evening and we were trying to search for top rated Italian restaurants in the North End (close to where we were staying) on Yelp. There were plenty to choose from but we decided to come to Giacomo's and brave the long lines we were expecting. When we arrived, there were about 3-4 parties waiting in line to be seated. Since it was just the two of us, we lucked out and were able to bypass the bigger parties ahead of us and got seated after about 15 minutes of waiting in line. Although I felt rushed, our waitress explained their menu & special since it was our first time there and she was pretty attentive throughout our time there. We ordered calamari for appetizers (might be the best ever and i do love my calamari). And for entrees, I had fettucini w/swordfish and tuna in a pesto cream sauce, and the boyfriend had fettucini w/ salmon and sundried tomatoes in a tomato cream sauce. We also each had a glass of wine. The service was really really fast. Our food came out right away but it does not at all take away from how great the food is from this restaurant. What to expect: long line (no reservations), great food, huge portions (we both had left overs that we had to take back to the hotel w us), cash only, fast service that it will definitely make you feel like they're trying to get you out of there as fast as possible (but it's understandable as it is a small place and they have plenty of customers in line).

Reviews.Author: Reed J.
Reviews.Content: With almost 500 reviews, there's not much more that can be said about Giacomo's, except that as you can see from the rating, I loved everything about this restaurant.  There is nothing fancy about it.  Just great food in a friendly cozy setting that is worth the wait.  The pumpkin tortellini was surprisingly out of this world great.  Lobster ravioli, mmmmmmmmm.  Fusili with lobster and shrimp in spicy red sauce was a hit too.  Oh, and order up some fried calamari for an appetizer.  That's good squishy!  Service was fast, efficient, and friendly!

Reviews.Author: Terry Y.
Reviews.Content: It was raining hard and I didn't have an umbrella.  My water resistant jacket was doing it's best to keep the water out as I stood in line for 30 minutes.  Yes, a line in the rain. I wasn't alone, except I was and the guy in front of me complimented my dedication.  Only that was my first time there and I had no idea why I would be doing such a thing.  I would do it again.I found this to be the definitive place for pasta.  It never ceases to disappoint, consistent, fantastic pasta...  Simple menu options, very friendly staff, fantastic neighborhood.Please be merciful of others and vacate tables shortly after paying.Edit:  I've now stood in line alone in the snow to eat here. (Forever alone.)  I'm sad Tony never remembers me, granted I only went every 3 months or so max.  Why does the staff always joke about him being not nice?  Tony's hella cool.  Years after my first visit, the Giacomo's + fra diavolo sauce blend remains consistent in its ability to impress.  The pasta has never been below perfect and the seafood has never been unfresh.  The menu also doesn't seem to change...  This is how you make a place feel like home.

Reviews.Author: Fan L.
Reviews.Content: My first plate of linguini was severely undercooked. The noodles were hard and still dry in the middle...I notified my server and she brought it back to the kitchen and got it redone. This time the noodles were good but the shrimp/scallops were overcooked =(

Reviews.Author: Brenna R.
Reviews.Content: One of my favorite restaurants! Every Good Friday, my mom and I go to the North End as our tradition. The key is that you have to arrive at 5pm for doors to open in order to get a seat. Their food is amazing. We always get a seafood dish because they are SO GOOD. I recommend their calamari as an appetizer.  We usually get the Zuppa De Pesce - Which consists of lobster, mussels, shrimp, clams in a marinara sauce over linguine.. I look forward this meal EVERY year.

Reviews.Author: Cameron W.
Reviews.Content: What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said?  I come to this place frequently when I'm in the mood for Italian food.  It's in the North End, so expect the parking situation to be terrible all around.   It's not a great place to go if you have more than 4 people because the restaurant is so small. Also, you can usually expect a line outside the restaurant.  But don't get bummed out - the place is too small to have a waiting area inside the restaurant.  It seems like usually there's a 30 minute wait on average, first come first served. That said, the food is delicious!  I got the frutti de mare with pesto sauce, and it was excellent.  Portion sizes were good.  Prices are reasonable.  The server was very helpful and friendly and answered all of our questions.  And any guests that I bring from out of town can't get enough of this place.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Author: Kate T.
Reviews.Content: This is well worth the wait and one of Boston's shining culinary stars. I had the special last night....brace yourself: homemade gnocchi stuffed with goats cheese and roasted red peppers, served with chicken in a sauce of plum tomatoes and marscapone. It changed my worldview.Beat (most of) the crowd by dining midweek and getting there after the office-let-out rush, say 7 p.m. or so. I was there at 8 and the line ended just past the edge of the restaurant and I only waited 20 minutes. If you go on a Friday night, you could find yourself waiting upwards of 2 hours. Protip: Don't bother trying to park in North End or at least have one person wait in line while you try to find a spot. I'd advise parking in the $10 lots down in the financial district instead.

Reviews.Author: Kathy Z.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely LOVE this place. Probably the best dinner you can get at that price in downtown Boston!! My friend told me this place. We got a house special for two, some garlic bread and calamari. We shared all the food among 5 girls and the plates were completely cleared!! Great experience, will definitely go there again and recommmend it to many many other friends too!!! But do rememeber to bring enough CASH. There's an ATM nearby but you might need to pay some process fee to withdrawl money.

Reviews.Author: Steven L.
Reviews.Content: This is one of the small restaurants that don't take reservations and have to wait forever for it.IT WAS WORTH IT. Although, I don't eat seafood and most of their pasta is made for seafood, I still enjoyed my chicken fettuccini and my girlfriend had her linguine with clams with red sauce. It was a great experience food-wise, especially their garlic bread. I didn't realize garlic bread can be that orgasmic. It was fresh out of the oven and it was just delicious. Please, for my sake, get the garlic bread if you go.Atomsphere-wise, it was very small, probably 12 tables? You are so close to other tables that you can overhear their conversations. And also you can see the kitchen, actually not only you can see the kitchen, I don't recall seeing any barrier between the kitchen space and dining. Haha. It was all in one room. So... the reason you should go here is for food; for its purely good, home-cooked, hearty Italian food. We went there around 5 pm on a Wednesday, and it was only a 10 min wait. And not the around the block wait. Whew. :D Be smart.Recommended for a good hearty meal. I don't think you should go there during weekends at night. As good as it is, I don't think its worth it for a "around the block, 2 hour wait" in the cold. But put this in your bucket list.*its like Gourmet Dumpling House of North End. Haha. Small place, Great Food, Long cold waits, and always coming back for more :)

Reviews.Author: Kimberly M.
Reviews.Content: I went on a Monday night at around 7ish.  I was expecting a long line from all the reviews but luckily I was the first one waiting at the door. The place was PACKED so it was still a bit of a wait.  Again, I  got lucky because a couple was just finishing up and I was able to get seated in less than 15 mins.There were so many dishes I wanted to try but only one me to eat it all.  I settled for their special that day, which was 1/2 lobster, mussels, and clams with your choice of sauce over linguini.  I had to try their house sauce.  After a short while, I had a heaping pile of pasta seafood in front of me.  I was debating on giving 4 stars only for the fact that it was really hard to eat the half lobster.  It was coated in sauce but had the shell intact and harder to scoop out than the mussels and clams.  But I realized that was just my fatass side complaining because I could not eat it all without stopping.

Reviews.Author: Linda C.
Reviews.Content: Welcome to an overly-hyped noodle factory. The calamari was way too salty and the lobster dish wasn't impressive. The pastas and their sauces are so standard, your 10 year old can make any of them in a kitchen. Super basic dishes for nonstandard prices.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: It's hard to argue with the hundreds of other reviews on Giacomo's. It's a very solid Italian restaurant.We knew if we didn't get there early enough on Friday that we would be waiting for a long time. The plan was to get there right at opening so our wait would be minimal and hopefully non-existent. After strolling around the North End, being not from Boston, we decided to stroll by the restaurant about 20 minutes before they opened just to find out where it was. When we walked by, there was a group waiting outside, but we were also surprised to see people sitting inside ordering food. Apparently they will open up the place before their official opening time. Not knowing the deal, we took another walk around the block before we went back at 5. We still were able to get right in with no wait. But if you don't mind eating early, if you get there before they actually open, there is a chance you could get a table with no wait.The food was outstanding. I had a fusilli seafood special. The homemade pasta is awesome. I tried the Giacomo's sauce which did not disappoint either. I inhaled all my food. The girlfriend tried the butternut squash ravioli, which she loved. I sampled a piece. Delicious. More butter than nut in those ravioli. Really, really good. Not to mention, the price can't be beat. We had a bottle of wine, an appetizer, and two delicious entrees for about $70.It's very small inside. You'll most likely become very friendly with someone else since you'll be seated very close to them (at the same table in some cases). Doesn't bother me and it shouldn't bother you. The food is good enough to look past any inconveniences the space might cause.

Reviews.Author: Ploy K.
Reviews.Content: I'll start with the good stuff:  the food is AMAZING!!  The BF and I had the burrata appetizer (a mozzarella/cream ball over tomatoes with olive oil and basil), then he had linguini with scallops and the giacomo sauce and I had pumpkin tortellini.  The burrata was ok; nothing too fancy there, but the pasta dishes were incredible.  His scallops were cooked perfectly, and the lobster base for the tomato sauce really helped it go with the scallops.  The sauce for the pumpkin tortellini was mascarpone, and it was just sweet enough to really balance the pumpkin's savory flavor.  It was really rich, which meant I had leftovers, but I could really eat this dish for meals in a row and not get sick of it.  I decided to give Giacomo's only four stars despite the food being truly wonderful because the space and service were just so-so.  The restaurant is very small, so it's hard to get around - a woman from another table had to get out of her chair so that I could get to my seat.  The tables are very close together, so it's as if people are eating on top of each other.  That, and the fact that there was a line out the door and around the block by 6:30pm made me feel as if I had to eat as quickly as possible then get out.  The cramped space made it hard for the servers to get around, so we only saw our waitress when she came to take our order and then when she brought us our food and then the check.  All in all, I will do my best to get back to Giacomo's (but definitely before 6:00!!)

Reviews.Author: R S.
Reviews.Content: The South End location is phenomenal.  Avoid the tourist trap of the N. End location

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: The atmosphere here is great but the food was nothing exciting.  It was bland and boring.

Reviews.Author: Cassandra M.
Reviews.Content: I think "Meh. I've experienced better." is the perfect explanation for how I feel about Giacomo's.I won't knock this place for the wait or the fact that it's cash only. These are things you should just be aware of before you go. Our waitress was pleasant enough and oozed that loud, rough and tumble, North End charm. That said, I've had better italian food pretty much anywhere else I've ever dined and consumed Italian food. The good: - Broccoli sauteed in garlic and oil. It was the best part of the meal by far.- The inexpensive wine selection. The bad:- The chicken parm. It was rubbery--a definite no-no. There was an icky strand of fat that ran down the center of the breast and crunched when I bit into it. Also disappointing: the sauce was bland. - One of my dining bud's got the shrimp scampi. Her pasta was stuck together. - My other dining bud got the shrimp fra diavolo. Her dish was MIA and came out about ten minutes after ours. Not the end of the world, but she didn't love her dish either.Overall, I left perplexed by all of the good reviews and slightly annoyed that no one in my party left satisfied with their meal.

Reviews.Author: Yujie Y.
Reviews.Content: u will know a good restaurant by just ordering one dish, in this case, Zuppa Di Pesce (didnt have the wine though). The dish is absolutely stunning, a giant seafood casserole with linguine for 2ppl. u can tell the freshness of lobster&clams etc. definitely WILL come back again! PS. one star less for cash only

Reviews.Author: Andrew R.
Reviews.Content: For more than 20 yrs this has been my favorite restaurant in Boston's North End. The ubiquitous line outside the door is there for a reason. Restaurant is small, noisy,and the ventilation is poor. Service is quick because they want to give everyone waiting their chance to enjoy. Rose Marie and Tony have been long term fixtures as servers. They treat you well and are very friendly. There is no dessert menu. Cash only. A great experience if you are out for a great meal but not to linger. Tons of Italian restaurants in the North End but Giacomo's is a classic.

Reviews.Author: Brent D.
Reviews.Content: The best italian food in Boston. They don't take reservations, but the line (that runs well out the door on busy nights) moves quickly. Its worth the wait because the food is so awesome. Definitely recommend coming here if you're looking for superior Italian food.

Reviews.Author: J C.
Reviews.Content: Great place for a very good meal.  Not sure it's worth the wait but it's very consistent and inexpensive.  There's no bar which is a downside but there's not much of a beverage selection anyway.I had the shrimp scampi and it was loaded with garlic which is perfect for me.  Portions are reasonable.If you walk by and there's no line, you'd be crazy not to stop!

Reviews.Author: Stephen D.
Reviews.Content: Went here with my wife for our two year anniversy two evenings ago.  We arrived around 4:45 and I am glad we did for by 5:00 there was a decent line waitinng out of bthe door.  The food is absolutely amazing, one of the best if not the best place I have eaten at in a very long time.  Lets just say, they do not have Italian food like this in Seattle!!  My wife ordered muscles and clams with pesto sauce while I had shrimp and scallops ziti.  Man were they both worth the trip.  The service was quick and friendly; I felt bad for the servers since it was so hot that day, clear near 100 degrees.  If you are visiting I would recommend going to this restaurant!

Reviews.Author: Kelly A.
Reviews.Content: I found the food to be heavy, greasy, way too rich, and nothing special.  We ordered the garlic broccoli and it came sitting in a pool of butter.  The sauce on both my pumpkin tortellini and my husband's butternut squash ravioli was sickeningly heavy.  If indigestion and gaining 2 lbs in a single meal is your thing, then maybe you will like this place.  But for the life of me I can not understand why this restaurant is so highly rated.  When I travel I heavily rely on yelp for restaurant suggestions.  Since I feel I was duped by the current reviews of Giacomo's I wanted to write my own review.  Maybe I just have a different palette than the locals.  But if fresh, healthy food, which focuses on the ingredients is your thing than Giacomo's is not for you.

Reviews.Author: Scott U.
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were visiting Boston and went to Giacomo's based on the Yelp recommendations.  We were not disappointed!  We got in line after the heavens opened for an amazing downpour and only had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  The hostess/server was great-friendly yet very authentic in her Boston Italian attitude.  We ordered a bottle of Chianti, thinking we might not finish it, and great green salads with plenty of homemade Italian dressing.I ordered the Shrimp and Scallops with Giacomo's sauce, which was amazing-just the right amount of spice in the red, just a little creamy, sauce.  My wife ordered the butternut squash ravioli and polished them off before me!  She usually leaves some of meal on the plate but had, in her words, "an emotional experience" with how the food made her feel.  "It tasted like Christmas," she said.

Reviews.Author: Justin B.
Reviews.Content: One word... WOW! I do not know where to start! I had the special of 1/2 lobster, mussels and clams served over linguine for $20.00. It was out of this world. Huge portions and fresh sauces. Wine by the glass for $4.25! In the top five meals I have ever eaten! The atmosphere was very noisy, but not too loud to have a conversation. It really added to the authenticity and quaintness.  Most main courses $13-19. Appetizers $6-12. Most bottles of wine about $16.A few tips...- Cash only!- No reservations. - Very small and no waiting area. I would suggest that if you do not want to wait outside (it was FREEZING tonight) that you arrive 15-20 minutes before open and be the one of the first seated.- I would not  take a party over 5 or 6.Overall, amazing! I WILL be back again and again!

Reviews.Author: Susan M.
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for a good quality, inexpensive, red sauce place, Giacomo's is the ticket. If you want fine dining, or ambiance, look elsewhere.The menu is heavy on lobster, clams, mussels and pasta. All were good and highly spiced, like I like them. One friend had the lobster ravioli and was very satisfied with them. Same for the chicken parm.It's a small place, and they don't encourage lingering. If you go, be polite to the staff and take off when you've finished eating. They have to turn those few tables quite a few times to make a living.

Reviews.Author: Lena L.
Reviews.Content: Very small but that gave it the intimate feel. I was seated next to the kitchen along with everyone else in the small restaurant. Usually I hate hate hate this, but here, it was okay. Couples of two were seated together at bigger tables because the wait was so long and the demand-impressive. There was a line outside every time my friend and I walked by. The line went by really quickly though.Now, for the important part-the food: It was very good. I liked my food a lot and my friend's dish the spinach ravioli was delic. My lobster risotto was a special and a very hefty portion. The wine was nice too, but I am not an expert.

Reviews.Author: Wontae S.
Reviews.Content: So this place doesn't take reservations, lines are wrapped around the corner, and they were featured on Food Network.  Normally I would avoid a hyped-up place like this, but Giacomo's is too good to neglect.  This cosy North End restaurant serves some of the best pasta and seafood dishes.  I might even go as far as to say that Giacomo's is my favorite Italian restaurant.The fried calamari was excellent, and had a bit of a spicy-kick.  Last time we went, my cousin had a Grilled Salmon and I ended up stealing most of his food.  The Fettuccine with Prosciutto was also very good.  Portions are hearty and prices are moderate.

Reviews.Author: Anne W.
Reviews.Content: This place is good, and maybe my expectations were set a little high after reading all the Yelp reviews, but I didn't think this place was blow-your-mind awesome.  My boyfriend and I stood outside for a little over an hour, which I guess isn't unreasonable given that this place only has about 10 tables.  We were part of the last few groups let into the restaurant for the night.It's true about the fried calamari- it's really tender.  But when we asked for another minute to place our entree orders, we got a "Well you'd better decide quick because the kitchen is closing".  Okay, I get that we were some of the last people that they let in, but we're still paying customers.  I don't think it's unreasonable to ask for another minute.I got the special- lobster and shrimp fusilli in a fra diavolo sauce.  The pasta was good but the shrimp was tough and rubbery.  My boyfriend's linguine with chicken in a pesto sauce was also good, but nothing I would classify as super special.  I'd go back just to try the butternut squash ravioli everyone's been raving about, but I wouldn't stand outside for an hour for it.

Reviews.Author: Lilian W.
Reviews.Content: The butternut squash raviolis with asparagus is my all time favorite! Just thinking about the delicious butternuttyness and creamy sauce makes me want to head over there right now. Boyfriend got the linguine with mussels and red sauce and he loved it.I've been here a few times already, and they really do not disappoint. The quality is consistent, which is hard to say for many places. I can see the wait being a problem during the winter. This is a very homey hole-in-the-wall type place, and there is no waiting room inside (there's barely any room to maneuver). It helps to have a small party though, I would recommend no more than 4, as they can't move their tables around too much to accommodate larger parties well.The boyfriend and I were told there would be a 45-minute wait, but after about 25-minutes or so, we got a table! Although I have to admit I felt a bit bad for the 10+ people we walked by to get inside, and even a bit worse when we could see them waiting outside still. But we forgot all about that after the short wait for our food [:

Reviews.Author: Michael P.
Reviews.Content: Great restaurant. Part of what makes giacomo's special are the people and the atmosphere. You're in, you eat, and you're out! It's a fun place to go and have hot fresh food. It's great food but don't expect to be blown away, there are tastier places elsewhere in the northend. However, you can't beat 3$ beers and 16$ pasta plates!Overall: One of my favorite places to eat in the northend because of the great atmosphere, relatively cheap (for the northend) great food. Tip: Line is about an hour on average so make sure you like who you're with! And they only take cash.

Reviews.Author: Aimee R.
Reviews.Content: They are AMAZING! This is the only restaurant that I'll wait an hour for...They make their pasta fresh...and the sauces are original and full of flavor. They make me "umm" and "ahhh" outloud. Their wine prices are also very reasonable, about 5 bucks for a glass, and they tasted better than fancier glasses I've had elsewhere for 3x the price......and their CALAMARI IS A MUST. It is super yummy. It is soft, not rubbery at all...and the octopus is crunchy...and the sauce is the perfect compliment....Their service is quick and to the point, no room for undecided people here...but they will answer questions....

Reviews.Author: PT R.
Reviews.Content: Truly a gem. I've tried both this location and the South End one several times and I prefer this one even though it doesn't take reservations and it's cash only. I think it's the smaller space with the open kitchen that gives it that authentic feel. Plus sometimes it's nice to just stand outside and people watch in the North End while you wait. If you're the impatient kind, just show up at 9:30 on a weekday or when it's raining -- sometimes there won't be a line :) For any newcomers, I would definitely recommend the butternut squash ravioli, the gnocchi special and Zuppa di pesce! They say it's for 2, but you can definitely get it for 3. It's a very generous serving. For wine, my favorite is their sauvignon blanc (~$16). At what other restaurant can you buy entire bottles of wine at non marked up prices?

Reviews.Author: Matthew I.
Reviews.Content: Some may snub Giacomo's (original North End) as not worthy of the hype. Or worth the wait. As in standing in line outside waiting for a table. As in always. That's right, always. There's ALWAYS a line. Only question is how long: 1 or 2 groups (really crappy weather on weeknight), or wrapped around the block (glorious weather weekend). And some snub Giacomo's as too much of a tourist draw. I admit, the past four times I've been there, including tonight, I've taken out-of-town friends or relatives visiting Boston. Oh, and the stupid "Rachel Ray recommends" sign in the window doesn't help. No it doesn't.But it's the snubbers' loss. All those folks wait in line in all kinds of weather for a reason. It's a fun experience and a North End legend.  And I love, I mean LOVE the homemade fusilli with lobster, shrimp and the combo Fra Diavolo  / Giacomo's sauce (marsala with lobster and a bit of cream). It's just $26!  And, look, the linguine with choice of seafood and sauce dishes range from $14 to $16. You can't beat the prices. And I've never had a mediocre (or bad) scallop there. No, never. It's worth the wait in line.  It's part of the experience. Have fun, and don't just wait til you have out-of-town friends to entertain.4.5 stars (I gave it 5 because you can't give half star increments and four stars just seems too stingy. I heart Giacomo's)

Reviews.Author: Erik F.
Reviews.Content: After we hit up NEPTUNES, my girlfriend wanted some Italian food so we came to Giacomo's.  It was late and as soon as we walk in the door the waitress told us we had five minute to order cuz the kitchen was closing.    Again we wanted to come here but it had a long line wrapping around the corner.  I guess we got lucky. The lobster ravioli was fantastic. Best Italian food ever.  The waitress made us feel at home, she said the kitchen was closing but she never told us to hurry up and eat. She told us to take our time, so of course I order another PERONI. This place is small and has good prices.  In Los Angeles we have all the towns (chinatown,lil tokyo,etc) but we dont have little ITALY. Something to think about having!!  ENJOY!!!

Reviews.Author: Gabriel O.
Reviews.Content: I figured I would write a review from the perspective of a food tourist who doesn't get many chances to eat in the North End and is trying to pick the perfect place, since that's the situation I found myself in this week. I chose Giacomo's based on the outstanding reviews on Yelp, and I was very happy. The place is tiny and somewhat austere - my wife and I were stuck at a four-person table where we were forced to either make conversation with or eavesdrop on our neighbors. We did the former, as they were jovial and interesting, though being seated next to different diners could have really ruined the entire experience.Food was good and the value was even better. I had fried calamari that were very good (I might even say they are a must), and my lobster, clams, and mussels with linguini Fra Diavolo was excellent - not homemade gourmet fancy inspired pasta and sauce, but just solid, standard Italian-American fare with incredibly fresh seafood all for $20. My wife had something a bit more inventive - homemade Gnocci with a red pepper tomato cream sauce that she says is the best pasta she's had outside of Italy. It was comforting to know they could rise above standard "red sauce" Italian food. Why not 5 stars? As I said, we were seated immediately next to another couple, which could have made for a disasterous dinner if they were not friendly people. It is cash only and there is no dessert and the wait is long. But if you're in the North End looking for some solid Italian-American fare at a great price, it is well worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Courtney C.
Reviews.Content: Butternut Squash Ravioli. Enough said. The line outside is worth it and is scarier looking than it actually is-moves quickly. Your whole party has to be there or you'll get ignored though. Don't go if you're looking for a private place to have a serious date or conversation; it's a packed house always. Bonus if you're into looking at other people's dinners before ordering, like myself!

Reviews.Author: Max and Steph C.
Reviews.Content: Visited Giacomo's on a vacation to Boston.  We heard good things and based on the long line expected greatness.  Standing in line (correction: sitting on an plastic crate in line) we had a nice conversation with a family from Florida that vacations in Boston every year and comes to Giacomo's every time.Our meal was good.  The menu selection was extensive.  The meal was good, but not quite great.  With that said, the experience was fantastic and we really enjoyed our evening.

Reviews.Author: Steve A.
Reviews.Content: So, we were able to have dinner here this evening, but before I get to that, let me explain that I can't count how many times we had previously walked by Giacomo's and thought that no restaurant would be worth that wait outside.Well, on a whim today, we decided to wait for dinner, thinking that even if it wasn't worth it, then at least we could say that we had done it before.Well, the line was about to the middle of 1-800-flowers next door, and it took about 90 minutes to get to the front of the line. There were times when it felt like the line was never going to move again, but we did have the opportunity to speak with the couples in line around us. Eventually we got in, and the dining room is quite cramped. But there was something about it, some sort of vibe that you could tell that the food was being taken seriously.We never got a menu when we sat down - there's a giant chalkboard on one side with the regular menu, and one on the other side with the specials. Also, there's one small paper menu outside, that you have time to read about fifty times before you get inside, so menus inside are completely irrelevant. I will say ths: Giacomo's has a simple menu. I think that's a good thing. There's nice variety on it, but not enough menu sprawl to be paralyzing.We ordered a large calamari appetizer, and it was pretty good. It comes with some pepper slices deep fried with the squid. The flavor was good, but it was a tiny bit on the chewy side, so it was a tad overcooked. I would order it again, both to see if it they get it 100%, and because it was still good, especially with the sauce they bring it with. Also, the bread they bring out is decent, but nothing to go crazy over. The olive oil on the table is very good though, with that nice peppery edge that fresh olive oil tends to have. Bland crap from a chain it is not.So, when our server - Tony - came by and asked us "What do you kids having for supper" I ordered the Frutti di Mare, and my wife ordered the Gnocci which was a special. We also both ordered a Chianti with dinner.Both meals were fantastic. The seafood in my Frutti was cooked as well or better than any seafood I've ever had before, especially the scallops. My goodness, the scallops were beyond good. They were exceptional. I had it in the Giacomo's sauce, which was excellent, because it's lobster based. I ended up with a bonus lobster leg in my meal. Oh, darn. :-) My wife's meal was very very good, but I didn't have more than a bite or two, because I was so infatuated with mine.Here's the bottom line about Giacomo's for me. We ordered: Large Calamari, Frutti di Mare, Gnocci special and two glasses of wine. The total check was a reasonable $58. Let me repeat that: $58. In the North End. In Boston. Boston, Massachusetts. I cannot go to the Olive Garden and get pre-made and reheated food for that price. And Giacomo's is cranking it out in an open kitchen.They don't serve dessert. They want your seat for the people still standing in line, so we went to Mike's. Perfect.The service wasn't white-glove, but it was prompt, attentive and very inviting. I felt like I was eating in Tony's home - and that's a great feeling when everyone working at this particular house is uber-Italian. So, while the price you pay for the food is tempered somewhat by the potentially enormous wait to get inside, you simply won't be disappointed. The value is incredible, and the food is incredible. The only thing that I would change is that I would ask for the Fra Diavolo and Giacomo sauce mix for my Frutti. Next time. In the end, I could dock Giacomo's a star for the wait, but really, it kind of adds to the charm, and frankly, I'd rather wait than pay more at a less impressive restaurant down the street. I'd wait again, and eat again. However, if you ever see a short line, and you don't get in it immediately, and I find out - you'll be dead to me.

Reviews.Author: Maria C.
Reviews.Content: I came here and was so amazed by the calamari, it is their specialty and boy do they take it seriously.I came on a Thursday night and the wait was about an hour - a line around the corner, but it was well worth the wait.For dinner I had the Lobster/clam/mussel linguini in red lobster marinara, it was so delicious I finished the whole thing!  yes, I felt so stuffed, but I wanted to lick my plate dry!Highly recommend this place, the waitress was very nice patient and friendly for Boston standards haha

Reviews.Author: S. K.
Reviews.Content: This was one of the weirdest restaurant experiences ever. So first, you have to wait in line outside and your whole party had to be there. I waited when the line died down but it was still a good 45 minutes because this place is SMALL. It's like a living room. The menu is basically the chalkboard on the wall and the specials are handwritten and given to you to look at. The garlic bread is hard as a rock. Not a fan. I also had the special which was 1/2 a lobster, clams, and mussels over linguini? (not too good with my pastas). The dish was good especially the lobster. Very tasty. Overall, the food was good except the garlic bread. The establishment is small and could use a lot of upgrades to be considered a classy restaurant. It may appear to be classy but it's not. I'm sure with all the money they make, they can afford menus and to take credit cards. Also, the waitress we had was very rude. Is it a Boston thing? Not worth coming back for this especially having to wait.

Reviews.Author: Food P.
Reviews.Content: I know this is a tourist spot but it was some damn good food. Even despite the fact that I had just grubbed on some baos in Chinatown 30 minutes before I came here! I visited Boston for vacation in the beginning of summer this year and my host told us we should go there for dinner one night because she had already made previous plans. So we trekked over there and noticed the long line that had formed outside. We were already there, so there was no going back. The line moved pretty quickly and before we knew it we were seated. Service was very brusque and understandably so because it was prime dinner time and the place was PACKED. We ordered the calamari, burrata salad and fruitti de mare (with lobster and mussels). Not one miss! Everything was so delicious. The calamari was crisp and tender (they also fry up some cherry peppers with it), while the burrata was fresh, soft and delicate. Oh and the tomatoes! They were perfectly ripe. And we may or may not had a couple baskets of bread. Yes, its good and it's fresh...I saw them bringing in the huge loaves one morning at the Columbus Ave. location. Once the plate of fruitti de mare was placed in front of me, my eyes must've looked like they were going to pop out of their sockets. A whole half lobster and a ton of mussels! Pasta was just an afterthought; this was all about the seafood, and I didn't mind one bit. My friend was actually getting full so she had some lobster and a couple of mussels...MORE FOR ME! I surprised myself and killed the entire thing. Sweet, fresh seafood! I definitely had a good time at Giacomo's.

Reviews.Author: melissa g.
Reviews.Content: I always recommend this place to people traveling to Boston. This is literally the best pasta I've had. So much so on our weekend trip there, we ate at both Giacomo's back to back nights. YUM. YUM. YUM.

Reviews.Author: Kathleen Y.
Reviews.Content: Went with 2 of my friends here on a Monday night. The line wasn't too long and we were able to get seated in 15 minutes. The only downside was that it was freezing and we were waiting outside. Inside is very compact and the tables are very close together, so sometimes we would accidentally bump our chairs with the neighboring table.Service: Server was very nice and had very good recommendations. Came to fill our water and check up on us. Food: Delicious and large portions! We ordered the calamari which was delicious and I loved how they had fried jalapenos mixed in. One of the best calamari I've had. We ordered one of the seafood linguine, fettuccine salmon and sundried tomatoes in a tomato cream sauce and lobster ravioli with diced tomatoes in a garlic cream sauce. They were all so good and very filling! We were not able to finish it and ended up packing the rest for another meal. I would come back here if I'm ever in the Boston area. Make sure you have cash, since it's cash only! but there is an ATM nearby.

Reviews.Author: Luke P.
Reviews.Content: It's good, no doubt, but as I get older, I get less patient, more picky and my standards for food perfection only increase. This coupled with what seems like a steady North End tourist population increase over the past 10 years has made me less and less likely to bother showing up to Giacomo's only to wait for over a hour then be rushed through a cramped, chaotic dinner service.:old man: Years ago, I used to be able to come here on a Friday/Saturday night, off-prime hours, and wait maybe 20 minutes max. Now it seems like even showing up at 8:30pm or 5:30pm results in an hour plus wait. :old man:As others say, the food is very good. Not perfect and sometimes a little inconsistent, but overall one of the better places to get seafood pasta in the North End. The pumpkin tortellini is sinfully good also. I understand their business model requires lightning fast service and being rushed in and out. I guess as I get older, I also become slower - 6 years ago I would have given a 4 or 5 star review. I usually love the servers though. There was an older man from years ago (not sure if he still works there) who was hilarious.

Reviews.Author: Reisa J.
Reviews.Content: 4 stars:  butternut squash ravioli, the garlic butter sauce the broccoli was in3 stars: lobster ravioli-several reviews discussed chunks of lobster. There was only one ravioli that had a chunk. I probably would have chosen something else if I had known2 stars: pasta with lobster and shrimp - pasta was nicely cooked but the lobster and shrimp were over cooked (the server did exchange the dish for something else when told about the over cooked seafood which is a positive)1 star: service was terrible - rushed throughout the meal. When asked about dessert, the person who answered told us that they don't serve dessert or coffee. The answer was fine but it was delivered in a rude tone. Left the table to go to the bathroom and found everything already cleared. It happened so fast, the person sitting at the table didn't have time to say she was still drinking her water.  The tables are really squashed in there.The value was not worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Larry L.
Reviews.Content: Best Italian restaurant in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Samik S.
Reviews.Content: Hot summer day. Told we'd wait an hour, only had to wait 30 minutes, great start. We were warned from yelp that it's not AC'ed inside, so we knew we may just have a sweaty meal, and we were completely right. The experience at Giacomo's all felt kinda rushed once we were seated. It might be partially our fault, since we decided what to order so quickly. But the food came out quickly, and the service was fast, which really seems like an odd thing to complain about, but I guess we were hoping to have a more relaxing dinner, especially after the 5 hour drive up.We got the calamari appetizer - very good.My friend and I went half and half on the raviolis. I preferred the lobster one - creamy and tasty. The butternut squash one is what you expect - slightly sweet filling. I prefer more savory entrees.I also snuck in bites of the pumpkin tortellini and chicken fettuccini. Both were good.At one point, my friend asked a waiter for parmesan a couple times, thinking the waiter didn't hear him, and immediately received attitude. The waiter dropped two massive spoonfuls on his plate, clearly out of spite.For the price point, the place is good for North End, but the overall experience was mediocre, so I give it a 3.

Reviews.Author: Lala I.
Reviews.Content: worst service ever encountered in a restaurant. food is mediocre at best. tourist trap

Reviews.Author: Charlie T.
Reviews.Content: My wife and I saw the number of great reviews on yelp last night while in the North End while trying to decide on a place to eat, glad we did.  Giacomo's opens at 5 and when we got there at 5:30 the line had already started forming and there were about 12-14 people in front of us.    It is a very small place with only a few tables but it its small size lends to a really nice atmosphere.  We were a little worried about the wait the the reviews noted that it was worth it.  We were seated by 6 o'clock and VERY glad we waited :).For appetizers, my wife ordered a house salad that was fantastic and I ordered the single order of fried calamari, it was awesome!  I highly recommend it!  TIP: a single order is plenty for two people, leaving you room for your main course.  Then for mains, I ordered the chicken parm and my wife got the pumpkin ravioli.  Both were AMAZING, not only do I highly recommend both but would go back to get them again :)

Reviews.Author: Rebecca I.
Reviews.Content: The food here is incredible! Everyone always complains about the wait... just go at off-peak hours. My friend and I showed up 45 minutes before they closed on a Tuesday and had our pick of tables. The butternut squash ravioli was unforgettable and our waitress was very cheery. Giacomo's is the best!

Reviews.Author: Stacey W.
Reviews.Content: The wait at the North End Giacomo's is looooooooooong, but you won't be sorry! For the price, Giacomo's is the best Italian restaurant in Boston. For comparably delicious food and a shorter wait, try the Giacomo's in the South End; they take reservations!

Reviews.Author: Sandy B.
Reviews.Content: Waited an hour on Labor Day but totally worth it. Best Italian dinner I've ever had!Small place, authentic servers, amazing dishes. Calamari was great. Pumpkin tortellini was out of this world. Subtle sweet taste that was to die for!Lobster ravioli was delicious!

Reviews.Author: TBone A.
Reviews.Content: Hands down best Italian food in North End!!! Go early to avoid long wait. We were there on Saturday night @ 5.20pm the place open at 5pm. We ended up waited for an hour 15 mins before we got sat. Shrimp scampi and out of this world Chicken Parmesan. Worth the wait. Still Cash only place.  Will be back definitely !!! Not a big fan of waiting in line, they also do take out.

Reviews.Author: John P.
Reviews.Content: Our first time to Giacomo's last night(Thursday). Don't expect to be "WOW" by the deco, service or the limited but adequate menu. The restaurant is small and cramp but robust. We got there before 6 pm, hoping to get a table right away but found a line on the sidewalk just like the pictures on Yelp. We waited approximately 25 minutes before getting seated at the only two seats at the bar. They are definitely in business to get people in and out. The tables turnover quickly. It's a CASH ONLY business, no credit accepted. We ordered the fried calamari and linguine dishes with glasses of wine. The food and drinks came quickly but the staff completely forgot our rolls. The pasta (al dente) and seafood were cooked perfectly. The quantity of the food was plentiful (been to another Italian restaurant in the North End that was pretty stingy with the pasta). Desert is not offer here. The meal cost slightly over $50 bucks. We were in and out within 45 minutes. We left with our bellies satisfied minus the waiting time after being seated. I couldn't give Giacomo's a 4 or 5 stars because it lacked an above average dining experience. It's more of a mom and pop restaurant, like a diner with an Italian menu on steroids.
