 I knew we were in trouble!  Thanks to my BF, whose patience made up for my lack there of, we got in line and waited....and waited....and finally after 1.5 hours, we were rewarded with some of the best pasta and cheapest good wine we've ever had!  So the restaurant itself was really really crowded because it's tiny!  Service was incredibly fast and friendly.  The majority of the pasta is served with a choice of 5 sauces: pesto, red (lobster base), fra diavolo (lobster base spicy red), Giacomo's (lobster base with a splash of cream~almost like a vodka sauce), or white (wine, olive oil, garlic).  So we started with the mussels appetizer in Giacomo's sauce--I'm not a fan of mussels, but they were perfectly cooked to just open so the meat is tender and the sauce is very flavorful.  We started with a bottle of the house Sauvignon Blanc which was an incredible value at $16/bottle and it was actually decent.  I ordered the special lobster and shrimp with homemade fussilli in fra diavolo and it was amazing for $25.  It had huge lumps of lobster meat and many big succulent shrimp.  The pasta was perfectly al dente.  I talked my BF into ordering the butternut squash ravioli which was served with diced asparagus and prosciutto in a cheesy cream sauce.  Also amazingly good and at the unbelievable price of $16 or $18.  Everything also came out very fast and the servings are enormous!  I could only finish half of mine...and my BF helped with the rest but still not all finished.  We also had a second bottle of wine, this time we had the Santa Margherita Pinot Grigio, which is our favorite Pinot Grigio for the price range (and at Giacomo's the mark up was minimal to only $36/bottle).  So for our entirely satisfying meal of very flavorful food and definite splurge on the wine (two bottles for two people!!) we walked away only having spent $120 including tax and tips.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but it was worth the 1.5hrs wait and I would actually do it again!

Reviews.Author: Chris J.
Reviews.Content: Probably the best Italian food I've had--ever. We missed the first round of tables and had to wait about 40ish, but it was so, so worth it. Small little place with only 15 tables or so. Wait staff was great; our waitress was 65 or so, but witty, fun and fast. The specials looked amazing, and the garlic bread and calamari were solid appetizers. But the entrees are what blew our minds. I had creamy pesto with chicken and shrimp and I can't say enough about it. The chicken pieces were juicy and tender, and the shrimp were fabulous... but the sauce, just ridiculous. I'd go back in a heartbeat. It's a must-do in the North End.

Reviews.Author: Brandan H.
Reviews.Content: There is a reason why a resturant with over 500 reviews manages to keep a 4.5 star rating. If you are hungry and reading this, go. Your tounge will thank you :)

Reviews.Author: Jing Y.
Reviews.Content: By far one of the most best Italian food I've had in awhile! For appetizer, I got the cream stuffed mozzarella with tomatoes and basil which was  phenomenal!  Their sauces are also really original and amazing, so it's worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Jacks S.
Reviews.Content: Let's say this- it was worth standing in line during a torrential rain storm for.  By the time I got seated (the line disappeared thanks to the rain) I was drenched and miserable, but as soon as I got their delicious food in my mouth I was on cloud nine.   I tried their butternut squash ravioli and their seafood pasta dish and I wanted to lick my plate clean but refrained from further embarrassment for the night.  What makes it 4 stars are the prices- you will not find these prices for the quality in the North end so stop looking and go to Giocomo's.

Reviews.Author: T D.
Reviews.Content: Waited for close to an hour in line on a Sunday evening but well worth the wait.  Fried calamari appetizer was excellent.  Spaghetti with scallops was perfect, ziti with lobster and shrimp was cooked perfectly. Chicken Parmesan was great.  Strongly recommend the homemade garlic bread.  Very casual and well priced.  A great relief from the tourist traps selling frozen pre-breaded calamari and carelessly prepared pasta that are difficult to avoid in the North End.  If you are visiting and only have one chance to get it right of Italian food in the North End this is a good call.

Reviews.Author: Mary L.
Reviews.Content: So I was determined to have good Italian when I visited Boston. I found this place on yelp on decided to give it a go. When I arrived, there was a line extending to almost around the corner. It's a small place inside so you have to wait for people to finish in order to eat. I waited about an hour. You can't leave though or you give up your place in line, so be prepared to entertain yourself. My group and I got the fried calamari and caprese salad to start. We ordered the small calamari which was plenty for three people. We actually still had left overs after. The caprese salad was decent. Fresh mozzarella and the peppers and basil and tomatoes were okay. I got one of their specials with lobster and shrimp. I mixed two of the sauces. My dish was decent but I wasn't really wowed. So why the 4 stars you may ask. Well, my friend ordered the lobster ravioli and I had one bite and fell in love. It was in a garlic cream sauce and the ravioli had that fresh quality where it kind of melts in your mouth. Oh man. I shared my dish with my friend and she ate part of mine as well. By the end, I was swiping up the left over sauce with the bread they gave us. I even ordered a lobster ravioli to go because I loved it so much. But otherwise, the waitress was really nice and patient. Even though we sat next to the window with people in line pressing their faces against the glass to see what we ordered, I didn't feel rushed at all. My water glass was never empty either. Overall: Delicious, fresh pasta + Friendly service= A place worth visiting again.

Reviews.Author: MacaSushi W.
Reviews.Content: We had a dinner here with a large party. Service was okay, nothing exceptional.  Food was delicious.   It was served family style.  Everything was nice and hot.  Bar tender looked a little miserable.  Chicken Parm, Calamari, Cheesecake, Tiramise were all excellent.

Reviews.Author: Laura S.
Reviews.Content: Love the S. End Giacomo's!  It's a great neighborhood spot.  The best thing about living close by is they always stay open during a blizzard.

Reviews.Author: T L.
Reviews.Content: Not sure but if you watch the food network at all, there is a lady named rachel ray on the show, she is a super eater in my book and she went to boston on one of her shows; she went to the north end to a restaurant called Giacomos and it looked real good (plus several people have recommended the place to me). So we went there the first time but there was literally a line down the street for this smallish restaurant but everything on the menu looked awesome, I was starving and hot as balls outside and we didn't end up going; take 2, last weekend, we tried again (located on hanover in north end boston) and long line once again but this time I was going to wait it out. We finally got in and noticed how small this place is, smells good, but kinda of cramped and the shitter is like a gym locker. They have a limited booze menu so I had some italian beer (miraz?). The waitress runs down how the menu is set up but you choose a sauce for the pasta they offered (lots of seafood stuff, mussles, lobster etc) I decided on a half lobster with mussels and clams over linguine with a fra diablo sauce (it is a red sauce, that is spicy and made with lobster base), this was out of this world, pasta was freshly made, and sauce was spicy and hearty, and lobster was cooked perfectly, and to top it off, the serving size was huge!! Maureen had a butternut squash ravioli with a asparagus and cream sauce, this is actually one of their specialties and favorite amoung diners. I cant recommend this place enough, and remember to bring some larger pants, cause I felt like I was going to explode afterwards.9 out of 10

Reviews.Author: David X.
Reviews.Content: I've eaten at seemingly hundreds of Boston area restaurants - tasted the finest food at the most expensive restaurants, and I can say this.  Giacomo's is the best restaurant in Boston - bar none.  I had the best meal I've had in 10 years here recently.The shrimp.  NOW I remember why I loved shrimp.  I'd forgotten after eating such crappy offerings everywhere else.  They tasted like they'd come from the ocean just hours before - fresh, succulent, perfectly prepared.  And the Caesar Salad?  So few places make their dressing from hand instead of getting them from a bottle, and the difference in taste is night and day.  If you've ever had freshly prepared caesar salad, made from scratch, you'd understand.

Reviews.Author: saru s.
Reviews.Content: yeah, see that line. looks long, huh?just get on it.

Reviews.Author: Vicki T.
Reviews.Content: Not sure what happened here.  I was so excited about trying this place, but Giocomo's was a real let down.  The wine was good, the mozzarella marinara was good, the caesar salads were okay, but our linguini with clams was not good.  I got a plate of linguini with the special Giocomo's sauce decorated with clam shells.  Unfortunately, only one clam shell had a small tender clam in it.  The pasta sauce contained lots of precooked chopped clams that were so hard and rubbery that they were impossible to eat.  One edible clam?  Was this a fluke?  Very disappointing!

Reviews.Author: BJ C.
Reviews.Content: In my opinion, this place has everything except space.  The menu is innovative, the food delicious, the staff seasoned and professional.  It's just bumping elbows with strangers and staring at the cooks in the open kitchen that keeps them from an incredible dining experience for me.  But hey, maybe you'll love that stuff!

Reviews.Author: Christie L.
Reviews.Content: We decided to try this place out on a Sunday night hoping the line wouldn't be as long. We got there at about 5:15 and had to wait about 45 minutes. It can go faster depending on the number of people in your party. It's a small space so they call out for parties of two who can jump the line before larger parties. Our waitress, Donna, was fast and efficient, explaining the sauces since we'd never been there before. We started with the calamari ($7), a glass of wine (4.50), and a beer ($3). This all came out very fast and it was some of the best calamari I've had. For dinner, I got the lobster rav ($16) and my bf got the frutti di mare with fra diavolo sauce ($19). The frutti di mare was decent, but the seafood didn't have much flavor and the clams (as another reviewer noted) weren't very good and tasted very fishy (minus the one star). Also, although the sauce was tasty, they may have given him the wrong sauce b/c it wasn't at ALL spicy. The ravioli, however, was the best lobster rav I've ever had. I didn't think a garlic cream sauce sounded like a good match for the dish, but I'm so glad I tried it. I could have licked the plate! My bf wished he would have ordered that as well. The bill was only $52 which is very affordable considering we were in the city, both had alcohol, and ordered an app. Overall, I'm so glad we went and I'd def go back soon if I didn't have to fight for parking!

Reviews.Author: Peter S.
Reviews.Content: Wonderful Veal Parmesan! Outstanding prices for Boston. Worth the wait to get in on a Saturday night. Cash only.

Reviews.Author: Stacey K.
Reviews.Content: Amazing food and great service considering it was a super busy Saturday night!  Appetizers and entrees were all super reasonably priced as well as the wine.  I recommend making a reservation.

Reviews.Author: Paul B.
Reviews.Content: Best small family Italian restaurant on the North End.   Service is quick and friendly, pasta sauce is great.    Seafood is fresh.   Don't expect to linger over dinner, however.  There is a line outside waiting to get in, so everyone gets in and out quickly.

Reviews.Author: Valerie S.
Reviews.Content: I had wanted to try this place since I had seen in on Rachel Ray a long time ago. I got the lobster ravioli and it was awesome. The place is small, but it's very Mom and Pop which is nice. I had gone here on a first date, so it was casual enough and not super fancy. I would definitely go here again.

Reviews.Author: Christina L.
Reviews.Content: I just came back from a weekend in Boston and had dinner at Giacomo's. First thing first, we stumbled upon this restaurant and only really went because there was a line from the minute it opened until we passed it later that night (they open at 5pm).The staff was AMAZING! We got a breakdown of how to order the food since it's a different type of menu. Ok #1 they serve the BEST calamari I've ever had in my entire life hands down! #2 a bottle of wine was only $16!!! The servings are huge and the prices are reasonable so it's worth the wait. Don't get intimidated by the line either, it was a block down and we waited for 30 minutes maybe, it goes really fast.

Reviews.Author: Karen B.
Reviews.Content: Authentic North End Italian experience. Lots of food but the chicken was Very very  tough. Don't believe I've ever had such tough chicken breast. So far I'm feeling like these Bostonians should visit California and find out what great food tastes like.  VERY crowded.  You are eating with strangers at pretty much the same table.

Reviews.Author: C C.
Reviews.Content: I'll keep this short and sweet.Best lobster ravioli I've ever had!The butternut squash was nothing I've ever had before. It was amazing.In terms of atmosphere, the place is very small, loud and crowded. I didn't mind this at all. I was too busy eating the delicious food to be bothered by it.Lastly, I agree with the other yelpers, this place was definitely worth the wait!

Reviews.Author: J L.
Reviews.Content: The food is nice, However, The atmoshere is very Noisy and tables are very tight and claustrophobic. The worst thing is, they are busy so they rush you through the whole meal and it takes away from the experience. food comes out lightning fast so they can flip the tables. It's not a relaxing dining experience but a little more dignified than a drive through fast food joint. I haven't been since that experience and will not return for this simple reason...despite the tasty food.

Reviews.Author: Joanna A.
Reviews.Content: We had friends in town and got here early on a Friday nite..10 of 5. We decided to walk around a little before they opened. Got back about 10 after 5 and good thing we did! The line was just starting to form! We got  one of the last 3 open tables. We were immediately given some cold wheat italian bread (my only compaint of the meal).  The waitress means business, she is ready to serve to keep those tables moving! we started with a crisp not overly greasy basic fried calamari appetizer. THe large was more than enough for 4 hungry people. Then we ordered our entrees off the chalkboard..pretty cool that there are no menus. 3 of us ordered from the pasta entrees where you choose your sauce and the variety of seafood you want. We all got the Giacomo house red sauce which is delicious... a slightly creamy  marinara but not really. My friend got the spicy sauce mixed in and good thing she did, just half was spicy enough for her! I got the scallops and shrimp. for $16, it was a huge filling entree with lots of seafood and plenty of leftovers for another meal. 2 of my companions got the mussels. And 1 of them got the ziti with chicken and shrimp in a cream sauce..he finished it so i guess it was good!Anyway, the food was ordered and in front of us before we knew it. Not a place for a slow leisurely meal, but its cozy in there and they don't really rush you, they are just on the ball. And btw, the line was in full force by the time we left.The bill came to $85 with 1 appetizer, 4 entrees, and 2 alcoholic drinks. Not bad.I don't think they have dessert here. but it doesnt really matter in the North End where you can walk dow nthe street and get a cannoli and a number of great cafes. which is what we did ;)Very satisfyilg meal on a cold cold day!

Reviews.Author: heather c.
Reviews.Content: --cash only (no visible warning sign of this fact, but non-branded ATM across street)--queue up outside for a table, NO reservations. the dining area is very small and contiguous with the kitchen. but surprisingly, you do not leave reeking of food. tables are tightly spaced.--our waiter was efficient yet engaging with great recommendations. --calamari-wonderful, best I have ever tasted, although I am not a maven.--antipasto-went nicely with the calamari. GET THE butternut squash ravioli. do it.$32/person for split 2 appetizers, bottle of wine, several bottles of beer and entree, 7 people. not too wallet-lightening....entrees were about $15-17  casual to dressypretty sure wine and beer only

Reviews.Author: Claire M.
Reviews.Content: Long line outside but definitely worth it.  Server meant business but was pleasant.  Surprising number of vegetarian options.  Generous portion sizes.  Affordable for the North End.

Reviews.Author: Kevin L.
Reviews.Content: People line up blocks for this place, and rightfully so. Calamari was on point and the house marinara was some of the best ive had. Had the shrimp, scallops and fettuccine which was amazing, also the butternut squash ravioli was delicious. Be prepared to wait an hour outside to get in and a pushy wait staff to turn tables, but all around best Italian food in the north end!

Reviews.Author: Danielle M.
Reviews.Content: Mmmm pepper in the pasta dough

Reviews.Author: Tina D.
Reviews.Content: I will not rehash everyone else's accurate 5 star reviews.  Had the pumpkin ravioli with asparagus sauce.  Loved it.

Reviews.Author: Kyle M.
Reviews.Content: After living in the North End for two years and eating in most of the restaurants, Giacomo's became, not only our favorite but the only one we went to consistently.Their butternut squash ravioli, seafood, and sauces are all exceptional.  And are among the most reasonably priced meals in the North End.  We Love This Place.

Reviews.Author: Kim Z.
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough good things about Giacomo's.  My friend was visiting from NC and it was her last night in town and I immediately thought of Giacomo's. We arrived at about 430 and got in a line of about 18-20 people. The restaurant opened about 5 minutes later and it was controlled chaos going in and getting seated. These folks know what they're doing.Our waitress was super helpful and knowledgeable and on top of things. My water glass was never empty! We ordered the phenomenal antipasto as an appetizer. It was a good size, if not a little big for just 2 people. The only reason we stopped eating it was because we knew we had entrees coming and wanted to save room!I was very impressed that our meals were held until a few minutes after we ate our appetizer. A lot of restaurants will simply force the entree on you before you have a chance to digest the appetizer. Not here. They are fast with their service, but not pushy. My friend got the butternut squash ravioli, a dish they've come to be known for. And with good reason. Even with a cream sauce, it was light and incredibly flavorful. I had the shrimp and scallops over linguine with Giacomo sauce, which is a red sauce with a little cream and pepper. Perfection. I was all ready to bring some home, but couldn't stop eating! It is a little cramped in the restaurant so you're most likely sitting on top of your neighbor and often have to scoot your chair here and there, but it really adds to the dining experience. The people who eat here always seem to be excited to eat here and truly enjoy the whole experience. The servers, host, cooks - they all seem to really enjoy their work and are good at it, making everyone feel very welcome and at home. Easily my favorite restaurant in the North End. I would happily wait in line to go again and again.

Reviews.Author: Michelina D.
Reviews.Content: Fantastico! BEST Italian food in the North End, hands down!

Reviews.Author: Malia M.
Reviews.Content: Pretty solid, but we thought the food is good not mind blowing.We got there at 445 and we were seated immediately, so no issues with that or the service.We shared the chicken parm, butternut squash ravioli, fettucini with salmon, calamari and garlic bread. It was a great value for only $50 dollars.Although the dinner was good, we just didn't think it was worth the hype. Our local Basta Pasta in Cambridge actually tastes better to us.It was good, but if you can't go there, there are many great alternatives in the North End, like Taranta.

Reviews.Author: Karen H.
Reviews.Content: Wow.  Garlic spinach ravioli were terrific.  Great food at a good price.  Boston favorite.

Reviews.Author: John S.
Reviews.Content: Skip it! I lived in Charlestown and I would eat out frequently in the north end. I have been told to try this place out but never wanted to wait in line. So one winter when the tourists were away, I decided to wait in line. Yes, there still was a line. The food was so-so and service was akin to ihop. I have no clue why this place has a line when there are so many other places near by that have far superior food and service. Check out Carmen's or terramia instead. You will be much happier.

Reviews.Author: Charlie K.
Reviews.Content: Best date spot ever. Don't be afraid of the line, or of doing whatever you want to do before you get into it. People show up and join the line, not all at once so just relax. Lobster ravs are the best. BEST. Really liked the broccoli dripping in butter, mostly because the garlicky butter was so good on the bread. Also, linguine with shellfish, though next time I'd beg for clams and squid only. Pumpkin tortelloni are fantastic. Nobody eats dessert here. But everyone drinks Chianti! Why not, it's only $14! Really, really love this place.

Reviews.Author: El D.
Reviews.Content: Just simply fantastic!  Went there the night after we went to Mama Maria's and, although we give MM its due, Giacomo just blows it away - first on the food and second on the charm and for a third of the price..  Cutting to the chase - we ordered the calamari appetizer - it was best of breed with ideal spicy tomato dipping sauce - and still, the worst thing we ordered.  I had the fusili with lobster and shrimp in spicy tomato sauce.  The pasta is clearly homemade fresh, perfect al dente - maybe best fusili I ever had.  Sauce - excellente and fresh.  Lobster was a tad chewy though but the homemade fresh flavor was awesome.  My fiancee asked the waiter what to choose between the lobster ravioli and the special ravioli - which was hot coppacola filling with dabs of goat cheese on top of amazing tomato chicken sauce.  The waiter said - "you can get lobster ravioli anywhere" - yeah right! - but steered us toward the special.  And special indeed it was - best ravioli dish on the planet - and that includes the planet Italy.Everything served piping hot right from the pot to the table.  All of this for a shockingly moderate price, including a very solid bottle of Montepulciano and we were out of there for $63.  I ended up leaving the biggest tip of my life (percentage wise).  Did I mention the large portions?  Really - read my other reviews and you will see that I am not easily impressed, but this place is special.  Well worth standing in line.

Reviews.Author: Widodo T.
Reviews.Content: The rather old waiter in this North End restaurant is a pervert, he touched my wife's face with both hands, I yelled at him but every now and then he kept touching her on the shoulder. We ordered the House Special Zuppa di pesce with mixed of fra-diavolo and giacomo sauces, very delicious. Even though it says the dish is for 2 person, but actually 6 people can eat and share it. Unfortunately, 1 hour later after eating this, my stomach hurt so bad, I had to take imodium. BAD!!!!When you are eating seafood like mussels and lobster, there are shells that you need to trash, so the busboy just kept talking to the female customers, until I asked for bowls to trash the waste. He did a good job taking the trash bowl, but didn't bring new ones back but continued talking to the female customers, lazy and stupid!They gave us free bread, but it was hard stone bread that you can't even rip it out with your hands, and didn't come with butter.

Reviews.Author: Meredith K.
Reviews.Content: This restaurant is one of my new faves.  It'll be a requirement to eat there whenever I visit.  The food was authentic, the service was good, and our waitress was very friendly, plus they have a diverse menu.  You have options to customize your own linguine or choose from their selected pasta/vegetarian dishes.   I choose the linguine and went w/ the spicy house sauce & the reg house sauce (w/ bechamel) - both lobster based, and mussels & shrimp.   It was a great combo.  Next time, I'll go with spicy all the way.  We waited about 30 mins on a Friday evening around 6pm - it was well worth the wait.

Reviews.Author: Wendy O.
Reviews.Content: I've been dining at Giacomo's for 8 years now....and have only ordered one dish- the buttnernut squash ravioli. This dish is so good that when I was living in California over the last few years I would be tempted to call and ask if I could have it delivered, shipped, anything just to taste it again. I just moved back to Boston three days ago and returned to Giacomo's as soon as I arrived. It was as delicious as I remember. The wait is worth it, just go!

Reviews.Author: Ashlee W.
Reviews.Content: Two words, Lobster Ravioli. Its life changing and I am proud to say I waited over 30 minutes in the rain to eat here. I was visiting and looked it up on Yelp. As my friends and I are standing outside it began to rain. We began chatting with some local people in front of us and they assured us it was worth the wait. The didn't lie! Some of the best Italian food I have ever had. Once we were seated we were immediately served and had a great experience. I can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Winnie W.
Reviews.Content: OMG - the best Italian food I've had this side of Atlantic!  The restaurant is small and they don't take reservation, so please, either come early for your own sake or be prepared to wait out in the streets.  I got here on a weekday 5:30pm, and I was lucky enough to not have to wait.  The dishes here are TO DIE FOR.  Get their seafood pasta - you will not be disappointed.  They have several good ones, it depends on which one you like.  Giacomo sauce (one of their red sauces) is really good, you can't go wrong with it.  The resaturant is very small and crowded, so it won't be a good first date restaurant.  Otherwise, if you and your buds are looking for an affordable Italian restaurant that will knock your sox off, this is it.  I envy those of you who live in Boston and have access to this restaurant.

Reviews.Author: Purvi R.
Reviews.Content: Eggplant Parm. Get it.

Reviews.Author: Rebecca Huicha K.
Reviews.Content: drooooooooooooooooooooooooool.this is a must eat place in boston. don't let the long line intimidate you, it'll be worth it in the end. my party of 5 waited about an hour and we were starving but the service is fast and the good is GREAT.must try items: pumpkin ravii cant wait for my next booooston visit just for giacomos!

Reviews.Author: Michelle L.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's* is totally the Serendipity of Boston - except instead of monstrous frozen hot chocolates, their specialty is mounds of pasta, and it was Rachael Ray, not John Cusack and Kate Beckinsale, who catapulted it into questionably deserved fame...My friend and I arrived for dinner around 8:30 or so. After getting barked at by the hostess/mob boss lady (takeaway: there is no list, so just get in the back of the line) and waiting in the rain for about fifteen minutes, we were seated next to these two gentlemen who immediately started up a conversation with us. This restaurant is tiny and there's hardly any space between tables, so it became an impromptu double date of sorts... Were they in town on business? Check. Their last night in Boston? Check. Ambiguous marital status? Check check check.We started with the fried calamari which was good, but it was pretty much what I'd expect from happy hour at McCormick and Schmick's or whatever, except there were fried jalapeño slices too. Big whoop. I ordered the linguine with fracomo's sauce (half-Giacomo's sauce, half-fra diavlo sauce - perfect for the tragically indecisive, comme moi!) and mussels and clams. The dish, served in a heaping portion, was straight-up comfort food. The sauce was hearty and light at the same time, and smelled like the sea - this is not marinara, people. I couldn't see or taste the bit of cream that was in it, but I think it added some depth. Still, I had to shake some red chili flakes on top because there wasn't enough kick. My friend had no expression after trying it: "All red sauce tastes the same to me." Enough said. Her lobster ravioli in garlic cream sauce was delicious but I think too rich for me as an entrée. I don't think anyone out of the four of us, all Giacomo virgins, was particularly impressed, but then again none of us is from Boston. My theory is that they are pretty starved out here for a good, old-fashioned plate of pasta... I invite any of the many Bostonians who think Giacomo's is a legend to visit Philly, where apparently quality Italian is less hard to come by, and for no wait to "boot" :)Our server was a sweetheart, but the rest of the staff seemed pretty happy to get us up and out of there. Which was fine - we ended up getting drinks afterwards with our new "friends." Haha. It wasn't quite serendipity, but it provided more to write home about than our less-than-memorable dinner.*Pronounced, I am told, "JAHK-a-mo's."

Reviews.Author: Jess M.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's deserves more than 5 stars. Have been to the South End location twice and the food is excellent . On my most recent visit, I ordered a caesar salad with anchovies and the goat cheese filled gnocchi with chicken. Both were delicious. Topped off the evening with a shared bottle of wine. Perfect accompaniment to an incredible meal. Best Italian restaurant in Boston!

Reviews.Author: Shweta V.
Reviews.Content: We waited in line on a cold evening for 45 minutes, and the food was completely worth it! This place was highly recommended by friends who used to live in the area, and I can see why they wanted us to experience it. The restaurant itself is quite small but it has an interesting vibe. The tables are set close to each other, the place is very noisy, and the servers are very friendly. We tried the special appetizer of the day - burata (sp?), a large mozzarella ball filled with cream, and served on a plate of tomatoes, olive oil, roasted red peppers, and fresh basil. The mozzarella has to be amongst the best I've had - so delicious and nearly melted in the mouth. The server informed us that it's imported in daily. Our entree was linguine with giacomo sauce, mussels, and shrimp - we loved it so much that we ended up wiping the plate clean with bread.I can't wait to go back to Boston just so that I can go back to Giacomo's!

Reviews.Author: Byron C.
Reviews.Content: Mind blowingly good. This is the best italian restaurant I've ever been to.Bread: The only real negative of the food here. Rough and chewy on the outside, soft but bland on the inside. 1.5/5Fried calamari: Good starter. Not too drastically different from that of most fried calamari but this one has more flavor because they add hot peppers to the mix. 3.5/5Burrata: Now we're getting to the good stuff. This is basically a mozarella ball served over sliced tomatoes but boy was it good despite the seeming simplicity. The soft and yet oh so slightly chewy texture was unlike anything I've ever had before. The mild flavor of the cheese and the sweet/sourness of the tomatoes worked wonderfully together. 4.5/5Pumpkin tortelini/butternut squash ravioli: I'm grouping these 2 together because they were both perfect and I can't decide which one I liked more. If I was to rank the best non-meat containing main courses I've had in my life these two would be 1a and 1b. 5/5Veal parmigana: The only non-amazing main course we ordered. Wasn't anything wrong with it, but it just tasted like any other veal parmigana I've had before. 3/5Fettucini with swordfish and tuna in pesto cream sauce: Overshadowed by the pumpkin tortelini and squash ravioli but an excellent dish in its own right. I'm pretty jaded when it comes to pesto sauce but this was something special. Had this been my sole main course I would have still left Giacomo's completely satisfied. 4.5/5Worth the line. Worth the hype.

Reviews.Author: Tiffany W.
Reviews.Content: italiano. molto bene.When there's still a line outside this small Italian restaurant at 9pm on a Monday night you know it's gotta be good! Giacomo has a pretty extensive food menu where you can mix and match seafood and sauces.  I recommend the pumpkin tortellini or  the Giacomo (pink) sauce linguine... everything looked and smelled delicious so you can't really go wrong!The wait can get a bit long, but time it right and you can catch a wave of ppl leaving (my friend and I got in within 15 min).  Very friendly wait staff and a lively close-dining atmosphere add to an overall awesome dining excursion.

Reviews.Author: Ryan J.
Reviews.Content: My favorite place in the North End, though I don't get there as much as I would like.

Reviews.Author: ashley m.
Reviews.Content: Like many others, I went with the Butternut Squash Ravioli. One word - AMAZING! The inside of the restaurant is tiny, so you can always expect a wait. The service feels a bit rushed and the space a bit cramped, but it really is worth it for the food. We started with a caprese salad and calamari - both were excellent and came out quick. First bottle of wine we ordered wasn't available - sad. Next the entrees...I almost died. The butternut squash ravioli is served in a proscuitto and mascarpone cream sauce. I dare say that it's the best sauce I've ever had. Yep, EVER. Proscuitto AND mascarpone cream?!? Two of my favorite things. I've been dying to go back ever since.

Reviews.Author: Ryan H.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's really is as good as everyone says. I went on a thursday night pretty early so i only had to wait a few minutes in the "HUUUUUUUGE LINE" that everyone else experiences. The food was worth my wait. I like the layout of the menu and the service was above average. The only thing that bothered me was the soda served in glass bottles. I know a lot of people think this is "charming" but it just left me thirsty.

Reviews.Author: Justin T.
Reviews.Content: Came here when I was on a road trip. My BU friend told us to go here and we happily listened. The fried calamari is freaking awesome and pretty cheap for what we got. The thing that makes this place a five star for me was the fact that I got a great lobster, mussel, clams, and oyster dish for 20 bucks flat without tax. The place is just freaking awesome and I'd suggest going there any time you are in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Jaime T.
Reviews.Content: OPENS AT 4:30PM! Please take note. We made the mistake of  going right at 5, and had to wait for over an hour. It was worth the wait! Excellent place. It's been a while since we went there, but my mouth still waters when I think of the Giacomo sauce. I wish I could get the recipe - it's one the best sauces I've ever had!  We got the Broccoli to start with and that was delicious. My husband had the Butternut Squash Ravioli and he loved his, too. Tony was our waiter and he was awesome! Very affordable, too. Can't beat it. You should definitely check it out...but go at 4:30!

Reviews.Author: The Tough And Honest Critic O.
Reviews.Content: Simple options, small restaurant, overpriced - I'm not big on pasta so maybe this is why the ranking is so low.

Reviews.Author: Serena H.
Reviews.Content: This is my favourite Italian place in Boston. I had some plain red sauce seafood linguine. The noodles are perfect. The sauce was perfect. The space is perfect. I love it. Northend is so faux in comparison.

Reviews.Author: J C.
Reviews.Content: This place is fantastic.  Period.  Whether you are lucky to sit down quickly or patiently wait in line, you will be rewarded.  I haven't had anything here that didn't taste good.  Their Giacomo sauce is insane.  Rich & creamy.  Yum!Some picks:-Homemade fusili w/ shrimp & scallops - tastes so dang good w/ Giacomo sauce.  Did I say I like this sauce?-Calamari - consistently perfect-Lobster ravioli - Excellent-Butternut Squash ravioli - I am not a big fan of squash but this is some real tasty squash-Mussels - this appetizer in fra diavolo sauce is good-Bottles of wine are very well pricedCaveats:-This is a tiny restaurant expect to sit cozily with other restaurant guests-Expect some gawking while waiting in line-Bring a snack (just in case you faint from hunger while waiting...)

Reviews.Author: Gary F.
Reviews.Content: This is the best authentic northern Italian food on Hanover St . For quality food at a great value Giacomo's is the place to go . You can have a appetizer 2 entrees and a bottle of wine for under $50.00. Say hello to Donna or Rosemary when your there you won't be sorry.

Reviews.Author: Mario A.
Reviews.Content: well worth waiting in line for over 30 minutes

Reviews.Author: Kate S.
Reviews.Content: The food here was AMAZING! our waitress was Julie, and she was sooo sweet and made sure we got exactly what we wanted. It's a great little Italian place that serves authentic food. It was a great find for out of towners!

Reviews.Author: Lester S.
Reviews.Content: Lobster ravioli is freakin excellent! Chicken parmesan is good as well.

Reviews.Author: William M.
Reviews.Content: This was my 2nd but last time for this place. Food is good (not great) but service was very bad this second go. Think Durgin Park, save the gimmick. For a while I was thinking this is their new gig. No appreciation that our groups of 4 were actually customers. As I will never tip for poor service, which averages to be about every 18 months or so, I was approached by our server  that the service fee was not included in the bill. I said I was aware of that and explained I do not tip for poor service. The server challenged me on what she did wrong, which I appreciated, and went on to give her the reasons. I truly hope the following customers were treated as "customers" but I'm guessing not--as it appeared to be inherent with all the wait staff.  This place may have been great in the past but is now benefiting from former glory day reputations and certainly not worth the fanfare it continues to get. I myself have gotten caught up in the "this place is great because everyone else says it's great" moment instead of being truly biased on my own experience. Cheers.

Reviews.Author: Alan Z.
Reviews.Content: 90 minute wait over the Labor Day weekend for this highly rated Italian restaurant in the North End. Tiny place with 10 tables. Service was extremely fast but the food was not worth the 90 minute wait, more like 30 minutes.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie G.
Reviews.Content: Before this place, I was not a fan of Italian food--which is ironic since my boy is Italian. Well....we read so many good reviews of this place on here, that it was our first stop when we headed up to Boston back in September for the Yankees/Soxs series. It was a quick walk from our hotel. First off, I hadn't been to Boston in forever and when I walked into the North End I immediately fell in love. We hiked over to Giacomo's--surprise! No line! (I think the fact that we went at 5:30 helped...there was a line when we left!)The place was packed, but they seated us right away. Everyone was super, super friendly. We each ordered a glass of wine and then had the calamari to start--YUM! I've only have calamari at one other place that was this good--and it was just this past weekend. I ordered the lobster ravioli with the red sauce..oh.my.god. So freakin' good. We knew the place was cash only....but unfortunately the people next to us did not and were wondering what they were going to do. Luckily, they were able to sneak out to an ATM.Yes, this place is small and crowded, but the food is to die for and you can make "friends" with the people eating next to you! The boy and I talk about making trips up to Boston just to eat here......

Reviews.Author: Doug P.
Reviews.Content: This is a wonderful treasure within the South End. It's a small, comfortable restaurant with a very pleasant staff. The seafood and pasta are all top Notch. I highly recommend the Pumpkin Ravioli.  This is an extremely popular restaurant and usually with a line out the door.  Because of this I either go when it is not a typically busy time in the South End (afternoons or weeknights).  It is worth the wait, but just don't go on a totally empty stomach if you hit a busy  time cause the line can be 10-20 groups deep.

Reviews.Author: Te R.
Reviews.Content: lots and lots of food! my guy and i came here for a fake date. we've got the seats at the bar after around 20 minutes of waiting.the service is kind of like diner-style, but the food was very good. the calamari was very good. but i particularly liked butternut squash ravioli. other things were all right. i never had lobster and a pile of seafood with pasta before so it was great. but this place is little bit overhyped on yelp though..

Reviews.Author: Sandy J.
Reviews.Content: I heard that Boston's North end has some of the best Italian restaurants in the US.  I decided to give this place a try based on all of the high ratings.  The menu was up on the wall and we decided to start with the Cesar salad (I needed to eat some veggies) and calamari.  The calamari was good, but not as delicious as everyone hyped it up to be.  I ordered the pasta special of the night, I forgot what it was called but it involved seafood and homemade pasta.  It was good, but I liked their fradiavolo sauce better than their Giacomo sauce.  It was too creamy and not as flavorful to me.  The portions are huge and service was different, but great.  Overall, this is a good Italian spot, but it didn't blow me away.  I would probably return, but not until I've tried a few other Italian places in Boston.

Reviews.Author: Nick A.
Reviews.Content: Some of the best pasta ive had..went twice while in boston..long wait small place but worth it

Reviews.Author: Kathryn B.
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend the butternut squash ravioli and pumpkin tortellini. Both amazing, cooked perfectly, wish I lived in Boston so I could eat these dishes more often. Worth the 45min wait for sure.

Reviews.Author: Derrick C.
Reviews.Content: Instead of the 2.5hr wait @ Neptune, we settled on the 20min wait @ Giacomo's.  This place doesn't seat many so quarters were tight, but good food/wine and more than reasonable prices make this a great dinner spot in the North End.  The fried calamari appetizer might've been my favorite dish of the night - perfect balance b/t the fried batter and maintaining the taste of the squid.  My linguine in a spicy fra diavolo sauce w/ a 1/2 lobster, mussels, and clams ran up to $22 which w/ the amt of seafood in it, I'm pretty sure I was committing robbery.  However, it makes absolutely no sense to me how this place that's pretty much considered fine dining can be cash only.  Basically if you're a pickpocketer, the line outside Giacomo's might be a good place to earn your living.

Reviews.Author: James B.
Reviews.Content: I mean, what can be said about this place that hasn't been already?  The staff isn't the friendliest in the world, but they are trying to turn tables and keep the line outside moving.  If the line is to the corner, the wait will be about an hour, but it is totally worth it.  Once inside the food is amazing.  Really the best Italian food I've ever had (don't tell my grandmother).  And the best part is that it won't break the bank.  I can't think of more to ask for from a restaurant (other than the ability to make reservations, but that would take half the fun of coming here away).

Reviews.Author: Christos C.
Reviews.Content: This place is great, but go on a non-weekend night. The line down the block is absurd and this place only takes cash. That being said, this pretty is pretty great if you like Italian.

Reviews.Author: Sarah B.
Reviews.Content: It is easy to see why there is always a line along Hanover Street in front of Giacomo's. The food is wonderful--they seem to specialize in seafood pasta dishes. The wine is great too, and they have a selection of well-priced options. Overall, I think it's a great value. The main reason I don't count this place among my favorite places in the North End is the line. My husband and I thought we wouldn't have to wait too long at 5:30 on a Tuesday in the rain, but we waited for about 45 minutes. Once inside, we rushed through our dinner because we felt guilty for all the other people waiting in the rain and gazing longingly at our food through the window. So I would recommend the other Giacomo's location or some of the other great restaurants in the North End over this one if you want a relaxing, leisurely Italian meal.

Reviews.Author: Lulu N.
Reviews.Content: Worth the wait! Now I know why it's so highly rated. Great food at a reasonable price.

Reviews.Author: Amy L.
Reviews.Content: Worth the wait, rain or shine (in our case it was rain).  We found this place in Little Italy.  There was a slightly line outside.  When we asked the guys ahead of us how long it would be, they told us about 45 minutes.  When we asked if it was worth the wait, they gave us an emphatic "YES!"  Judging by their accents, we were figured they were local and we could trust their word on food.  Boy were we glad we did.  Although it started raining, we only had to wait outside for 25 minutes, mostly under an overhang.  I would have waited another 25 minutes if I had to get a delicious meal from this place.Its extremely small and intimate with your party, as well as this around you.  We ordered the baratta (fresh motz ball with cream, tomato slices, and balsamic).  It was amazing.  I could have ordered two more of those.  Fortunately, I also ordered an entree.  I went with the butternut squash raviolis.  There is no way to describe how delicious my meal was.  I am always appalled when someone suggests going to eat at Olive Garden back home in Texas (even though this is really our only Italian option) but I don't think I will EVER be able to eat Italian food anywhere else and be truly satisfied.  I would wait an hour in the rain to eat here again.  Also, the prices are amazing for the quality and quantity of food you receive. BONUS!

Reviews.Author: James W.
Reviews.Content: Delicious food, decent service. Nothing will blow you away but you'll enjoy the time while you're there.

Reviews.Author: Kaylee C.
Reviews.Content: I wish I could have two or 3 stomaches. I wanna try everything. I never ate that much in my life, and I still wanted more. Seafood makes me sink. Gotta visit again

Reviews.Author: Adrienne P.
Reviews.Content: Always wonderful food, reasonable prices, and welcoming, friendly atmosphere.

Reviews.Author: Tyler G.
Reviews.Content: I haven't been here in a couple of years b/c of a bad experience.  Rachel Ray went to Giacomo's when she did a show on Boston.  So when my two friends came to visit, we went there for dinner.  The wait wasn't that long..maybe 20 minutes (7:00 p.m.).  Our server was unintrested and not helpful.  They were out of several entrees that we ordered.  We did order the calamari and it was good.  My friend had a hair in her entree and when we told the waitress; she didn't seem to care.  I don't know...maybe we just had a bad server...maybe I'll try them again.

Reviews.Author: Michelle T.
Reviews.Content: Definitely worth the long wait. I always get my pasta with the fracamo sauce- SO good. The seafood is so fresh that you can smell the freshness once you enter the restaurant. Service is friendly and attentive. A must-go restaurant to anyone visiting Boston.

Reviews.Author: Scott S.
Reviews.Content: Amazing little restaurant with home cooked, fresh Italian food.  The wait staff is awesome and service is quick.  Make sure to arrive early when it opens, even on a week night the wait can be 45min and more.  This place came highly recommended by friends of ours who live local.  Let me reiterate again - the wait staff is awesome, good customer service can make food taste even better!

Reviews.Author: Jen C.
Reviews.Content: My fave place in the North End! Always good but, try going after or before the dinner rush for less of a wait

Reviews.Author: Jen T.
Reviews.Content: Love it love it. Have to second Lauren E. on the butternut squash raviolo. Unreal. If there is a wait, wait! It is definitely a place to be in the North End, especiall y in the summer time.

Reviews.Author: Momo R.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's claim to fame is hosting and subsequently being recommended to the masses by Rachael Ray.  My foray to this esteemed Italian establishment, however, was prompted by the raves of a colleague.  I thought the service was good naturedly no nonsense, yet the food left a lot to be desired.  Like Rachael Ray, I ordered the pumpkin tortellini, which consisted of slightly over al dente rings of pasta swimming in a deep pool of oil.  I didn't enjoy the calamari either, but that had more to do with my aversion to stuffing tentacles in my mouth than the quality of the food.  All in all, overrated, especially considering that this is supposed to be the epitome of Boston's reputed Italian cuisine.

Reviews.Author: Nina H.
Reviews.Content: This is one of my fav places to eat.   If you are looking for a nice down, this isn't the place.  You almost kind of feel forced to leave after you eat your meal but it;s worth it.  It's a little hole in the wall that seats probably 20 people.  I wouldn't go here if you had a big group of people because you could be waiting forever for a table.  They do not take reservations either so you will usually find a line outside of the restaurant.  When you are finally seated,  make sure you get their calamari.  It;s absolutely THE BEST calamari.  It's super fresh and hits the spot.  You can't go wrong with any of thepasta dishes with their special giacomo sauce.  They don't serve dessert but a bottle of wine is only $16!!!  This restaurant is definitely a MUST if you are visiting Boston.

Reviews.Author: Erin B.
Reviews.Content: Astounding that I lived in the Northend for over 3 years before I finally visited Giacomo's.  Perhaps it was the huge line that was always a deterrent.  Why am I going to wait in line for an hour when there are a hundred other restaurants?  Well, I finally waited in that line (30min on a Sunday at 4:30pm) and it was worth it!! The prices (for the Northend) are unbeatable.  With entrees in the mid teens, and food that is fabulous, Giacomo's is a hit.  I suggest going during off times (middle of the week, or early) to avoid the line.  For me the slightly disgruntled service and wait was a determining factor in that ever elusive 5th star.  Nonetheless, Giacomo's is a must go, and I must go there again!

Reviews.Author: Andrea C.
Reviews.Content: Wow! Wow! Wow!!!!! I love this place. The wait is ridiculous and the lady who comes out to get your party number totally fibs on the amout of time to wait. She told us it would be 30 minutes, and it was more like 75 minutes. But.... here is a big BUT..... it was sooo worth the wait.The food was amazing and so surprisingly affordable. I loved it. I had the night special which was linguine with your choice of sauce with mussels, clams, and 1/2 a lobster for $20 bucks. Really a dish with all that seafood and HALF a lobste for only $20 bucks. Plus the have an extremely satisfying wine list all for under $20 as well. Giacomo you are my new favorite place to eat. Plus the waiters here are absolutely hilarious. We had so much fun. This is the only place I have ever heard a waiter curse out a group of patrons because someone wanted spaghetti and meatballs. Seriously, wtf would you wait up to 2hours in line for just spaghetti and meatballs. They don't even have meatballs. If you don't eat seafood, eat their butternut squash ravioli, if you don't want that seafood isn't really meat right? Just eat it... it is absolutely heavenly here.

Reviews.Author: Cris L.
Reviews.Content: Sure, you have to wait outside at least a half an hour (at most over an hour) to get a seat at Giacomo's, but of all the hours in a day, you can spare a few for the food here. I've worked in the North End for years, and this is still my number one place to go. There are so many mediocre places in the north end...and alot of them are willing to charge you 20+ a plate.    This isn't a fine dining establishment, so if you're going for that, look elsewhere. I personally love the prosciutto and peas, or the seafood fra diavolo. The fried calamari is also delish. The service is rapid-fire, so don't be alarmed or offended if they seem to rush you (the line outside is the obvious reason why). Wine and beer is cheap so don't be afraid to splurge a bit.   One more thing--bring cash. Giacomo's doesn't take credit cards. It also doesn't serve dessert, but with Mike's pastry and Modern Pastry so close, you really aren't missing out.

Reviews.Author: S And B D.
Reviews.Content: We went last night because of the reviews, we are going back tonight because of the food..and the fun. This place is a blast. Believe everything good written about it... and the part about having to wait in line.

Reviews.Author: Crystal C.
Reviews.Content: We decided on Giacomo's because it is currently the highest rated italian restaurant in the north end on yelp. we were not let down. they do not take reservations or credit cards. we had to wait in line outside for 15-20 minutes, but it was well worth the wait. Inside it's cozy and you feel like you're eating in a real italian family kitchen. we split the calamari appetizer, which also included breaded and fried red peppers and tomatoes. It was delicious. For entrees we had the lobster ravioli and the eggplant parm. Both exceeded expectations. The waitress was friendly and personable, and even though it's a tiny busy place with people waiting, the never made you feel rushed. The only complaint I had with our experience was that they seated the two of us at a 4 top with a pair of college co-eds. Having to share a table with them and listen to their lame conversation while trying to pretend we had the table to ourselves was a bit...awkward. But the food was so good, I forgive them.PS- we had the $16 bottle of spanish sauv blanc, but can not remember the name. It was also outstanding! I believe it has a green vine on the bottle, if you know the name of this wine PLEASE send me a personal message! We've tried calling the restaurant, but it goes straight to voicemail.

Reviews.Author: Daniel W.
Reviews.Content: When we went to Boston our friends who live in Boston decided to take us here. Our friend's boyfriend is a third generation Boston native and recommended this restaurant. The food was excellent. It's clear that Italian food in Boston is superior to Italian food in the bay area, where we're from. We would have given Giacomo's five stars, however, they only get four stars because although our friend made a reservation for us, we didn't get seated until at least 15-20 minutes after our reservation time. The place is really busy, but I guess that's a good thing.

Reviews.Author: Jenny L.
Reviews.Content: god, that was enough pasta to last two meals.  i think even though it's great that they gave so much food, you really start to feel tired of it after a quarter of the plate.  this definitely takes away from the enjoyment of the flavors...speaking of flavors, my salmon fettuccini with a lobster stock based tomato cream sauce had no hint of a lobster stock, or even fish stock, whatsoever, not to mention it really wasn't a cream sauce at all...thought this restaurant was extremely reputable, so imagine my surprise when the waitress came over with a bowl of pre-grated, flavorless parmesan cheese to spoon over our pasta??the energy of the restaurant was great, but i didn't really feel that the food was very special.  i liked the calamari, but my bf said that they were frozen and he saw one of the cooks pull them out of a bag.

Reviews.Author: Barry S.
Reviews.Content: Everything was wicked good ... small space reminded me of Italy ... not enough choice and uniqueness to push it to five stars but certainly worth going when I'm off Hanover again ...

Reviews.Author: Brandon Y.
Reviews.Content: Certainly one of the best Italian meals I've had bar none. Linguine with calms and garlic wine sauce were very tasty. Mussels appetizer was super fresh. Place is tiny, really reasonable, forget about finding street parking. Take a cab, well worth it. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Author: joana b.
Reviews.Content: ugh, i feel bad stating my honest opinion because everyone was so liberal with the 5 stars. here's what we experienced.having read the reviews for giacomo's , i've wanted to try this place since this past summer. after a matinee of peter pan (awesome), we headed to hanover to begin our "adventure" of the "best italian food ever."arrived at 450pm seated at 625pm after waiting outside. appeared that each "round" of sitting was about 40 minutes. we went in on the third "turnover" and i feel bad for those still waiting. the best thingthe $16 bottle of chianti, and the great employees.someone spoke so highly of the garlic bread, which i was soooo excited for but quite depressed in. maybe i should have ordered chicken parm or something more italian. i ordered the fuscilli with lobstah and shrimp with a tomato cream sauce. honestly it wasn't as mind blowing as all the reviews said it was. i tried my son's ziti, with red sauce and that was more pleasing than my entree. the smells coming out of the kitchen we delish, perhaps, i just ordered the wrong thing.we ordered the calamari for apptz and that was again just average. so three hours  and $90 later, we leave our giacomo's adventure with the intent to not revisit. we did however get some yummy gelato on the way out of hanover street. next stop mauricio's.

Reviews.Author: Sannie L.
Reviews.Content: My roommate and I's first time at Giacomo (and in Boston). We heard so much about this place and were determined to try it. Even determined enough to wait in line for just about 2 hours!! We thought we were pretty early but the locals know what's up and showed up even earlier than we had anticipated. Looking back at it, I have no idea why I agreed to that...Anyway, once we were seated (in a cramped corner, uncomfortably close to other patrons) the waiter came over and introduced us to the Giacomo experience. He was very patient and friendly, recommending things to us and explaining what a few of the dishes/sauces were. We decided on the homemade fusilli with lobster and giacomo sauce, lobster ravioli, and an appetizer of calamari. I'm not sure if we were starving from waiting so long or what, but the food was deeelicious. My roommate especially loved the calamari. The marinara it came with tasted tangy and sweet, full of flavor. For the price, the lobster ravioli was not really worth it because there weren't that many raviolis. The fusilli came in a generous portion (enough for two meals!) but was still really expensive...I guess that's what comes with all the hype! Also, the fusilli was slightly under cooked as it still had a hard center. In their defense, they were generous with the lobster.All in all, I'd only come back here if I suddenly developed the patience of a zen master. The waiting almost drove me crazy...and my wallet was hating me for a few weeks afterwards. Protip: CASH ONLY

Reviews.Author: Hilary B.
Reviews.Content: Waited too long to get in, but once we made it in, it was worth it!  I had the shrimp over linguini with the house sauce.  Amazing.  Service was great.

Reviews.Author: Allison F.
Reviews.Content: Oh man, this place is everything you could dream of in a North End restaurant. Better food than your Nonnie used to make - sorry, Nonnie. What really makes it is the atmosphere. The dining room is so intimate and cozy. You get this feeling like it's run by a family with mob roots because it's that authentic. Go while your parents are in town because it's a tad pricier than your campus 711. They'll pay, you'll all get to eat delicious food, maybe get some cannolis afterward, what a night it'll be.

Reviews.Author: Cristina A.
Reviews.Content: I was very eager to go to Giacomo's based on the rave reviews and so many referrals by so many friends and locals... Before O say anymore, let me frame my review with some key points: I'm half Italian, grew up in NJ/NY surrounded by THE best restaurants, had the privilege of eating my grandmother and mother's authentic  dishes throughout my life AND am very particular about food - I know what I like and if I'm paying a premium for a meal I want to be dazzled... Anyway, we ordered the calamari which was nothing special... Yes, it wasn't chewy but the breaking and marinara was bland... For dinner I had the eggplant parm because it's one of my favorite dishes... It wasn't heavily breaded or oily/greasy which was great but again the dish was nothing special... My husband ordered the special which featured homemade fusilli with lobster meat and shrimp. He chose the giacomo sauce which was absolutely delicious - finally some flavor! In short, I don't really think this place is worth all the hype or the long wait... But if you insist, go right for the giacomo sauce!

Reviews.Author: Sugartime X.
Reviews.Content: Went there with some friends early, the wait wasn't bad. Had a killer delicious meal. Fettuccini swordfish /tuna Yummmm  Worth a repeat!!

Reviews.Author: Ed W.
Reviews.Content: Very good and inexpensive peasant food. Don't expect fried squash blossoms... they have 5 sauces they put on most anything + parmesans...there's pesto, scampi, lobster red sauce, Giacomo sauce, and Fracomo sauce (mix of the last two). Seafood pasta had seafood a little overcooked, and the pasta a little softer than aldente. If you've been re-watching The Soprano's and need a southern Italian fix...this is the place for you! Large portions will leave you looking like Tony Soprano if you make this place a habit.

Reviews.Author: Steve N.
Reviews.Content: the best place but only when i can get there right after they open and get mt 'secret' parking spot behind the firehouse.simply outstanding food. no frills, but then, you didn't want frills.go. go early.

Reviews.Author: Tom H.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is that cute little place with the sea shell sign past most of the restaurants on Hanover St. The one with the crowd of people waiting outside. I can understand why some would find if over-hyped and overrated, but I can't help but love this place. At 5:00 they cram as many people as they can into the tiny restaurant and start taking orders. The waitresses, all clearly Bostonians, are very curt but caring at the same time, kind of like they are family. The kitchen can be seen from any of the tables, and the cooks work hard and fast. The food comes steaming hot, seconds after it's finished, and has been consistently delicious. I love the calamari and I usually try one of the specials. Giacomo's is a winner for me.

Reviews.Author: B.Kiddo K.
Reviews.Content: I was going to give this three stars but the definition of two stars completely covers my overall feeling("meh. I've had better"). Nice spot. Suyper popular, sot of touristy. Always a long line but I think the line is long because tourists see other ppl in line so they get in line so the longer the line gets. The food is good but not great. The line was an hour which passed fast since I was with a friend. It is definitely cheap which is a bonus and we got a good cheap bottle of wine and two dinners for ~$50. But I think you might be better off going straight accross the street to Prezza, much more personal and no hour wait( that I have experienced.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer S.
Reviews.Content: I was in Boston on a business trip and came here with my coworker.  We got here just in time, so that we didn't have to wait outside in the cold for a table.   The restaurant is very small, and if you don't come here at the right time you'll have to wait awhile.  However, I can guarantee that it is worth the wait.  We got a bottle of white wine and tried out some pasta dishes and calamari.  I got a seafood pasta with the spicy red sauce.  All of the food was delicious, (especially since my company paid for my meal...)  Yes!

Reviews.Author: A C.
Reviews.Content: Food is pretty good!  I had the house special for 2 (all kinds of seafood with a whole lobster on top) in their giacomo sauce along with their delicious calamari and a bottle of wine to share with 2 other girls and we were stuffed by the end.  Downside: long wait with no reservation option, cramped environment, and get to the point staffs.

Reviews.Author: Hamid N.
Reviews.Content: After a long wait we got a table in the crowded restaurant.  We ordered  They have a limited wine list, with reasonable prices. Fried calamari was just okay. The pasta was good. There's no desert.

Reviews.Author: Jack M.
Reviews.Content: When we have guests we want to impress, we take'em here.  Yes, there's a reason why there's a line out the door.  Consider yourself lucky if you actually get in.  It's that good.

Reviews.Author: Ron A.
Reviews.Content: I was here two weekends ago and my opinion of this place hasnt changed even after reconsideration. If I ever find myself in Boston again in the future, I will definitely go back to Giacomo's for dinner. Little Italy in Boston has a different feel than in NYC. It has more of a home-like feeling, far less tourist infested so dont expect a huge venue. It is very cozy. Be warned: get in line before they open for dinner or you will be waiting in a very long line. I had the lobster ravioli and it was very well done. Not too rich, not watered down either; the right creamy texture that Italian food should have. And for a place that is so busy, the service is lightning fast.

Reviews.Author: Kitty C.
Reviews.Content: My husband and I come here when we want the experience and the food.  The wait time is a bitch, but I just love a place with attitude and Rosemary brings it.  We always tip her extra.  It was raining one night and we waited anyway, Rosemary was handing umbrellas out to everyone standing in line.  Pasta is always delicious, calamari is amazing, wine is cheap and yummy, can't beat this place.

Reviews.Author: Emily G.
Reviews.Content: I think maybe I walked into Giacomo's really really really hyped up about it.  Between all the awesome yelp reviews and one of my co-workers calling this place "wonderous" - I have been excited to go to Giacomo's for months!! I am originally from NY and know good Italian food since everyone I grew up with was Italian, I've visited Italy, and been eating all of my friends parents and granparents from Italy's food all my life.I live for a great Italian meal..... I was psyched when I got there last friday at like 5:00pm and only waited until like 5:30 to get in.The waitresses seemed very confused about who was serving us and kind of kept switching off. This wasn't really a problem but a bit disorderly. We started with an anti-pasta, which was good, but not mindblowing by any means.   My fiance got the lobster ravioli and I got the butternut squash ravioli.  I think my fiances dish was defininitly way above average. It tasted great, was presented well, and was worth a wait.My dish, which many yelpers have raved about, was, I felt, mediocre at best.  I'm not trying to put Giacomo''s down, but with soooo many amazing Italian restaurants in this area - I by no means feel it is appropriate to wait for over an hour, outside on a line, for this one. I want to give Giacomo's another chance sometime - but for now, I think it was just ok.

Reviews.Author: Jahan M.
Reviews.Content: This was some amazing italian food.  It was all freshly prepared.  The restaurant is very small, but the staff is very friendly and accomadating to try and help you.  The is a staple of the North End.  You got to make it here.  Try to get here a half hour before opening or expect to wait outside for an hour.  The prices are reasonable and the food is awesome.

Reviews.Author: Lilly K.
Reviews.Content: DELICIOUS. When I went there was not much of a wait, but it was also nearly closed here... I ordered a pasta with the lobster sauce and I DOWNED THAT SUCKA like there was no tomorrow. It was DELICIOUS.

Reviews.Author: Yb W.
Reviews.Content: Wow, Yelpers weren't kidding when they warned about the long lines. On a Friday evening, the queue consisted of over 30 people and turned around the corner. After nearly an hour of exasperating waiting, we were seated at two tiny seats in front of an open kitchen. Altogether, the restaurant seats only a handful of people, but service is fast and turn around time per table is relative short. The menu is written on a large chalk board at one end of the room.  We opted for the calamari, lobster ravioli, and seafood pasta in Diablo sauce. The food came fast, and the flavors were fresh and simple, without a lot of fuss or invention. Overall, the food is solid for a good price, but in my opinion, does not justify the long wait. If you want a pleasant North End experience, any of a slew of other Italian restaurants on the same street are as enjoyable.

Reviews.Author: Rosie Z.
Reviews.Content: Inexpensive, family-style, delicious Italian food. Despite the rude hostess, the dining experience is straight-forward and satisfying.

Reviews.Author: Ruby T.
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I came out to Boston to celebrate his birthday and decided to check out Giacomo's. We didn't mind the 45 minute wait on Friday!! The food was amazing! Calamari was great!! the house sauce was very very tasty!!!! and the price was extremely reasonable! I highly recommend this place and we will definitley come back next time we are in Boston again!!!

Reviews.Author: Steve S.
Reviews.Content: This is just fantastic Italian food, get the Giacomo's sauce, simply the best!  North End is slightly better than South, but fills up quicker; arrive before 5:30PM for minimal lines.  Cash only.  Amazing place!!!

Reviews.Author: Lawrence L.
Reviews.Content: This place doesn't really need another 5 star review.  It lived up to its name.  Had the Frutta di mare with Giacomo's sauce as well as the fried calimari for appetizer.  Everything was cooked to perfection and perfectly seasoned.  the seafood was very fresh.  Prices were very reasonable too.  The wine (by the glass) was pretty cheap however and tasted cheap as well.  Nonetheless, this is one of the best pasta dishes i've ever had.

Reviews.Author: Ian M.
Reviews.Content: I enjoyed my lobster ravioli in a garlic cream sauce. What I didn't enjoy was the one hour of standing in line, the cramped seating, and the frazzled employees. The quality of the food was good but not great. The portion size was generous.

Reviews.Author: Stacy H.
Reviews.Content: my friend and i came here on a rainy day to explore north end, and we made the best decision to bypass all the empty restaurants to go to giacomo's. all of the places that we passed in the north end were empty, with their maitre d's waiting at their threshold looking for customers. not giacomo's. when we got there, there was still a line out the door, albeit a small one. this place is so small, but is super romantic. make sure your date isn't claustrophobic when you come here, because we were definitely squished up against the wall, with another table just a foot away from ours. i had the pumpkin tortelloni, which was super creamy and rich. it might be a little sweet for dinner, but it's a good thing i have a huge sweet tooth :) my friend got the special for the night -- something with a half lobster, clams and mussels. they definitely pile on the food, and both of us had to bring our meals home in boxes. thanks, giacomo's, for introducing to me the beauty that is authentic italian food in the north end :)

Reviews.Author: Alicia G.
Reviews.Content: I would be even fatter than I already am if I lived in Boston because of this place.

Reviews.Author: May W.
Reviews.Content: We went on Sunday at 8pm and only waited about 15 minutes for a table for 3 people. The bottles of wine are such a steal and the food comes out quick. We started with calamari with a delicious dipping sauce and their garlic bread. So good. I then had the scallops in their house sauce with fettucini. My friend had the butternut squash ravioli, which was divine. DIVINE. Go for that, and you won't regret it.

Reviews.Author: Jenzy Y.
Reviews.Content: We arrive on the early side of dinner and surprisingly, didn't have to wait very long (for a table of 2) as there were larger parties ahead of us. The house special Lobster Fusili is a must-order, accompanied with the Fradiablo sauce. The noodles were good in thickness and a bit al dente for me, but still, very good. There was a generous portion of lobster and eaten with the sauce, was just right. For fear of a heart attack, we ordered s small Ceasar salad that was anything but small. In between our pasta bites, we muched on greens, covered in dressing...yum. The Barolo went very well with our order.

Reviews.Author: Sean S.
Reviews.Content: I'm still making my way through the North End and sampling all sorts of Italian eateries in the Boston (and surrounding areas).  Giacomo's so far is definitely my favorite.  Considering how long wait was when we went and the fact that like most places in the North End, was "cash only", it had a lot to live up to in my mind, and boy did they NOT disappoint.  At first I thought was somewhat cramped but after sitting down, it became more cozy - sort of of like the dreaded family re-union thanksgiving dinner - sucks on paper, but once you are seated down nothing really matters at that point.  There were 3 of us, each having our own entree and splitting two appetizers.  Every plate was just as delicious and succulent as the last with obviously some outshining others, but every last bit of it was just amazing.  I highly recommend the steamed mussels appetizer with an ice cold Moretti Lager, followed by the Lobster ravioli...magnificent.  The food was on point, the service was nothing short of impressive considering the small confines of the dining floor and kitchen.  It was almost a spectacle to watch the staff work in those conditions all the while maintaining a smile, and delivering with raw efficiency.  They also somehow still had time to stop and talk and cut jokes with us (well, the server we had anyway, I can't really speak for the others as far as jokes....but they were ALL on point as far as service from what I could see).  Huge fan of Giacomo's.  This is a place i reserve for special events...like anniversary, in town guests, etc. If you want to have some really good italian in the North End, Giacomo's is sure to NOT disappoint.

Reviews.Author: Bianca T.
Reviews.Content: The best restaurant in the north end ... Hands down ! ... The food is fresh, bursting with flavor and authentic Italian !!  I have gone over a dozen times and every time I go back it gets better ... When deciding where to dine out ... I always think of Giacomo's first and my mouth starts to water just thinking about the lobster and shrimp in the "Giacomo" sauce over hand made in house fusilli ($26).... It's to die for !! The seafood practically just jumped out of the ocean an on the the plate ... So delicious !!!

Reviews.Author: M s.
Reviews.Content: Had the chicken piccata as take out and though it was good it would have been nice to have it served on a bed of pasta. Instead I got spaghetti with red sauce which was good but hard to reconcile with the piccata. Probably would have been a different experience had I sat down.

Reviews.Author: Jim F.
Reviews.Content: We went here for my wife's birthday and to this day I am totally puzzled what all the fuss is about.  The food was Ok.  It was certainly not anything I'd go back to even without a wait.  I am completely puzzled by why so many people rave about this place which has, in my opinion, mediocre cuisine.  Absolutely nothing special about it.

Reviews.Author: William L.
Reviews.Content: Really good Italian in a fun atmosphere. Definitely hitting the right price point.

Reviews.Author: Erin D.
Reviews.Content: Affordable decent standard Italian food but nothing out of this world. The line is only worthwhile if you plan ahead and maybe catch up with friends during your wait.

Reviews.Author: Ashley F.
Reviews.Content: Giacomo's is my fiance's and my favorite Italian place at which to dine.  The wait can be a drag as the place is tiny, so we always get there before 5:30 to avoid the crush of after work or weekend diners.  Giacomo's serves up great pasta fair with quick, efficient service.  As the dining area is so small (under a dozen tables), the waiters are quick with your food and beverages and are never far from hand to deliver the bill or whatever else you may need.  Get in, get out, and enjoy a wonderful meal.

Reviews.Author: Nicole D.
Reviews.Content: Giacomos, I miss you.  The line was REALLY long and everyone who passed by kept saying "I hope it's worth it" and asking "Is it really that good?"  While we stood there, hungry, at 10pm, I was asking myself the same thing. I'm glad to report, it really is that good. The wait was long and we were worried if we would get in or not, but we did. They can only seat about 30 people at a time with 2 at the bar, but they turn tables pretty quickly.  The tables are tightly squeezed and the waiters will joke around (one called my boyfriend's bluetooth a hearing aid and poked fun at him all night), just be wary of the older woman who works there (I hear she's like the soup nazi).  We ordered calamari, caesar salad, lobster ravioli and the seafood linguini with giacomo's sauce.  They make the best calamari.  It was expensive, but it was worth it.Oh, and their bathroom is down this creepy, narrow flight of stairs. They have a camera so that is either a good or bad thing. I did my business and got out of there...quickly.

Reviews.Author: Kristen L.
Reviews.Content: This place is one of those tiny little hole in the wall places that have some of the best food.  I loved the butternut squash ravioli and the calamari is great with the spicy cherry peppers.  Friendly service and good choices.  Just be prepared to wait outside for a table unless you get there right when they open.

Reviews.Author: Matthew G.
Reviews.Content: I went here for a family dinner and everyone loved the food. It was totally worth waiting in line! Reminds me of House of Nanking in San Francisco. You wait in a big line to get in, they bring you amazing food at reasonable prices, and then they get you out to make room for the next customers as soon as possible.

Reviews.Author: Phil J.
